Reviewing Your 2015 Predictions
Reviewing Your 2015 Predictions
The Cranky Flier
January 1, 2016 Friday 6:59 AM EST
Copyright 2016 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 2833 words
Byline: CF
Body
Dec 31, 2015( The Cranky Flier: http://www.crankyflier.com Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> It's a relatively new 
tradition here on the blog, but I like it. At the end of each year, I ask for your thoughts on the year ahead. Now, it's 
time to review how you said for your 2015 predictions[1] to see how they panned out. 
Let me first say that you have a LOT of predictions. For 2016, I'm going to limit each person to no more than 3 
predictions to help make my life easier when sifting through them all.<nl/> There were so many last year that I had 
to cut several out. Here are the ones that made the cut, in no particular order.<nl/> IAG Buying Aer Lingus and 
More<nl/>Billy - British Airways will succeed in buying a European flag carrier: they have been rebuffed by Aer 
Lingus, they will try again and also go for TAP (facing regulators)<nl/> Rzn - Aer Lingus is Bought By IAG after a 
second takeover bid between 2.40£ and 2.50£ a share, which in turn The Irish Government, Ryanair, and other 
investors quickly jump at. Still don't know how Etihad will take part.<nl/> Lauri - IAG will buy Finnair<nl/> Good 
work, Billy (and Rzn), at least on the first part. You hit that one on the nose. BA did indeed take another swing at 
Aer Lingus (well, technically, its parent IAG did). And Aer Lingus is now a member of the IAG family. TAP? That 
didn't happen. instead TAP went to JetBlue and Azul founder David Neeleman's team of investors.<nl/> As for 
Finnair… well that hasn't happened yet, Lauri. But it could still be on the table.<nl/> American's Merger 
Progresses<nl/>Len - The new American will complete the transition to a single operating certificate with little 
fanfare or hassle. Post-merger life will be better for the masses compared to the glitchy United.<nl/> Carl - The 
newly merged AA will find labor peace elusive, as pilot groups and FA groups continue to bicker while at the same 
time lusting after a greater share of the profits. The systems integration will be delayed beyond May 2015. 
Management will continue to roll out moves that irritate AA elites, and back down on some of them.<nl/> Yo - 
American Airlines makes outrageous amounts of dough, again. Pilot seniority: the US East guys lose big (I said it 
last year, but this stuff takes time). AA increases Asia services by the end of the year, going after United, Charlotte 
hub gets smaller, PHX remains the same. Doug might start looking to buy off a competitor.<nl/> IO - > aa - wraps-
up remaining labor contracts and begins to bring together tasks/systems together<nl/> Len and IO were spot on. 
The transition has been incredibly smooth for American. Carl wasn't as accurate with labor peace being somewhat 
achieved. (Though true peace is never going to happen.) Yo? Well, Charlotte didn't get smaller and Doug doesn't 
seem to be interested in buying anyone right now. There's still too much work to be done. <nl/> Revenue-Based 
Frequent Flier Programs<nl/>MeanMeosh - After being totally wrong on this last year, AA will buck the trend and 
announce that they will maintain the existing mileage-based structure of the AAdvantage program for 2016 and 
beyond, deciding that it provides a significant competitive advantage over DL and UA.<nl/> IO - > aa - It announces 
mostly tactical changes in frequent flyer and pricing areas with strategic changes being a minor component. 
Reviewing Your 2015 Predictions
meaning that changes can be done/undone easily.<nl/> Tara - AA does not adopt a revenue based mileage 
program but in the 4th quarter they release the new award charts with substantial devaluations.<nl/> Carl - UA and 
DL get more of a negative hit from the lowered dollar-based mileage earning than they expected as formerly loyal 
lower level elites favor AA, AS and even WN.<nl/> The conventional wisdom agreed with all of you, that American 
wouldn't go revenue-based in 2015 for the 2016 program. Apparently American doesn't like conventional wisdom, 
because it has done just that, proving all predictions wrong.<nl/> Meanwhile, United and Delta do not seem to have 
taken any kind of hit from their move.<nl/> American's Hub Rebanking<nl/>MeanMeosh - Speaking of AA, the hub 
rebanking strategy is left in tatters after a day of training summer thunderstorms at DFW leads to days-long delays 
for some fliers, many stranded after being diverted to alternate airports due to lack of gate space, and the resulting 
bad press.<nl/> TC99 - American will discontinue the hard banks after losing a lot of money in missed connections 
at MIA. (Hotel rooms, Transportation to/from, meals) They will try to blame Immigration and Customs for being too 
slow, but the problem is they schedule these connections. <nl/> American rebanked its hubs last year, allowing for 
more flights operating at peak times. Connections became shorter, but some of you thought the risk of things going 
wrong would be too much. It wasn't. The rebanking seems to have been successful and though American isn't 
running at the top in terms of operational performance, it is doing very well for an airline that is trying to integrate 
two different airlines into one.<nl/> Cheap Oil and Fare Wars<nl/>Len - Lower (for now) fuel prices will reduce 
pressure on bottom lines, but will not do much for fares. No more new fees for now, but the biz traveller won't be 
seeing any $99 trips anytime soon.<nl/> Jim M - With oil cheap, fares relatively high, consumer and business 
spending robust, and planes full there will be some fairly healthy profits. Which will lead someone, somewhere to 
dream up an airline start-up. And it might actually work.<nl/> Peter V - One of the big five will start a fare war in a 
tightly contested market. Fare wars are like crack to airline executives and will spread industry wide. Ticket prices 
will come down on the eastern seaboard and some transcontinental flights.<nl/> Mitch - Low oil prices will lead to 
debilitating fare wars in 2015. 2014 brought profits due to high load factors and stable fares. At least one major 
carrier will lose this restraint and try to dominate a market through crazy fares and high frequency. It is rare for the 
airline industry to show year-after-year of high profits. 2015 will see at least one major go back to the same old 
formula.<nl/> A - Oil prices will be lower than 2014 but highly volatile thus price wars will not happen and ticket 
prices remain unchanged or higher equalling solid profits across the board.<nl/> Guido - Oil prices will continue to 
drop in 2014, up until the point the domestic shale drillers throttle back production due to lack of profit, at which 
point oil shoots back up to over $90 a barrel.<nl/> Some conflicting opinions on oil here. Oil prices did indeed 
continue to drop and they have stayed very low with no rise in sight. Peter V was probably the closest to describing 
the state of the industry. Fares have come down and there have been some fare wars. But in general, airlines are 
still making a ton of money.<nl/> Alaska and Seattle<nl/>Len - I still think something will happen out west. Alaska 
has got to be feeling pretty good and make a disruptive move. I was wrong in 2014, but hey, maybe I was just a 
year early!<nl/> Carl - Surprisingly, both AS and DL both continue to prosper in SEA.<nl/> Jeremy McMillen - 
Alaska starts code sharing with UA and uses the big three to just feed its large west cost network. <nl/> PF - Delta 
downsizes domestic in Seattle.<nl/> Nick Barnard - Alaska and Delta end their codeshare and frequent flier 
partnership. Its not a huge deal as many would expect, but is announced with a joint press release.<nl/> Nick 
Barnard - Also shortly after ending the Alaska-Delta partnership Alaska and American announce a closer 
relationship. American also makes a token investment in Alaska.<nl/> CraigTPA - ALASKA - Ends partnership with 
Delta, suddenly and with much drama on Delta's part. Alaska looks for opportunities to expand relationship with 
American. By year's end AS and AA begin preliminary merger discussions (UA may kick the tires as well) - these 
are mainly window dressing to satisfy dissident shareholders and don't go very far.<nl/> IO - > AS - wonders why 
DL has not gone away and begins to explore alliance/merger partners versus expanding nationwide on their 
own.<nl/> You guys love speculating about Alaska and Seattle, and what happened? Nothing. Oh sure, the Delta 
partnership frayed further, but it's not completely gone yet. Alaska and American do seem to be getting cozier, but 
there was really little movement. Alaska just continues to kick ass.<nl/> Flying Down Under<nl/>Tara - AA also 
announces at least one route to an Australian city, probably SYD (though I would prefer BNE).<nl/> chris r - AA or 
UA will take a look at the NZ monopoly on the US-NZ route and start services DFW(AA)AKL or HOU(UA)AKL with a 
view to starting West Coast services later.<nl/> Adrian in NZ - 4. A One World or Sky Team carrier will challenge 
NZ's monopoly on NZ-US flights by flying direct to DFW or SEA. (Maybe a bit of wishful thinking as AA, CO, QF ... 
have all flown AKL to USA in the past but no longer do.)<nl/> Right on, Tara, as American announced and started 
Sydney. Adrian and chris, you were right about Auckland but wrong on the US destinations. As we know now, 
United is doing San Francisco and American is doing LA.<nl/> The Fate of Malaysia 370<nl/>Jeremy - They will find 
Reviewing Your 2015 Predictions
MH-370.<nl/> Rzn - MH370 is found I predict some wreakage on the Australian coast, but mostly either in Indonesia 
coast or near antarctica.<nl/> A - MH 370 will not be found and conspiracy theories will continue.<nl/><nl/>So who's 
right? I have no idea. Maybe part of it has been found? Maybe not. I'm still confused.<nl/> The Rise of 
United<nl/>Carl - UA will improve its operational reliability. But it will continue to lag behind DL in most polls.<nl/> 
PF - United continues to improve service ...rception, gaining back with CO had.<nl/> I'd say you summed it up well 
Carl. United has most certainly improved, but it has a ways to go before it reaches Delta level. At least it looks like 
it's finally trying after many years of sucking.<nl/> Basic Economy<nl/>MeanMeosh - DL's rollout of Basic Economy 
is a failure, primarily due to problems with disclosure on OTAs. After tens of thousands of DOT complaints, Delta 
initially shelves the idea, but brings it back by the end of the year at a substantially lower price point that the current 
$10 each way discount. I'm guessing $50.<nl/> I'd say the opposite is true here. Basic Economy has only grown 
and now we hear both American and United making rumblings about doing something similar.<nl/> The Middle East 
3<nl/>MeanMeosh - Sustained low oil prices roil the Middle Eastern carriers. At least one, my guess being Etihad, 
begins to substantially cut back service, and jettisons its interests in a handful of the money-losing carriers it has 
picked up over the past few years.<nl/> PF - The middle east big 3 (QR, EY, EK) slow down their aggressive growth 
and rightsize.<nl/> There's no question that growth has become more challenging this year compared to previous 
ones, and the results have shown that. But that doesn't mean they've slowed down. Regulatory pressure appears to 
be rising, with Europe showing interest in taking a more active stand against the Middle East carriers. But those 
orders keep coming in and those airplanes have to go somewhere.<nl/> Pilot Crunch<nl/>Eric C - The US majors, 
American in particular but also United, will discover that transferring regional aircraft from large operators to smaller 
cheaper ones doesn't mean the pilots will go with. Envoy and ExpressJet will see a pilot exodus greater than their 
shrinkage accounts for, while carriers like Trans States and PSA will find it exceedingly difficult to recruit them.<nl/> 
It's actually the bigger operators (*cough* Republic *cough) that have been having the hardest times maintaining 
their schedules. But clearly the pilot shortage is really hitting home this year, and there's no easy solution on the 
horizon in the short term.<nl/> JetBlue<nl/>CraigTPA - By year end, has a timetable to add Mint to all service 
between their major West Coast business-customer airports (SFO, LAX, LGB) and their Northeastern counterparts 
(JFK, BOS, EWR, with EWR last.) This is directly aimed at Virgin America. The Mint introduction won't be complete 
until enough A321s are on hand with a Mint cabin, but the process will be started.<nl/> IO - > B6 - begins to 
implement shareholder happy changes and stock makes big gains; however, b6 determines that aa is in the way of 
its successful implementation and asks to expand ff alliance. if aa agrees then stock continues to rise but if aa says 
no then b6 aggresively looks to merge with as to gain scale and press aa.<nl/> The JetBlue/American partnership is 
now a distant memory, and there aren't any credible rumors of a merger. But, IO, you're right that the 'shareholder 
happy' changes have been implemented. The thing is, they're 'customer happy' too. CraigTPA, you were right about 
Mint expanding, but so far it's only to Boston and on limited Caribbean routes during off-peak transcon days. I'm 
guessing there's more to come.<nl/> Southwest Bag Fees<nl/>Yo - Southwest labor issues continue, if oil goes 
back up to where it was, they will…finally start charging a nominal fee for bags.<nl/> No luck on this one, Yo. And 
honestly, it couldn't have happened anyway since Southwest's existing reservation system can't support bag fees 
anyway. But instead of just trying to wait it out, Southwest is doubling down on the no bag fee thing with its 
Transfarency campaign.<nl/> Frontier's Future<nl/>Daniel - Frontier leads U.S. airlines in DOT complaints.<nl/> PF 
- Frontier's Investors buy or sell to merge, and/or IPO.<nl/> Guido - Frontier will have difficulty getting a foothold as 
a low cost carrier, in light of the other horses in that race having such a head start. They will soldier on through 
2014 on the backs of the economic recovery but they won't see the ridiculous profits that Southwest and Spirit will 
see next year.<nl/> Frontier has certainly had a lot of complaints, Daniel, and we won't have full year stats for a 
couple more months, but thanks to Spirit, I'm thinking Frontier may escape the title.<nl/> Beyond that, Frontier has 
actually done well with its ultra low cost model and continues to push on, Guido. But, PF, you're a little premature. 
This might be better on the 2016 list.<nl/> Jetstar Hong Kong<nl/>Adrian in NZ - 1. Jetstar Hong Kong will never get 
off the ground.<nl/> Good call, Adrian. Hong Kong shot this one down and it never did go anywhere.<nl/> Spirit and 
Miami<nl/>TC99 - Spirit will expand into MIA after seeing the success that Frontier has with domestic flights. They 
will eventually add International flights to most of the cities they serve out of FLL because of the demand.<nl/> 
There has been a lot of speculation about this over the last couple years, but still nothing. From what I hear, Miami 
is just too expensive and too difficult for any low cost carrier to take a serious shot at service. Frontier's operation is 
still pretty tiny.<nl/> Another International Incident<nl/>TC99 - Finally, we will have another tragic International 
Incident involving the shooting down of a passenger plane. This will lead to a major military action to take out the 
people behind it.<nl/> I'm sad to say that I think the bombing of the Metrojet aircraft in Egypt fulfills the first part of 
Reviewing Your 2015 Predictions
this prophecy. As for a major military action, well, it depends on what you consider major. Russia has certainly 
stepped up its attacks on Daesh, but there's probably a lot more to come.<nl/> C-Series Delays<nl/>R - Bombardier 
CSeries encounters additional delays and will not be introduced in 2015.<nl/> Yes, indeed. That was the case, but 
delivery isn't far away now… we hope.<nl/> CEO Trouble<nl/>Daniel - One of the 4 major U.S. carriers' CEO 
resigns.<nl/> So define 'resign'…. It's hard to say that Smisek's disappearance at United was in any way a 
resignation since it clearly wasn't his choice. But I'll give half credit on this one.<nl/> Alitalia's Rise or 
Fall<nl/>Adrian in NZ - 7. Alitalia will morph into an LCC.<nl/> My favorite topic. Alitalia actually went in the opposite 
direction, trying to follow in Etihad's footsteps and go upscale. There is no indication that this is in any way working 
so far. Viva Alitalia!<nl/> Baltia<nl/>Daniel - Baltia Air Lines sells it's first ticket but will give the passenger a 
refund<nl/> HAHAHAHAHAHA. No. (But I admire your optimism, sir.)<nl/><nl/>If you'd like to discuss other 
predictions from last year that I didn't cover, go for it in the comments. We'll open a new post on Friday to discuss 
your

Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY) Reaches New 52-Week High at $88.24
Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY) Reaches New 52-Week High at $88.24
The Legacy
December 30, 2015 Wednesday 5:23 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 658 words
Byline: Rick
Body
Dec 30, 2015( The Legacy: http://www.localizedusa.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/>            
http://stocktwits.com/widgets/share <nl/> Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) shares reached a new 52-week 
high on Tuesday , Market Beat.com[1] reports. 
The stock traded as high as $88.24 and last traded at $87.39, with a volume of 203,756 shares. The stock had 
previously closed at $87.32.<nl/> Several research analysts have weighed in on RYAAY shares. HSBC 
downgraded Ryanair Holdings plc from a 'buy' rating to a 'hold' rating in a research note on Friday, October 2nd. 
Vetr[2] upgraded Ryanair Holdings plc from a 'buy' rating to a 'strong-buy' rating and set a $90.63 price target for 
the company in a research note on Monday, November 16th. Beaufort Securities restated a 'buy' rating on shares of 
Ryanair Holdings plc in a research note on Tuesday, October 6th. Zacks Investment Research[3] downgraded 
Ryanair Holdings plc from a 'buy' rating to a 'hold' rating in a research note on Friday, November 20th. Finally, 
Raymond James upgraded Ryanair Holdings plc from a 'market perform' rating to an 'outperform' rating in a 
research note on Tuesday, November 3rd. One equities research analyst has rated the stock with a sell rating, 
seven have issued a hold rating, seven have issued a buy rating and one has assigned a strong buy rating to the 
stock. Ryanair Holdings plc currently has an average rating of 'Buy' and an average target price of $86.88.<nl/> The 
company has a market cap of $22.99 billion and a P/E ratio of 14.46. The firm's 50 day moving average is $81.79 
and its 200-day moving average is $78.84. <nl/> Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last announced its 
quarterly earnings results on Monday, November 2nd. The company reported $0.99 earnings per share for the 
quarter, missing the consensus estimate of $3.30 by $2.31. Equities research analysts forecast that Ryanair 
Holdings plc will post $5.15 earnings per share for the current fiscal year. <nl/><nl/> Ryanair Holdings plc 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY[4]) is a holding company for Ryanair Limited (Ryanair). Ryanair operates a low fare, scheduled-
passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes between Ireland, the United Kingdom, Continental Europe 
and Morocco. The Company's principal fleet consists of Boeing 737-800 aircraft, each having 189 seats. The 
Company offered over 1,600 short-haul flights per day serving approximately 190 airports across Europe, and flying 
approximately 1,600 routes, with a fleet of approximately 315 Boeing 737-800 aircraft and six additional leased 
aircraft acquired on short term leases. Ryanair's fleet totaled to 308 Boeing 737-800s. Ryanair also provides 
various ancillary services and engages in other activities connected with its air passenger service, including non-
flight scheduled services, Internet-related services, and the in-flight sale of beverages, food and 
merchandise.<nl/><nl/>This story was originally published by Putnam Standard (http://putnamstandard.com) and is 
the sole property of Putnam Standard. If you are reading this article on another website, that means this article was 
illegally copied and re-published to this website in violation of U.S. and International copyright law. You can view the 
Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY) Reaches New 52-Week High at $88.24

new-52-week-high-at-88-24/712273/ <nl/> <nl/> <nl/><nl/>Receive News ...tings for Ryanair Holdings plc Daily -

HEFA, IMTM: Big ETF Inflows
HEFA, IMTM: Big ETF Inflows
Market News Video
December 30, 2015 Wednesday 5:17 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 199 words
Body
View Video
Dec 30, 2015 (Market News Video:http://marketnewsvideo.com/ Delivered by Newstex)
 Comparing units outstanding versus one week ago at the coverage universe of ETFs at ETF Channel, the biggest 
inflow was seen in the iShares Currency Hedged MSCI EAFE ETF (HEFA), which added 9,950,000 units, or a 7.7% 
increase week over week. Among the largest underlying components of HEFA, in morning trading today iShares 
MSCI EAFE Index (EFA) is down about 0.5%. 
And on a percentage change basis, the ETF with the biggest increase in inflows was the iShares MSCI International 
Developed Momentum Factor ETF (IMTM), which added 100,000 units, for a 33.3% increase in outstanding units. 
Among the largest underlying components of IMTM, in morning trading today Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY) is down 
about 1.2%.

Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY) Reaches New 12-Month High at $88.24
Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY) Reaches New 12-Month High at $88.24
The Legacy
December 29, 2015 Tuesday 9:49 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 658 words
Byline: mitch
Body
Dec 29, 2015( The Legacy: http://www.localizedusa.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/>            
http://stocktwits.com/widgets/share <nl/> Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) reached a new 52-
week high on Tuesday , Market Beat.com[1] reports. 
The company traded as high as $88.24 and last traded at $87.39, with a volume of 203,756 shares traded. The 
stock had previously closed at $87.32.<nl/> RYAAY has been the subject of a number of recent analyst reports. 
HSBC downgraded shares of Ryanair Holdings plc from a 'buy' rating to a 'hold' rating in a research report on 
Friday, October 2nd. Vetr[2] raised shares of Ryanair Holdings plc from a 'buy' rating to a 'strong-buy' rating and set 
a $90.63 price objective for the company in a report on Monday, November 16th. Beaufort Securities reaffirmed a 
'buy' rating on shares of Ryanair Holdings plc in a report on Tuesday, October 6th. Zacks Investment Research[3] 
downgraded shares of Ryanair Holdings plc from a 'buy' rating to a 'hold' rating in a report on Friday, November 
20th. Finally, Raymond James raised shares of Ryanair Holdings plc from a 'market perform' rating to an 
'outperform' rating in a report on Tuesday, November 3rd. One analyst has rated the stock with a sell rating, seven 
have assigned a hold rating, seven have given a buy rating and one has issued a strong buy rating to the company. 
The stock currently has a consensus rating of 'Buy' and an average target price of $86.88.<nl/> The company has a 
market cap of $23.22 billion and a P/E ratio of 14.61. The stock's 50 day moving average price is $81.64 and its 
200-day moving average price is $78.73. <nl/> Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last issued its quarterly 
earnings results on Monday, November 2nd. The company reported $0.99 EPS for the quarter, missing analysts' 
consensus estimates of $3.30 by $2.31. On average, equities analysts anticipate that Ryanair Holdings plc will post 
$5.15 EPS for the current fiscal year. <nl/><nl/> Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY[4]) is a holding company 
for Ryanair Limited (Ryanair). Ryanair operates a low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-
point routes between Ireland, the United Kingdom, Continental Europe and Morocco. The Company's principal fleet 
consists of Boeing 737-800 aircraft, each having 189 seats. The Company offered over 1,600 short-haul flights per 
day serving approximately 190 airports across Europe, and flying approximately 1,600 routes, with a fleet of 
approximately 315 Boeing 737-800 aircraft and six additional leased aircraft acquired on short term leases. 
Ryanair's fleet totaled to 308 Boeing 737-800s. Ryanair also provides various ancillary services and engages in 
other activities connected with its air passenger service, including non-flight scheduled services, Internet-related 
services, and the in-flight sale of beverages, food and merchandise.<nl/><nl/>This story was originally published by 
Putnam Standard (http://putnamstandard.com) and is the sole property of Putnam Standard. If you are reading this 
article on another website, that means this article was illegally copied and re-published to this website in violation of 
U.S. and International copyright law. You can view the original version of this story at

Airlines We Lost 2015
Airlines We Lost 2015
The Cranky Flier
December 28, 2015 Monday 12:31 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 2076 words
Byline: CF
Body
Dec 28, 2015( The Cranky Flier: http://www.crankyflier.com Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> It's the end of the year, 
and you know what that means. As we do every year[1], it's time to look back and remember those airlines we lost. 
The biggest surprise is that SpiceJet is not on this list. 
It was teetering last year, but it shrunk and recapitalized so it continues to live.<nl/> Once again, I turned to Thomas 
at the excellent ch-aviation[2] site to make sure I had a complete list. Still, it's always possible something was 
missed, so feel free to leave those in the comments below.<nl/><nl/> Cyprus Airways - January 9, 2015[3]<nl/>The 
failure of Cyprus Airways is a tale as old as time. (No, not Beauty and the Beast; a different one.) Cyprus was the 
flag carrier in a small country with limited air service demand. That worked in the old days, but then low cost carriers 
invaded. There are a bunch of them in the market now from easyJet to Wizz (and Ryanair entering soon). That 
meant that there just wasn't a place for Cyprus Airways to exist. The airline is gone, but air service in Cyprus 
continues to grow. Flag carriers just aren't necessary in every country. Go ask Hungary about 
that.<nl/><nl/>Tyrolean - March 1, 2015[4]<nl/>This story always made me feel kind of dirty. Tyrolean was a 
regional airline that was bought by Austrian. But once Lufthansa Group got its claws into Austrian, it saw problems. 
Notably, Lufthansa came to the conclusion that labor costs at Austrian were too high. No agreement could be 
reached, so guess what happened? Austrian stopped flying airplanes. That's right. Tyrolean took over the entire 
fleet and operated all Austrian flights at a lower cost (using Austrian crews). Management finally got the 
concessions it wanted, so Tyrolean no longer needed to exist. Flights were transferred back to Austrian and 
Tyrolean disappeared. Dirty.<nl/><nl/>EuroLOT - March 31, 2015[5]<nl/>EuroLOT started out as a regional airline 
in Poland, and it eventually became a regional feeder for LOT itself, ultimately flying only under the LOT name. If 
that were the end of the story, then EuroLOT might still exist today. Instead, it was turned into a semi-low cost 
carrier type of operation and started flying under its own name. This was a disaster. The entire airline was such a 
mess, that the decision was made to just shut the whole thing down. That was probably the best strategy the airline 
had.<nl/><nl/>B...irlines - June 11, 2015[6]<nl/>After the Soviet Union fell apart, many Eastern European countries 
formed their own airlines, and this was one of those. It started as Air Bosna in 1994, but it eventually shut down and 
came back to life as the national carrier of Bosnia and Herzegovina in 2005. The airline never did well, but at one 
point it had a lifeline thrown by Turkish Airlines. If this sounds a lot like Air Serbia and Etihad, it does… except for 
the part where Turkish realized this was a bad idea and walked away. The airline only had a couple of props to its 
name and it never prospered. Eventually the government gave up and shut it down, letting other airlines fill the (very 
tiny) void in Sarajevo.<nl/><nl/>Syphax Airlines - July 31, 2015[7]<nl/>There were such high hopes for Syphax. In 
the wake of the Arab Spring overthrow of the Tunisian government, Syphax was founded by a local businessman. 
Airlines We Lost 2015
The airline had big plans, it picked up some widebodies and even placed orders for A320neos. But the airline never 
found solid financial footing, and the Tunisian market didn't flourish as hoped. As the losses mounted, the orders 
were canceled and the airline shut down. There was word that it was going to restart with new capital, but I don't 
believe that ever actually happened. Put this into the growing pile of broken dreams in that 
region.<nl/><nl/>SkyGreece - August 27, 2015[8]<nl/>What a silly idea this was. SkyGreece was actually a 
Canadian-owned airline primarily meant to connect Greek people in Canada and the US with their homeland. The 
airline picked up a 767 and actually briefly flew to Montreal, Toronto, and New York. But as silly as the idea was, 
the execution was worse. Flights were unreliable (it used contractors which it apparently didn't like to pay) and 
within a couple months, this experiment was done. It never should have made it off the ground in the first 
place.<nl/><nl/>CanJet - September 2, 2015[9]<nl/>You might be asking yourself 'Didn't CanJet fail years ago?' 
Well yes, and no. CanJet has had nine lives, or close to it. After starting in 1999, it soon merged with Canada 3000, 
an airline that failed shortly after. It came back as an independent airline in 2002 and flew for four years until that 
didn't work. Then, it became a charter carrier. Things were looking up as it picked up some charter business and 
began to grow. Ultimately, it lost the bulk of its business, and that was that. It was finally put to sleep this 
year.<nl/><nl/>BizAir Shuttle - September 3, 2015[10]<nl/>Remember how I said SkyGreece was a silly idea? 
BizAir Shuttle makes SkyGreece look brilliant. When United Express carrier SkyWest retired its last props, it had to 
cancel service to a handful of cities including Carlsbad in North San Diego County. That was the last commercial 
service at the airport, so somebody thought there was opportunity. They took a Dornier 328JET (one of the few 
commercial jets that could operate on that short runway) and flew it to LA and Vegas. The problem in LA was that 
BizAir Shuttle had no agreements with other airlines, so it was a cumbersome process to fly anywhere beyond LA… 
and nobody wanted to just fly to LA. Demand tanked and service disappeared. I just wish I had flown the 328JET 
when I had the chance.<nl/><nl/>Korongo Airlines - September 4, 2015[11]<nl/>It might not seem surprising to hear 
about yet another failed airline in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. After all, most of them fail or crash (or 
both) at some point. But Korongo was going to be different. Brussels Airlines wanted to have a feeder operation in 
Congo for some time. (As a former colony, Congo has plenty of Belgian business interests.) After one aborted 
attempt, Korongo was founded with 70 percent owned by a Belgian consortium including Brussels Airlines. The 
airline's launch was delayed multiple times, but it did finally get airborne. Why did it fail? This is the saddest thing. It 
had an incident with the only airplane in its fleet and couldn't operate. Looking at the competitive landscape, they 
figured it best to just quit.<nl/><nl/>Virgin Atlantic Little Red - September 26, 2015[12]<nl/>2015 clearly was the 
year for many bad ideas to fail. Though to be fair, Little Red wasn't started for commercial reasons alone. When 
British Airways bought bmi, it had to divest some slots at Heathrow. Some of those were set aside to serve UK 
destinations. Virgin Atlantic thought it worth a go, so it contracted with Aer Lingus to operate Little Red flights to 
Aberdeen, Edinburgh, and Manchester. Planes were empty, fares were low, and the service hemorrhaged. 
Presumably once Delta took its stake in Virgin Atlantic, it told the airline to knock it off. So it did.<nl/><nl/>US 
Airways - October 17, 2015[13]<nl/>This has already been covered extensively, but 2015 marked the official end of 
US Airways. In reality, US Airways died in 2005 when it was days away from liquidation. America West's decision to 
step in and put together a merger was the only thing that kept US Airways going. Really, the surviving airline was 
America West, but since they kept the US Airways name, it seemed otherwise. After the American merger, it was 
only a matter of time until the US Airways name was gone. That day came on October 17 when flights were all sold 
under American's code. US Airways was an unlikely survivor and the last airline born as one of the original local 
service airlines in the US. It should be remember for that. (Just forget about all the bad stuff.)<nl/><nl/>Transaero - 
October 26, 2015[14]<nl/>When the Soviet Union fell apart, it wasn't just Eastern European countries that formed 
their own airlines. New airlines began to pop up in Russia itself to challenge Aeroflot. Transaero actually started by 
leasing airplanes from Aeroflot and was the first private scheduled carrier in Russia. It made bold moves, including 
operating Western-built aircraft early in its life. The airline grew a lot, but not in a seemingly smart way. It had a 
motley fleet with a bunch of different classes of service. As the Russian economy tanked, Transaero's past issues 
began to catch up to it. With a crushing debt load, it was forced to shut down and its fleet scattered to anyone who 
showed an interest.<nl/><nl/>Estonian Air - November 8, 2015[15]<nl/>Estonian was another one of those airlines 
that came out of the break-up of the Soviet Union, and like Air Lituanica from its neighbor Lithuania, Estonian didn't 
make it through 2015. Estonian first caught my attention in 1999 when I visited Helsinki. I didn't realize until then 
that Tallinn, the capital, was a mere 63 miles by air from Helsinki. As far as air service goes, Tallinn wasn't a huge 
market, but low cost carriers had begun to creep in as they did in Cyprus. easyJet, Norwegian, Ryanair, and 
Vueling all have a presence at the airport. There just wasn't a need for another flag carrier.<nl/><nl/>Island Airlines 
Airlines We Lost 2015
- December 11, 2015[16]<nl/>If you're like me, you probably thought this was Island Air in Hawai'i. After all, that 
airline hasn't been doing well and has struggled to find its place in the world. But Island Air keeps flying. This is 
Island Airlines, the oldest airline to fail on this year's list. It had been flying to Nantucket since 1930. The 
predecessor to Island Airlines was the first to fly into Nantucket, long before Sandpiper and Aeromass launched 
their brutal rivalry[17]. Times changed, and eventually, Island Airlines just didn't see a way to continue.<nl/>Those 
are the most notable failures this year, but as usual there were many more that I didn't feature. Here they 
are.<nl/>Tomb of the Unknown Airline<nl/> Adriatic Skyways Aerocon Air Lituanica Air Melbourne Ak Bars Aero 
Alitalia Express Appalachian Air Asia Airways Aviogenex Business Air (Thailand) ES-air Falcon Air Express Fil-
Asian Airways flyvista Freedom Air (Guam) Guinea Lineas Aéreas HolidayJet Intersky KAPO Aviakompania LAC 
(Lignes Aériennes Congolaises) León Airlines Nordic Flyways Nordic Global Airlines Midex Airlines Osprey Wings 
Pegasus Asia Seabird Airlines Sky Bishkek Skyforce Aviation Snowbird Airlines SomAir South Supreme Airlines 
Southeast Airlines (Kenya) Tomskavia Transportes Generales Aéreos Turks Air Cargo UTair-Express Volare 
Airlines Wizz Air Ukraine<nl/> Rest in peace, failed airlines. Let's hope for fewer failures in 2016.<nl/> [ 1]:

Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY) Reaches New 52-Week High at $86.97
Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY) Reaches New 52-Week High at $86.97
The Legacy
December 21, 2015 Monday 9:56 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 678 words
Byline: Reagan
Body
Dec 21, 2015( The Legacy: http://www.localizedusa.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Ryanair Holdings plc 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY) hit a new 52-week high during mid-day trading on Monday , Analyst Ratings Network.com[1] 
reports. The company traded as high as $86.97 and last traded at $85.76, with a volume of 129,657 shares. 
The stock had previously closed at $84.75.<nl/> RYAAY has been the subject of a number of research analyst 
reports. Beaufort Securities restated a 'buy' rating on shares of Ryanair Holdings plc in a research report on 
Tuesday, October 6th. HSBC lowered Ryanair Holdings plc from a 'buy' rating to a 'hold' rating in a research report 
on Friday, October 2nd. Zacks Investment Research[2] lowered Ryanair Holdings plc from a 'buy' rating to a 'hold' 
rating in a research report on Friday, November 20th. Evercore ISI initiated coverage on Ryanair Holdings plc in a 
research report on Monday, September 28th. They set a 'buy' rating and a $100.00 price objective for the company. 
Finally, TheStreet restated a 'buy' rating on shares of Ryanair Holdings plc in a research report on Wednesday, 
October 21st. One equities research analyst has rated the stock with a sell rating, seven have issued a hold rating, 
seven have given a buy rating and one has given a strong buy rating to the company. Ryanair Holdings plc 
presently has an average rating of 'Buy' and a consensus price target of $86.88.<nl/> The firm has a market 
capitalization of $22.72 billion and a PE ratio of 14.45. The company's 50-day moving average price is $81.05 and 
its 200 day moving average price is $78.02.<nl/><nl/>Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last issued its 
quarterly earnings data on Monday, November 2nd. The company reported $0.99 earnings per share for the 
quarter, missing analysts' consensus estimates of $3.30 by $2.31. On average, analysts expect that Ryanair 
Holdings plc will post $5.15 earnings per share for the current year.<nl/> The company also recently disclosed a 
dividend, which was paid on Friday, November 27th. Shareholders of record on Tuesday, October 27th were given 
a $1.635 dividend. The ex-dividend date was Friday, October 23rd.<nl/><nl/>Ryanair Holdings plc 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY[3]) is a holding company for Ryanair Limited (Ryanair). Ryanair operates a low fare, scheduled-
passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes between Ireland, the United Kingdom, Continental Europe 
and Morocco. The Company's principal fleet consists of Boeing 737-800 aircraft, each having 189 seats. The 
Company offered over 1,600 short-haul flights per day serving approximately 190 airports across Europe, and flying 
approximately 1,600 routes, with a fleet of approximately 315 Boeing 737-800 aircraft and six additional leased 
aircraft acquired on short term leases. Ryanair's fleet totaled to 308 Boeing 737-800s. Ryanair also provides 
various ancillary services and engages in other activities connected with its air passenger service, including non-
flight scheduled services, Internet-related services, and the in-flight sale of beverages, food and merchandise.<nl/>

main indexes pared gains in midday trading Monday, as the new "Star Wars" movie failed to give Disney 
(NYSE:DIS[1]) shares any fuel. The Nasdaq, which had been up as much as 0.9%, was 0.6% higher after the 
composite came off its session lows. 
The S...00 was up 0.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.3%.<nl/> Volume was tracking sharply lower after 
Friday's witching session. Winning stocks led losers 8-to-5 on the NYSE and by 9-to-7 on the Nasdaq in the stock 
market today[2].<nl/> "Star Wars: The Force Awakens" made a box-office record[3] as ticket sales for the opening 
weekend topped $500 million worldwide. But that didn't help its studio.<nl/> Walt Disney fell 1% in heavy trading, 
sliding deeper below its 50-day and 200-day moving averages. Shares had already triggered a sell signal by falling 
more than 8% from a 117.68 buy point.<nl/> Imax (NYSE:IMAX[4]), another company expected to benefit from the 
blockbuster film, slid 3% in busy volume. It triggered a sell signal as it fell more than 8% from the 39.97 buy point of 
last week's breakout attempt.<nl/> Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY[5]) broke out of a flat base, surging past the 85.66 
buy point. But volume was tracking below average, leaving some doubts about the move. The stock was discussed 
in IBD last week[6] in a story that noted the airline's favorable travel and operating trends.<nl/> Other travel stocks 
were rallying after Stifel Nicolaus raised its price target on Carnival (NYSE:CCL[7]) to 64 from 61. On Friday, the 
cruise line operator beat earnings expectations.<nl/> Carnival shares were up 2% as they close in on the 54.69 buy 
point of a flat base. Norwegian Cruise Line (NASDAQ:NCLH[8]) was up nearly 2%. It is also basing.<nl/> [ 1]:

3 people were injured after a Southwest Airlines plane skidded off the 
runway in Nashville
The Business Insider
December 16, 2015 Wednesday 2:40 AM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 546 words
Byline: blogan@businessinsider.com,  (Bryan Logan) Bryan Logan
Body
Dec 16, 2015( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) ;<nl/> Screenshot via 
WSMV-TV<nl/>A Southwest Airlines jet reportedly landed off the runway at Nashville International Airport on 
Tuesday evening.<nl/>
 Injuries were reported, according to a report from WSMV-TV in Nashville[1].<nl/> Southwest Airlines Flight 31 had 
been traveling to Nashville from Houston when it skidded off the runway.<nl/> Citing FAA officials, WKRN-TV 
reported[2] that the Boeing 737 "rolled off the taxiway into the grass and got stuck" while heading to its gate.<nl/> 
The news station said that the incident occurred shortly before 6 p.m. local time.<nl/> One passenger said that "the 
plane landed hard and seemed to make a loud 'thud.'"<nl/> Passengers were let off the aircraft and bused to a 
terminal.<nl/> The Tennessean said that at least three people were injured, including one who was suffering 
from chest pain. Several ambulances have responded[3] to the scene.<nl/><nl/>Southwest Airlines confirmed in a 
statement[4] that Flight 31 "exited the taxiway shortly after arriving into Nashville, as the airplane was approaching 
the arrival gate."<nl/> Here's the full statement from Southwest:<nl/> At approximately 5:20 p.m. local time, 
Southwest Airlines Flight #31 from Houston Hobby Airport to Nashville International Airport exited the taxiway 
shortly after arriving into Nashville, as the airplane was approaching the arrival gate. The 133 Passengers and five 
Crewmembers were safely evacuated from the plane and bussed into the airport, and our Employees are currently 
working to support their needs. We are coordinating with local airport officials and responding agencies. The Safety 
of our Customers and Employees remains our primary focus.<nl/>NOW WATCH: This is what it's like to fly on 
Ryanair — the famously cheap European airline[5]<nl/>See Also: Something strange is happening to US 
temperatures right now[6]Los Angeles closed all of its schools Tuesday because of a 'serious' threat[7]This 
revolutionary 
underwear 
is 
shaking 
up 
the 
$26.5 
billion 
feminine 
hygiene 
market[8]<nl/>

Airline Face-to-Face Flying Not Going Over Too Well
Airline Face-to-Face Flying Not Going Over Too Well
WKRB News and Analysis
December 15, 2015 Tuesday 7:42 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 453 words
Byline: David
Body
Jul 11, 2015( WKRB News and Analysis: http://www.wkrb13.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/>            
https://stocktwits.com/widgets/share?via=AnalystRatingsNetwork...y=Airline+Face-to-
Face+Flying+Not+Going+Over+Too+Well <nl/>            http://www.wkrb13.com/images/wrkb-19.jpgBudget flights 
already can be considered cramped, noisy and stuffy, but things could become a great deal worse. 
A patent was recently filed by Zodiac Seats France an airline industry supplier. The patent proposes to squeeze 
even more passengers into planes by turning passengers around so they will be facing one another.<nl/> It would 
have the middle seat in each section of three be reversed meaning that passenger would be facing two other 
people during the flight.<nl/> The diagrams supplied in the patent filing show in detail that arms would intertwine, 
making for a trip that is even more intimate that currently.<nl/> Zodiac has given it the name Economy Class Cabin 
Hexagon, because of the rough shape it creates when looked at from above.<nl/> Zodiac says that along with 
increasing the density of cabin passengers, the passengers themselves would also benefit from additional shoulder 
space.<nl/> This is not any guarantee that the new formation in seating will actually come to fruition, but it is 
another example of how it could become even worse to travel aboard budget airlines.<nl/> This is not the first time 
there has been an attempt by the airline industry to squeeze more people into the economy class cabin.<nl/> 
Ryanair CEO Michael O'Leary as showed interest previously in what are called standing seats as a method of 
lowering prices on plane tickets.<nl/> The way the new hexagon is set up there could be problems when a flight 
experiences turbulence and when someone wants to get out of their seat for whatever reason.<nl/> When the news 
of this first broke, both online and social media news showed that many people were not enthused with what might 
take place.<nl/> Tweets were very critical of the idea saying that it would make flying the discount airlines that much 
more difficult. Others questioned if the saving of having more passengers on board for the airlines was worth 
upsetting and possibly losing overall passenger count due to discontent.<nl/><nl/>This story was originally 
published by WKRB News (http://www.wkrb13.com) and is the sole property of WKRB News. If you are reading this 
article on another website, that means this article was illegally copied and re-published to this website in violation of 
U.S. and International copyright law. You can view the original version of this story at            
http://www.wkrb13.com/business/668788/airline-face-to-face-flying-not-going-over-too-well/<nl/> 
Load-Date: December 16, 2015
Airline Face-to-Face Flying Not Going Over Too Well
End of Document
Security Fears Blight European Tourism, Oil, Economy Offer Relief
Security Fears Blight European Tourism, Oil, Economy Offer Relief
Newstex Blogs
Voice of America
December 14, 2015 Monday 3:40 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLCAll Rights Reserved
Length: 551 words
Body
Dec 14, 2015( Voice of America: http://www.voanews.com Delivered by Newstex) ; Europe's travel industry could 
lose over $1 billion in revenues because of the impact of the Paris attacks, analysts say, though low oil prices and a 
recovering economy will offset security worries for the best-placed companies. Keen to benefit from the positive 
factors, investors are focusing on groups that offer a wide range of destinations, can avoid places where safety is in 
doubt, and have robust enough finances to absorb potential shocks.
 "Big companies may be better prepared because they have more ... and further destinations that will be tempering 
the losses," said Ipek Ozkardeskaya, market analyst at London Capital Group. The full impact of the Nov. 13 
attacks that killed 130 people in Paris will become clearer with fourth-quarter results, but there is already evidence 
of a significant hit to Europe's tourism industry, worth $500 billion according to the U.N.'s World Tourism 
Organization. Hotel revenues in Paris are down 30-40 percent from last year's levels, restaurant revenues have 
fallen by a similar margin while new flight bookings to Paris fell by 27 percent in the week following the attacks. That 
cost Air France KLM 50 million euros ($55 million), while British bus and train operator Stagecoach last week issued 
a profit warning because of customer fears about trips to big cities. "I suspect that we're going to see a little bit more 
of a lingering impact for the travel industry," said Ken Odeluga, market analyst at City Index. Analysts who spoke to 
Reuters gave estimates of the total revenue hit on Europe's travel and tourism sectors from the Paris attacks 
ranging from 800 million euros to well over 1 billion euros. With the political and security situation still volatile in 
many parts of the Middle East and major Western countries on high alert for further Islamist attacks, safety fears will 
continue to hang over the sector for the foreseeable future. "It can get worse when, instead of having one event, 
you are starting to have a series of events, because people then feel very insecure," said Daniele Patti, senior 
research analyst at Allianz Global Investors. On the positive side, analysts cited tour operator TUI, cruise operator 
Carnival, online holiday retailer On The Beach Group, Ryanair and British Airways parent IAG as being able to 
weather the storm. TUI, the world's largest tour operator, said on Thursday it was confident of increasing earnings 
by more than 10 percent this year, as it switched out of Egypt and Tunisia to focus on the Canary Islands and 
Cyprus instead. With ships seen as less likely to be targeted in attacks, Carnival was cited as a good bet in the 
current context, while On The Beach Group could benefit from its focus on destinations like Spain, Portugal and the 
Canaries. Airlines are also attractive as they are trading at a discount to the market, with Ryanair and IAG's price-
to-earnings ratios at 13 and 11.5 respectively, compared with an average of 16.6 on the STOXX Europe 600 index 
and 16.4 on the UK FTSE 100 index. Oil is a key factor for airlines, with analysts estimating that a dollar drop in the 
oil price added between 10 and 15 pence (15 to 23 cents) to their share prices last year. ($1 = 0.9129 euros) ($1 = 
0.6592 pounds) 
Security Fears Blight European Tourism, Oil, Economy Offer Relief
Load-Date: December 14, 2015
End of Document
Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY ) Receives Consensus Rating of 'Buy' from Brokerages
Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) Receives Consensus Rating of 
'Buy' from Brokerages
The Legacy
December 9, 2015 Wednesday 11:49 AM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 676 words
Byline: Taylor Nule
Body
Dec 09, 2015( The Legacy: http://www.localizedusa.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Shares of Ryanair Holdings 
plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) have earned a consensus rating of 'Buy' from the sixteen ratings firms that are currently 
covering the stock, Market Beat reports[1]. One investment analyst has rated the stock with a sell recommendation, 
seven have given a hold recommendation, seven have issued a buy recommendation and one has given a strong 
buy recommendation to the company. The average twelve-month target price among brokerages that have covered 
the stock in the last year is $86.88.<nl/>
 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY[2]) opened at 82.64 on Wednesday. The stock has a market 
capitalization of $21.80 billion and a PE ratio of 14.13. Ryanair Holdings plc has a one year low of $62.53 and a one 
year high of $85.56. The firm's 50-day moving average is $80.71 and its 200-day moving average is $77.39.<nl/> 
Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last released its quarterly earnings results on Monday, November 2nd. 
The company reported $0.99 earnings per share for the quarter, missing analysts' consensus estimates of $3.30 by 
$2.31. On average, analysts expect that Ryanair Holdings plc will post $5.11 earnings per share for the current 
fiscal year.<nl/> The company also recently announced a dividend, which was paid on Friday, November 27th. 
Stockholders of record on Tuesday, October 27th were issued a dividend of $1.635 per share. The ex-dividend date 
of this dividend was Friday, October 23rd.<nl/> A number of analysts recently commented on the stock. Raymond 
James upgraded shares of Ryanair Holdings plc from a 'market perform' rating to an 'outperform' rating in a 
research note on Tuesday, November 3rd. Vetr[3] upgraded shares of Ryanair Holdings plc from a 'buy' rating to a 
'strong-buy' rating and set a $90.63 target price for the company in a research note on Monday, November 16th. 
TheStreet reiterated a 'buy' rating on shares of Ryanair Holdings plc in a research note on Wednesday, October 
21st. Evercore ISI assumed coverage on shares of Ryanair Holdings plc in a research note on Monday, September 
28th. They issued a 'buy' rating and a $100.00 target price for the company. Finally, Macquarie assumed coverage 
on shares of Ryanair Holdings plc in a research note on Friday, August 14th. They issued an 'underperform' rating 
for the company.<nl/> Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY[4]) is a holding company for Ryanair Limited 
(Ryanair). Ryanair operates a low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes 
between Ireland, the United Kingdom, Continental Europe and Morocco. The Company's principal fleet consists of 
Boeing 737-800 aircraft, each having 189 seats. The Company offered over 1,600 short-haul flights per day serving 
approximately 190 airports across Europe, and flying approximately 1,600 routes, with a fleet of approximately 315 
Boeing 737-800 aircraft and six additional leased aircraft acquired on short term leases. Ryanair's fleet totaled to 
308 Boeing 737-800s. Ryanair also provides various ancillary services and engages in other activities connected

with its air passenger service, including non-flight scheduled services, Internet-related services, and the in-flight 
sale of beverages, food and merchandise.<nl/> This story was originally published by Putnam Standard

Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY) Trading 2.7% Higher
Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY) Trading 2.7% Higher
The Legacy
December 5, 2015 Saturday 4:48 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 691 words
Byline: Reagan
Body
Dec 05, 2015( The Legacy: http://www.localizedusa.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Ryanair Holdings plc 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY) shares traded up 2.7% on Friday , MarketBeat[1] reports. The stock traded as high as $80.94 
and last traded at $80.86, with a volume of 615,262 shares changing hands. 
The stock had previously closed at $78.70.<nl/> Several brokerages recently commented on RYAAY. Zacks 
Investment Research[2] lowered shares of Ryanair Holdings plc from a 'buy' rating to a 'hold' rating in a research 
report on Friday, November 20th. Vetr[3] raised shares of Ryanair Holdings plc from a 'buy' rating to a 'strong-buy' 
rating and set a $90.63 price objective on the stock in a research report on Monday, November 16th. Raymond 
James upgraded shares of Ryanair Holdings plc from a 'market perform' rating to an 'outperform' rating in a 
research note on Tuesday, November 3rd. TheStreet reiterated a 'buy' rating on shares of Ryanair Holdings plc in a 
research note on Wednesday, October 21st. Finally, Beaufort Securities restated a 'buy' rating on shares of Ryanair 
Holdings plc in a research note on Tuesday, October 6th. One research analyst has rated the stock with a sell 
rating, seven have issued a hold rating, seven have given a buy rating and one has issued a strong buy rating to 
the company's stock. The company presently has a consensus rating of 'Buy' and an average price target of 
$86.88.<nl/> The stock's 50-day moving average price is $80.70 and its 200 day moving average price is $77.01. 
The firm has a market capitalization of $21.37 billion and a price-to-earnings ratio of 13.84.<nl/><nl/>Ryanair 
Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last announced its quarterly earnings data on Monday, November 2nd. The 
company reported $0.99 earnings per share (EPS) for the quarter, missing the Zacks' consensus estimate of $3.30 
by $2.31. Equities research analysts expect that Ryanair Holdings plc will post $5.11 earnings per share for the 
current year.<nl/> The business also recently declared a dividend, which was paid on Friday, November 27th. 
Stockholders of record on Tuesday, October 27th were given a dividend of $1.635 per share. The ex-dividend date 
of this dividend was Friday, October 23rd.<nl/> Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY[4]) is a holding company for 
Ryanair Limited (Ryanair). Ryanair operates a low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-
point routes between Ireland, the United Kingdom, Continental Europe and Morocco. The Company's principal fleet 
consists of Boeing 737-800 aircraft, each having 189 seats. The Company offered over 1,600 short-haul flights per 
day serving approximately 190 airports across Europe, and flying approximately 1,600 routes, with a fleet of 
approximately 315 Boeing 737-800 aircraft and six additional leased aircraft acquired on short term leases. 
Ryanair's fleet totaled to 308 Boeing 737-800s. Ryanair also provides various ancillary services and engages in 
other activities connected with its air passenger service, including non-flight scheduled services, Internet-related 
services, and the in-flight sale of beverages, food and merchandise.<nl/> This story was originally published by

Stocks Build On Gains As Jobs Report Sings
Stocks Build On Gains As Jobs Report Sings
Stock Market Today
December 4, 2015 Friday 5:33 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 467 words
Body
Dec 04, 2015( Stock Market Today: http://www.investors.com/stock-market-today/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> 
Stocks rocketed higher going into the noon hour Friday, ignited by a better-than-expected jobs report that seemed 
to cement the deal for an interest rate hike on Dec. 16.<nl/>
 The Nasdaq gained 1.3% to trade near its session highs, while the S...00 and the Dow Jones industrial average 
gained 1.1% each in the stock market today[1]. The small-cap Russell 2000 trailed with a 0.8% gain.<nl/> Volume 
was running higher on the Nasdaq exchange.<nl/> The Labor Department said nonfarm payrolls rose 211,000 in 
November vs. estimates of 190,000. The October number was revised upward to 298,000 from 271,000. The 
unemployment rate held steady at 5%.<nl/> The CME Group FedWatch Tool[2] shows futures traders are firmly 
convinced the Fed will raise the fed funds rate — the interest that banks pay on overnight loans — during the 
central bank's Dec. 15-16 meeting. The traders currently are pricing in a 79% chance of a hike to 0.5% from the 
current range of 0 to 0.25%, which has held since December 2008.<nl/> After Thursday's tumultuous day, triggered 
by a milder-than-expected stimulus by the European Central Bank, oil was lower, the dollar higher and the euro 
lower. Treasury yields also declined.<nl/> Among IBD 50 stocks, 46 were higher and four were lower. The best 
performer was Ulta Beauty (NASDAQ:ULTA[3]), which turned heads[4] with a better-than-expected earnings report 
after the close Thursday. It rose 10% in heavy volume, breaking out of a ragged base with a 175.88 buy point.<nl/> 
NetEase (NASDAQ:NTES[5]), another IBD 50 name, rose 5% to a new high. It's now extended 15% from a cup-
base breakout at 154.98; the Chinese game software and Internet content firm initially broke out of that base Nov. 
12.<nl/> Airlines were among the top-performing industry groups, up 2.8%. Alaska Air (NYSE:ALK[6]) rose nearly 
4%, completing a breakout from a late-stage flat base. Southwest Airlines (NYSE:LUV[7]) is also ascending from a 
base, up nearly 3%. Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY[8]) was up 2.6%.<nl/> [ 1]: http://www.investors.com/stock-market-

The 10 things in advertising you need to know today (YHOO, FB, GOOG)
The Business Insider
December 2, 2015 Wednesday 11:35 AM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 935 words
Byline: loreilly@businessinsider.com,  (Lara OReilly) Lara OReilly
Body
Dec 02, 2015( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) ;;<nl/> Peter 
Barreras/AP<nl/>Good morning. Here's everything you need to know in the world of advertising today.<nl/>
 1. Yahoo's board is reportedly going to consider a potential sale of its internet business when it meets later this 
week.[1] Among the potential buyers expected to take a look at Yahoo's business are private-equity shops.<nl/> 2. 
Budget airline Ryanair is taking Google to the high court over alleged "misleading and deceptive" online 
ads.[2] Ryanair is complaining about the way an unaffiliated "screenscraper" website called eDreams, which it 
claims masquerades as its brand, is promoted right at the top of Google's search engine listings.<nl/> 3. New York 
City-headquartered ad tech startup Undertone has been acquired by Israeli marketing software company Perion in 
an all-cash deal worth $180 million.[3] Perion will now have a bigger presence in the US and combined the two 
companies are estimated to generate $350 million in net revenue this year.<nl/> 4. French-based publicly-listed ad 
tech company Criteo has joined the list of firms that pay Adblock Plus to appear on its "Acceptable Ads" list.[4] Two 
types of Criteo ads are now whitelisted.<nl/> 5. Microsoft employees sang carols outside Apple's flagship store for a 
Christmas commercial.[5] The video, posted on YouTube, shows Microsoft's New York City store employees 
performing a version of "Let There Be Peace On Earth" outside the Fifth Avenue Apple Store.<nl/> 6. Even Adobe 
wants everyone to quit using Flash.[6] The company is encouraging users to make animations in HTML 5 instead 
and it has rebranded Flash Professional CC to Animate Professional CC.<nl/> 7. Kate Hudson's workout brand is 
mocking Lululemon.[7] Fabletics has posted two videos to YouTube that seem to directly mock the extremely 
popular athleisure brand.<nl/> 8. GE's odd "What's the Matter with Owen" commercials are working like a charm, it 
says.[8] The TV commercials have been turning heads among the target recruits, college grads, says Tony 
Denhart, University Relations Leader at GE Corporate and Andy Goldberg, GE's Chief Creative Officer.<nl/> 9. 
Mark Zuckerberg said he is giving away 99% of his shares in Facebook during his lifetime to help initiatives that 
"advance human potential and promote equality."[9] That equals around $45 billion today.<nl/> 10. World Cup 
sponsors Adidas, Coca-Cola, Visa, McDonald's, and AB InBev have written to FIFA's executive committee calling 
for "independent oversight" of the governing body's reform process, AP reports.[10] The competition's other lead 
sponsors, Hyundai and Gazprom, are not signatories on the letter.<nl/>NOW WATCH: This Chipotle hack lets you 
get free Guac[11]<nl/>See Also: The former CEO of Vodafone Europe told us why he's joining the board of an ad 
blocker[12]These are the 10 candidates most likely to replace Marissa Mayer if she leaves Yahoo[13]Here's what 
the logos for Amazon, Levi's, and HBO Go would say if they were being honest[14]<nl/> [ 1]:

Stocks, Volume Mixed, Nasdaq Up; Delta Triggers Airline Rally
Stocks, Volume Mixed, Nasdaq Up; Delta Triggers Airline Rally
Stock Market Today
December 2, 2015 Wednesday 4:53 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 790 words
Body
Dec 02, 2015( Stock Market Today: http://www.investors.com/stock-market-today/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> 
Stocks wobbled in and out of gains and losses early Wednesday, as company news[1] and mixed economic reports 
powered the bulk of early trade.<nl/> The Nasdaq held steady with a 0.2% gain. 
The Dow Jones industrial average and the S...00 each logged 0.1% declines. The small-cap Russell 2000 clung to 
a fractional gain.<nl/> Volume was mixed at the start of trade, up 19% on the Nasdaq and 13% lower on the NYSE, 
vs. activity at the same time Tuesday.<nl/> Yahoo (NASDAQ:YHOO[2]) and Qualcomm (NASDAQ:QCOM[3]) were 
the opening stories in the stock market today[4], with Qualcomm up 8% on a patent royalty deal in China and 
Yahoo jumping 4% on news that it may spin off not one, but two units into separately traded entities.<nl/> A heavy 
lineup of speeches form Federal Reserve officials, including two speeches from Chief Janet Yellen, could figure in 
the day's trade as investors attempt to divine how the central bank will proceed with a possible policy shift at its 
Dec. 15-16 meeting. The Fed's beige book report for December is due out at 2 p.m. ET.<nl/> Private employers 
added 217,000 workers in November, according to the ADP national employment report. Economists had forecast 
183,000 added jobs. Nearly all of the hirings were among service sector employers.<nl/> Oil prices swung nearly 
2% lower, but with West Texas Intermediate and Brent crude holding within their recent trading ranges, ahead of 
the Energy Information Administration's weekly stockpiles report, due out at 10:30 a.m.<nl/> Logistics leader C.H. 
Robinson (NASDAQ:CHRW[5]) dived almost 7%, the worst showing among S...00 stocks.<nl/> Airlines staged an 
early rally after Delta Air Lines (NYSE:DAL[6]) reported a surprise gain in monthly per passenger revenue in 
November. Delta, United Continental (NYSE:UAL[7]) and American Airlines (NASDAQ:AAL[8]) were all up nearly 
3%. JetBlue (NASDAQ:JBLU[9]), Southwest Airlines (NYSE:LUV[10]) and Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY[11]) gained 
2% apiece.<nl/> Among IBD 50 stocks, Hawaiian (NASDAQ:HA[12]) jumped 4%, Alaska Air (NASDAQ:AAL[13]) 
took a 1% gain.<nl/> Hawaiian's gain left shares just below its Nov. 6 high as the stock works on the fourth week in 
a flat consolidation. The airline triggered an eight-week hold rule on Oct. 19, rising more than 20% above a 25.69 
buy point in less than two weeks.<nl/> IBD 50 peer AMN Healthcare Services (NYSE:AHS[14]) popped almost 3% 
at the open. The medical staffing agency is up 32% from a late October low, climbing the right side of a deep, two-
month consolidation.<nl/> Retailers and apparel makers will make a showing in a busy after-hours session 
Wednesday, with quarterly reports due out from PVH (NYSE:PVH[15]), American Eagle Outfitters (NYSE:AEO[16]) 
and Aeropostale (NYSE:ARO[17]), as well as from chipmaker Avago Technologies (NASDAQ:AVGO[18]).<nl/> 
Overseas, Europe's markets were a bit more broadly mixed near midday than U.S. stocks, ahead of the European 
Central Bank's key policy vote due out there Thursday. China's markets rose, with the Shanghai Composite jumping 
2.3% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng index ending up 0.4%.<nl/> [ 1]: http://news.investors.com/investing.aspx [ 2]:

Ryanair launches court action against Google, eDreams
Ryanair launches court action against Google, eDreams
Phys.org - Science and Technology News
December 1, 2015 Tuesday 7:42 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 487 words
Body
Dec 01, 2015( Phys.org - Science and Technology News: http://phys.org/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Irish budget 
airline Ryanair says Google has not been providing the carrier's true prices and claimed that eDreams was creating 
websites including the word "Ryanair" to mislead customers <nl/> Irish low-cost carrier Ryanair on Tuesday said it 
had launched court action against Internet giant Google and online travel agent eDreams, accusing them of 
misleading customers and not offering the best deal. 
<nl/>"We're launching legal proceedings[1] in the Irish High Court with Google and eDreams," Ryanair boss Michal 
O'Leary said at a press conference in London.<nl/> The company[2] said it started the action on Monday.<nl/> It 
said Google was not providing true Ryanair prices and claimed that eDreams was creating websites including the 
word "Ryanair" to mislead customers.<nl/> "It's the deception we have a problem with, not the advertising," through 
which companies pay Google to have their ads high up in search results, O'Leary said.<nl/> Sites like eDreams, 
whose parent company is based in Spain, pay the US giant to come out higher up.<nl/> Google offers them 
preferential placement but with a yellow sign to indicate that the ads are sponsored.<nl/> "Ryanair has engaged in 
several legal cases across Europe against screenscraper websites such as eDreams to prevent consumers from 
being deceived and subjected to false prices and hidden charges," the Irish company said in a statement.<nl/> 
Ryanair said it had received "numerous complaints from Ryanair customers who were deceived into buying on the 
eDreams website when they thought they were booking on Ryanair.com".<nl/> eDreams said it "disagreed strongly" 
with Ryanair's accusations. <nl/> "This action is clearly just another attempt from Ryanair to stop online travel 
agencies from offering consumers the best price and choice when it comes to booking flights," it said in a 
statement. <nl/>Relevant stories<nl/> French paper goes global, risks ridicule with translation[3] Flights grounded 
as ash cloud reaches Britain[4] Google loses Australian advert cases[5] Spain's eDreams Odigeo skids on market 
debut[6] Buying a Paris to Berlin ticket: what Google really offers[7] India's antitrust probe into Google moves into 
next phase[8]<nl/> [ 1]: http://phys.org/tags/legal+proceedings/ [ 2]:            http://phys.org/tags/company/ [ 3]:            
http://phys.org/news/2009-07-french-paper-global-ridicule.html#nRlv [ 4]:            http://phys.org/news/2011-05-
flights-grounded-ash-cloud-britain.html#nRlv [ 5]:            http://phys.org/news/2012-04-google-australian-advert-
cases.html#nRlv [ 6]:            http://phys.org/news/2014-04-spain-edreams-odigeo-skids-debut.html#nRlv [ 7]:            
http://phys.org/news/2015-04-paris-berlin-ticket-google.html#nRlv [ 8]:            http://phys.org/news/2015-08-india-
antitrust-probe-google-phase.html#nRlv 
Load-Date: December 1, 2015
Ryanair launches court action against Google, eDreams
End of Document
Skyscanner Reveals the Hot Destinations for 2016
Skyscanner Reveals the Hot Destinations for 2016
Pressat
November 27, 2015 Friday 11:14 AM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 691 words
Byline: Pressat
Body
Nov 27, 2015( Pressat: http://www.pressat.co.uk Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Friday 27 November, 2015<nl/> 
Global travel search engine Skyscanner has released its predictions for the hot spots to watch in 2016. These 
destinations range from the new set of all-inclusive destinations like Cape Verde to the more intrepid destinations, 
such as the Azores.<nl/>
The predictions are based on the analysis of millions of Skyscanner flight searches from the last three years, 
combined with qualitative research carried out by our team of travel experts.<nl/>The top five hot spots for 2016 
(based on percentage increase in searches from the UK over the last three years*):<nl/>1. Ponta Delgada (the 
Azores) - 63%With more airlines flying to the Azores, including Ryanair's new weekly flight from Stansted to Ponta 
Delgada, this autonomous region of Portugal is opening up as a viable budget travel destination and is therefore 
experiencing a tourism boom. With excellent hiking, whale watching, surfing and diving, the Azores is likely to 
feature heavily on adventure travellers' bucket lists in 2016. <nl/>2. Havana (Cuba) - 33%After years in the cold, 
Cuba is back on the world stage as the USA restored diplomatic relations in July and continues to loosen 
restrictions on trade. If more restrictions are lifted we may see flights from the US and US hotel chains opening in 
Cuba in 2016. Many are therefore booking flights to Cuba to experience the country before it changes beyond 
recognition (and before prices rise as a result). Having been shut off for so long Cuba is trapped in a time warp, with 
crumbing colonial buildings and 1950s cars. It is like nowhere else on earth.<nl/>3. Tokyo (Japan) - 25%Tourism 
has boomed under the current prime minister's administration. The national tourist board are actively targeting 
niche UK markets by focusing on ski, honeymoon and adventure tourism offerings. Thanks to the excellent value 
Japan Rail Passes and Airbnb type accommodation, Tokyo is now 50% cheaper for UK travellers than in 2013 
according to the Post Office's Long Haul Report.<nl/>What's more, Japan will host the 2020 Olympics and the 2019 
Rugby World Cup so attention will only increase throughout 2016. Hokkaido's first Shinkansen high speed train will 
also launch in 2016, opening up more of Japan to visitors.<nl/>4. Copenhagen (Denmark) - 21%Recently voted the 
ninth most reputable city in the world, Copenhagen is a must visit for culture vultures and foodies alike. Home to the 
five-month long Tivoli Festival (May - September 2016), classical music fans can expect a star-studded line up 
hosted at the stunning Tivoli Gardens.<nl/>February is also a great time to visit the capital, with the Copenhagen 
Cooking festival showcasing ever-increasingly popular Nordic cuisine, whilst fashionistas can immerse themselves 
in Copenhagen's Fashion Week, the largest of its kind in Northern Europe. <nl/>5. Sal (Cape Verde) - 14%With a 
reputation for unspoilt beaches and cobbled streets, the island of Sal is only just emerging as a tourist destination. 
Thomson Airways is adding to its portfolio with a new route from Bristol in summer 2016. What's more, with chart 
topping acts and reality stars frequenting these West Africa isles Skyscanner predicts the destination's popularity 
Skyscanner Reveals the Hot Destinations for 2016
will continue to rise. Sal is also a great base for exploring the rest of the archipelago, from the canyons, gorges and 
valleys of Santo Antao to the Sahara-like dunes of Boa Vista.<nl/>Skyscanner has created travel guides to each of 
these destinations, which can be found at www.skyscanner.net/news. <nl/>Commenting on the findings, 
Skyscanner's travel editor Cat McGloin said, 'With 50 million searches to the site every month from all over the 
world, our search data gives us some really robust insight in to these trends. It's interesting to see how people's 
travel interests are changing and what these destinations are offering to become even more appealing.'<nl/><nl/>

Stock Futures Hold Wobbly Gains; Disney Hurt By ESPN
Stock Futures Hold Wobbly Gains; Disney Hurt By ESPN
Stock Market Today
November 27, 2015 Friday 3:08 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 561 words
Body
Nov 27, 2015( Stock Market Today: http://www.investors.com/stock-market-today/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> 
Stock futures bobbed in narrowly positive territory ahead of Friday's open, as the market prepared for a short post-
holiday trading session. Dow futures traded 14.6 points above fair market value and had halved their gains over the 
prior hour.<nl/>
<nl/>Nasdaq 100 futures doubled their hour-earlier gains to 18 points. S...00 futures were steady, showing a 3.6-
point gain.<nl/> The small-cap S...00 starts Friday with a 1.6% gain and just back above its 200-day line. The 
broader Russell 2000 has climbed a shade less than 2% since Monday, but is still well below its 200-day level.<nl/> 
Premarket action was subdued among most Dow and S...00 stocks. Walt Disney (NYSE:DIS[1]) dropped nearly 
2%, the Dow's biggest move and the largest loss among S...00 companies. A regulatory filing late Wednesday 
showed Disney's profitable ESPN franchise had lost 3 million subscribers from the start of 2015 through October, 
putting the channel's two-year subscriber loss at 7 million.<nl/> Citigroup (NYSE:C[2]), Xerox (NYSE:XRX[3]) and 
Target (NYSE:TGT[4]) led the S...00 before the open with gains of just over 1%.<nl/> China-based issues were 
seeing some selling pressure after a tough day in China's markets.<nl/> Online retailer JD.com (NASDAQ:JD[5]) 
dropped more than 3%, marking the widest loss among Nasdaq 100 companies. The stock ended Wednesday in a 
struggle to hold support at its 10-week moving average as it attempts to build the right side of a five-month cup 
base.<nl/> On the IBD 50 list, premarket gains held to less than 1%. China-based social networking platform YY 
(NASDAQ:YY[6]) fell more than 2% to the bottom of the list. The stock is also working to climb the right side of a 
five-month consolidation.<nl/> On IBD's Your Weekly Review list, Ireland-based Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY[7]) 
popped 2% before the open. The budget airline tripped two sell signals on Tuesday, falling below its 10-week line in 
strong trade and undercutting a flat-base buy point of 82.81 by more than 7%.<nl/> Overseas, China's markets 
careened lower, with the Shanghai Composite diving 5.5% Friday and Hong Kong's Hang Seng down 1.9%. 
Investors were apparently raising cash ahead of next week's re-entry of IPOs to the Chinese markets and reacting 
to news[8] late Thursday that regulators were investigating the country's largest brokerage firm. Shanghai ended 
the week down 5.3%. Hong Kong took a 3% loss.<nl/> In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 trimmed off 0.3% Friday to 
post a flat finish to the week.<nl/> Europe's markets were flat, with the leading benchmark indexes trading within 
0.1% of their starting points at midsession on Friday.<nl/> [ 1]: http://research.investors.com/quotes/nyse-walt-
