EZU, QCAN: Big ETF Inflows
EZU, QCAN: Big ETF Inflows
Market News Video
October 5, 2015 Monday 3:49 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 200 words
Body
View Video
Oct 05, 2015 (Market News Video:http://marketnewsvideo.com/ Delivered by Newstex)
 Comparing units outstanding versus one week ago at the coverage universe of ETFs at ETF Channel, the biggest 
inflow was seen in the iShares MSCI Eurozone ETF (EZU), which added 9,700,000 units, or a 3.2% increase week 
over week. Among the largest underlying components of EZU, in morning trading today Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY) 
is up about 2.2%. 
And on a percentage change basis, the ETF with the biggest increase in inflows was the SPDR MSCI Canada 
Quality Mix ETF (QCAN), which added 50,000 units, for a 33.3% increase in outstanding units. Among the largest 
underlying components of QCAN, in morning trading today Canadian Imperial Bank Commerce (CM.CA) is up 
about 1.4%, and Toronto Dominion Bank (TD.CA) is up by about 2.1%.

JetBlue Flies to Mexico City, Boosts Latin American Presence
JetBlue Flies to Mexico City, Boosts Latin American Presence
Zacks Investment Research
October 2, 2015 Friday 7:10 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 647 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
Oct 02, 2015( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Low-cost carrier 
JetBlue Airways Corp. JBLU[1] is consistently engaged in efforts to expand its operations. In keeping with this 
objective, the Long Island City, NY-based carrier announced the commencement of daily flights to Mexico City, 
thereby making the capital of Mexico its 91st destination across the globe. 
As far as the Latin America and Caribbean region is concerned, Mexico City marks the 35th destination for 
JetBlue.<nl/>Effective yesterday, JetBlue has started operating flights from the Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood 
International Airport (FLL) and Orlando International Airport (MCO) to the Mexico City International Airport (MEX), 
thereby enhancing connectivity between two key Florida cities and Mexico's capital. We note that Mexico City is a 
popular tourist spot, thanks to its large number of museums.<nl/>That Latin America is at the center of JetBlue's 
expansion plans is evident. In addition to Mexico City, the company announced that it will start operating daily non-
stop flights connecting FLL and the busy Mariscal Sucre International Airport in Ecuador. The new route, which will 
be operational from Feb 25, 2016, will facilitate connectivity between Fort Lauderdale in Florida and Ecuador's 
capital, Quito. Tickets for the new route, which are initially priced at $139 (one-way), are already 
available.<nl/>Quito is also a key tourist spot with various attractions like museums, parks and is home to one of the 
best-preserved historic centers across the globe. Consequently, we are positive on the carrier's decision to offer 
flights to Mexico City and Quito. We believe this should boost the company's top line further on the back of 
increased demand.<nl/>Zacks Rank<nl/>JetBlue currently carries a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy). Investors 
interested in the airline space may also consider Delta Air Lines DAL[2], Alaska Air Group, Inc. ALK[3] and Ryanair 
Holdings RYAAY[4]. All the three carriers also sport a Zacks Rank #1.<nl/>Want the latest recommendations from

Alaska Air Group ( ALK ) Adds Raleigh to Seattle Network
Alaska Air Group (ALK) Adds Raleigh to Seattle Network
Zacks Investment Research
October 2, 2015 Friday 4:40 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 611 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
Oct 02, 2015( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Recently, Alaska 
Airlines, a division of Alaska Air Group, Inc. ALK[1] has initiated flight service between the cities of Seattle and 
Raleigh/Durham, North Carolina, starting Oct 1.<nl/>
An introductory fare of $169 for one-way travel between Seattle and Raleigh/Durham is on offer through Oct 3, 
2015, for customers traveling by Dec 16, 2015.<nl/>Under the new extension, Alaska Airlines will fly Boeing's Next 
Generation 737 aircraft which offers high fuel efficiency. Moreover, passengers will be offered unlimited video 
streaming services on their personal devices along with snacks and other refreshments. <nl/>Meanwhile, Alaska 
Airlines flagged off flights from Seattle to Nashville and New York City's JFK airport last month. In 2015, the carrier 
has added six new cities, inclusive of the latest addition of Raleigh.<nl/>Last month, Alaska Airlines started 
operating non-stop flights between Nashville and Seattle, thereby expanding its non-stop service to 84 destinations 
from Seattle alone.<nl/>However, we believe that addition of Raleigh will intensify competition as Delta Air Lines 
DAL[2] is continuously expanding its presence at the Raleigh-Durham International Airport, from where it currently 
operates non-stop flights to 20 destinations.<nl/>Despite such headwinds, increased flight frequencies coupled with 
low fares and the upcoming holiday season are a few encouraging factors which are likely to boost revenues for 
Alaska Airlines.<nl/>Stocks to Consider<nl/>Alaska Air Group currently carries a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy). 
Other favorably ranked stocks in the same space are Ryanair Holdings plc RYAAY[3] and JetBlue Airways Corp. 
JBLU[4]. Both the stocks sport the same Zacks Rank as Alaska Air Group.<nl/>Want the latest recommendations

JetBlue to Connect Syracuse Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood
JetBlue to Connect Syracuse Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood
Zacks Investment Research
October 1, 2015 Thursday 8:45 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 608 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
Oct 01, 2015( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> In sync with its 
seasonal plans, low-cost carrier JetBlue Airways Corp. JBLU[1] recently announced non-stop flights between 
Syracuse Hancock International Airport (SYR) and Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport (FLL).<nl/>
JetBlue will be offering one round-trip service every day starting Jan 13, 2016 through May 1, 2016. An introductory 
fare of $79 for one-way travel is presently on offer for customers booking for flights during that period.<nl/>JetBlue 
will fly EMBRAER 190 aircraft which offer two-by-two seating facility. Moreover, passengers will be able to enjoy 
better leg space along with complimentary free snacks and other refreshments. Passengers will also be able to 
access free DIRECTV channels and Sirius XM Holdings Inc.'s SIRI[2] satellite radio service.<nl/>In order to boost 
its Florida gateways during winter months, JetBlue has decided to run 95 flights daily at the FLL Airport. Moreover, 
the company's South Florida region also serves as an important hub for JetBlue flights connecting Latin American 
cities.<nl/>Recent Reuters reports reveal JetBlue's plans to add a second charter flight service from New York's 
John F. Kennedy airport to Havana. This non-stop, round-trip service, starting Dec 1, 2015, will be offered on every 
Tuesday in coordination with Cuba Travel Services.<nl/>Hence, we believe that increased flight frequency coupled 
with low fares will enhance traveling options apart from boosting passenger revenues for JetBlue.<nl/>JetBlue 
currently sports a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy). Other favorably ranked stocks in the same space are Ryanair 
Holdings plc RYAAY[3] and Delta Air Lines DAL[4], both the stocks sporting the same Zacks Rank as 
JetBlue.<nl/>Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today, you can download 7 Best 
Stocks for the Next 30 Days. Click to get this free report >>[5]<nl/>Want the latest recommendations from Zacks

Why Ryanair Holdings ( RYAAY ) Could Be Positioned for a Surge?
Why Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY) Could Be Positioned for a Surge?
Zacks Investment Research
September 30, 2015 Wednesday 1:25 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 476 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
Sep 30, 2015( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Ryanair Holdings 
plc (RYAAY[1]) is a company in the Transport - Airline space that could be an interesting play for investors. That is 
because, not only does the stock have decent short-term momentum, but it is seeing solid activity on the earnings 
estimate revision front as well.<nl/>
<nl/> These positive earnings estimate revisions suggest that analysts are becoming more optimistic on RYAAY's 
earnings for the coming quarter and year. In fact, consensus estimates have moved sharply higher for both of these 
time frames over the past four weeks, suggesting that Ryanair Holdings could be a solid choice for 
investors.<nl/><nl/> Current Quarter Estimates for RYAAY<nl/><nl/> In the past 30 days, 2 estimates have gone 
higher for Ryanair Holdings while none have gone lower in the same time period. The trend has been pretty 
favorable too, with estimates increasing from $2.87 a share 30 days ago, to $3.21 a share today, a move of 
11.8%.<nl/><nl/> Current Year Estimates for RYAAY<nl/><nl/> Meanwhile, Ryanair Holdings' current year figures 
are also looking quite promising, with 4 estimates moving higher in the past month, compared to none lower. The 
consensus estimate trend has also seen a boost for this time frame, increasing from $4.01 per share 30 days ago to 
$4.81 per share today, an increase of about 20%.<nl/><nl/> Bottom Line<nl/><nl/> The stock has also started to 
move higher lately, adding 7.4% over the past four weeks, suggesting that investors are starting to take note of this 
impressive story. So investors may definitely want to consider this Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy) stock to profit in the 
near future.<nl/><nl/> Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today, you can

GOL Linhas August Traffic Deteriorates, Capacity Down
GOL Linhas August Traffic Deteriorates, Capacity Down
Zacks Investment Research
September 30, 2015 Wednesday 5:00 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 579 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
Sep 30, 2015( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> GOL Linhas 
Aereas Inteligentes S.A. GOL[1] posted a decline in air traffic for the month of August this year. Traffic - measured 
in revenue passenger kilometres (RPK) - stood at 3.05 billion, down 2% from 3.12 billion recorded a year ago.<nl/>
Also, on a year-over-year basis, consolidated capacity (or available seat kilometres /ASKs) inched down 0.3% to 
4.04 billion mainly because of a 0.6% drop in domestic capacity. However, international capacity improved 2.2%. 
Likewise, international RPK for the month inched up 3.5% while the domestic figure fell 2.8%.<nl/>Meanwhile, the 
load factor or percentage of seats filled by passengers fell to 75.7% from 77% recorded in Aug 2014. GOL's 
strategy to trim down domestic capacity may allow it to improve the load factor.<nl/>At the end of the first eight 
months of 2015, RPK hiked 5.3% while ASK climbed 3%. Load factor for the same period inched up 
1.7%.<nl/>Adverse conditions in the Brazilian economy coupled with foreign currency headwinds owing to the 
strengthening of the U.S. dollar against the Brazilian real have largely resulted in the dismal performance. 
Moreover, in Aug 2015, the carrier witnessed a 7.5% drop in passenger count.<nl/>Meanwhile, we expect such 
factors to prevail in the near future as well.<nl/>Zacks Rank ...ocks to Consider<nl/>GOL Linhas currently carries a 
Zacks Rank #4 (Sell). Better-stocks in the same industry are JetBlue Airways Corp. JBLU[2], Ryanair Holdings plc 
RYAAY[3] and Delta Air Lines DAL[4]. All three sport a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy).<nl/>Want the latest 
recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today, you can download 7 Best Stocks for the Next 30 Days.

Bull of the Day: Ryanair (RYAAY)
Bull of the Day: Ryanair (RYAAY)
Zacks Investment Research
September 29, 2015 Tuesday 3:05 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 535 words
Byline: David Bartosiak
Body
Sep 29, 2015( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> I'm not going to lie 
to you, it's very hard to sit up here and choose a 'Bull of the Day' when it seems like it's hitting the fan from every 
direction right now. First it was energy, then China, then biotech, now healthcare. 
There seems to be nowhere to hide in this market right now, other than under the desk. Well I'm a big guy and it's 
not too spacious down there so I propose an alternate solution; search for the strength.<nl/><nl/>The airline 
industry is in the top 9% of the 265 industries we rank with our Zacks Industry Rank. Among the Zacks Rank #1 
(Strong Buy) stocks to choose from is our 'Bull of the Day' Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY[1]). Ryanair operates an ultra-
low cost, scheduled airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes between Ireland, the United Kingdom, 
Continental Europe and Morocco. The company's principle fleet consists of Boeing 737-800 aircraft.<nl/><nl/>Click 
'FOLLOW THE AUTHOR' above for free weekly stock picks!!! Twitter @bartosiastics[2]<nl/><nl/>Over the last thirty 
days, three analysts have upped their earnings estimates for the current year and next year. The bullish attitude has 
pushed up the Zacks Consensus estimate to $4.77 from $3.85 for the current year and up from $4.34 to $5.41 for 
next year. Those upward revisions are a big reason for the Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy). This stock also happens to 
be blessed with a Zacks Momentum Style Score of 'A' making it very attractive at these levels.<nl/><nl/><nl/>With 
the market seeming to crumble around it, shares of Ryanair has remained resilient. A great earnings report last 
October was the catalyst that started the uptrend that began in the mid-$50s and has gone through to the low $80s. 
The last few rocky trading days have sent shares retreating from the highs but the fall from grace hasn't been too 
harsh. Shares found buyers stepping back in at the $78 level. The commodity channel index has come down from 
an extremely overbought level over 200 to cross below the zero line. It may be best to wait for the CCI to dip below 
-100 then come back a bit before jumping in headfirst.<nl/><nl/>Be sure to click FOLLOW THE AUTHOR above to 
stay on top of all the hot momentum stocks at Zacks.com. David Bartosiak is the Momentum Stock Strategist with 
Zacks, editor of the Momentum Trader and Home Run Investor, and host of 'Trending Stocks';<nl/><nl/> <nl/> Want 
the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today, you can download 7 Best Stocks for the 
Next 30 Days. Click to get this free report[3] RYANAIR HLDGS (RYAAY): Free Stock Analysis Report[4] To read 
this article on Zacks.com click here.[5]<nl/> [ 1]: http://WWW.ZACKS.COM/STOCK/QUOTE/RYAAY [ 2]:

Ryanair Holdings, Halliburton , JPMorgan Chase , Citigroup and Wells Fargo highlighted as Zacks Bull and 
Bear of the Day
Ryanair Holdings, Halliburton, JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup and Wells Fargo 
highlighted as Zacks Bull and Bear of the Day
Zacks Investment Research
September 29, 2015 Tuesday 2:15 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 1905 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
Sep 29, 2015( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> For Immediate 
Release<nl/> Chicago, IL - September 29, 2015- Zacks Equity Research[1] highlights Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY[2]) 
as the Bull of the Day and Halliburton (HAL[3]) as the Bear of the Day. In addition, Zacks Equity Research provides 
analysis on JPMorgan Chase .... (JPM[4]), Citigroup Inc. 
(C[5]) and Wells Fargo ...mpany ( WFC[6]).<nl/><nl/> Here is a synopsis of all five stocks:<nl/><nl/> Bull of the 
Day[7]: <nl/><nl/> I'm not going to lie to you, it's very hard to sit up here and choose a 'Bull of the Day' when it 
seems like it's hitting the fan from every direction right now. First it was energy, then China, then biotech, now 
healthcare. There seems to be nowhere to hide in this market right now, other than under the desk. Well I'm a big 
guy and it's not too spacious down there so I propose an alternate solution; search for the strength.<nl/><nl/> The 
airline industry is in the top 9% of the 265 industries we rank with our Zacks Industry Rank. Among the Zacks Rank 
#1 (Strong Buy) stocks to choose from is our 'Bull of the Day' Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY[8] ). Ryanair operates an 
ultra-low cost, scheduled airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes between Ireland, the United Kingdom, 
Continental Europe and Morocco. The company's principle fleet consists of Boeing 737-800 aircraft.<nl/><nl/> Click 
'FOLLOW THE AUTHOR' above for free weekly stock picks!!! Twitter @bartosiastics[9] <nl/><nl/> Over the last 
thirty days, three analysts have upped their earnings estimates for the current year and next year. The bullish 
attitude has pushed up the Zacks Consensus estimate to $4.77 from $3.85 for the current year and up from $4.34 
to $5.41 for next year. Those upward revisions are a big reason for the Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy). This stock also 
happens to be blessed with a Zacks Momentum Style Score of 'A' making it very attractive at these levels.<nl/><nl/> 
Bear of the Day[10] :<nl/><nl/> When I'm looking for a stock to be my 'Bear of the Day' I look for weak stocks in a 
weak industry. So you see it's easy for me to look at a Zacks Rank #5 (Strong Sell) in an industry that ranks in the 
bottom 18% of the 265 industries we rank with our Zacks Industry Rank, and find myself a bearish idea. But when 
that stock also happens to be in the energy business that's taken the biggest hit this year, I almost feel like I'm 
making it too obvious.<nl/><nl/> Falling crude prices have put pressure on companies across the energy sector. 
Today's 'Bear of the Day,' Halliburton ( HAL[11]), is one of the world's largest providers of products and services to 
the energy industry. The company serves the upstream oil and gas industry throughout the lifecycle of the reservoir. 
It's no wonder that business would be struggling as oil is becoming cheaper and cheaper as more is brought to 
market.<nl/><nl/> Click 'FOLLOW THE AUTHOR' above for free weekly stock picks!!! Twitter @bartosiastics[12] 
<nl/><nl/> You don't have to take my word for it. Recently, ten analysts have revised their earnings estimates to the 
Ryanair Holdings, Halliburton , JPMorgan Chase , Citigroup and Wells Fargo highlighted as Zacks Bull and 
Bear of the Day
downside for the current year, while eleven have done so for next year. Most of that bearish change took place 
between thirty and sixty days ago. But in the last week, another round of negative revisions have come through, 
dropping the Zacks Consensus Estimates even further. Currently, the consensus for the current year has gone from 
$1.68 to $1.60, while next year's number has fallen from $1.95 to $1.71.<nl/><nl/> Additional content:<nl/><nl/> 
Energy Lending Now a Major Burden for Banks?<nl/><nl/> The rippling effects of the plunge in oil prices over the 
past year continue to hit harder on the banking sector. Energy lending, which once aided the U.S. oil boom, now 
seems to give jitters to banks as they face continuous regulatory pressure to limit exposure in the sector.<nl/><nl/> 
Concern arises on the fact that amid the still low oil prices, credit quality of the loans made to the energy companies 
will continue to deteriorate, which may ultimately hit bank's profitability. This is because higher provisioning to cover 
the bad loans of the energy companies is likely to shrink the banks' overall earnings.<nl/> <nl/> A report released 
by the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC) in June 2015, on Semiannual Risk Perspective, placed oil 
and gas lending on the top of its list of risks that demand awareness among bankers and examiners. It stated that, 
'The significant decline in oil prices in 2014 could put pressure on loan portfolios in the oil and gas production and 
services sector.'<nl/> <nl/> Regarding credit underwriting, the report highlighted, 'where indicated, examiners will 
also assess banks' actions to assess, monitor, and manage both direct and indirect exposures to the oil and gas 
sector, given the recent decline in oil prices and the potential for a protracted period of low or volatile prices.'<nl/> 
<nl/> Banks extend loans to energy companies on the basis of the value of their oil and natural gas reserves. Owing 
to the acute drop in oil prices, which is currently trading below the key psychological level of $50-a-barrel, after 
hitting new 6-1/2 year low of $37.75 last month, the worth of several of those reserves dropped to around half 
compared to previous year.<nl/> <nl/> Banks adjust the revolving credit lines, termed 'redetermination,' twice a year 
which is generally around April and October. Notably, the redeterminations of these reserve-based loans, which are 
expected to occur this fall are likely to hit the small and midcap exploration and production companies harder 
compared to the larger-cap companies because the smaller companies depend more on bank debt placing the 
energy reserves as collateral.<nl/> <nl/> Banks, which have extended credit to troubled energy firms in order to 
avoid large amounts of defaults, are however tightening their finding pipeline to these companies. Amid regulatory 
pressure, banks have commenced their fall reviews on the collateral quality placed by the small and mid-sized 
firms.<nl/> <nl/> The Concerns<nl/> <nl/> Banks, which continue to embrace stricter rules and regulations post 
crisis, are currently in a rift with regulators with loan reviews in the energy portfolio.<nl/> <nl/> Notably, the issues 
came into light after major U.S regulators - the OCC, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC), and the 
Federal Reserve Board, increased their scrutiny on the banks that lend to the energy sector, as a part of the Shared 
National Credit (SNC) review program that is currently underway.<nl/><nl/> Notably, earlier this month the 
regulators met with several energy bankers from companies including JPMorgan Chase .... (JPM[13]), Citigroup Inc. 
(C[14]) and Wells Fargo ...mpany ( WFC[15]). According to a recent report by the Wall Street Journal, the banks 
raised concern as regulators' spring review rated several reserve-based loans as more risky than the banks had 
contemplated.<nl/> <nl/> In their standing, the banks have explained why reserve-based loans resemble lower-risk, 
asset-based loans. They also raised question about the OCC's consideration of an energy company's total debt 
when evaluating reserve-based loans, which are usually paid earlier than other debt in case there is a 
restructuring.<nl/><nl/> Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today, you can

JetBlue : Another Cuba -Bound Charter Flight Coming Up?
JetBlue: Another Cuba-Bound Charter Flight Coming Up?
Zacks Investment Research
September 28, 2015 Monday 5:20 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 549 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
Sep 28, 2015( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Low-cost carrier 
JetBlue Airways Corp. JBLU[1] recently announced a second charter flight from New York's John F. Kennedy 
airport to Havana, as per Reuters reports. 
<nl/>This non-stop, round-trip service starting Dec 1, 2015 will be offered every Tuesday in coordination with Cuba 
Travel Services, a leading provider of carrier services - a unit licensed by the U.S. government for arranging travel 
services to the island.<nl/>Notably, JetBlue is the first carrier to announce direct charter flights on the New York-
Havana route after the U.S. government announced its decision to ease travel restrictions to Cuba.<nl/>The easing 
of the restrictions, after over 50 years, will significantly increase travel demand as Cuba had been a popular tourist 
spot for Americans before the embargo was imposed in 1962. Meanwhile, carriers like Delta Air Lines DAL[2] and 
United Continental Holdings UAL[3] are looking to make the most of the lifting of this ban.<nl/>We believe that the 
increased number of flights to Cuba and Latin America coupled with low fares and growing popularity of the Mint 
service will not only enhance flying options for travelers but will also boost revenues for JetBlue.<nl/>JetBlue 
currently sports a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy). Another favorably ranked stock in the same space is Ryanair 
Holdings plc RYAAY[4] with a Zacks Rank #1.<nl/>Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment 
Research? Today, you can download 7 Best Stocks for the Next 30 Days. Click to get this free report 
>>[5]<nl/>Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today, you can download 7 Best 
Stocks for the Next 30 Days. Click to get this free report[6] RYANAIR HLDGS (RYAAY): Free Stock Analysis 
Report[7] JETBLUE AIRWAYS (JBLU): Free Stock Analysis Report[8] DELTA AIR LINES (DAL): Free Stock

Why You Shouldn't Bet Against Ryanair Holdings ( RYAAY ) Stock
Why You Shouldn't Bet Against Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY) Stock
Zacks Investment Research
September 25, 2015 Friday 1:25 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 468 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
Sep 25, 2015( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> One stock that 
might be an intriguing choice for investors right now is Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY[1]). This is because this 
security in the Transport-Airline space is seeing solid earnings estimate revision activity, and is in great company 
from a Zacks Industry Rank perspective.<nl/><nl/> This is important because, often times, a rising tide will lift all 
boats in an industry, as there can be broad trends taking place in a segment that are boosting securities across the 
board. 
This is arguably taking place in the Transport-Airline industry as it currently has a Zacks Industry Rank of 31 out of 
more than 250 industries, suggesting it is well-positioned from this perspective, especially when compared to other 
segments out there.<nl/><nl/> Meanwhile, Ryanair Holdings is actually looking pretty good on its own too. The firm 
has seen solid earnings estimate revision activity over the past month, suggesting analysts are becoming a bit more 
bullish on the firm's prospects in both the short and long term.<nl/><nl/> In fact, over the past month, current 
quarter estimates have risen from $2.87 per share to $2.97 per share, while current year estimates have risen from 
$4.01 per share to $4.58 per share. The company currently holds a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy), which is also a 
favorable signal.<nl/><nl/> So, if you are looking for a decent pick in a strong industry, consider Ryanair Holdings. 
Not only is its industry currently in the top third, but it is seeing solid estimate revisions as of late, suggesting it could 
be a very interesting choice for investors seeking a name in this great industry segment.<nl/><nl/> Want the latest 
recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today, you can download 7 Best Stocks for the Next 30 Days.

The Innovative GatwickConnects Allows You to Connect Between Airlines That Don't Work Together Without 
the Risk
The Innovative GatwickConnects Allows You to Connect Between Airlines 
That Don't Work Together Without the Risk
The Cranky Flier
September 24, 2015 Thursday 11:49 AM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 1255 words
Byline: CF
Body
Sep 24, 2015( The Cranky Flier: http://www.crankyflier.com Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Ultra low cost carriers are 
great at bringing low fares to places, but they don't really help connect people into the broader air travel network. 
None of these airlines interline with other carriers, and a good number don't even allow you to connect between 
flights on that airline. London's Gatwick airport has partnered with Dohop[1] to do something really interesting. 
It has taken its previous Gatwick Connect program and put it on steroids. The new service is called 
GatwickConnects[2] and it's like a strange hybrid travel agent/ground service provider/insurance company. It's 
awesome, and I can only hope that US airports will consider something similar. Let's walk through how this thing 
works.<nl/> In the US, Spirit and Frontier sell connecting flights, but they don't work with other airlines. In Europe, 
the big ultra low cost carriers are even more strict. They operate more like Allegiant here in the US. Ryanair and 
easyJet don't allow connections to be booked on the same ticket at all. If you want to connect, you have to buy two 
separate tickets and you'll get no help connecting your bags. If things go wrong? Tough luck.<nl/> For Gatwick 
Airport, this is a problem. Gatwick has become a major hub for leisure travel in the UK. easyJet is the largest airline 
with 41 percent of passengers[3], but British Airways is second with 15 percent. You get a big mix of short and long 
haul carriers in there, but published connections are few and far between since most airlines there don't work with 
each other or even with themselves. Despite all that, an increasing number of people had begun building their own 
connections because the fares were so good.<nl/> Gatwick saw an opportunity to help those people and boost 
traffic further by finding a way to allow those connections to happen more easily. It first launched Gatwick 
Connect[4] in May 2013. Previously if you wanted to build your own connections, you could. But you had to claim 
your own bags, take them to the ticket counter, re-check them, and then go through security. That was a real pain, 
especially if one airline was in the North Terminal and the other in the South Terminal.<nl/> The original Gatwick 
Connect had a desk in the baggage claim area that acted like a bag re-check you find with international carriers 
elsewhere. Once you claimed your bag, you walked over to the desk and they re-tagged it and took it to your next 
flight. In effect, Gatwick was creating an interline arrangement through its own devices. You could also get your 
boarding pass for your connection if you didn't have it yet. This eliminated the need to go to the ticket counter at all. 
You could just head back through security and on to your connecting gate.<nl/> But that only solved part of the 
problem. You still had to go buy your own tickets separately, building your own connections. You were also on your 
own if you had delays or cancellations. So, the airport put Gatwick Connect on steroids, removed all sense of 
proper word-spacing, and created GatwickConnects. It kept the original bag service (which is still free for people 
The Innovative GatwickConnects Allows You to Connect Between Airlines That Don't Work Together Without 
the Risk
who buy their own connections), but it created a service to make it more seamless.<nl/> To tackle the separate 
ticket issue, Gatwick worked with Dohop. Dohop already self-builds connections in its system so that was easy. 
Now when you search Dohop, GatwickConnects will come up as an online travel agent option on those flights that 
connect through Gatwick. But keep in mind this only works for sale in the UK, Norway, and Iceland right now. That's 
going to change, but you have to change your country in the upper right if you want to see it today. (The Gatwick-
branded site is at dohop.com/gatwick, but I don't think you can change your country there. So just use the regular 
Dohop site.) You'll see a result like this:<nl/><nl/>You can see that Dohop shows you an option to buy separate 
tickets, but if you pay more, you get GatwickConnects looking like another online travel agency. When you click it, 
you go off to the Gatwick Airport website where you see this:<nl/><nl/>The cost of this service is GBP 27.50 per 
person for a one way or GBP 40 per person for a roundtrip. You buy the tickets in a single transaction via 
GatwickConnects, but you're really getting three things. You get one ticket on Wow, one on easyJet, and then you 
get the GatwickConnects service. If you need to make changes or anything, you'd come back to GatwickConnects 
to handle, just as you would with another online travel agent.<nl/> That's helpful to have it done all it one place, but 
is it really worth the extra cost when you could just book it on your own? There are a couple of extra benefits here. 
First, you get priority security to make it easier to get back to your next gate. You also get a luggage tracking 
service. But most important is what the airport calls a 'Protected Connection' service. This is like travel 
insurance.<nl/> My biggest issue with building self-connections is that if something goes wrong on the first flight, the 
second airline isn't going to care. You lose the ticket and have to find your own way to the destination, paying 
whatever fare is out there to make it happen. That's why I've seen plenty of people shy away from building their own 
connections. The risks involved are too great.<nl/> GatwickConnects, however, treats the connection like a regular 
online connection at a legacy carrier. If you miss your flight, GatwickConnects will put you on the next one without 
cost. It'll also put you up in a hotel, give you meal vouchers, etc. As is always the case, there's bunch of fine print 
here, but it generally matches what you find with standard connections. For example, they won't do this if the 
reason for the misconnection is outside of the airline's control (weather, strike, air traffic control, etc). You can see 
all the restrictions here[5]. <nl/> Of course, there may not be a connecting flight for days, in theory. And flights could 
be full. So GatwickConnects can't make this a perfect solution. But it's still a good insurance-style option that would 
make me feel much more confident about booking a connection on airlines that don't work together.<nl/> So far this 
works for easyJet, Norwegian, Virgin Atlantic, Thomas Cook, Flybe, and WOW. That means once this gets 
expanded beyond the UK/Norway/Iceland point-of-sale, people in the US who have Virgin Atlantic service to 
Gatwick (Florida and Vegas) can build their own connections with these other carriers and have it all protected 
through GatwickConnects.<nl/> This is a really innovative idea. Just imagine what would happen if an airport like 
Las Vegas did this. Think of all the small communities with Allegiant service that could be better connected into 
global airline networks. It's not perfect, but it would take the reliance on airline interline agreements away. And that's 
great for consumers.<nl/> [ 1]: http://www.dohop.com/ [ 2]:            http://www.prnewswire.com/news-
releases/dohop-and-gatwick-launch-gatwickconnects-a-ground-breaking-new-flight-connection-service-
528161941.html [ 3]:            http://www.gatwickairport.com/business-community/about-gatwick/at-a-glance/facts-
stats/ [ 4]:            http://www.gatwickairport.com/at-the-airport/flight-connections1/gatwick-connect/ [ 5]:            
http://www.gatwickairport.com/globalassets/global/p_0_passenger_images/at-the-airport/18-a-gatwick-connect-
website-tcs-final-14072015.pdf 
Load-Date: September 24, 2015
End of Document
Stocks Lower But Climb Off Session Lows; VW Chief Quits
Stocks Lower But Climb Off Session Lows; VW Chief Quits
Stock Market Today
September 23, 2015 Wednesday 6:39 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 441 words
Body
Sep 23, 2015( Stock Market Today: http://www.investors.com/stock-market-today/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> The 
stock market was lower early Wednesday afternoon, although a number of top-rated stocks were higher.The 
Nasdaq was down only a fraction, while the S...00 was off 0.3% and the Dow Jones industrial average shed 
0.4%.<nl/>
 Volume was tracking sharply lower. Declining stocks led advancers by 7-to-5 on the Nasdaq and 8-to-5 on the 
NYSE.<nl/> Energy, metals, transportation and machinery stocks were among the weakest.<nl/> Volkswagen 
(OTCPK:VLKAY[1]) bounced 6% after CEO Martin Winterkorn resigned, saying "Volkswagen needs a fresh 
start."<nl/> Shares of the German automaker plummeted 36% in the previous three days after revelations that 
software in some of its vehicles circumvented air-pollution regulations.<nl/> A lot of the pharmaceutical stocks that 
got hammered in the prior two days were higher in the stock market today[2].<nl/> Regeneron (NASDAQ:REGN[3]) 
and Valeant (NYSE:VRX[4]) were up 1% to 3%. Biotechs and other drug companies came under fire earlier in the 
week after presidential candidate Hillary Clinton attacked what she called "price gouging" in the industry.<nl/> In the 
travel and leisure area, a couple of leaders were higher.<nl/> Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY[5]) hit a new high, but 
pared its gain to 1%. Shares of the Ireland-based airline have been trending higher thanks to strong passenger 
traffic in Europe, which caused Ryanair to raise its full-year profit guidance.<nl/> Carnival (NYSE:CCL[6]) climbed 
nearly 3% in about double its average volume. The cruise line operator topped analyst estimates Tuesday, but 
shares slid on weak Q4 guidance. Reports said analysts made bullish comments after the profit report, which 
helped shares recover. The stock is forming a base.<nl/> Fleetmatics Group (NYSE:FLTX[7]) climbed nearly 3% in 
active trading and is near the 52.55 buy point of a cup-shaped base. The stock's relative strength line is already at a 
new high, which is a good sign for an eventual breakout.<nl/> [ 1]: http://research.investors.com/quotes/otcpk-
volkswagen-a-g-adr-vlkay.htm [ 2]:            http://www.investors.com/stock-market-today/ [ 3]:

TV review: 20,000 cars sold per year..but was House of Cars a deal or a gamble for Hursts?
TV review: 20,000 cars sold per year..but was House of Cars a deal or a 
gamble for Hursts?
Slugger O'Toole
September 22, 2015 Tuesday 8:04 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 1447 words
Byline: C Johnston
Body
Sep 22, 2015( Slugger O'Toole: http://www.sluggerotoole.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> After the very first 
episode of House of Cars[1] - a BBC NI documentary looking at life for the sales force at Charles Hurst Group 
Boucher Road - over on Twitter Newton Emerson quickly drew a comparison between one sales manager and the 
Fast Show's comedy salesman Swiss Toni.<nl/>And therein lies the problem: on the show the salespeople talk 
about sales and the managers demand even more sales (or else) while Twitter and Facebook users find reasons to 
mock and the customer….well, according to social media the customer could be forgiven for feeling lost in the 
noise.<nl/> While BBC NI (through Erica Starling Productions[2] have produced a documentary which has attracted 
plenty of conversation and a lot of social media chatter, most has not been complimentary about the company 
featured. 
Many social media posters have been wondering what the aggressive, Darwinian management style shown at 
times - including swearing at staff and pitting sales staff against each other - says about their place as a 
customer.<nl/> At the time of writing from approximately 140 Tweets, easily two thirds were either poking fun at or 
criticising the behaviour of some of the people featured. Tweeters stated that they wouldn't buy a car from the 
company or even wondered why the firm had agreed to take part in filming in the first place.<nl/> Over on 
Facebook, from around 45 posts on the Charles Hurst page some praise for the show could be found, especially for 
some of the young salespeople and newcomers, but still a large number of people voicing the same concerns as 
most Twitter posters about what they'd seen.<nl/> All in all, while Charles Hurst made an annual pre-tax profit of 
£8.7m at the last count[3], most social media users seemed to wonder if, image-wise, this was a lost deal.<nl/> In 
episode one we saw a very highly-motivated sales manager deliver a buzzword pep talk and explain how he 
cleared out his 'rubbish' old sales-team, then tell a young salesman that he'd be sent home if he came to work 
unshaven. He followed this with various other 'shape up or ship out' high-pressure statements some Twitter users 
compared to the style of David Brent.<nl/> A famous Richard Branson quote tells us that staff should be trained well 
enough to leave but also treated so well they prefer to stay, thereby creating low staff turnover. It is probably safe to 
assume which of the two options the paying 'punter' would prefer.<nl/> Which brings us to the elephant in the room: 
particularly in the earlier episodes, we saw very little talk of the most valuable commodity of all…the customer.<nl/> 
The closest at first came about when a salesman was given a sales 'process' to make his own and apply when 
dealing with a customer. Or else. Sales rules included an instruction to keep talking to the customer during a test 
drive and training given to attempt a close to get the business 'today'.<nl/> I wonder if a number of potential 
customers, after seeing the headings including 'GAP', 'Warranty' etc above the sales board columns and the efforts 
TV review: 20,000 cars sold per year..but was House of Cars a deal or a gamble for Hursts?
made ensure they are kept filled, will have second thoughts about the advice of a salesperson advising on these 
add-ons after they have been shown what is at stake.<nl/> To digress for a second: I've been 'processed' twice by 
big name car sellers in Northern Ireland. It was not a good experience, from the embarrassingly transparent and 
manipulative generic sales lines to the downright disingenuous, such as 'there have been people looking at that car 
all day' (points at freezing cold car with no rain underneath) and onwards to repeatedly pretending not to hear when 
I realised a car's service book had been lost.<nl/> The 'process' was cold, impersonal, did absolutely nothing to 
reflect my needs as a customer and instead left a 'never, ever again' feeling, a promise that I didn't want to see any 
of the disinterested staff ever again. I went back to small, country garages who live and die on their personal 
reputation and then aim - successfully - to gain customers for life. There are a few of these places with such a 
phenomenal reputation that they never have to close a deal as their customer loyalty does all the work. Have a look 
at a Ballymena church car park and you'll see what I mean.<nl/> As for the reasons behind taking part in the House 
of Cars filming, the likes of Ryanair benefit from the 'no such thing as bad publicity' theory. After all, stories such as 
charging to use a bathroom associate their brand with cheapness, and not entirely in a bad way. But how could that 
possibly apply to the expensive product sold in this case?<nl/> Closer to home, to compare House of Cars to, say, 
the documentary about the Europa Hotel, the difference was that we were left with an affectionate feel for the 
Europa after that show. But how is the customer to feel about the subject of House of Cars, especially following the 
earlier, more sales-based episodes?<nl/> There were some startling statements made during the series: 
salespeople who are given crisps and energy drinks to 'fill them up with shit', a salesman who said the internet had 
made it harder to use smoke and mirrors to 'make something look good', a staff member told to keep an eye on 
what colleagues are doing to beat their sales, a hope that another staff member would become more 
'ruthless'….then a pep talk about the importance of working as a team.<nl/> The actual documentary itself was very 
watchable in its own way, with the stars of the show providing plenty of material, although as - again - pointed out 
by Newton Emerson on Twitter, the repeated breathless obsession with the size of the Charles Hurst operation 
('biggest car lot in Europe') was a little bizarre.<nl/> As it happens, as the show moved through episodes two and 
three it began, with some occasional f-word laden 'staff coaching', to draw out the personalities of the likable 
younger salespeople and even settled down to a fascinating scratch below the surface by way of wandering into the 
psychology and motivation of one sales manager.<nl/> Bosses spoke fondly of their young protégés, one 
particularly aggressive sales manager could be seen enjoying more rapport and chemistry with his staff and we 
were able to follow a fledgling young salesman growing in confidence after his first sale: much to the obvious and 
genuine pride of his boss.<nl/> We also heard a little more reference to the customers themselves, some young 
salespeople were told their salary and perks (£25,000 to £40,000, plus demo car) made them a fortunate group for 
their age and we had the interesting diversion of a promotional video shoot for a new Toyota Aygo car[4].<nl/> But 
back on social media and, I'd imagine, in canteens around Northern Ireland, the talk seemed to be stuck on episode 
one, with an ironic and negative House of Cars Fan Club tweet account also now in full flow.<nl/> One Tweeter 
made the fascinating point that they'd be watching the response of mainstream media to the show with 
interest.<nl/> As the final episode was showing the rapidly expanding[5] Charles Hurst Group had been creating a 
buzz in the media about the further growth[6] of their company. Requests from myself for their input into this piece 
weren't answered.<nl/> Ultimately, the fascinating question is this: whether a business taking part in a fly-on-the-
wall documentary is gambling with their image? For the likes of Ryanair and the Europa Hotel, it seems to have 
paid off. Opinions about how the brand shown in House of Cars has faired from the exposure seem to be very 
mixed, at best.<nl/> A book I read recently about copy writing claimed that a reader is only interested in one 
thing…themselves. While House of Cars successfully showed us the lengths the company featured will go to in 
driving staff, sales and profit, some customers seem to have been left wondering if the focus of the show should 
have been on how the firm works to make happy customers, not happy sales managers.<nl/><nl/> 
Shares<nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/>

JetBlue 's (JBLU) August Traffic Rises 6.7%, Load Factor Slips
JetBlue's (JBLU) August Traffic Rises 6.7%, Load Factor Slips
Zacks Investment Research
September 14, 2015 Monday 7:15 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 639 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
Sep 14, 2015( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Low-cost carrier 
JetBlue Airways Corp. JBLU[1] witnessed a significant improvement in air traffic for Aug 2015. Traffic - measured in 
revenue passenger miles (RPMs) - came in at 3.97 billion, up 6.7% from 3.72 billion recorded a year ago.<nl/>
On a year-over-year basis, consolidated capacity (or available seat miles/ASMs) increased 8.3% to 4.56 billion. 
However, the load factor or percentage of seats filled by passengers decreased to 87% from 88.3% in Aug 2014. 
The greater increase in capacity compared to traffic led to a decrease in load factor. <nl/>With the Labor Day 
holiday falling late this year, PRASM (a measure of unit revenue: passenger revenue per available seat mile) for 
August naturally suffered and declined 3% year over year. We note that the Labor Day holiday period (Sep 2-8) this 
year fell entirely in September. The Long Island City, NY-based carrier expects this key metric to display a change 
in the band of -0.5% to +0.5% in the third quarter of 2015 on a year-over-year basis.<nl/>For the first eight months 
of 2015, JetBlue generated RPMs of 28.06 billion (up 9.2% year over year) and ASMs of 32.81 billion (up 8.7%). 
Further, the load factor in the period improved 40 basis points to 85.5%.<nl/>We note that the decline in load factor 
for August is not unique to JetBlue. Other American carriers like United Continental Holdings UAL[2] and Delta Air 
Lines DAL[3] also reported a fall in their respective load factors for August as traffic growth was outpaced by 
capacity increase.<nl/>Zacks Rank<nl/>JetBlue has been witnessing positive estimate revisions of late thanks to its 
expansion efforts, impressive growth prospects and the benefit of weak oil prices. The stock presently carries a 
Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy).<nl/>Apart from JetBlue, investors interested in the airlines industry may also consider 
Ryanair Holdings RYAAY[4], which too sports a Zacks Rank #1.<nl/>Want the latest recommendations from Zacks 
Investment Research? Today, you can download 7 Best Stocks for the Next 30 Days. Click to get this free report 
>>[5]<nl/>Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today, you can download 7 Best 
Stocks for the Next 30 Days. Click to get this free report[6] RYANAIR HLDGS (RYAAY): Free Stock Analysis

Lufthansa flights expected to return to normal following strike injunction
Lufthansa flights expected to return to normal following strike injunction
Deutsche Welle Germany
September 10, 2015 Thursday 7:52 AM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 334 words
Body
Sep 10, 2015( Deutsche Welle Germany: http://www.dw.de/top-stories/germany/s-1432 Delivered by Newstex) 
<nl/> Germany's biggest airline has said that service should be back to normal after a court ordered striking pilots 
back to work. 
The court granted Lufthansa a temporary injunction against the work stoppage. A Lufthansa spokesperson said 
early on Thursday that Germany's flag carrier airline anticipated no further disruptions to its regular flight 
schedule.<nl/> "We expect normal flight service without any cancellations," the spokesperson said.<nl/> This 
comes a day after a regional labor court in Frankfurt, where Lufthansa has its headquarters, ruled in favor of 
management and ordered the pilots, represented by the Vereinigung Cockpit (VC) trade union to return to 
work.<nl/> The decision by the regional court overturned an earlier verdict by the lower Frankfurt labor court, which 
on Tuesday evening had declined Lufthansa's request for an injunction.<nl/> The presiding judge found that not 
only was the union striking over early retirement provisions that the airline wants to cut, but was also seeking to 
influence the company's corporate strategy.<nl/> For months, the union and management have been at 
loggerheads over Lufthansa's creation and expansion of Eurowings, a low-cost subsidiary. As it is incorporated in 
Austria, it is not subject to German labor agreements reached through collective bargaining.<nl/> Lufthansa argues 
that it needs to reduce costs in order to fight off competition from budget air carriers such as Easyjet and 
Ryanair.<nl/> The latest walkout was the 13th by pilots represented by VC in the space of 18 months. It was also 
the first since March, when an Airbus operated by Lufthansa's Germanwings subsidiary crashed into a 
mountainside in the French Alps, killing all 150 people on board. <nl/> Lufthansa has put the cost of the strikes to 
the airline at more than 300 million euros ($334 million) over the past two years.<nl/> pfd/se (Reuters, dpa)<nl/> 
Load-Date: September 10, 2015
End of Document
Ryanair Shares Soar on Profit Upgrade
Ryanair Shares Soar on Profit Upgrade
The Legacy
September 9, 2015 Wednesday 8:03 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 379 words
Byline: David Green
Body
Sep 09, 2015( The Legacy: http://www.localizedusa.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/>            
http://www.lulegacy.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/legacy-16.jpgShares of discount carrier Ryanair soared on 
Wednesday after it hiked its profit forecast for the year by 25 pence, following a strong summer performance 
boosted by foul weather in the northern region of Europe, strength of the pound and higher prices.<nl/>
 The increase in the profit forecast was released on Wednesday through a trading update. The airline, which is due 
to give an update to its shareholders at its general meeting of shareholders September 24, said the strength of both 
July as well as August numbers, which are continuing into September, caused them to move the update 
forward.<nl/> Ryanair announced that the increase was due to many factors that included an increase in traffic that 
was higher than expected during the first six months of 2015; an increase in its fares; and growth in traffic during 
the third quarter.<nl/> The company however cautioned that its results for the full year would be heavily dependent 
upon close-in bookings for the third quarter, which currently is 30% sold and in the fourth quarter, which currently 
there is zero visibility.<nl/> Ryanair said it recovered all of its funds, which were part of a fraudulent transfer 
electronically to a bank in China back in April.<nl/> Michael O'Leary the CEO at Ryanair said the company was 
surprised by the strength of its close-in bookings as well as fares during the summer.<nl/> The CEO added that not 
all of the improvement is from our management or model, but the airline has clearly been a benefactor from industry 
trends that have been favorable during the summer.<nl/> That includes poor weather in Northern Europe, a strong 
sterling pound that encourages more families in the UK to go on vacation in the Mediterranean, capacity remaining 
reasonably flat in the EU and lower prices from un-hedged oil.<nl/> He added that the airline industry does not 
expect the favorable conditions to persist and urges shareholders and Wall Street analysts to avoid any over 
exuberance while the airline continues to execute it ambitious growth plan during a period of sustained fare wars in 
much of Europe this coming winter.<nl/>

Ryanair hikes profit outlook by 25pc
Ryanair hikes profit outlook by 25pc
Business Matters
September 9, 2015 Wednesday 9:14 AM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 375 words
Byline: Business Matters
Body
Sep 09, 2015( Business Matters: http://www.bmmagazine.co.uk/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Ryanair has seen its 
profits take off after a great escape from Britain's damp summer combined with cheaper jet fuel to boost trading, 
reports The Telegraph[1].<nl/>
<nl/> The discount airline expects full-year profits to be in the range of €1.18bn to €1.23bn, which is 25 per cent 
higher than previous guidance.<nl/><nl/> Michael O'Leary, chief executive, said: 'We have been surprised by the 
strength of close-in bookings and fares this summer during which we delivered record 95 per cent load factors in 
both July and August while fares grew by over 2 per cent, when we had expected them to be flat.'<nl/><nl/> Mr 
O'Leary said the industry as a whole had benefited from bad weather across Northern Europe, stronger sterling, 
which encouraged more UK families to holiday in the Med, and falling jet fuel prices.<nl/><nl/>The strength of the 
trading forced Ryanair to make the announcement two weeks earlier than the planned update at the shareholder 
annual general meeting on September 24.<nl/> Mr O'Leary was cautious on the outlook for the full-year to the end 
of March, adding: 'Being the airline industry we do not expect these favourable conditions will persist, and we would 
urge shareholders and analysts to avoid irrational exuberance while we continue to execute our very ambitious 
growth plans during what we expect to be very attritional and sustained fare wars across Europe this winter.'<nl/> 
The Dublin-based airline first rolled out its 'Always Getting Better' campaign in 2014, with a renewed emphasis on 
'being nice' to customers[2]. It tripled its marketing spend to €35m and cut some of its most notorious fees, such as 
charging 
€70 
to 
check 
in 
at 
an 
airport 
desk 
rather 
than 
online.<nl/>

The Ryanair Model: you don't get rich playing by the rules
The Ryanair Model: you don't get rich playing by the rules
New Europe
September 9, 2015 Wednesday 11:29 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 626 words
Byline: roubanis
Body
Sep 09, 2015( New Europe: http://neurope.eu Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Share on Facebook Share on Twitter 
Share on Google+ Share on LinkedIn<nl/><nl/>What's This?
<nl/><nl/>Ryanair on Wednesday revised its profit forecast, bringing it to a whopping 47%. The low cost model is 
something we all appreciate as consumers; the market does too.<nl/> The company is now valued at € 18,8 bn and 
is the fifth most valuable carrier in the world. This story is often narrated as the story of a heroic CEO[1] who picked 
up a few tricks from Southwest Airlines Co. in the US, the third most valuable company in the world. In this story a 
company went from one aircraft and 5,000 passengers to Europe's biggest discount carrier, with more passengers 
than its main rivals combined, that is, 104 million people.<nl/> A full service carrier - Air France-KLM - with nearly 
five times Ryanair's revenue stream, that is 25 € bn, is valued €2 bn. But, the market values at € 18,8 bn a 
company that can guarantee profit margins rather than revenue stream by lowering airport costs, reducing space in 
cabins, taking on unions, unbundling the services offered by full service carriers, charging separately for luggage, 
food, and drinks, etc.<nl/> Ryanair is also known for taking on trade unions across Europe.<nl/> In July, Ryanair 
initiated a public online campaign aimed at banning the right to strike of air traffic controllers, entitled 'Keep 
Europe's Skies Open[2]'. The company aimed at obtaining the one million petition signatures required to 'urge' the 
EU Commission and the European Parliament to take action. The company wants nothing less than removing the 
right to strike from ATC unions, bringing Europe in line with the US regime.<nl/> Later the same month, the 
company proceeded to what is in effect a 'lockout' closing down its base in Denmark, Copenhagen, to resettle in 
Kaunus, Lithuania. The Danish Confederation of Trade Unions (LO) responded by saying that strikes against 
Ryanair will take place not only in Copenhagen but also in Billund and Aarhus. The company warned that Ryanair 
would respond in kind, shutting down bases in Denmark.<nl/> As it is also known that Ryanair has been 
investigated and cautioned by the European Commission multiple times[3] for its practices. Most recently, it was 
found that Ryanair was in the business of knocking on the door of regional governments thirsting for tourism to elicit 
subsidies for using their region's airports, thereby creating conditions that the European Commission considers[4] 
'an undue economic advantage' or 'distortion of competition.'<nl/> Now Brussels is demanding a € 6.3 million refund 
from Ryanair over the use of Nimes airport in southern France, €2.4 million euros over the use of the Pau Pyrenees 
airport, and €420,000 for the use of the Angouleme airport in central France. To ensure that the company will cough 
back the money, the European Commission has referred France to the European Court of Justice.<nl/> A company 
which takes labour market regulation or indeed open market rules to their legal limits is now Europe's most 
profitable company. It is because of tumbling oil prices, careful pricing, but also because it competes in a manner 
that is often scrutinized for its conformity to EU and national legislation. Indeed, it's cheap, but at a price.<nl/> 
The Ryanair Model: you don't get rich playing by the rules
Share 
on 
Facebook 
Share 
on 
Twitter 
Share 
on 
Google+ 
Share 
on 
LinkedIn<nl/>

Lufthansa strikes intensify as court injunction fails
Lufthansa strikes intensify as court injunction fails
Deutsche Welle Germany
September 9, 2015 Wednesday 4:29 AM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 377 words
Body
Sep 09, 2015( Deutsche Welle Germany: http://www.dw.de/top-stories/germany/s-1432 Delivered by Newstex) 
<nl/> A walkout by the pilots union Vereinigung Cockpit is set to affect around 140,000 would-be passengers after 
Lufthansa failed to stop it via a court injunction. 
A deputy of Merkel's caucus calls the strike "dangerous." The pilot strike at Lufthansa has intensified as the airline 
attempted to prevent Wednesday's walkout via a court injunction.<nl/> However, labor courts in the German cities 
of Frankfurt and Cologne rejected the company's attempt to undermine the pilot union Vereinigung Cockpit's (VC) 
walkout.<nl/> Around 140,000 out of 180,000 would-be passengers are expected to be affected by the strike.<nl/> 
Nearly 1,000 of Lufthansa's scheduled 1,520 flights are expected to be cancelled. It is the 13th strike inside 18 
months at the airline.<nl/> <nl/> The dispute focuses on pensions and a planned austerity plan to allow the German 
airliner to compete with budget airlines such as Ryanair and Easy Jet by reducing tariffs.<nl/> "Despite the labor 
action, Lufthansa is able to offer 90 of the scheduled long-haul flights to its passengers and all cargo flights," the 
company said in a statement.<nl/> 'Highly dangerous'<nl/> Michael Fuchs, a deputy head of German Chancellor 
Angela Merkel's conservative caucus, told the German newspaper "Bild" on Wednesday that the pilots' actions 
were "dangerous."<nl/> "What the pilots are doing is highly dangerous," Fuchs said, adding that the union was 
jeopardizing the company's ability to face "tough international competition."<nl/> "It cannot be that hundreds of 
thousands are constantly held hostage to the interests of a small minority," Fuchs told the newspaper.<nl/> Fuchs 
noted that compulsory arbitration would be necessary in the future to prevent "recurring strikes."<nl/> Meanwhile, 
VC spokesperson Markus Wahl on Tuesday told reporters at Frankfurt airport that more strikes could be 
imminent.<nl/> "Until further notice, it is possible that every week there will be new actions," said Wahl.<nl/> 
Lufthansa has provided a special schedule for the strike, although passengers must search for their flights on the 
company's website to see whether they are affected.<nl/> ls/jr (AFP, dpa)<nl/>

Nikkei soars, lifting European shares
Nikkei soars, lifting European shares
Deutsche Welle Business
September 9, 2015 Wednesday 9:29 AM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 379 words
Body
Sep 09, 2015( Deutsche Welle Business: http://www.dw-world.de/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> European stocks 
have rallied for a second day in a row after markets in China appeared to stabilize and Japan's benchmark index 
Nikkei posted its biggest one-day gains since the 2008 financial crisis. 
The good news from Asia lifted Germany's DAX by 2.15 percent to 10,489.29 points in the first minutes of trading 
on Wednesday. The CAC 40 in Paris followed suit, shooting 2.37 percent higher to 4,707.41 points.<nl/> Outside 
the eurozone, London's FTSE 100 index gained 1.68 percent to 6,249.02 points. The pan-European FTSEurofirst 
300 jumped 2.1 percent in initial trade, lifted by a strong performance by the no-frills airline Ryanair, whose shares 
rose to an all-time high after the company raised its full-year profits outlook by 25 percent.<nl/> Earlier in the day, 
traders at the Tokyo Stock Exchange watched the benchmark index Nikkei 225 post its strongest gains in nearly 
seven years, rising 7.7 percent to 18,770.51 points.<nl/> The jump was significant because yesterday the index lost 
2.34 percent, wiping out all progress since the beginning of the year. Weak trade data from China had compounded 
investors' worries that the economic malaise of the world's second-largest economy could eventually spill over into 
other markets.<nl/> More 'Abenomics'<nl/> The Japanese index's rebound came after the country's Prime Minister 
Shinzo Abe, raised hopes that his government would do more to stimulate the economy. In remarks read aloud at a 
conference in Tokyo, Abe promised to slash corporate tax rates by 3.3 percent next year.<nl/> Investors were also 
emboldened after China's Ministry of Finance unveiled new measures aimed at reviving slumping growth, including 
more infrastructure spending and tax reforms for small businesses.<nl/> Those signs that Beijing was doing what 
was necessary to stabilize markets led to a rebound in Shanghai shares on Tuesday. US stocks also kept the 
momentum going and posted broad gains across the three major indexes.<nl/> "At long last we may be seeing a 
real rebound," Bloomberg News quoted Chihiro Ohta, the general manager at SMBC Nikko Securities, as saying of 
the upswing in Chinese shares.<nl/> cjc/uhe (AFP, Reuters, dpa, AP)<nl/>

German court orders Lufthansa pilots to stop their strike
German court orders Lufthansa pilots to stop their strike
Deutsche Welle Germany
September 9, 2015 Wednesday 12:29 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 390 words
Body
Sep 09, 2015( Deutsche Welle Germany: http://www.dw.de/top-stories/germany/s-1432 Delivered by Newstex) 
<nl/> A labor court in the German state of Hesse has issued a temporary injunction against the pilots' union 
Vereinigung Cockpit, ordering Lufthansa pilots to halt their strike. 
The walkout is the 13th amid a pay dispute. The regional labor court in the German city of Frankfurt issued the 
injunction on Wednesday in response to an appeal by Lufthansa, which had earlier failed to stop the strike through 
the courts.<nl/> The court called the strike "unlawful," saying it was not directed at achieving a concrete goal with 
regard to wages, but rather against Lufthansa's plans to expand its budget airline subsidiaries.<nl/> Strikes that 
take aim at company policy without concrete pay or benefits objectives in view are not allowed under German 
law.<nl/> The pilots' union Vereinigung Cockpit said Wednesday's ruling meant all pilots must immediately return to 
work. However, it remained unclear when flights would return to normal.<nl/> Flights canceled<nl/> The strike had 
led on Wednesday to the cancelation of some 1,000 flights and the grounding of 140,000 passengers, Lufthansa 
said.<nl/> The decision by the regional court overturned an earlier verdict by the lower Frankfurt labor court, which 
on Tuesday evening had declined Lufthansa's request for an injunction.<nl/> Lufthansa subsidiary Germanwings 
has placed a similar request at a labor court in Cologne, which also declined to issue an injunction. The higher state 
labor court of North Rhine-Westphalia is reconsidering an appeal, but has yet to announce its decision.<nl/> Pilots 
from the union laid down their work on Tuesday in what is the 13th strike inside 18 months at the airline.<nl/> 
Controversial restructuring<nl/> The union and Lufthansa are embroiled in a longrunning dispute over pensions and 
a proposed austerity plan designed to allow the airline to reduce tariffs in a bid to better compete with budget 
companies such as Ryanair and Easy Jet.<nl/> The union has criticized Lufthansa's restructuring policy, which has 
seen the airline creating and expanding an Austria-based subsidiary, Eurowings, where pilots receive less pay. The 
subsidiary is taking over many routes formerly flown by Lufthansa in a bid to cut costs.<nl/> tj/ (Reuters, dpa, 
AFP)<nl/> 
Load-Date: September 9, 2015

Is Air India the WORST airline? List of worst 15 here!
Is Air India the WORST airline? List of worst 15 here!
Travel.India.com
September 9, 2015 Wednesday 2:13 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 1216 words
Byline: Bhagyashri Pawar
Body
Sep 09, 2015( Travel.India.com: http://travel.india.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> India's national carrier may not 
exactly be having a great year but does it make it to the list of worst airlines in the world? Find out here!<nl/>
 Tuesday was clearly not Air India's day.<nl/> Two flights made emergency landings at New Delhi's Indira Gandhi 
International Airport on the day.<nl/> First was the incoming flight from Varanasi, AI 405, which reported hydraulic 
failure. And then there was the Bagdogra-bound AI 879[1] that had to turn around because a tyre burst while taking 
off.<nl/> Hydraulic failure and tyre burst! We're going to let that sink in for a second.<nl/> Fact is that Air India isn't 
the first airline of choice for several young Indians and the fact that dead insects[2] occasionally make their way into 
the meals doesn't help much.<nl/> But by no standards is Air India the worst airline in the world. In fact it isn't even 
in the worst 15. Skytrax's latest ranking gives Air India a three-star rating,<nl/>same as Jet Airways and several 
other top airlines in the world.<nl/> The rankings did however reveal some of the worst airlines that are (somehow 
miraculously) flying in 2015.<nl/> So, without much ado, here's the infamous list:<nl/>15. US Airways<nl/><nl/> The 
American airline is the most preferred mode of flying for all those who want their baggage lost.<nl/> What's worse, 
not only do they lose your bags they also provide fairly terrible flights and p-r-e-t-t-y terrible customer 
service.<nl/>14. Frontier<nl/><nl/> Cancellations, delays… Frontier offers you everything you hate about 
flying.<nl/> What is perhaps sad about Frontier is that it was once a well-reputed airline that is now ailing thanks to 
cost-cutting measures.<nl/>13. United Airlines<nl/><nl/> Yet another American airline to appear on this dubious list 
is United.<nl/> UA's customer service is so bad the US Department of Transport fined them a million dollars to drive 
home the point. Sigh!<nl/>12. Tigerair<nl/><nl/> This Singapore-based low-cost airline initially served Singapore 
and Asia but has expanded its operations to include Australia in 2007.<nl/> This year, the federal government-
appointed airline ombudsman declared Tigerair as Australia's worst-performing airline… thrice in a row.<nl/> The 
airline has nonchalant about its ultra-low costs (which are not bad at all if you are travelling with minimal baggage) 
and its terrible pay scale for its<nl/>employees. But it seems keen to shed this image with its recent rebranding 
(from Tiger Airways to Tigerair).<nl/> Will it stick? Only time will tell.<nl/>11. EasyJet<nl/><nl/> If you are flying the 
UK-based Easyjet, don't expect any assistance whatsoever. While it does have fairly low prices, its services are 
lower still.<nl/>10. Pakistan International Airline<nl/><nl/> Rounding off the top ten is our very own neighbor's 
national carrier.<nl/> So far this year, PIA's on-time record is… and you may have to sit down for this… 40 per 
cent.<nl/> And considering that they fly just as little as around 3,000 flights every month, that is a terrible, terrible 
record indeed.<nl/> Skytrax also ranked their staff's language skills and other services.<nl/>9. Ryanair<nl/><nl/> 
Dublin-based Ryanair takes ultra low-cost to another level altogether.<nl/> They cram seats so close to each other 
you will forget what legroom is; their seats don't recline; and on some occasions they have known to have done 
Is Air India the WORST airline? List of worst 15 here!
away with extra bathrooms so they could accommodate more seats.<nl/> Care to fly?<nl/>8. China Eastern 
Airline<nl/><nl/> At about 50 per cent, Shanghai-based China Eastern Airline's on-time arrival is only slightly better 
than Pakistan International Airline.<nl/> But when you consider the fact that they fly some 50,000 flights a month 
you will realize just how big a problem that is. 25,000 flights of China Eastern Airline don't land on time. Every. 
Single. Month.<nl/>7. Lion Air<nl/><nl/> Lost baggage and flight delays should perhaps be the least of your 
concerns if you're flying Jakarta-based Lion Air.<nl/> In 2012 several crew members, including pilots, were tested 
positive for meth.<nl/>6. Smartwings<nl/><nl/> Then there is the Czech Republican airline Smartwings.<nl/> Lost 
baggage? Check! Flight cancellation? Check! Hidden fees? Check!<nl/> Now suddenly Air India doesn't seem so 
bad after all, does it?<nl/> Anyway, moving on…<nl/>5. Spirit Airlines<nl/><nl/> Considering that the new airline

list.<nl/> And the fact that it outranks Ryanair says something.<nl/>4. Nepal Airlines<nl/><nl/> How difficult would it 
be to run an airline that has all of s-e-v-e-n functional aircraft in their fleet?<nl/> Very, very, very difficult it would 
seem. Because Nepal Airlines is so, so bad the EU banned it from flying its airspace in 2013.<nl/> Skytrax rated 
them a shameful one on the scale of five in almost every major category. Heck even their website received an 
abysmal one star!<nl/> And oh… only 30 per cent of their flights have arrived on time so far in 2015.<nl/>3. Bulgaria 
Airline<nl/><nl/> Now, if you are desperate (or quite simply travelling on a shoestring budget) you would most 
probably ignore all the typical airline problems — cramped seats, terrible loos, poor on-time performance — as long 
as they made sure you landed safely, right?<nl/> Bulgaria Airline manages to check that last box too.<nl/> Its safety 
policies are so bad, they have been banned from flying in US airspace! And they have a shabby two-star rating 
across all services (or the lack thereof) that they offer.<nl/> But what (we imagine) is the biggest problem with 
Bulgaria Airline is that their planes seem to skid more often than an amateur skater. Which we suppose is the 
scariest. thing. ever.<nl/>2. Pegasus<nl/><nl/> The second largest airline in Turkey, infamous for its passenger 
class on international flights that has no food and no entertainment, Pegasus had topped this dubious list in 2013 
and 2014.<nl/> We're not quite sure if anything improved for it to slip to number two because the airline that tops 
the list this year scored a shocking one on five star ranking on Skytrax's ratings.<nl/>1. Air Koryo<nl/><nl/> 
Welcome to Air Koryo that has the dubious distinction of being the only carrier to get a one-star rating on 
Skytrax.<nl/> Air Koryo has such a terrible safety and maintenance record that it was banned from flying from EU 
airspace. And even in 2010, only one particular model was permitted.<nl/> Like everything in North Korea, Air 
Koryo is sponsored by the state and is, somewhat miraculously, still flying!<nl/> Now, do you still have complaints 
about Air India? We didn't think so either! <nl/>The post Is Air India the WORST airline? List of worst 15 here![3]

Stocks Keep Most Of Early Gains; Wal-Mart 3% Pop Leads Blue Chips
Stocks Keep Most Of Early Gains; Wal-Mart 3% Pop Leads Blue Chips
Stock Market Today
September 8, 2015 Tuesday 6:43 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 340 words
Body
Sep 08, 2015( Stock Market Today: http://www.investors.com/stock-market-today/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> 
Stock indexes were trading in the middle of the day's price range Tuesday afternoon while holding on to most of the 
gains from a strong open. 
The Nasdaq gripped a 1.7% gain while the S...00 clutched 1.6%. The Dow Jones industrial average was up 1.7%. 
Volume in the stock market today[1] was running roughly 10% higher on both major exchanges vs. Friday's quiet 
pace.<nl/> Blue chips were up without exception.<nl/> Wal-Mart Stores (NYSE:WMT[2]) pegged a 3% gain, the 
biggest percentage move in the Dow. However, Wal-Mart remains far off its January high, and the up-down volume 
ratio points to more institutional selling than buying.<nl/> About the only good angle to Wal-Mart's 23% stock-price 
decline this year is that the annualized dividend yield is now 3.1%. However, that alone is not a good reason to buy 
a stock.<nl/> Although the indexes were posting advances Tuesday, top-rated stocks weren't making much of a 
splash.<nl/> For example, only a handful of stocks with good ratings were posting new highs. They included 
homebuilder LGI Homes (NASDAQ:LGIH[3]), which rose 4%; engineering and services provider to telecoms Dycom 
Industries (NYSE:DY[4]), up 4.5%; and Irish airline Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY[5]), up 1.5%.<nl/> Among IBD's 197 
industry groups, the day's biggest gains were found in beaten-up groups such as miners, oil drillers and 
chipmakers. No industry groups were down, but a few showed only trivial gains.<nl/> Follow Paul Whitfield on 
Twitter @IBD_PWhitfield[6].;<nl/> [ 1]: http://www.investors.com/stock-market-today [ 2]:
