Strong Global Traffic Data in July, Fall Forecast Disappoints
Strong Global Traffic Data in July, Fall Forecast Disappoints
Zacks Investment Research
September 8, 2015 Tuesday 7:15 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 1286 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
Sep 08, 2015( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> The monthly data 
released by the International Air Transport Association (IATA) revealed an 8.2% year-over-year increase in demand 
for air travel across the globe for the month of July 2015. The rise was attributable to an increase in both 
international and domestic traffic (measured in revenue passenger kilometers) in the month. Results were boosted 
by the timing of Ramadan this year. This year, only a part of Ramadan fell during July as opposed to 2014 when the 
holy period, which traditionally results in weak air travel, coincided entirely with the month of July.<nl/>
The report also revealed a 6.5% rise in capacity (measured in available seat kilometers or ASKs). The greater 
increase in air traffic compared with capacity resulted in the load factor (percentage of seats filled with passengers) 
improving 140 basis points (bps) to 83.6% in July.<nl/>International Traffic<nl/>The 8.6% increase in International 
demand was driven by strong performance of carriers across all regions including Africa, which had been a weak 
link till June this year.<nl/>International traffic in the Asia-Pacific region registered a handsome 8.5% growth on a 
6.5% rise in capacity. The greater increase in traffic compared with capacity led to a 150 bps rise in load factor to 
80.3%. Carriers in the Middle East, which include the likes of Emirates, Etihad and Qatar Airways, reported a 19.8% 
increase in July traffic due to the favorable Ramadan timing this year. Moreover, the lesser increase in capacity 
(17.7%) resulted in the load factor improving 150 bps to 79.6% for carriers in the region.<nl/>International traffic for 
Latin American carriers, which include the likes of GOL Linhas Aereas Inteligentes S.A. GOL[1] and Copa Holdings 
SA CPA[2], for July, was up 8.5% on an 8% rise in capacity. Improvement in trade in the region offset the soft 
economic scenario prevalent in Brazil and Argentina, resulting in improvement in business travel. International July 
traffic for European carriers, such as Ryanair Holdings RYAAY[3], climbed 6.7% on a 4% rise in capacity. The 
region witnessed the most packed planes with load factor of 87.3% topping across all regions. Economic recovery 
in the Eurozone boosted demand for carriers in the region. African carriers reported a 4.9% improvement in traffic 
on a 3.9% rise in monthly capacity.<nl/>Robust North American Performance<nl/>Bullish expectations with regard 
to the U.S. economy drove the healthy 5.3% year-over-year rise in July traffic. The rise was more than double the 
growth witnessed in June 2015. Capacity rose 3.5% and another important metric, load factor, climbed 140 basis 
points to 86.5%. In fact, carriers in the North American region are coming off a strong second quarter, aided by low 
fuel costs. Major companies like Delta Air Lines DAL[4], American Airlines Group AAL[5] and United Continental 
Holdings UAL[6] posted better-than-expected earnings in the second quarter of 2015, bolstered by weak fuel prices. 
American Airlines Group, Delta Air Lines, Southwest Airlines Co. LUV[7] and United Continental Holdings together 
raked in a net income of $4.99 billion in the second quarter.<nl/>India, China Lead Domestic Traffic 
Surge<nl/>According to the report, domestic travel demand was also strong in July. Stellar domestic traffic growth 
Strong Global Traffic Data in July, Fall Forecast Disappoints
in India (28.1%) and China (10.9%) boosted domestic passenger traffic by 7.6%. The domestic traffic picture in the 
U.S. also fared better than the broader international space, with the metric reporting 5.9% growth.<nl/>Total 
domestic capacity for the month climbed 6.5% and load factor climbed 80 bps to 83.6% driven by the greater 
increase in traffic. Capacity contracted in Japan during the month even as traffic increased, leading to empty 
planes.<nl/>Fall Forecast Tepid<nl/>The strong traffic numbers for July did not however lead to an encouraging 
projection with respect to air travel for the fall of 2015. According to the IATA, the projection is nothing less than 
'unsettled' as far as the outlook for air travel this fall is considered. The prevalent global worries, led by the China 
turmoil, are certainly not helping matters. The forecast for fall certainly comes as a dampener given that carriers 
have had a really busy summer this year.<nl/>Air Freight Demand Weak<nl/>The IATA revealed that air freight 
volumes slipped 0.6% on a year-over-year basis in July 2015. Air cargo volume is a key indicator of business 
confidence. Weak world trade growth due to global concerns was blamed for the weakness in demand growth for 
air freight.<nl/>However, the outlook of air cargo volumes is rosier for the back end of the year due to bullish 
expectations about world trade that should support economic growth. Want the latest recommendations from Zacks 
Investment Research? Today, you can download 7 Best Stocks for the Next 30 Days. Click to get this free report >>

Lufthansa to cancel long-haul flights amid fresh strike
Lufthansa to cancel long-haul flights amid fresh strike
Deutsche Welle Germany
September 7, 2015 Monday 11:10 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 541 words
Body
Sep 07, 2015( Deutsche Welle Germany: http://www.dw.de/top-stories/germany/s-1432 Delivered by Newstex) 
<nl/> Flight crews have begun fresh strikes at Lufthansa, prompting the German airline to cancel 84 long-haul 
flights for Tuesday. The union Cockpit is upset over a planned subsidiary to be based in Austria. 
Germany's classic airline said it would still run 90 intercontinental flights and 7 cargo flights on Tuesday using 
volunteer crews after the union declared the breakdown of talks focused on cost-cutting efforts.<nl/> The strike by 
Cockpit (VC), which represents some 5,000 pilots with Lufthansa and another subsidiary Germanwings, is the 13th 
such work stoppage in the past 18 months. Its last strike was in March, shortly before the Germanwings disaster in 
France.<nl/> Cockpit said short and medium-range flights from Germany would be subjected to strike action on 
Wednesday.<nl/> Airline board member responsible for personnel Bettina Volkens said Lufthansa could only 
apologize to passengers, including families with intended flights home at the end of school vacations in Germany's 
southern states of Bavaria and Baden-Württemberg.<nl/> Strife centers on new unit Eurowings <nl/> Lufthansa 
managers want to further slash costs by transferring one Germanwings jet per month to a new low-pay unit 
Eurowings. It is incorporated in Austria, where German collective labor deals do not apply. <nl/> Union spokesman 
Markus Wahl said Lufthansa's chief executive Carsten Spohr had refused to delay the relocation of jobs while both 
sides still negotiated. Lufthansa in turn said it had made "far-reaching" offers on Monday.<nl/> Wahl said 
management had rejected union savings suggestions worth about half-a-billion euros. This showed, Wahl said, that 
Lufthansa wanted to break out of existing collective agreements and weaken the union.<nl/> More strikes, with one 
day prior notice, were likely in the coming week to put pressure on the management of Europe's largest airline, he 
said.<nl/> Long-haul flights affected<nl/> The 84 long-haul flights canceled among Tuesday's usual schedule of 
1,500 Lufthansa flights affect passengers traveling from and to Frankfurt, Munich and Düsseldorf.<nl/> Lufthansa 
said it would rebook affected passengers on alternative airlines.<nl/> The 18 months of fractious negotiations have 
centered on Lufthansa's plan to cut entitlements for pilots wanting to retire early and establish a cheaper salary 
structure at Eurowings.<nl/> Union concessions offered include increasing the average retirement age to 60.<nl/> 
"With our offer, we made it clear that the pilots are not against the necessary adjustments," Wahl said. <nl/> 
Standard practice, says Spohr<nl/> Last Friday, Spohr told Reuters that over 1,000 pilots from within the Lufthansa 
group and outside had applied for jobs at Eurowings.<nl/> "To create an airline's operating certificate in another 
country is something the other low-cost carriers do and we copied that model for our low-cost operation, he 
said.<nl/> Lufthansa is facing challenges from budget airlines such as Easyjet and Ryanair and Middle East-
financed operators such as Etihad, which has a stake in another German-based operator, Air Berlin.<nl/> ipj/jr (dpa, 
Reuters, AP)<nl/>

Sep 05, 2015( Arabian Money: http://www.arabianmoney.net/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> European airlines will 
have the 'mother and father of all fare wars' this winter as oil hedged prices come off, Ryanair CEO Michael O'Leary 
told CNBC on Friday.<nl/> Talking from the Ambrosetti Forum in Italy, Mr. O'Leary said that the fall in oil prices has 
been fundamentally good for the world economy and for the airline industry. However due to oil price hedging there 
is a time lag between lower oil prices and lower air fares, and that is about to end… <nl/>

Summertime blues help profits at easyJet take off
Summertime blues help profits at easyJet take off
Business Matters
September 4, 2015 Friday 8:10 AM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 430 words
Byline: Business Matters
Body
Sep 04, 2015( Business Matters: http://www.bmmagazine.co.uk/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> The short-haul airline 
expects profits of up to £700 million for its financial year, which closes at the end of this month.<nl/>
 That is 20 per cent higher than the £581 million booked last year and 6 per cent higher than the outcome that it 
was suggesting less than six weeks ago.<nl/> The Times[1] reports that a new forecast made easyJet's shares 
among the top risers in the FTSE 100 yesterday, up more than 5 per cent at £17.62.<nl/> 'The best route network 
connecting Europe's primary airports . . . meant that easyJet was best placed to maximise the strong late summer 
demand from UK passengers to get away,' said Carolyn McCall, the chief executive.<nl/> That late demand meant 
that easyJet planes have never flown so full, with load factors of 94.4 per cent in August against an average of 91.4 
per cent for the year as a whole.<nl/> The so-called yield management systems of airlines such as easyJet means 
that late bookers may have to pay three times the average fare for the flight. As the aircraft is flying anyway, most of 
that additional revenue falls directly to the bottom line.<nl/><nl/>Several factors contributed to the late 
getaway.<nl/> They include people being put off sun holidays earlier because of the Greek economic crisis and the 
Tunisian terrorist beach attacks; Britons waking up late to how much cheaper European holidays are this year 
because of the strength of sterling over the euro; and for some parts of the country it was the wettest August on 
record.<nl/> Even after expanding to bases around the Continent, easyJet still has 40 per cent of its 68 million 
passengers a year originating in Britain, where it is the biggest airline for both Gatwick and Luton airports.<nl/> The 
better than expected performance at easyJet comes a day after Ryanair reported a record summer in which it 
carried 30 million passengers, more than many international carriers fly in a year.<nl/> Yesterday International 
Consolidated Airlines reported a 12 per cent growth in passenger numbers to 9.1 million during August. Much of 
that came from its Spanish-based Iberia and Vueling operations rather than British Airways.<nl/> Wizz Air, the rising 
force in low-cost airlines in the east of Europe and the second biggest airline at Luton airport,carried 1.99 million 
people 
last 
month, 
up 
19 
per 
cent 
on 
the 
year.<nl/>

Allegiant Travel's August Traffic Up, Load Factor Slips
Allegiant Travel's August Traffic Up, Load Factor Slips
Zacks Investment Research
September 4, 2015 Friday 6:40 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 618 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
Sep 04, 2015( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Las Vegas, NV-
based Allegiant Travel Company ALGT[1], the parent company of Allegiant Air, reported impressive traffic numbers 
for the month of Aug 2015. Traffic for the total system, which includes scheduled service and fixed fee contract, 
measured in revenue passenger miles (RPMs) climbed 20.1% on a year-over-year basis to 757.4 
million.<nl/>System capacity, measured in available seat miles (ASMs), climbed 25.6% in the month to 890.3 
million. 
With capacity growth outpacing the rise in traffic, load factor (% of seats filled with passengers) declined 380 basis 
points from Aug 2014 to 85.1%. Allegiant carried 22.6% more passengers in Aug 2015.<nl/>Moreover, according to 
the preliminary financial results released by the company for August, the system-wide average fuel cost per gallon 
was approximately $1.75 per gallon. The company expects system-wide capacity growth for the third quarter of 
2015 in the band of 23% to 25%. The metric is projected to grow in the band of 21% to 26% in the final quarter of 
2015.<nl/>The increase in August traffic brings further positive news for Allegiant Travel which has already been 
witnessing good times courtesy weak oil prices. The positive impact of soft oil prices on the bottom line is evident 
from the fact that the stock has delivered positive earnings surprises in three of the last four quarters with an 
average beat of 6.62%. Moreover, earnings estimates for this impressive player in the airline space are also on an 
upswing.<nl/>Zacks Rank<nl/>Allegiant Travel Company currently carries a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy). Other well-
ranked stocks in the transportation sector are Ryanair Holdings RYAAY[2], China Eastern Airlines Corp. Ltd. 
CEA[3] and SkyWest Inc. SKYW[4]. All the three stocks carry a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy).<nl/>Want the latest

Delta Air Lines ' August Traffic Trends Up, PRASM Woes Stay
Delta Air Lines' August Traffic Trends Up, PRASM Woes Stay
Zacks Investment Research
September 3, 2015 Thursday 7:00 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 621 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
Sep 03, 2015( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Delta Air Lines Inc. 
DAL[1] witnessed an increase in air traffic in the month of August wherein traffic - measured in revenue passenger 
miles (RPMs) - stood at 20.8 billion. 
This figure reflects a 3.9% increase from 20.03 billion recorded a year ago.<nl/>On a year-over-year basis, 
consolidated capacity (or available seat miles/ASMs) inched up 4.2% to 23.8 billion. Meanwhile, the load factor or 
percentage of seats filled by passengers decreased to 87.3% in the month being discussed from 87.6% in the year-
ago month.<nl/>In the first eight months of 2015, Delta generated RPMs of 142.7 billion (up 3.4% year over year) 
and ASMs of 168.1 billion (up 4.2% year over year). Load factor stood at 84.9% compared with 85.5% in Aug 2014. 
Likewise, passengers boarded in the month improved 4.6% while that for the full year rose 4.3%.<nl/>However, 
Delta witnessed a 6.5% drop in PRASM (passenger revenue per available seat mile) in the month mainly affected 
by weaker foreign exchange rates in comparison to a strengthening U.S. dollar. Moreover, lower surcharge rates in 
international markets further affected PRASM growth.<nl/>Delta continues to perform impressively on the back of 
new route launches, ancillary product introductions, revamping of fleet structure and efficient customer service. 
Further, the company continues to deliver solid results through its joint venture and expects trans-Atlantic revenues 
and capacity to increase backed by the strength in the New York-London route.<nl/>Zacks Rank ...ocks to 
Consider<nl/>Delta Airlines currently carries a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). Better-ranked stocks in the airline space 
include Ryanair Holdings plc RYAAY[2], JetBlue Airways Corp. JBLU[3] and SkyWest Inc. SKYW[4]. All three 
companies sport a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy).<nl/>Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment 
Research? Today, you can download 7 Best Stocks for the Next 30 Days. Click to get this free report

Alaska Air Group (ALK) August Traffic Up 7% Y/Y, Stock Gains
Alaska Air Group (ALK) August Traffic Up 7% Y/Y, Stock Gains
Zacks Investment Research
September 3, 2015 Thursday 7:00 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 659 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
Sep 03, 2015( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Shares of Seattle, 
WA-based Alaska Air Group ALK[1] gained 5.39% to reach $78.83 on Sep 2, following the release of impressive 
traffic results for Aug 2015. Traffic - measured in revenue passenger miles (RPMs) - came in at 3.09 billion on a 
consolidated basis, reflecting a year-over-year improvement of 7%.<nl/>Furthermore, consolidated capacity (or 
available seat miles/ASMs) improved 7.7% to 3.57 billion. 
However, another important metric load factor (percentage of seats filled by passengers) decreased marginally to 
86.7% as the rise in capacity was more than the improvement in traffic.<nl/>At the end of the first eight months of 
2015, Alaska Air Group generated RPMs of 22.41 billion (up 8.4% year over year) and ASMs of 26.35 billion (up 
9.8%). Load factor declined 110 basis points to 85.1%.<nl/>Apart from the rise in August traffic, Alaska Air, like 
many other carriers, has been benefiting from weak oil prices. Despite the recent rally, crude prices have been 
hovering around the $40 a barrel mark. This represents a significant decline from the approximately $105 per barrel 
witnessed in July last year.<nl/>Weak oil prices have helped the carrier report higher-than-expected earnings in 
each of the last four quarters. With oil prices expected to be soft for at least the rest of 2015, Alaska Air Group's 
bottom line should continue to benefit.<nl/>Moreover, earnings estimates for 2015 and 2016 are on an upswing, 
further reflecting good times for the carrier. The Zacks Consensus Estimate for 2015 has climbed 10 cents to $6.29 
over the last 30 days, while the same for 2016 has increased 17 cents to $6.65 per share over the same time 
period.<nl/>Alaska Air Group's Zacks Rank #2 (Buy) is further indicative of our bullish stance on the 
stock.<nl/>Other Stocks to Consider<nl/>Investors interested in the airline space may also consider stocks like 
Ryanair Holdings RYAAY[2], China Eastern Airlines Corp. Ltd. CEA[3] and SkyWest SKYW[4]. All the three stocks 
carry a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy).<nl/>Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research?

recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today, you can download 7 Best Stocks for the Next 30 Days.

NUGT, EIRL: Big ETF Inflows
NUGT, EIRL: Big ETF Inflows
Market News Video
September 1, 2015 Tuesday 3:33 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 202 words
Body
View Video
Sep 01, 2015 (Market News Video:http://marketnewsvideo.com/ Delivered by Newstex)
 Comparing units outstanding versus one week ago at the coverage universe of ETFs at ETF Channel, the biggest 
inflow was seen in the Daily Gold Miners Index Bull 3x Shares (NUGT), which added 21,600,000 units, or a 12.6% 
increase week over week. Among the largest underlying components of NUGT, in morning trading today Market 
Vectors Gold Miners ETF (GDX) is down about 1%. 
And on a percentage change basis, the ETF with the biggest increase in inflows was the iShares MSCI Ireland 
Capped ETF (EIRL), which added 1,100,000 units, for a 33.3% increase in outstanding units. Among the largest 
underlying components of EIRL, in morning trading today Icon (ICLR) is trading flat, and Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY) 
is lower by about 1%.

JetBlue to Add Flights on New York -Southern California Route
JetBlue to Add Flights on New York-Southern California Route
Zacks Investment Research
September 1, 2015 Tuesday 6:25 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 631 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
Sep 01, 2015( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Low-cost carrier 
JetBlue Airways Corp. JBLU[1] recently decided to expand its seasonal non-stop flight service between New York's 
John F. Kennedy International Airport (JFK) and Palm Springs International Airport (PSP) in Southern California. 
The service is expected to commence this winter, subject to government approval.<nl/>Under the new extension, 
JetBlue will run flights from Thursday to Monday every week beginning Jan 14, 2016, through May 1, 2016. As a 
promotional offer, ticket fares will start at as low as $99 for a one-way trip. This service will largely serve travelers 
interested in a winter escape.<nl/>The company has decided to fly Airbus A320 on both the routes. These aircraft 
will provide more leg space, free unlimited snacks as well as soft drinks. Moreover, passengers will be able to 
watch unrestricted movies and TV programs on DIRECTV channels and stream music on SIRIUS XM Holdings 
Inc.'s SIRI[2] radio stations. In addition, fliers will be able to access free in-flight Wi-Fi connectivity.<nl/>Coming to 
traffic data, JetBlue recently revealed encouraging numbers for the month of July on the back of increased travel 
demand. Traffic - measured in revenue passenger miles (RPMs) - stood at 3.99 billion, up 8.9% year over year. 
Likewise, PRASM (passenger revenue per available seat mile) in the month inched up 1% from the last-year 
period.<nl/>Meanwhile, we believe that JetBlue's increased flight frequencies coupled with low fares will enhance 
travel options for New York dwellers during winter months while boosting passenger revenues for the 
company.<nl/>Zacks Rank ...her Key Picks<nl/>JetBlue currently sports a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy). Other 
favorably-ranked stocks in the airline space include Ryanair Holdings plc RYAAY[3] and SkyWest Inc. SKYW[4]. 
Both the companies carry a Zacks Rank #1.<nl/>Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment

Canadian National Railway: Coal Woes Stay, Margins Improve
Canadian National Railway: Coal Woes Stay, Margins Improve
Zacks Investment Research
August 28, 2015 Friday 5:00 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 636 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
Aug 28, 2015( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> On Aug 24, 2015, 
we issued an updated research report on Canadian National Railway Company CNI[1].<nl/>Recently, Canadian 
National reported second-quarter 2015 financial results wherein both the top and the bottom line surpassed the 
Zacks Consensus Estimate aided by higher freight volumes.<nl/>
In view of the strong fundamentals, we believe that the company will be able to achieve its double-digit year-over-
year earnings growth target in 2015. Meanwhile, operating ratio in the reported quarter, stood at 56.4% compared 
with 59.6% in the year-ago quarter. We are impressed by the company's efforts to return more to shareholders 
through dividend payments and share buybacks. Canadian National has a strong balance sheet with solid free cash 
flow, which encourages it to raise dividends and repurchase shares.<nl/>However, uncertainties surrounding the 
coal market have been a major concern for Canadian National, particularly owing to lower pet coke export. Offshore 
coal export is expected to remain a challenge going forward. Lower coal shipments will offset the positive impact of 
other products lines, thus affecting the company's revenues. At the end of the second quarter of 2015, revenues 
from the coal business dropped 26%.<nl/>Canadian National faces significant competition from rail carriers and 
other modes of transportation. It faces rivalry specifically from Canadian Pacific Railway, which operates the other 
major rail systems in Canada and services almost similar areas in which Canadian National serves. It also faces 
intense competition from trucking companies in eastern Canada.<nl/>Canadian National currently has a Zacks 
Rank #3 (Hold). Better-ranked stocks in the transportation-related space are Ryanair Holdings plc RYAAY[2], 
JetBlue Airways Corp. JBLU[3] and SkyWest Inc. SKYW[4]. All the three companies sport a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong 
Buy).<nl/>Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today, you can download 7 Best

Southwest Airlines Adds Flights on Memphis- Texas Route
Southwest Airlines Adds Flights on Memphis-Texas Route
Zacks Investment Research
August 27, 2015 Thursday 6:05 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 606 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
Aug 27, 2015( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Southwest Airlines 
Co. LUV[1] decided to launch two new non-stop seasonal flights from Memphis to Austin, Texas. Under the new 
extension, the carrier will operate flights only on Saturdays and Sundays starting Dec 5, 2015 through Jan 3, 2016. 
This also marks the inclusion of Austin as the seventh destination in the carrier's network.<nl/>
However, at the closing of the winter holiday season, the flight service will be available only on Saturdays from Jan 
9 through Mar 5, 2016. Launch of non-stop flights during weekends will open up more options to passengers and 
will allow them to skip connecting flights, thereby helping them save travel time.<nl/>Notably, Southwest Airlines' 
weekend flights will create significant competition for Allegiant Air as the latter also plans to initiate Thursday and 
Sunday non-stop flights on the Memphis-Austin route. Allegiant Air's service is slated to begin from Oct 1 this 
year.<nl/>In keeping with its expansion efforts, Southwest Airlines recently announced plans of introducing non-stop 
flights to Orlando International as well, starting Dec 5, 2015. Even in April this year, the carrier flagged off two non-
stop daily flights connecting Memphis and Dallas Love Field.<nl/>Hence, we believe that increased flight 
frequencies coupled with low fares will not only enhance travel options for travelers during busy travel periods but 
will also boost revenues for Southwest Airlines.<nl/>Currently, Southwest Airlinescarries a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy). 
Other favorably-ranked stocks in the airline space include Ryanair Holdings plc RYAAY[2], JetBlue Airways Corp. 
JBLU[3] and SkyWest Inc. SKYW[4]. All the three companies sport a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy).<nl/>Want the

Will Republic Airways File For Bankruptcy? Shares Plunge
Will Republic Airways File For Bankruptcy? Shares Plunge
Zacks Investment Research
August 27, 2015 Thursday 8:50 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 743 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
Aug 27, 2015( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Shares of 
Indianapolis-based Republic Airways Holdings Inc. RJET[1], the parent company of Republic Airlines and Shuttle 
America, plummeted 36.72% to close the trading session on Aug 26 at $2.12. The drastic fall came on the heels of 
a local pilot union's (Teamsters' Local 357) adverse recommendation pertaining to pilots voting on the 'last, best 
and final offer' by the beleaguered company, according to a Bloomberg report. 
<nl/>We remind investors that the company made the above contract offer last week in a bid to resolve the long-
standing labor dispute that has been hurting it big time, resulting in pilot shortage. Republic Airways put forward the 
offer to the International Brotherhood of Teamsters Local 357, for consideration. The body represents 
approximately 2,100 pilots belonging to the company. The Bloomberg report stated that according to the offer put 
forward by the company, new first officers would receive a pay hike to the tune of 74%. Senior pilots would be 
eligible for a smaller raise. Moreover, pilots would also apparently get a ratification bonus in the range of $1,000 to 
$11,000 depending on the duration of service, in addition to a bonus on the completion of one-year of 
ratification.<nl/>The Bloomberg report stated that the adverse recommendation from the local pilot union came due 
to the presence of a clause in the contract that would stand in the way of the union from encouraging its members 
taking up jobs at other regional carriers.<nl/>The adverse stance of the local pilot union is a huge blow to the 
company since it had already stated that in the event of the pilots rejecting the final offer filing for Chapter 11 
bankruptcy protection may be the only option available to it. In such a scenario, the only ray of hope is that the 
national union has powers to overrule the recommendation of the local union and ask the pilots to vote on the 
contract.<nl/>We expect investor focus to remain on updates on the labor problems at Republic Airways. No 
wonder, the company carries a bearish Zacks Rank #4 (Sell) - a true reflection of the troubled times it is currently 
going through.<nl/>Stocks to Consider<nl/>While Republic Airways is clearly a stock that should be dumped now, 
there are other airline stocks which may prove to be prudent additions to an investor's portfolio. Investors may 
consider augmenting their portfolios with Ryanair Holdings RYAAY[2], JetBlue Airways Corporation JBLU[3] and 
SkyWest SKYW[4]. All three stocks sport a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy).<nl/>Want the latest recommendations 
from Zacks Investment Research? Today, you can download 7 Best Stocks for the Next 30 Days. Click to get this 
free report >>[5]<nl/>Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today, you can 
download 7 Best Stocks for the Next 30 Days. Click to get this free report[6] REPUBLIC AIRWAY (RJET): Free 
Stock Analysis Report[7] RYANAIR HLDGS (RYAAY): Free Stock Analysis Report[8] JETBLUE AIRWAYS (JBLU): 
Free Stock Analysis Report[9] SKYWEST INC (SKYW): Free Stock Analysis Report[10] To read this article on 
Zacks.com click here.[11] Zacks Investment Research[12]<nl/> [ 1]: http://www.zacks.com/stock/quote/RJET [ 2]:

Delta Air Lines - Virgin Atlantic to Enhance Transatlantic Ties
Delta Air Lines-Virgin Atlantic to Enhance Transatlantic Ties
Zacks Investment Research
August 26, 2015 Wednesday 4:55 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 636 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
Aug 26, 2015( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Premium U.S. 
carrier Delta Air Lines DAL[1] and British carrier Virgin Atlantic Airways recently decided to boost the trans-Atlantic 
network with the launch of two new routes. The new extension will connect Salt Lake City and Heathrow, and New 
York's JFK airport to Edinburgh, Scotland routes, starting May, next year.<nl/>
Under this new agreement, Delta will be operating the only non-stop service between Salt Lake City to London 
Heathrow. Notably, Salt Lake City will be the carrier's eighth location from Heathrow.<nl/>On the other hand, the 
non-stop service between New York's JFK and Edinburgh will commence from May 26, 2016, allowing passengers 
in the U.K. up to 60 convenient onward connections from JFK.<nl/>Similarly, Delta's newly-launched flight service 
connecting Scotland's capital city equals Virgin Atlantic's three times weekly summer seasonal service from 
Glasgow to Orlando.<nl/>Flyers of Delta One cabin on both the Salt Lake City to Heathrow and New York-JFK to 
Edinburgh carrier will have access to full flat-bed seats and can enjoy a wide variety of personalized dining options. 
Furthermore, the carrier will offer on-board entertainment options which include Wi-Fi connectivity, on-demand 
movies and TV shows.<nl/>Launch of two new networks will significantly expand flight frequency and also offer 
more options to passengers traveling between the U.S. and the U.K. Moreover, busy holiday seasons heighten 
traffic between these nations which we believe will result in an increased number of flights across the trans-Atlantic 
network, simultaneously driving passenger revenue for the carriers.<nl/>Delta currently carries a Zacks Rank #3 
(Hold). Better-ranked stocks in the airline space include Ryanair Holdings plc RYAAY[2], JetBlue Airways Corp. 
JBLU[3] and SkyWest Inc. SKYW[4]. All the three companies sport a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy).<nl/>Want the 
latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today, you can download 7 Best Stocks for the Next 30 
Days. Click to get this free report >>[5]<nl/>Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research?

Fly Away Bride: Airport Parking And Hotels (APH) Compares The Cost Of Transporting Wedding Dresses 
Onboard Major Airlines
Fly Away Bride: Airport Parking And Hotels (APH) Compares The Cost Of 
Transporting Wedding Dresses Onboard Major Airlines
Pressat
August 26, 2015 Wednesday 3:13 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 807 words
Byline: Pressat
Body
Aug 26, 2015( Pressat: http://www.pressat.co.uk Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Wednesday 26 August, 2015<nl/> 
With many UK couples looking for reliable weather and lower wedding costs, the trend for getting married abroad is 
increasing with an estimated 1.5 million people in the UK travelling abroad in 2014 as a wedding guest or as part of 
the wedding party*. Airport Parking ...tels (APH) is therefore helping 'Fly Away Brides' to plan ahead with a 
comprehensive guide which compares the different airline policies for transporting wedding dresses and cakes 
abroad. The research can be found in the Know Before You Go section of the APH website at            
www.aph.com/weddingdresses.<nl/>
The research compares the guidelines for travelling with a wedding dress and/or cake across 15 major airlines 
including easyJet, Virgin Atlantic and Thomson Airways, and highlights the different policies for carrying dresses as 
hand baggage and hold luggage. The guide also highlights the airline regulations relating to how the dress needs to 
be packed and whether any additional baggage options are available to couples.<nl/>All of the 15 airlines in the 
study were found to allow wedding dresses to be transported as hand luggage although 14 of the airlines offer no 
additional baggage allowance for the bride, meaning the dress must still remain within the individual airlines' 
luggage policy. Meanwhile, couples who have booked a wedding package through Thomas Cook are entitled to 
11kgs hand luggage spread across two bags for each person travelling, instead of the usual policy of 6kgs in one 
bag.<nl/>For those brides happy to transport their wedding dress as part of their checked luggage allowance, most 
of the airlines apply normal checked baggage rules whereas couples who have booked a Thomson Wedding are 
entitled to an extra 5kgs of checked luggage free of charge. For those travellers flying with flybe and opting for a 
traditional Scottish wedding abroad, they must be aware that the kilt pin and sgian gubh (sock knife) can only be 
carried as checked luggage for obvious security reasons.<nl/>When it comes to the all-important packing of the 
wedding dress, airlines such as Air Canada, British Airways, Lufthansa and US Airways recommend that the dress 
is packed in a foldable garment bag to reduce creases and damage during the flight. Whereas, Virgin Atlantic 
require the dress to be packed in a separate suitcase marked 'fragile wedding garments' if it is to travel in the 
hold.<nl/>In terms of special assistance whilst onboard, brides travelling with British Airways and Virgin Atlantic can 
request for their dress to be hung in the wardrobe storage area if space is available. Meanwhile, Ryanair will go one 
step further and allow passengers to book an additional seat for their dress for the duration of the flight. Passengers 
must note that if they require an extra seat for their wedding dress with Ryanair, they must pay the full ticket price 
for the seat occupied.<nl/>Three of the 15 airlines compared in the survey, including Aer Lingus, easyJet and flybe, 
Fly Away Bride: Airport Parking And Hotels (APH) Compares The Cost Of Transporting Wedding Dresses 
Onboard Major Airlines
also allow passengers to bring their wedding cakes onboard. For those travelling with Aer Lingus, there is the option 
of checking the cake in or carrying it as hand luggage whereas with easyJet, wedding cakes can only be carried as 
hand luggage and stored in the overhead locker or under the seat, but not on the passenger's lap. Meanwhile, 
passengers with flybe on an international flight must contact the Department for Environment Food ...ral Affairs 
(Defra) to ensure they are allowed to export their wedding cake.<nl/>For further information on Airport Parking and 
Hotels (APH),<nl/>Visit www.aph.com or call 01342 859515.<nl/>ENDS<nl/>NOTES TO EDITORS<nl/>*Research 
taken from ABTA in May 2015, available from: abta.com/news-and-views/press-zone/over-1.5-million-to-go-to-a-
wedding-abroad-this-year<nl/>About Airport Parking and Hotels (APH)<nl/>Airport Parking and Hotels (APH) is the 
UK's award winning long stay airport parking operator and booking agency, after winning the Best Airport Parking 
Company for a fifth year running at British Travel Awards 2014. This year APH also celebrates its 35th year as a 
retailer and operator of pre-booked airport parking and travel extras. APH offers parking at all major UK airports as 
well as airport hotels packaged with parking and airport lounges. APH is also a carbon balanced company and has, 
through support of the World Land Trust, helped purchase more than 1,000 acres of endangered 
rainforest.<nl/>Media Enquiries<nl/>Sarah Salord / Lauren Hill / McCluskey International / 020 8747 2170 / 
aph@mccluskey.co.uk;<nl/><nl/> No media attached. Please contact Pressat Wire for more information.<nl/><nl/> 
Distributed by            http://www.pressat.co.uk/[1]<nl/> [ 1]:            http://www.pressat.co.uk/ 
Load-Date: August 26, 2015
End of Document
American Airlines Group to Stop Philadelphia-Tel Aviv Service
American Airlines Group to Stop Philadelphia-Tel Aviv Service
Zacks Investment Research
August 24, 2015 Monday 7:15 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 698 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
Aug 24, 2015( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> According to 
various media reports, Fort Worth, Texas-based American Airlines Group AAL[1], which was formed following the 
Dec 2013 merger between AMR (American Airlines' parent group, founded in 1934) and US Airways, will no longer 
fly to Israel from early January next year. Apparently, lack of profitability led to the decision of terminating the 
carrier's sole direct flight to Israel, which connected Philadelphia and Tel Aviv.<nl/>
The route has been operative for six years now but has unfortunately not been able to deliver profits. . In fact, 
according to the Street, the carrier has lost in excess of $20 million in 2015 due to its operations on the route. 
According to the Association of Professional Flight Attendants (APFA), the union representing flight attendants of 
American Airlines and US Airways, the route will be discontinued effective Jan 4, 2016. US Airways was 
responsible for operating flights on the route.<nl/>Flights on the route were apparently packed (operated with high 
load factor). However, the metric is not the sole criterion for judging the financial performance of a route, according 
to the APFA release. The carrier has also reportedly stated that post-termination, passengers already booked on 
the flights will either be offered full refund or provided with alternative arrangements.<nl/>However, according to an 
article appearing in the Times of Israel, the possibility of a political motive behind American Airlines' decision cannot 
be ruled out. The article conjectured whether the move to close down the route was necessitated by American 
Airlines' inclination to strengthen its ties with Arab carriers such as Royal Jordanian and Qatar Airways. American 
Airlines apparently shares flights and other services with its Arab counterparts, being a part of the OneWorld 
alliance of airlines.<nl/>Although American Airlines has decided to omit Israel from its operational itinerary from 
early next year, we note that many other carriers, including Delta Air Lines DAL[2], have operations in 
Israel.<nl/>Zacks Rank<nl/>American Airlines carries a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). Better-ranked stocks in the airline 
space include Ryanair Holdings RYAAY[3] and SkyWest Inc. SKYW[4]. Both the stocks carry a Zacks Rank #1 
(Strong Buy).<nl/>Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today, you can download 7

Copa Holdings : 52-Week Low on Weak Real, Dismal IATA View
Copa Holdings: 52-Week Low on Weak Real, Dismal IATA View
Zacks Investment Research
August 19, 2015 Wednesday 7:15 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 672 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
Aug 19, 2015( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> On Aug 18, 2015, 
shares of Copa Holdings SA CPA[1] dropped to a 52-week low of $59.61 and eventually closed at $59.95. 
Moreover, year to date, the company's shares have declined a massive 41%.<nl/>Notably, the price decline can be 
largely attributed to adverse foreign currency movements stemming from the strengthening of the U.S. dollar 
against the Brazilian real. 
We believe these factors have not only forced most passengers to defer their travel plans but have also hurt the 
carrier's air traffic and profit numbers.<nl/>Additionally, the 2015 projection by the International Air Transport 
Association (IATA) paints a gloomy picture for Latin American carriers. According to the forecast, these carriers will 
account for only $600 million of the $29.3 billion global net profit projected by IATA.<nl/>Moreover, Copa Airlines, 
the business arm of Copa Holdings, posted a decrease in air traffic for the month of June 2015. Traffic - measured 
in revenue passenger miles (RPMs) - came in at 1.28 billion, down 3.4% from 1.32 billion recorded in the 
comparable month a year ago.<nl/>Further, despite increased flight frequencies and route expansion, load factor of 
Copa Airlines continues to suffer. The load factor or percentage of seats filled by passengers in the month fell to 
72% from 77.4% in Jun 2014.<nl/>Adding to the woes, stiff competition from the likes of LATAM Airlines, Azul 
Brazilian Airlines and GOL Linhas - which largely dominate the Brazilian aviation space - may continue to mar 
revenues for Copa Holdings.<nl/>Meanwhile, over the past 60 days, the company has witnessed downward 
estimate revisions for both the current quarter and year. The Zacks Consensus Estimate for the quarter has moved 
down to $1.48 from $1.90 whereas the same for the year has fallen 17.7% to $6.52.<nl/>Copa Holdings currently 
carries a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold).<nl/>Stocks to Consider<nl/>Better-ranked stocks in the same space include China 
Eastern Airlines Corp. Ltd. CEA[2], SkyWest Inc. SKYW[3] and Ryanair Holdings plc RYAAY[4]. All three stocks 
sport a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy).<nl/>Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research?

Henri Coanda Airport ranked No. 4 among European airports with highest air traffic growth
Henri Coanda Airport ranked No. 4 among European airports with highest air 
traffic growth
ACTmedia News
August 18, 2015 Tuesday 8:38 AM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 316 words
Body
Aug 17, 2015( ACTmedia News: http://actmedia.eu Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Airports Council International 
ranked Henri Coanda International Airport of Bucharest Europe No. 4 among the airports having recorded the 
highest growth of the air traffic in the first half of 2015, in the group of the airports welcoming between 5 and 10 
million passengers a year. 
The top three airports in this group included Milan-Bergamo, Porto and Glasgow, with Budapest ranking 5th. The 
National Bucharest Airports Company (CNAB) recorded more than 4.217 million passengers and 52,116 flights 
(landings and take-offs) at Bucharest's International Henri Coanda 'Otopeni' Airport and International Bucharest-
Baneasa Aurel Vlaicu Airport in the six months as compared to last Jan.-June, thus setting the prerequisites for 
hitting the 9-million passenger mark this year, CNAB said in a release. According to it, Henri Coanda Airport 
accounted for the bulk of such traffic, with 4,215,314 passengers and 46,426 aircraft movements. The evolution of 
the number of passengers at the two Bucharest international airports significantly outdoes the general European 
trend of 4.5 percent. Aircraft landings and take-offs at Bucharest airports also grew and passed the 2 percent 
European trend. Thus, the number of aircraft movements at the two international airports in the first six months was 
up 8.7 percent from the same period last year. Operating at Henri Coanda International Airport at present are 31 
airlines, which fly passengers to 70 destinations. Two new airlines began operating at Henri Coanda Airport in 
2014, Ryanair and Air Baltic respectively. CNAB began functioning in Feb. 2010 and it provides the operating 
coordination and management of the two Bucharest airports. CNAB was set up by the merger of the companies that 
managed the two Bucharest airports — Henri Coanda and Bucharest-Baneasa respectively.<nl/> 
Load-Date: August 18, 2015
End of Document
Cool Off in Lisbon's Hottest Rooftop Bars
Cool Off in Lisbon's Hottest Rooftop Bars
Pressat
August 18, 2015 Tuesday 10:42 AM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 1011 words
Byline: Pressat
Body
Aug 18, 2015( Pressat: http://www.pressat.co.uk Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Tuesday 18 August, 2015<nl/> 
Following a series of new openings for 2015, this summer visitors to Lisbon have more choice than ever before for 
a drink with a view. <nl/>
Featuring stunning vistas, signature cocktails and chill-out vibes, the city's hotels open up their top floors to anyone 
looking to make the most of a relaxing summer evening - whether you are looking for a 'Sunset Party', want to cool 
off in an infinity pool (or a open air Jacuzzi!), have a late drink at 2am or simply chill out in an intimate rooftop 
garden.Below are some of the most memorable spots in the Portuguese capital for a drink with that 'extra touch of 
Lisbon'.<nl/>Deck 7, Porto Bay Liberdade NEW FOR 2015<nl/>Rua Rosa Araújo 8, 1250-195 Lisbon; +351 21 001 
5700<nl/>Deck 7 is the rooftop lounge bar that crowns Porto Bay Liberdade, the latest five-star hotel to open in 
Lisbon (February 2015). Located close to Avenida da Liberdade, the city's premier shopping destination and home 
to some of the world's most prestigious luxury brands, you can take in the views as you enjoy your drink on the 
wooden deck - or from the rooftop Jacuzzi!<nl/>www.portobay.com/en/hotels/portugal/lisbon-portugal/porto-bay-
liberdade<nl/>Limão, H10 Duque de Loulé NEW FOR 2015<nl/>Av. Duque de Loulé 81, 1050-088 Lisbon; +351 21 
318 2000<nl/>The recently opened H10 Duque de Loulé (March 2015), decorated by celebrated Spanish interior 
designer Lázaro Rosa-Violán, takes hospitality to new heights in central Lisbon. Limão, its 'chill-out terrace', is 
located on the hotel's tenth floor, combining an elegant open-air space with stunning views across the city and the 
Tagus Estuary, especially at sunset.<nl/>           www.hotelh10duquedeloule.com<nl/>UpScale, Epic Sana Lisboa 
Hotel<nl/>Av. Eng. Duarte Pacheco 15, 1070-100 Lisbon; +351 21 159 7300<nl/>If you are looking for the best 
infinity pool with views in Lisbon look no further. UpScale, the rooftop bar on the ninth floor of five-star Epic Sana 
Lisboa Hotel, features lush lounge beds, breathtaking vistas and a growing menu of popular fruity cocktails. While 
here try its signature drink, the exotic 'UpScale Colada', made with rum, pineapple juice and coconut ice 
cream.<nl/>           www.lisboa.epic.sanahotels.com<nl/>Rooftop Bar, Hotel Mundial<nl/>Praça Martim Moniz 2, 
1100-341 - Lisbon; +351 218 842 000<nl/>Watching the sunset from the rooftop bar of Hotel Mundial is a must, 
which is why every summer the hotel organises regular 'Sunset Parties' with resident DJs at the panoramic lounge 
of its ninth floor. Featuring a relaxed atmosphere and modern ambience, prepare yourself for jaw-dropping views 
over one of Lisbon's most famous must-sees, the São Jorge Castle.<nl/>           www.hotel-mundial.pt<nl/>Vicius 
Lounge Bar - Skyna Hotel Lisboa NEW FOR 2015<nl/>Rua da Artilharia 1 nº112, 1070-015 Lisbon; +351 21 248 
4900<nl/>Skyna Hotels is the first Angolan chain to go global, with Lisbon chosen as the location of its first 
international property, launched in March 2015. Vicius Lounge Bar, the hotel's intimate, 60-seat rooftop garden, is 
located on the sixth floor and is open daily from midday to midnight, offering memorable views over Lisbon.<nl/>      
Cool Off in Lisbon's Hottest Rooftop Bars
     www.skynahotels.com/hotels/skyna-lisbon/ <nl/>Varanda do Castelo, Vintage Lisboa Hotel<nl/>R. Rodrigo da 
Fonseca 2, 1250-191 Lisbon; +351 21 040 5400<nl/>This is the place to come if you want a really late drink, 
combined with some of the best night-time views in Lisbon. Varanda do Castelo, located on the top floor of the five-
star Vintage Lisboa Hotel, is open until 2am offering a relaxed environment, chill-out vibes, scrumptious Portuguese 
tapas 
and 
dazzling 
vistas 
over

opened in 2005 and a decade later it is still impossible to find a hotel in this part of the city that can claim better 
views! Famous with locals and a compulsory stop for visitors, it is the perfect spot for lunch during shopping, a thirst 
quenching

cocktail 
or

or 
enrique@humewhitehead.co.uk;<nl/>About Lisbon<nl/>Portugal's national capital, Lisbon, boasts one of the 
longest histories, warmest climates and bustling nightlife of any major European city alongside its dramatic location 
sprawled along seven hills overlooking the river Tagus and the country's west coast. Famed for its year-round 
sunshine and beauty, Lisbon's grand architecture dazzles and its old-world charm mingles with chic streets, 
galleries, lively nightlife and a centre which gives way to sandy beaches just minutes away. It is also one of the 
most affordable capitals in Europe, perfect for a captivating city break or short haul escape.<nl/>           
www.visitlisboa.com<nl/>About Turismo de Lisboa<nl/>Turismo de Lisboa is a non-profit organisation established 
through an alliance of public and private bodies operating in the tourist sector. It now has 713 associated members. 
Since its inception in 1998, the main objective of this association is to improve and increase the promotion of Lisbon 
as a tourist destination and therefore enhance the quality and competitiveness of the cit<nl/><nl/> No media 
attached. Please contact Pressat Wire for more information.<nl/><nl/> Distributed by

Renault Zoe Review
Renault Zoe Review
Gas 2.0
August 17, 2015 Monday 2:09 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 1862 words
Byline: Zachary Shahan
Body
Aug 17, 2015( Gas 2.0: http://gas2.org/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Originally published on EV Obsession[1].<nl/> 
I finally got to test drive a Renault Zoe[2]. Two years after trying out the Nissan Leaf[3], BMW i3[4], Volkswagen e-
Up![5], Smart Electric Drive[6], and Renault Twizy[7], I got my hands on the popular electric car that barely escaped 
my grasp a few times at EVS27[8] in Barcelona. For the most part, it was better than I expected it would be. 
However, there were some downsides to the vehicle that I wasn't prepared for as well.<nl/>            
http://cleantechnica.com/files/2015/08/Renault-Zoe-1.jpg            http://cleantechnica.com/files/2015/08/Renault-Zoe-
4.jpg<nl/>Renault Zoe Acceleration<nl/>
First of all, let's talk about the big dog — acceleration. Instant torque and the wonderful acceleration that comes 
with it is the first[9] or second[10] biggest consumer advantage of electric cars for most electric car drivers. Like I 
said, it has been a couple of years since I drove all of those electric cars listed above. The biggest thing that caught 
my attention[11] at the time was the wonderful, quick acceleration those vehicles had, and also how smooth and 
quiet that acceleration was. But I was starting to wonder recently if my perception had been warped, or if I was 
flowering it up too much in my memory.<nl/> I recently (in the past two months or so) rented a Mercedes A180, a 
Mercedes C180, and a BMW 320i. They were much nicer than the other gasmobiles I rented in the past year or so, 
so I was starting to wonder if they perhaps compared more favorably to affordable electrics like the Leaf and Zoe. I 
also drove the Tesla P85D[12] a few months ago, which completely messed me up and warped my perception of 
reality and 'what a car is.' Then, about one month ago, I test drove a Mitsubishi Outlander PHEV[13]. Expecting to 
love the acceleration like I had when I first drove the electric cars listed above, I was a little let down, as it wasn't as 
thrilling as before. So I was thinking, 'Is my memory warped? Were those electric cars as nice as I think I 
remember?'<nl/> Indeed, I did remember correctly. Electric drive rocks. I love it, and I can't imagine anyone not 
loving it. Test driving the Renault Zoe, I could quickly tell that it totally kicked the butts of the Mercedes A180, 
Mercedes C180, and BMW 320i… and every other gasmobile I've ever driven. Of course, it didn't compare to the 
Tesla P85D (at a price ~$100,000 lower, how could it?), but it was much better than those three gasmobiles, the 
Toyota Auris Hybrid[14] I recently drove, and also the two plug-in hybrids I've driven — the Outlander PHEV and 
the Audi A3 e-tron (which I test drove about an hour after the Zoe — review coming soon, along with more on the 
difference between 100% electrics and PHEVs).<nl/> Bottom line: The Zoe's acceleration was great. I didn't keep 
my eye on the speedometer, but the high-quality acceleration did taper off at some point, which I think was around 
30 mph. Again, it's no P85D, but it's often just that first 30 mph or so where quick acceleration comes in handy. We 
don't typically drive on 0-60 mph race tracks.<nl/>Interior<nl/>One thing that impressed me was the great visibility, 
particularly in the front. I'm not sure how you're supposed to phrase this and talk about the specifics of such 
Renault Zoe Review
matters, but the bottom line is that there was a lot of glass and I could see around the car really well, which I (and 
many others) hugely appreciate. It makes driving much less stressful… and much safer.<nl/> Both in the front and 
the back, you feel like you are sitting up quite higher, somewhat like in a crossover/CUV. The Renault sales guy 
pointed out that the battery sits underneath the seats, and thus bumps the humans inside up a bit.<nl/> Overall, that 
left for quite a lot of space, yet another thing I was impressed with. There was a lot of space the in front, what 
looked like a ton of space in the trunk, and more space in the back seat than I would have expected. At about 6'1″, I 
was able to sit in the back seat comfortably, with extra room (not at all like on my Ryanair flight to the UK). It doesn't 
look that way in the pictures, but I'll share them anyway:<nl/> http://cleantechnica.com/files/2015/08/Renault-Zoe-
6.jpg 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
http://cleantechnica.com/files/2015/08/Renault-Zoe-2.jpg 
 
 
 
 
 
 
     
http://cleantechnica.com/files/2015/08/Renault-Zoe-3.jpg<nl/><nl/> <nl/>One place where Renault clearly cut some 
costs was in the interior materials. They are not what you'd find in a $50,000 car, but this certainly isn't a $50,000 
car. The starting price is £13,445 (~$21,000). But I'll get to pricing matters in a minute.<nl/> The steering wheel was 
not my favorite — it wasn't like the thick ones I had in the Mercedes A180, Mercedes C180, BMW 320i, or Tesla 
Model S — but it was quite okay. Certainly good enough, I'd say.<nl/> The Zoe also had a backup camera, much 
like the one in the Nissan Leaf or BMW i3. I don't care for many of the extras they throw in many higher-end cars 
these days, but I like me a good backup camera, so it was nice to see that in this super affordable car.<nl/> One 
more thing I found to be a really nice surprise was the comfort of the seat. I don't know if my body was built weird, if 
my body design simply doesn't match many driving seats, or what, but my lower back often gets very tired after 
driving for a bit. My back was quite tired from activities I was doing in the morning that put a lot of strain on it, and I 
was very pleasantly surprised out how comfy the seat was. For my body, it was clearly better than the Mercedes 
A180 I had rented as well as the slightly better Audi A3 e-tron's seat. That's a really important factor for me, so it 
just made me love the Zoe that much more.<nl/>            http://cleantechnica.com/files/2015/08/Renault-Zoe-
5.jpg<nl/>Price<nl/>The sales guy I talked with noted that about 99% of customers got a lease (or what they call a 
PCP) rather the purchasing the car. Renault knocked £5,000 off the starting price with that option (but not with 
the purchase option). After the £5,000 UK EV grant, that brought the ~£20,000 model I was looking at down to 
~£10,000 — based on mileage figures I pulled out of the air.<nl/> The thing is, you lease the battery as well, and 
the price of that depends on how many miles you intend to drive. (Go over your mileage, on average across the 
term of your lease, and you end up paying much more per mile — just like what happens if you use your phone 
beyond the minutes in your monthly phone plan.) Of course, the monthly payments are also lower if you put more 
money down up front, but either way, the total I came to was a bit less than £10,000 (+ ~£70-90 a month for the 
battery) after the UK and Renault incentives. The car sells pretty well in the UK[15]. I doesn't match the Leaf, 
however.<nl/>Customer Service<nl/>Aside from the car, I was curious how well the salesman would sell the car. He 
said almost right off the bat that he wasn't super knowledgeable about the car, and that I probably knew more since 
I was an electric car fan (I told him that off the bat too). However, I found that he knew quite a lot, and certainly 
more than me about the three Zoe trims they sell. He seemed to know the answer of every question I had.<nl/> He 
was proactive when showing me the car too, had a positive attitude about it, and didn't try to steer me elsewhere. 
He didn't come across as an EV fanatic, unfortunately, but he maintained a positive attitude about the car and its 
competitiveness throughout. I found out from him that the Zoe actually sells quite well there. This small salon moves 
about 8-9 of them out each month. It would have been cool if he was really into the technology, but as things go, he 
was more positive and knowledgable than I expected, so that's a + for Renault.<nl/>Aesthetics<nl/>Visual taste is, 
of course, a highly subjective matter — despite many people talking about how 'beautiful' or 'ugly' cars are as if it's 
a matter of fact. Personally, I love how the Zoe looks. The sales guy and I talked a bit, via my prompting, about 
what made buyers choose a Zoe over a Leaf, and it turned out the look was a big reason. I actually like the look of 
the Leaf quite a bit, but I do prefer the Zoe.<nl/>Zoe vs Leaf?<nl/>Other benefits over the Leaf, by the way, 
were reportedly a bit more range in real-world driving, and that the Zoe came with a single charging cable that 
provided various charging options whereas you'd have to get an extra charging cable for the Leaf to have the same 
capability.<nl/> I'd have to check out a Leaf again, and see pricing in the UK, to make a decision between these two 
vehicle. At the moment, though, I'm actually leaning toward the Zoe.<nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/> Tags: Renault[16], Renault 
Zoe[17], UK[18]<nl/><nl/> About the Author            http://gas2.org/author/zshahan/<nl/>Zachary Shahan[19] is the 
director of CleanTechnica[20], the most popular cleantech-focused website in the world, and Planetsave[21], a 
world-leading green and science news site. He has been covering green news of various sorts since 2008, and he 
has been especially focused on solar energy, electric vehicles, and wind energy since 2009. Aside from his work on 
CleanTechnica and Planetsave, he's the founder and director of Solar Love[22], EV Obsession[23], and 
Renault Zoe Review
Bikocity[24]. To connect with Zach on some of your favorite social networks, go to ZacharyShahan.com[25] and 
click on the relevant buttons.<nl/> [ 1]:            http://evobsession.com/renault-zoe-in-uk-test-drive-review/ [ 2]:

test-drive-videos/ [ 6]:            http://evobsession.com/smart-electric-drive-review-pictures/ [ 7]:

Renault Zoe Test Drive Review (Exclusive)
Renault Zoe Test Drive Review (Exclusive)
CleanTechnica
August 17, 2015 Monday 12:22 AM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 2077 words
Byline: Zachary Shahan
Body
Aug 16, 2015( CleanTechnica: http://cleantechnica.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Cars[1] <nl/>Published on 
August 16th, 2015 | by Zachary Shahan<nl/><nl/>August 16th, 2015 by Zachary Shahan[2] <nl/> Originally 
published on EV Obsession[3].<nl/> I finally got to test drive a Renault Zoe[4]. Two years after trying out the Nissan 
Leaf[5], BMW i3[6], Volkswagen e-Up![7], Smart Electric Drive[8], and Renault Twizy[9], I got my hands on the 
popular electric car that barely escaped my grasp a few times at EVS27[10] in Barcelona. For the most part, it was 
better than I expected it would be. However, there were some downsides to the vehicle that I wasn't prepared for as 
well.<nl/>            http://c1cleantechnicacom.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/files/2015/08/Renault-Zoe-1.jpg            
http://c1cleantechnicacom.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/files/2015/08/Renault-Zoe-4.jpg<nl/>Renault 
Zoe 
Acceleration<nl/>
First of all, let's talk about the big dog — acceleration. Instant torque and the wonderful acceleration that comes 
with it is the first[11] or second[12] biggest consumer advantage of electric cars for most electric car drivers. Like I 
said, it has been a couple of years since I drove all of those electric cars listed above. The biggest thing that caught 
my attention[13] at the time was the wonderful, quick acceleration those vehicles had, and also how smooth and 
quiet that acceleration was. But I was starting to wonder recently if my perception had been warped, or if I was 
flowering it up too much in my memory.<nl/> I recently (in the past two months or so) rented a Mercedes A180, a 
Mercedes C180, and a BMW 320i. They were much nicer than the other gasmobiles I rented in the past year or so, 
so I was starting to wonder if they perhaps compared more favorably to affordable electrics like the Leaf and Zoe. I 
also drove the Tesla P85D[14] a few months ago, which completely messed me up and warped my perception of 
reality and 'what a car is.' Then, about one month ago, I test drove a Mitsubishi Outlander PHEV[15]. Expecting to 
love the acceleration like I had when I first drove the electric cars listed above, I was a little let down, as it wasn't as 
thrilling as before. So I was thinking, 'Is my memory warped? Were those electric cars as nice as I think I 
remember?'<nl/> Indeed, I did remember correctly. Electric drive rocks. I love it, and I can't imagine anyone not 
loving it. Test driving the Renault Zoe, I could quickly tell that it totally kicked the butts of the Mercedes A180, 
Mercedes C180, and BMW 320i… and every other gasmobile I've ever driven. Of course, it didn't compare to the 
Tesla P85D (at a price ~$100,000 lower, how could it?), but it was much better than those three gasmobiles, the 
Toyota Auris Hybrid[16] I recently drove, and also the two plug-in hybrids I've driven — the Outlander PHEV and 
the Audi A3 e-tron (which I test drove about an hour after the Zoe — review coming soon, along with more on the 
difference between 100% electrics and PHEVs).<nl/> Bottom line: The Zoe's acceleration was great. I didn't keep 
my eye on the speedometer, but the high-quality acceleration did taper off at some point, which I think was around 
30 mph. Again, it's no P85D, but it's often just that first 30 mph or so where quick acceleration comes in handy. We 
Renault Zoe Test Drive Review (Exclusive)
don't typically drive on 0-60 mph race tracks.<nl/>Interior<nl/>One thing that impressed me was the great visibility, 
particularly in the front. I'm not sure how you're supposed to phrase this and talk about the specifics of such 
matters, but the bottom line is that there was a lot of glass and I could see around the car really well, which I (and 
many others) hugely appreciate. It makes driving much less stressful… and much safer.<nl/> Both in the front and 
the back, you feel like you are sitting up quite higher, somewhat like in a crossover/CUV. The Renault sales guy 
pointed out that the battery sits underneath the seats, and thus bumps the humans inside up a bit.<nl/> Overall, that 
left for quite a lot of space, yet another thing I was impressed with. There was a lot of space the in front, what 
looked like a ton of space in the trunk, and more space in the back seat than I would have expected. At about 6'1″, I 
was able to sit in the back seat comfortably, with extra room (not at all like on my Ryanair flight to the UK). It doesn't 
look that way in the pictures, but I'll share them anyway:<nl/> http://c1cleantechnicacom.wpengine.netdna-
cdn.com/files/2015/08/Renault-Zoe-6.jpg 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
http://c1cleantechnicacom.wpengine.netdna-
cdn.com/files/2015/08/Renault-Zoe-2.jpg 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
http://c1cleantechnicacom.wpengine.netdna-
cdn.com/files/2015/08/Renault-Zoe-3.jpg<nl/><nl/> <nl/>One place where Renault clearly cut some costs was in the 
interior materials. They are not what you'd find in a $50,000 car, but this certainly isn't a $50,000 car. The starting 
price is £13,445 (~$21,000). But I'll get to pricing matters in a minute.<nl/> The steering wheel was not my favorite 
— it wasn't like the thick ones I had in the Mercedes A180, Mercedes C180, BMW 320i, or Tesla Model S — but it 
was quite okay. Certainly good enough, I'd say.<nl/> The Zoe also had a backup camera, much like the one in the 
Nissan Leaf or BMW i3. I don't care for many of the extras they throw in many higher-end cars these days, but I like 
me a good backup camera, so it was nice to see that in this super affordable car.<nl/> One more thing I found to be 
a really nice surprise was the comfort of the seat. I don't know if my body was built weird, if my body design simply 
doesn't match many driving seats, or what, but my lower back often gets very tired after driving for a bit. My back 
was quite tired from activities I was doing in the morning that put a lot of strain on it, and I was very pleasantly 
surprised out how comfy the seat was. For my body, it was clearly better than the Mercedes A180 I had rented as 
well as the slightly better Audi A3 e-tron's seat. That's a really important factor for me, so it just made me love the 
Zoe that much more.<nl/>            http://c1cleantechnicacom.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/files/2015/08/Renault-Zoe-
5.jpg<nl/>Price<nl/>The sales guy I talked with noted that about 99% of customers got a lease (or what they call a 
PCP) rather the purchasing the car. Renault knocked £5,000 off the starting price with that option (but not with 
the purchase option). After the £5,000 UK EV grant, that brought the ~£20,000 model I was looking at down to 
~£10,000 — based on mileage figures I pulled out of the air.<nl/> The thing is, you lease the battery as well, and 
the price of that depends on how many miles you intend to drive. (Go over your mileage, on average across the 
term of your lease, and you end up paying much more per mile — just like what happens if you use your phone 
beyond the minutes in your monthly phone plan.) Of course, the monthly payments are also lower if you put more 
money down up front, but either way, the total I came to was a bit less than £10,000 (+ ~£70-90 a month for the 
battery) after the UK and Renault incentives. The car sells pretty well in the UK[17]. I doesn't match the Leaf, 
however.<nl/>Customer Service<nl/>Aside from the car, I was curious how well the salesman would sell the car. He 
said almost right off the bat that he wasn't super knowledgeable about the car, and that I probably knew more since 
I was an electric car fan (I told him that off the bat too). However, I found that he knew quite a lot, and certainly 
more than me about the three Zoe trims they sell. He seemed to know the answer of every question I had.<nl/> He 
was proactive when showing me the car too, had a positive attitude about it, and didn't try to steer me elsewhere. 
He didn't come across as an EV fanatic, unfortunately, but he maintained a positive attitude about the car and its 
competitiveness throughout. I found out from him that the Zoe actually sells quite well there. This small salon moves 
about 8-9 of them out each month. It would have been cool if he was really into the technology, but as things go, he 
was more positive and knowledgable than I expected, so that's a + for Renault.<nl/>Aesthetics<nl/>Visual taste is, 
of course, a highly subjective matter — despite many people talking about how 'beautiful' or 'ugly' cars are as if it's 
a matter of fact. Personally, I love how the Zoe looks. The sales guy and I talked a bit, via my prompting, about 
what made buyers choose a Zoe over a Leaf, and it turned out the look was a big reason. I actually like the look of 
the Leaf quite a bit, but I do prefer the Zoe.<nl/>Zoe vs Leaf?<nl/>Other benefits over the Leaf, by the way, 
were reportedly a bit more range in real-world driving, and that the Zoe came with a single charging cable that 
provided various charging options whereas you'd have to get an extra charging cable for the Leaf to have the same 
capability.<nl/> I'd have to check out a Leaf again, and see pricing in the UK, to make a decision between these two 
vehicle. At the moment, though, I'm actually leaning toward the Zoe. Keep up to date with all the hottest cleantech 
news by subscribing to our (free) cleantech newsletter[18], or keep an eye on sector-specific news by getting our 
(also free) solar energy newsletter[19], electric vehicle newsletter[20], or wind energy newsletter[21]. <nl/><nl/>

30 Hainan Airline passengers injured after severe turbulence throws them from seats
30 Hainan Airline passengers injured after severe turbulence throws them 
from seats
Shanghaiist
August 12, 2015 Wednesday 4:49 AM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 403 words
Byline: Katie Nelson
Body
Aug 12, 2015( Shanghaiist: http://www.gothamist.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> A total of 30 passengers were 
injured when a Hainan Airlines flight began violently shaking as it was descending in Beijing yesterday afternoon. 
<nl/><nl/>Passengers onboard flight HU7148, which took off from Chengdu, Sichuan province, said people were 
thrown from their seats and described the experience as "terrifying".<nl/><nl/>Fortunately, the plane landed 
safely[1] at the Beijing Capital International at 2:17 p.m. Of the 30 people injured, 23 were sent to the hospital while 
seven of them suffered only minor wounds that didn't require medical attention. <nl/><nl/>One of the passengers, 
surnamed Lin, said many of the passengers were not wearing seat belts at the time. <nl/><nl/>"We heard two 
alarms at around 2:00 p.m. which were immediately followed by weightlessness. I didn't buckle up, so I was directly 
thrown to the ceiling and landed on the row behind us," Lin said.<nl/><nl/>'During the flight, I experienced the 
strongest shaking I have ever had on an airplane,' another passenger[2] wrote online.<nl/><nl/>'Seeing people 
behind me having their heads knocked [against the ceiling of the plane] and being covered in blood, hearing the air 
stewardess speak through a microphone in sobs, I was truly scared.'<nl/><nl/><nl/>One person onboard the flight 
posted an image of an overhead panel that was left dangling in the air after being damaged in the turbulence. 
<nl/><nl/>A representative with Hainan Airlines said[3] cabin crew had no pre warning about the rough air, likely 
contributing to the shock of the experience.<nl/><nl/><nl/>"Around 25 minutes before arrival in Beijing, the aircraft 
suddenly encountered clear air turbulence at the aircraft was descending to 42-hundred meters. Medium air 
turbulence lasted for one to two seconds, and then strong turbulence followed for two seconds. There was no sign 
of any turbulence in advance," the airliner said.<nl/><nl/>And that, Ryanair CEO Michael O'Leary[4], is why they put 
seat belts on planes.<nl/> [ 1]: http://china.org.cn/china/2015-08/12/content_36283869.htm [ 2]:            
http://www.scmp.com/news/china/society/article/1848702/chinese-passengers-crew-injured-after-flight-turbulence-

Allegiant Air Expands: Adds Routes, Unveils Low One-Way Fares
Allegiant Air Expands: Adds Routes, Unveils Low One-Way Fares
Zacks Investment Research
August 12, 2015 Wednesday 7:15 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 659 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
Aug 12, 2015( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Las Vegas-based 
Allegiant Travel Company ALGT[1], the parent company of Allegiant Air, announced the addition of multiple new 
routes, in a bid to expand further. In what can be deemed a customer-friendly move, the carrier has kept one-way 
fares as low as $49 for all the new routes and destinations.<nl/>
The expansion will allow travelers to fly to their favorite vacation spots at affordable costs. The carrier stated in its 
press release that fliers must purchase tickets by Aug 14, 2015 to avail the low-priced introductory offer for travel 
within Feb 16, 2016.<nl/>As part of the expansion drive, the carrier has decided to operate nonstop flights on as 
many as 17 new routes, including two new cities, San Antonio and Kansas City. The move naturally found favor 
with investors. Consequently, the stock was up 2.25% to $226.99 on Aug 11.<nl/>As per plans, the carrier will start 
operating nonstop flights connecting Oklahoma City and Las Vegas from Nov 5, 2015. Nonstop flights (twice a 
week) on three routes to Tampa Bay will also see the light of day from November. These new flights will connect 
the St. Pete-Clearwater International Airport in Florida to Appleton, WI (Nov 6); Scranton, PA (Nov 6) and Kansas 
City, MO (Nov 12). Furthermore, the carrier stated that it will fly nonstop, twice a week, connecting the Fort 
Lauderdale/Hollywood International Airport and San Antonio from Nov 5.<nl/>The expansion drive comes close on 
the heels of the carrier's impressive second-quarter 2015 results. The company reported earnings per share of 
$3.18 which surpassed the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $3.13. Quarterly revenues increased 10.9% year over 
year to $322 million, in line with the Zacks Consensus Estimate.<nl/>Zacks Rank<nl/>Allegiant Travel Company 
currently carries a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy). Other well-ranked stocks in the transportation sector include Ryanair 
Holdings RYAAY[2], China Eastern Airlines Corp. Ltd. CEA[3] and SkyWest Inc. SKYW[4]. All the three stocks carry 
a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy).<nl/>Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today,
