Airline Stocks Hit a Bullish Note - Global Week Ahead - Analyst Blog
Airline Stocks Hit a Bullish Note - Global Week Ahead - Analyst Blog
Newstex Blogs
Zacks Investment Research
August 10, 2015 Monday 5:50 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLCAll Rights Reserved
Length: 1106 words
Body
Aug 10, 2015( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  Global markets looked 
for a strong open on Monday. Why? Fed Vice Chair Stanley Fischer made a provocative statement to open the 
trading week. 
He commented-- global disinflation "is a factor that bothers us. It is not inevitable, it is not baked in the economies 
abroad, but it is there right now." In light of that, will the Fed hold off on raising rates a bit longer?  Last Friday, 
Zacks consensus poll was evenly split between Sept and Dec rate hikes. This week's key global indicators update 
us on the long-term Eurozone outlook. Is Europe still trapped in weak growth, or has European QE caused a boost? 
On Monday, the Eurozone Sentix indicator came out at 18.5, in line with its prior reading. On Tuesday, Germany's 
ZEQ survey will show financial professionals' optimism. It is likely to be around its long-term average. This is 
consistent with only moderate growth. On Wednesday, Eurozone industrial production could show output rose to a 
+1.7% y/y rate in June. Again, unchanged. On Friday, overall Eurozone Q2 output is likely to be unchanged too. 
The preliminary GDP growth data is projected to show +0.4% in quarterly growth. Q4-14 and Q1-15 recorded the 
same +0.4% GDP growth rate.  In other words, consensus doesn't think Europe's economy has budged. If any 
European macro data surprise this week, that would lift global stocks. Are you a bull and looking for a growth stock 
in Europe? Take a look at Zacks #1 Rank (Strong Buy) Ryanair Holdings (ticker RYAAY[1]). This Irish budget airline 
is in the sweet spot. Air transport benefits from lower oil prices, and the greater spending power of Europe's air 
vacationers. The bullish theme of a strong discretionary spender and weakening oil prices is not limited to the U.S. 
and Europe! In Asia, there are two more strong airline stocks to look into. Two current Zacks #1 Rank (Strong Buy) 
stocks I like are China Eastern Airlines (ticker CEA[2]) and Cathay Pacific Air (ticker CPCAY[3]).  Follow me on 
Twitter @johnblank100 to get my weekly comments on the Global Economy and Global Stocks. Here is the Global 
Week Ahead-- On Monday,in Japan, consumer confidence came in at 40.3, below the prior 41.7 reading. The more 
important Economy Watchers Survey in Japan also came out. It was 51.6, above the prior 51 reading. In Europe, 
the Eurozone Sentix indicator was flat at 18.5, in line with the prior reading, and below the consensus for 20.3. In 
Switzerland, the core CPI came in a t +2.6% y/y, below the prior +3.2% y/y rate. On Tuesday, the NAB (Australia) 
Business Confidence looks to be 10, while Business Conditions looks to be 11. The final HICP Italian inflation rate 
came in at +0.4% y/y, the same as the prior reading. The German ZEQ current conditions index looks to be 64.2, 
above the prior 63.9. The economic sentiment index looks to be 31.9, above the prior 29.7. The Bank of Japan 
releases its minutes.  OPEC releases its monthly oil market report. On Wednesday, the final reading for Industrial 
Production in Japan is projected to be +2% y/y. In comparison, Industrial Production in China is projected to be 
+6.6%, below the prior +6.8% reading. Retail sales in China should be +10.6%, and Urban Fixed Asset Investment 
Airline Stocks Hit a Bullish Note - Global Week Ahead - Analyst Blog
should be +11.4%. They should be unchanged from the prior readings. Central planning lives! The U.K. ILO 
unemployment rate looks to be 5.6%. The Eurozone Industrial Production number looks to be +1.7% y/y, basically 
in line with the prior +1.6% y/y rate. Portugal's HICP inflation rate should be +0.8% y/y. In Brazil, broad retail sales 
should be -4% y/y, better than the awful -10.4% y/y number, but still awful. Retail sales should be -2.9...y, better 
than the prior -4.5% y/y reading. In Japan, the very important Key Machinery Orders data comes out. The +17.6% 
y/y growth looks to be weaker than the prior +19.3% y/y reading. On Thursday, the Bank of Korea announces its 
interest rate decision. The BoK base rate should remain unchanged at 1.5%. The final German HICP inflation rate 
comes out. Look for +0.1% y/y. The French HICP inflation rate looks to be +0.3%. Those are near deflation 
readings. The Spanish HICP inflation rate should be -0.1% y/y. That is a deflation reading.  In Greece, the 
preliminary reading for GDP looks to be -0.6% y/y. That's worse than the prior +0.2% y/y reading. The protracted 
shutdown and negotiations made GDP worse for a quarter.  The ECB releases the minutes of its prior meeting. The 
Fed's Dudley speaks in Rochester. U.S. initial claims should be 270K. That's strong. The U.S. retail sales data (ex 
auto) comes out. Look for +0.4% y/y. That should turn around the prior -0.1% y/y reading. On Friday, the Greek CPI 
should be -0.1% y/y.  Preliminary GDP in Germany should be +1.5% y/y. Italy's preliminary GDP growth should be 
+0.5% y/y, better than the prior +0.1% y/y rate. The Eurozone GDP growth rate should be +0.4% in a preliminary 
reading. That's in line with the prior reading. The Eurozone HICP inflation rate should be +0.2% y/y. The Brazil 
proxy GDP growth rate should be -2.15% y/y, better than the prior -4.75% y/y rate, but still awful. The U.S. capacity 
utilization rate looks to be 78, better than the prior 77.8. The University of Michigan index should be 93.6, better

Ryanair broke a record in July
Ryanair broke a record in July
The Business Insider
August 5, 2015 Wednesday 8:20 AM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 348 words
Byline: Ben Moshinsky Ben Moshinsky
Body
Aug 05, 2015( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Did you 
wonder why your flight last month was so packed? Ryanair 's July passenger traffic zoomed up 11%, to break the 
10 million barrier.<nl/>
 The Irish no-frills airline claims to be the first ever to carry more than 10 million passengers in a month. <nl/> Kenny 
Jacobs, Ryanair's chief marketing officer, said: "For example we carried more customers in one month (10.14 
million in July) than Aer Lingus carried in a whole year (9.77 million in 2014)."<nl/> The company reported in 
April reported its full-year results [1]in May, which revealed a 12% jump in revenue to €5.65 billion (£3.95 billion) 
and a 66% rise in profit after tax to €867 million (£605 million), helped along by a plan to improve its customer 
service.<nl/><nl/>Here's the chart:<nl/><nl/> NOW WATCH: The 'Uber of helicopters' can get you from Manhattan

Lisbon Joins Europe's Capitals of Cool
Lisbon Joins Europe's Capitals of Cool
Pressat
August 5, 2015 Wednesday 10:53 AM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 973 words
Byline: Pressat
Body
Aug 05, 2015( Pressat: http://www.pressat.co.uk Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Wednesday 5 August, 2015<nl/> 
Portugal's capital may be packed with history, but it is also full of options for the travel trendsetter. With its vibrant 
nightlife, hip art spaces, quirky shopping and contemporary dining scene, Lisbon is a rising star among Europe's 
coolest cities.<nl/>Below are 10 travel ideas that affect the new face of Lisbon:<nl/>1. Savour gourmet canapés by 
the Portuguese Heston Blumenthal: A star chef in his home country, Michelin-starred José Avillez is Portugal's 
answer to Heston Blumenthal and Ferran Adrià. Mini Bar (           www.minibar.pt) is his latest opening, a casual bar 
with a retro décor, serving experimental yet affordable canapés and gourmet small plates for less than €5 per 
dish.<nl/>2. Hang out at Lisbon's coolest market: The Mercado de Campo de Ourique (           
www.mercadodecampodeourique.pt) has been the heart of the neighbourhood for more than 80 years - but after its 
recent renovation, you will find the traditional vegetable stalls next to gourmet food stands, fresh juice counters and 
bars serving all types of Portuguese wine.<nl/>
3. Party at the 'Pink Street': Until its recent makeover, riverside Cais do Sodré was one of the city's seediest 
neighbourhoods - but today Rua Nova do Carvalho is Lisbon's liveliest street for nightlife, packed with live music 
venues, burlesque clubs and tapas bars. Closed to the traffic, the street is painted with a cheerful bright pink colour, 
giving it its nickname 'Pink Street'.<nl/>4. Buy the perfect souvenir, quirky and 100% Portuguese:Located at the 
much-loved Terreiro do Paço, the Lisbon Shop (https://pt-br.facebook.com/LisbonShop) is the ideal place to buy 
that special gift and take with you a little part of Lisbon - from colourful tiles to urban design, quirky books to 
handmade jewellery, contemporary crafts to recycled materials.<nl/>5. See the likes of Picasso, Dalí, Bacon and 
Warhol for free:There is no entrance fee to visit Museu Colecção Berardo (           http://en.museuberardo.pt/). Its 
wide collection focuses on the major European and American art movements of the 20th and early 21st century, 
covering from surrealism, pop art and hyper-realism to minimalist and conceptual arts.<nl/>6. Take in the latest 
street art exhibition: Lisbon is one of the few capitals in the world to have a government division that encourages, 
promotes and funds street art. There is an 'official' exhibition wall by Galeria de Arte Urbana (           
www.facebook.com/galeriadearteurbana) in Bairro Alto, but you can see street art even on waste collection trucks 
and bottle banks!<nl/>7. Be wowed by one of the best fashion and design collections in Europe: The stark exhibition 
rooms of MUDE (           www.mude.pt), formerly a bank, make its exhibits really pop. Featuring iconic works from 
the design and fashion's world greatest from 1937 to present, this is where Phillipe Starck and Charles Eames 
come together with Jean Paul Gaultier and Vivienne Westwood.<nl/>8. Dine alfresco at Lisbon's latest hotspot: U 
Chiado Trendy Bar ...staurant (           http://uchiado.pt) offers all things to all people and at all hours, both indoors 
and outdoors, from snacks to sushi, weekend brunches to exotic cocktails. Industrial chic is the theme here - and if 
Lisbon Joins Europe's Capitals of Cool
you prefer a late dinner alfresco, the cosy terrace comes with warm blankets available.<nl/>9. Pay a late night visit 
to the impressive Museu do Oriente:The riverfront Museu do Oriente (           www.museudooriente.pt) is so 
superbly converted that few would guess that until a few years ago it was a salt cod warehouse! Open until late 
every Friday, it brings to the forefront the history of Portugal in the Far East during the Age of Discovery.<nl/>10. 
Head to bohemian Bairro Alto for all things vintage and alternative: Once one of the city's least desirable areas, 
today the backstreets of Bairro Alto are crammed with alternative shops, hip hairdressers and fashionable bars. 
Vintage rules in this sassy bohemian enclave, where you can pick up outrageous hand-me-down attires and heaps 
of odd accessories.<nl/>Direct flights to Lisbon operate from London, Manchester, Liverpool, Edinburgh and Bristol 
with TAP Portugal, British Airways, easyJet and Ryanair.<nl/>For more information visiting Lisbon please go to            
www.visitlisboa.com.<nl/>-ENDS-<nl/>For media information and images, please contact: Tom Panagos: 0845 498 
9980 or tom@humewhitehead.co.uk Enrique Martin: 0845 498 9984 or enrique@humewhitehead.co.uk;<nl/>About 
Lisbon<nl/>Portugal's national capital, Lisbon, boasts one of the longest histories, warmest climates and bustling 
nightlife of any major European city alongside its dramatic location sprawled along seven hills overlooking the river 
Tagus and the country's west coast. Famed for its year-round sunshine and beauty, Lisbon's grand architecture 
dazzles and its old-world charm mingles with chic streets, galleries, lively nightlife and a centre which gives way to 
sandy beaches just minutes away. It is also one of the most affordable capitals in Europe, perfect for a captivating 
city break or short haul escape.<nl/>           www.visitlisboa.com<nl/>About Turismo de Lisboa<nl/>Turismo de 
Lisboa is a non-profit organisation established through an alliance of public and private bodies operating in the 
tourist sector. It now has 713 associated members. Since its inception in 1998, the main objective of this 
association is to improve and increase the promotion of Lisbon as a tourist destination and therefore enhance the 
quality and competitiveness of the city.<nl/><nl/> No media attached. Please contact Pressat Wire for more 
information.<nl/><nl/> Distributed by            http://www.pressat.co.uk/[1]<nl/> [ 1]:            http://www.pressat.co.uk/ 
Load-Date: August 5, 2015
End of Document
Expeditors Beats on Earnings, Misses on Revenues in Q2 - Analyst Blog
Expeditors Beats on Earnings, Misses on Revenues in Q2 - Analyst Blog
Zacks Investment Research
August 4, 2015 Tuesday 7:15 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 669 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
Aug 04, 2015( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Expeditors 
International of Washington Inc.'s EXPD[1] second-quarter 2015 earnings of 61 cents per share beat the Zacks 
Consensus Estimate by 8 cents. Earnings improved 33% on a year-over-year basis.<nl/>//           
www.findthebest.com/w/fAz5DXtDVMF[2] Expeditors International of Washington Inc. 
- Earnings Surprise | FindTheBest[3] Total revenue of $1.69 billion fell short of the Zacks Consensus Estimate of 
$1.74 billion. Revenues climbed 6% from the year-ago figure. Strong air freight and ocean freight revenues 
facilitated the year-over-year top-line improvement in the second quarter.<nl/>Gross profit (net revenue) increased 
14% year over year in the second quarter to $552.1 million. Gross margin (yield) improved to 32.6% in the reported 
quarter. Expeditors exited the second quarter with cash and cash equivalents of $985.7 million as compared with 
$927.1 million at the end of 2014.<nl/>Segmental Revenues<nl/>Airfreight Services revenues improved 4% year 
over year to $693.8 million in the second quarter. Ocean Freight and Ocean Services revenues increased 7.5% 
year over year to $576.8 million. Customs Brokerage and Other Services revenues rose 6.5% to approximately 
$421 million.<nl/>Our Take<nl/>We are pleased by Expeditors' earnings outperformance in second-quarter 2015, 
which marks the fourth successive earnings beat at the company. We believe continued strength in the airfreight 
business, led by growing trade between the U.S. and China, places the company favorably in the freight forwarding 
and customer brokerage business. Furthermore, the company's growing supply chain and cost-control measures 
should support revenue and margin expansion, going forward.<nl/>Zacks Rank<nl/>Currently, Expeditors has a 
Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). Better-ranked stocks in the transportation sector include China Eastern Airlines CEA[4], 
Ryanair Holdings RYAAY[5] and Allegiant Travel Company ALGT[6]. All the three stocks carry a Zacks Rank #1 
(Strong Buy).<nl/>Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today, you can download 7 
Best Stocks for the Next 30 Days. Click to get this free report >>[7]<nl/>Want the latest recommendations from

Delta Air Lines (DAL) to Ban Trophy Animal Shipments on Flights - Analyst Blog
Delta Air Lines (DAL) to Ban Trophy Animal Shipments on Flights - Analyst 
Blog
Zacks Investment Research
August 4, 2015 Tuesday 8:35 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 770 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
Aug 04, 2015( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Following the furor 
surrounding the killing of the lion Cecil at Zimbabwe's Hwange National Park, Georgia-based Delta Air Lines 
DAL[1], which has operations in Africa, issued a statement banning shipments of trophy kills on its 
aircraft.<nl/>Cecil, who was part of a 13-year Oxford University study, was hunted down last month by a Minnesota-
based dentist, Walter Palmer, along with a group of hunters including local guide Theo Bronkhorst, using bows and 
arrows. 
The dentist was on a vacation in Zimbabwe and, according to a report appearing in Fortune, paid a fee of $50,000 
for the trophy hunting.<nl/>The killing of the much-loved 13-year old African lion has sparked an outrage across the 
globe. The incident is being investigated by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, according to a report appearing in 
Bloomberg.<nl/>Following the killing, animal rights groups are demanding a ban on trophy hunting. Moreover, the 
African nation has requested for the extradition of the dentist, whose gross act has invited criticism from all 
quarters. Moreover, according to the Bloomberg report, wildlife authorities in Zimbabwe have pulled the strings on 
hunting of lions, leopards and elephants in select areas near the Hwange National Park - Zimbabwe's biggest 
animal sanctuary. Rumors surfaced that another lion, Jericho (possibly Cecil's brother), has also been killed by 
poachers. However, the rumors have thankfully been put to rest with the reports proven to be false.<nl/>In this 
backdrop, Delta has taken strict measures to ban transportation of trophies of lions, leopards, elephants, rhinoceros 
and buffalos as cargo on its planes. Even though the carrier has not mentioned the Cecil incident as a reason 
behind its decision, the move will surely find favor with animal protection groups. A message posted on the airline's 
website stated, 'Prior to this ban, Delta's strict acceptance policy called for absolute compliance with all government 
regulations regarding protected species. Delta will also review acceptance policies of other hunting trophies with 
appropriate government agencies and other organizations supporting legal shipments."<nl/>Delta is the latest 
airline to announce a ban on shipment of hunting trophies. Many foreign carriers have earlier announced similar 
bans. We expect investors to stay tuned on further updates from the airline space pertaining to this sensitive 
issue.<nl/>Zacks Rank<nl/>Delta currently carries a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). Better-ranked stocks in the airline space 
include China Eastern Airlines CEA[2], Ryanair Holdings RYAAY[3] and Allegiant Travel Company ALGT[4]. All the 
three stocks carry a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy).<nl/>Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment 
Research? Today, you can download 7 Best Stocks for the Next 30 Days.Click to get this free report[5]>><nl/>Want 
the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today, you can download 7 Best Stocks for the 
Next 30 Days. Click to get this free report[6] RYANAIR HLDGS (RYAAY): Free Stock Analysis Report[7] DELTA

Friday fantasies
Friday fantasies
Newstex Blogs
IPKat Weblog
July 31, 2015 Friday 1:08 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLCAll Rights Reserved
Length: 955 words
Body
Jul 31, 2015( IPKat Weblog: http://ipkitten.blogspot.com Delivered by Newstex)             http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-
Wq0aN-MXOcg/VbtGFOhYmHI/AAAAAAAA8Ck/lYQtOMOuT5w/s1600/wain.jpg Twitter jokes: Katpost goes viral 
and it's no joke! "Lifting Jokes on Twitter", recently posted [1]to this weblog by leading copyright Kat Eleonora, has 
attracted the attention of the wider media. First we learned that this article on Twitter's take-down of tweets that 
allegedly infringed copyright had been picked up[2] by practitioners' publication Legal Week. Then we discovered 
that our good friends at Managing Intellectual Property had been giving it some air[3]. Says the IPKat, it's lovely to 
know that what we post on this weblog is put to good use by others. Adds Merpel, yes, just like you put their content 
to 
good 
use 
too 
... 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-
mL3sFtvMjgM/VbtWVHi8QvI/AAAAAAAA8DU/M6GDK2LW6mI/s1600/soon.jpgForthcoming attractions. 
Apart from the IPKat's frequent Friday reminder that there are lots of great events coming up, which you can check 
on his Forthcoming Events page[4], it's also the dawn of a new month -- August -- which means that it's time for the 
monthly Queen Mary Journal of Intellectual Property summary of events [5]coming up in that lovely month. Talking 
of events, the next JIPLP-GRUR London seminar, on IP Enforcement in the wake of the IP Enforcement Directive,, 
is coming up on 8 September: more than 60 people have now registered, but there's still room for more. Details of 
this seminar, which is free and has this Kat in the chair, can be accessed here[6].http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-
mqKGwFjQ0Pg/VbtQDKsaUII/AAAAAAAA8C8/q5In1XoQByk/s1600/bosphorus-bridge.jpgPatents 
for 
second 
medical use, coming to a Bosphorus near you. The mysteries of the patentability of a substance that already has 
one known medical use, one a further medical use is found for it, have been recently addressed in numerous 
Katposts on the litigation in England and Wales between Warner-Lambert and Actavis, most recently here [7]and 
here[8]. This Kat thanks his friends at the Turkish IP practice of Deri  for the information that Turkish practice, 
following that of the European Patent Convention, indicates that patents are available there for second medical use. 
Thanks go to Okan Can for sending him this link[9] to the piece he wrote together with his colleagues.           
http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-CnR4_dJnaPc/VbtYK4N0BuI/AAAAAAAA8Dg/Ffw8wbPXCs0/s1600/navy.jpgAround 
the 
weblogs. "Old Money, Old Navy, Fabric Copyright Infringement Suit, Oh Dear!" is Marie-Andrie Weiss's instructive 
post[10] on the 1709 Blog about a US copyright infringement action involving fabric designs (clothing designs per se 
are unprotected by copyright law on the basis that they are "useful articles"). There's also a CopyKat post [11]from 
Ben Challis with a round-up that includes the latest on the sad saga of copyright in that eternal dirge "Happy 
Birthday to You". The jiplp weblog features a note [12]by Indranath Gupta and Vishwas H. Devaiah on the Court of 
Justice of the European Union ruling in Ryanair v PR Aviation, on whether the"you can't contract out" provisions of 
the Database Directive apply to data that isn't protected as well as to data which is. PatLit carries a helpful account 
Friday fantasies
[13]by Marquis Jarque and Silvia Saenz de Ormijana on the new Spanish Patent Act and what it foretells for a 
jurisdiction that is determined not to be marginal in innovation terms, whatever it feels about the new European 
patent 
package. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-
wkRWEANmZls/VbtCX4bosUI/AAAAAAAA8CY/r1fsKsZ694I/s1600/netflix.jpgIn brief, and now at length. The 
AmeriKat neatly potted this month's resolution of the major US patent dispute between Netflix and Rovi, relating to 
five Rovi patents covering interactive programme guides and multiple-device playback, in a single succinct 
paragraph here[14]. Katfriend Kevin Winters[15], not to be outdone, has prepared his own summary of this decision 
which stretches to a little over 4,000 words: you can check it out here[16]. [ 1]:

Causeway International Value Fund June 30, 2015 Commentary
Causeway International Value Fund June 30, 2015 Commentary
Phil's Stock World
July 16, 2015 Thursday 9:40 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 713 words
Byline: ValueWalk
Body
Jul 16, 2015( Phil's Stock World: http://www.philstockworld.com Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> By VW Staff. 
Originally published at ValueWalk[1].<nl/><nl/>Causeway International Value Fund performance review for 
the month ended June 30, 2015.<nl/>Causeway International Value Fund: Commentary<nl/>Concerns of US 
monetary tightening, weakening global growth, and the Greek debt crisis pressured global equity markets in the 
month of June. All but one developed market, Ireland, delivered negative returns in the period. Other top performing 
markets in the developed world included Belgium, Israel, Singapore, and Japan. The biggest laggards in our 
investable universe included New Zealand, Australia, South Korea, Switzerland, and Norway. The best performing 
sectors in the MSCI EAFE Index ('Index') were telecommunication services, financials, health care, consumer 
Staples, Inc. (NASDAQ:SPLS[2]), and consumer discretionary. The worst performing sectors in the Index were 
utilities, materials, energy, information technology, and industrials. Every major currency except the Canadian dollar 
appreciated versus the US dollar during the period, thus improving overall returns on overseas assets for US dollar-
based investors.<nl/>            http://www.valuewalk.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/Causeway-International-Value-
Fund-1.jpg<nl/>Causeway International Value Fund: Performance review<nl/>
The Fund modestly underperformed the Index during the month. Fund holdings in the automobiles ...mponents, 
food beverage ...bacco, consumer durables ...parel, utilities, and insurance industry groups detracted from relative 
performance versus the Index in June. Fund holdings in the consumer services, materials, and commercial 
...ofessional services industry groups, as well as an overweight position in the telecommunication services industry 
group and an underweight position in the real estate industry group, offset some of this relative underperformance. 
The largest single detractor from performance was automaker, Hyundai Motor Co (KRX:005380[3]) Co., Ltd. (South 
Korea). Other notable detractors included baked goods food producer, Aryzta AG (Switzerland), energy 
management firm, Schneider Electric SE (France), paints ...atings producer, Akzo Nobel NV (Netherlands), and 
pharmaceutical ...nsumer healthcare company, GlaxoSmithKline Plc (United Kingdom). The largest individual 
positive contributor to return was telecommunication services provider, KDDI Corp. (Japan). Additional top 
contributors during the period included cruise ship operator, Carnival (United Kingdom), financial services provider, 
Credit Suisse Group AG (ADR) (NYSE:CS[4]) (Switzerland), low-budget airline, Ryanair Holdings plc 
(ADR) (NASDAQ:RYAAY[5]) (LON:RYA[6]) Holdings Plc (Ireland), and low-voltage electronics manufacturer, 
Legrand 
SA 
(France).<nl/>

International-Value-Fund-4.jpg<nl/> The market commentary expresses the portfolio managers' views as of the 
date of this report and should not be relied on as research or investment advice regarding any stock. These views 
and the Fund holdings and characteristics are subject to change. There is no guarantee that any forecasts made 
Causeway International Value Fund June 30, 2015 Commentary

The Purge Begins: Tsipras To Expel Hard Core Left Wingers, Including Energy And Deputy Labor Ministers
The Purge Begins: Tsipras To Expel Hard Core Left Wingers, Including 
Energy And Deputy Labor Ministers
Phil's Stock World
July 12, 2015 Sunday 10:25 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 1186 words
Byline: Zero Hedge
Body
Jul 12, 2015( Phil's Stock World: http://www.philstockworld.com Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Courtesy of 
ZeroHedge[1]. View original post here[2].<nl/> Submitted by Tyler Durden.<nl/> In the first sellside reaction to the 
latest Greek tragicomedy, moments ago Citi's Richard Cochinos, in a note titled '72 hours for Greece' said what our 
readers have already known for about 6 hours: namely that 'Greece will have 72 hours to implement the changes' 
and goes straight to the bottom line: 'If they are unable to get the package through parliament, then this ends the 
dialogue and the government collapses.<nl/>
 He adds that 'the issue that Greece faces is it might not be possible - cracks in Syriza appeared already over the 
proposal sent to Brussels, what is coming back is even more stringent than the rejected referendum. There is a 
decent chance the Greek government will reshuffle next week, possibly fold on reforms. Domestically they can't 
afford 3-4 weeks for new elections. The Economic Minister has suggested capital controls will remain in place for 
the next two-months (though they may be lightened). During the tourist season this is proving to be a death touch to 
the economy. RyanAir announced last week it is discounting flights to Greece by 30% due to low volumes.'<nl/> We 
had a more directed view: in light of his 'mental waterboarding', Tsipras who has already lost all his credibility with 
both his people and the Troika, should do the only possible thing he can at this point: preserve some integrity with 
his voters, and resign… <nl/> Following the 'mental waterboarding' Tsipras should resign right now 
https://t.co/bhGJaPFiTj[3]<nl/> — zerohedge (@zerohedge) July 12, 2015[4]<nl/><nl/> <nl/> … knowing full well 
that it is very likely that Syriza would be re-elected in the next elections, but meanwhile throwing the ball in Europe's 
court for the final time, forcing the Eurozone to make the Grexit decision instead of, as Merkel has done passive-
aggressively, letting Greece to pick its own poison. Also, in doing so, the blame for the collapse of the Eurozone 
would fall on Germany, something Merkel's ego would hardly be able to withstand. ;<nl/> And as if reading the 
collective's mind, Tsipras did already begin the governmental reshuffling, only instead of quitting he has started the 
purge of the hard-core leftwingers still defending the anti-bailout platform, who are certain to make life a living hell 
for the premier once he returns to Athens from Brussels and has to explain his actions to both his party and to the 
population.<nl/> As Reuters reports, the first targets of Tsipras purge of 'party rebels opposed to an austerity 
package that will have to go through parliament within days' include the most prominent rebels, Energy Minister 
Panagiotis Lafazanis, leader of the so-called 'Left Platform' within Syriza and Deputy Labour Minister Dimitris 
Stratoulis, a former unionist and a fierce opponent of pension cuts. <nl/> Under a Syriza party agreement, deputies 
are supposed to resign their seats if they publicly disagree with government policy although there is nothing to stop 
them refusing to stand down and holding on to their seats as independents.<nl/> Terence Quick, a member of the 
The Purge Begins: Tsipras To Expel Hard Core Left Wingers, Including Energy And Deputy Labor Ministers
rightwing Independent Greeks, the junior coalition partner in the government, said that any deputies who voted 
against the government should resign.<nl/> 'I don't think abstaining or being absent shows you are responsible or 
honorable in these particular circumstances. You either go in and say a forceful no and you leave or you say 'Yes' 
and you continue to fight,' he said<nl/><nl/>The next scalp Tsipras would love to have is that of the 
'uncompromising speaker of parliament, Zoe Constantopoulou, who also defied Tsipras and abstained from the 
vote' although she would require a no confidence vote to be replaced 'but the other rebels would be expected to 
resign their seats, the same people say.'<nl/> And if not resign they will simply be among the first group of party 
leaders sacked, with many more to come as Tsipras effectively morphs into his predecessor Samaras. <nl/> 
According to Reuters, the 40-year-old prime minister 'can not afford to wait' because 'a mini-rebellion of lawmakers 
on Friday laid bare tensions in the ruling Syriza party. The revolt saw 17 deputies from the government benches 
withhold support in a vote to authorise bailout negotiations, leaving Tsipras reliant on opposition parties to pass the 
measure.' <nl/> Dealing with the consequences of that revolt will provide a clear signal of how determined Tsipras 
will be in pushing through the reforms European partners are demanding. <nl/> Whether cooperation with 
opposition parties leads to a full-scale national unity government, with seats in the cabinet is still unclear but the 
change has left the future of the radical leftwing government in doubt. The government has 162 seats in the 300 
seat parliament.<nl/><nl/>Then again after Friday's vote, and following this weekend's crushing blow by the Troika, 
it is almost certain that many Syriza loyalists will exit the party, either voluntarily or otherwise, leaving the ruling 
coalition with a minority vote, which in turn will likely result in a few round of government elections within 2-3 
months. <nl/> However, the purge will be only the first of many hurdles now facing the morally and financially 
bankrupt government:<nl/> Clearing out the leftwingers still defending the anti-bailout platform on which Syriza won 
power in January would underline how seriously the situation has worsened for Greece in the past six months.<nl/> 
With the financial system on the brink of collapse and shuttered banks running short of cash, the six-year Greek 
crisis has escalated dangerously, forcing Tsipras to change course only a week after voters resoundingly rejected a 
milder package of bailout terms in a referendum. <nl/> There are also questions about how stable any such 
government would prove, given the deep ideological differences between Syriza and the centre-right New 
Democracy or Socialist Pasok parties.<nl/><nl/>But the biggest hurdle is not what Tsipras will do to the 
government, but rather what, if anything, the Greek people will do to Tsipras. If they have had enough, they may 
just shift from the 'radical left' to the 'radical right' as the only remaining political party that hasn't promised the sun, 
moon and stars, or been terminally discredited. <nl/> Unless, of course, the population, so disenchanted by the 
endless game of political thrones, becomes the first social manifestation of 'learned helplessness[5]' and simply 
refuses to care, instead opting to go gentle into that good night and with it taking what was once the world's oldest 
democracy.<nl/> [ 1]:            http://www.zerohedge.com/ [ 2]:            http://www.zerohedge.com/news/2015-07-
12/purge-begins-tsipras-expel-hard-core-left-wingers-including-energy-and-deputy-labor- 
[ 
3]: 
 
 
 
 
 
 
     
https://t.co/bhGJaPFiTj [ 4]:            https://twitter.com/zerohedge/status/620299602105733120 [ 5]:            
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Learned_helplessness

Airline Face-to-Face Flying Not Going Over Too Well
Airline Face-to-Face Flying Not Going Over Too Well
WKRB News and Analysis
July 11, 2015 Saturday 6:23 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 355 words
Byline: David
Body
Jul 11, 2015( WKRB News and Analysis: http://www.wkrb13.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/>            
http://www.wkrb13.com/images/wrkb-19.jpgBudget flights already can be considered cramped, noisy and stuffy, but 
things could become a great deal worse. 
A patent was recently filed by Zodiac Seats France an airline industry supplier. The patent proposes to squeeze 
even more passengers into planes by turning passengers around so they will be facing one another.<nl/> It would 
have the middle seat in each section of three be reversed meaning that passenger would be facing two other 
people during the flight.<nl/> The diagrams supplied in the patent filing show in detail that arms would intertwine, 
making for a trip that is even more intimate that currently.<nl/> Zodiac has given it the name Economy Class Cabin 
Hexagon, because of the rough shape it creates when looked at from above.<nl/> Zodiac says that along with 
increasing the density of cabin passengers, the passengers themselves would also benefit from additional shoulder 
space.<nl/> This is not any guarantee that the new formation in seating will actually come to fruition, but it is 
another example of how it could become even worse to travel aboard budget airlines.<nl/> This is not the first time 
there has been an attempt by the airline industry to squeeze more people into the economy class cabin.<nl/> 
Ryanair CEO Michael O'Leary as showed interest previously in what are called standing seats as a method of 
lowering prices on plane tickets.<nl/> The way the new hexagon is set up there could be problems when a flight 
experiences turbulence and when someone wants to get out of their seat for whatever reason.<nl/> When the news 
of this first broke, both online and social media news showed that many people were not enthused with what might 
take place.<nl/> Tweets were very critical of the idea saying that it would make flying the discount airlines that much 
more difficult. Others questioned if the saving of having more passengers on board for the airlines was worth 
upsetting and possibly losing overall passenger count due to discontent.<nl/>lade<nl/> 
Load-Date: July 11, 2015
End of Document
Ryanair takes on Trade Unions across Europe
Ryanair takes on Trade Unions across Europe
New Europe
July 10, 2015 Friday 2:52 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 330 words
Byline: roubanis
Body
Jul 10, 2015( New Europe: http://neurope.eu Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Share on Facebook<nl/> Share on 
Twitter<nl/> Share on Google+<nl/> Share on LinkedIn<nl/><nl/><nl/>On Friday, Ryanair announced it would be 
closing down its base in Denmark, Copenhagen, base resettling in Kaunus, Lithuania, in response to the planned 
union strike on July 18th.<nl/> The Danish Confederation of Trade Unions (LO) responded by saying that strikes 
against Ryanair will take place not only in Copenhagen but also in Billund and Aarhus. The company warned that 
Ryanair would respond in kind, shutting down bases in Denmark.<nl/>           http://www.neurope.eu/article/ryanair-
takes-on-trade-unions-across-europe/#socialbuzz-bottom-infinite-view-402584<nl/> LO has recently won a case 
against Ryanair in Denmark's Labout Court, which stipulates than Ryanair must adhere to Danish rather than Irish 
labour law in Denmark. 
Therefore, strike action is legal. Ryan<nl/> Ryanair has been fighting unions across Europe, kicking off last week a 
public online campaign aimed at banning the right to strike by air traffic controllers. This will be known as the 'Keep 
Europe's Skies Open[1]' campaign, with the objective of obtaining one million petition signatures to urge the EU 
Commission and the European Parliament to take action.<nl/> The campaign coincided with a strike last Thursday 
(2-4, July) by the French ATC union. Ryanair wants nothing less than removing the right to strike from ATC unions, 
bringing Europe in line with the US regime.<nl/> Ryanair chief marketing officer Kenny Jacobs told the Financial 
Times that the situation was 'unacceptable,' adding that controllers used 'strikes as a first weapon rather than a last 
resort.'<nl/> Spain's ATC union will strike twice in July (11-12 and 25-26), in what is regarded as high season in 
Europe.<nl/><nl/> Share on Facebook<nl/> Share on Twitter<nl/> Share on Google+<nl/> Share on LinkedIn<nl/> [ 
1]: http://www.keepeuropesskiesopen.com/

Ryanair caved under pressure and just accepted IAG's £961 million takeover of Aer Lingus
Ryanair caved under pressure and just accepted IAG's £961 million takeover 
of Aer Lingus
The Business Insider
July 10, 2015 Friday 8:15 AM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 483 words
Byline: owilliamsgrut@businessinsider.com,  (Oscar Williams-Grut) Oscar Williams-Grut
Body
Jul 10, 2015( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) ;<nl/> British Airways 
owner International Airlines Group (IAG) is buying Irish national carrier Aer Lingus, after Ryanair rolled over and 
accepted the deal[1].<nl/> IAG has targetted Irish national carrier Aer Lingus for months. 
Its latest €1.36 billion (£961 million) bid was OK'd by the Irish government in late May[2], leaving Aer Lingus' biggest 
shareholder Ryanair the only obstacle.<nl/> Budget airline Ryanair owns 29.8% of Aer Lingus and many thought it 
would try to block the bid. Ryanair has made three unsuccessful attempts to buy Aer Lingus[3]. It is currently under 
orders from the UK's Competition and Markets Authority to sell its stake[4], something Ryanair heavily 
contested[5].<nl/> But Ryanair said today that it has "voted unanimously" to accept the bid from IAG, which owns 
British Airways and Spanish airline Iberia.<nl/> Ryanair's colourful CEO Michael O'Leary said in a statement 
today[6]: "We believe the IAG offer for Aer Lingus is a reasonable one in the current market and we plan to accept 
it, in the best interests of Ryanair shareholders. The price means that Ryanair will make a small profit on its 
investment in Aer Lingus over the past 9 years."<nl/> But he couldn't resist a parting dig, adding: "We wish IAG well 
with their takeover of Aer Lingus. When Ryanair first bid for Aer Lingus in late 2006, Ryanair (36m passengers) 
carried 4 times Aer Lingus traffic (9m). Today Ryanair (over 100m) carries more than 10 times Aer Lingus traffic 
(10m), and we will continue to deliver the vast majority of Ireland's traffic and tourism growth in the coming months 
and 
years."<nl/>NOW 
WATCH: 
Here's 
how 
Cristiano 
Ronaldo 
spends 
his 
money[7]<nl/>

Jul 09, 2015 (Market News Video:http://marketnewsvideo.com/ Delivered by Newstex)
 Looking at units outstanding versus one week prior within the universe of ETFs covered at ETF Channel, the 
biggest outflow was seen in the iShares MSCI EAFE ETF (EFA), where 13,200,000 units were destroyed, or a 1.4% 
decrease week over week. Among the largest underlying components of EFA, in morning trading today Ryanair 
Holdings (RYAAY) is up about 1.6%. 
And on a percentage change basis, the ETF with the biggest outflow was the MLP and Energy Infrastructure ETF 
(MLPX), which lost 3,700,000 of its units, representing a 32.3% decline in outstanding units compared to the week 
prior. Among the largest underlying components of MLPX, in morning trading today Antero Midstream Partners 
(AM) is up about 1.2%, and Boardwalk Pipeline Partners (BWP) is up by about 0.3%.

Ryanair (RYAAY) Plans to Launch Flights to Israel at $32 - Analyst Blog
Ryanair (RYAAY) Plans to Launch Flights to Israel at $32 - Analyst Blog
Zacks Investment Research
July 8, 2015 Wednesday 5:55 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 771 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
Jul 08, 2015( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> In line with its 
ambitious five-year expansion plans, Irish low-cost carrier Ryanair Holdings plc RYAAY[1] has decided to introduce 
round-trip flights to Israel for as low as $32.<nl/>Ryanair connects 170 cities in Europe, inclusive of the less popular 
destinations, at reasonable fares. 
Interestingly, Israel is the 31st market to be entered by Ryanair. The inclusion of Israel will certainly enhance 
Ryanair's network in the Middle East.<nl/>Ryanair will flag-off bi-weekly flights starting Nov 2015 from Budapest, 
Kaunas and Krakow to Israel's Ovda airport, near the Red Sea resort town of Eilat. Gradually, the carrier plans to 
expand its service to other Middle East cities. Ryanair also expects to fly nearly 40,000 passengers every year on 
this route.<nl/>Going forward, Ryanair plans to initiate flights from Israel's popular Tel Aviv Ben Gurion airport which 
is being served by carriers like EasyJet, Wizz Air and Norwegian. In 2013, Israel entered into an 'Open Skies' deal 
with the European Union, thereby allowing more direct flight service to other European nations.<nl/>Meanwhile, a 
few days back, Ryanair announced plans of extending its operations from Edinbergh to Copenhagen with three 
weekly services starting Nov 6, 2015.<nl/>Also, to forge ahead with its expansion plans, Ryanair will connect 
around 14 cities like London, Berlin and Dublin in Europe and a dozen locations in the U.S., including cities like 
New York, Boston and Chicago. Moreover, the carrier intends to fly around 100 million passengers this 
year.<nl/>To support such large-scale expansion, Ryanair has decided to expand its fleet size by adding Boeing 
787 Dreamliners. The company has also placed an order for 183 Boeing 737 aircraft and 200 Boeing MAX 200 
planes.<nl/>Recently, the Ryanair reported impressive air traffic numbers for the month of June. Traffic - measured 
in revenue passenger miles (RPMs) - stood at 9.5 million, up 14% from 8.3 million recorded in the comparable 
month a year ago. The load factor for the month was 93% against 88% in Jun 2014. The company also expects 
fiscal 2016 traffic to exceed 100 million with load factor likely to reach 90%.<nl/>Braving all economic odds, Ryanair 
has been performing well over the last 30 years, surpassing the performance of most European carriers. Further, 
we expect Ryanair to gain significantly from the Israel route addition.<nl/>Stocks to Consider<nl/>Ryanair currently 
carries a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). Better-ranked stocks in the same space include Deutsche Lufthansa 
Aktiengesellschaft DLAKY[2], SkyWest Inc. SKYW[3] and China Eastern Airlines Corp. Ltd. CEA[4]. All the three 
companies carry a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy).<nl/>Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? 
Today, you can download 7 Best Stocks for the Next 30 Days. Click to get this free report >>[5]<nl/>Want the latest 
recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today, you can download 7 Best Stocks for the Next 30 Days.

(CEA): Free Stock Analysis Report[8] SKYWEST INC (SKYW): Free Stock Analysis Report[9] LUFTHANSA -ADR

Ryanair against union action rights
Ryanair against union action rights
New Europe
July 2, 2015 Thursday 11:27 AM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 282 words
Byline: roubanis
Body
Jul 02, 2015( New Europe: http://neurope.eu Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Share on Facebook<nl/> Share on 
Twitter<nl/> Share on Google+<nl/> Share on LinkedIn<nl/><nl/><nl/>On Wednesday, Ryanair announced it was 
initiating a public online campaign aimed at banning the right to strike by air traffic controllers. This will be known as 
the 'Keep Europe's Skies Open[1]' campaign, with the objective of obtaining one million petition signatures to urge 
the EU Commission and the European Parliament to take action.<nl/> The low cost Irish airliner is arguing that this 
campaign is designed to defend consumers from Air Traffic Control (ATC) union strikes.<nl/>           
http://www.neurope.eu/article/ryanair-against-union-action-rights/#socialbuzz-bottom-infinite-view-399570<nl/> The 
kick off of the campaign coincides with a strike that begins on Thursday (2-4, July) by the French ATC union. 
The company argues that since 2009, the French ATC union has gone on strike for 39 days.<nl/> The company 
wants nothing less than removing the right to strike from ATC unions, bringing Europe in line with the US regime. 
Ryanair chief marketing officer Kenny Jacobs told the Financial Times that the situation was 'unacceptable,' adding 
that controllers used 'strikes as a first weapon rather than a last resort.'<nl/> Spain's ATC union will strike twice in 
July (11-12 and 25-26), in what is regarded as high season in Europe.<nl/> Alternatively, Ryanair suggests that air 
controllers from other EU member states should be allowed to take over traffic control.<nl/><nl/> Share on

on 
Google+<nl/> 
Share 
on 
LinkedIn<nl/>

Ryanair Have a Typically Efficient and Cost Effective Solution
Guido Fawkes' Blog
July 2, 2015 Thursday 5:12 AM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 174 words
Byline: Neo-Guido
Body
Jul 01, 2015( Guido Fawkes' Blog: http://www.order-order.com Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Ryanair have a long 
term economic plan, to allow Britain to compete in the global race:<nl/> 'Ryanair believes that the proposed 
Heathrow runway - which won't be delivered for 10 or 15 years - won't solve the runway capacity crisis in the South 
East. Ryanair strongly advocates taking politicians out of runway decision making and allowing each of the three 
London airports, Heathrow, Gatwick and Stansted, to build 3 competing runways which will solve the capacity crisis 
in the South East for the next 100 years, while at the same time allowing competition between the airports to deliver 
this capacity efficiently. It remains a fact that additional runways in Stansted and Gatwick can and will be delivered 
much earlier than any Heathrow third runway.'<nl/> Even better if the airports want to pay for it…<nl/> Tagged:

Ryanair is waging war on France 's air traffic controllers
Ryanair is waging war on France's air traffic controllers
The Business Insider
July 1, 2015 Wednesday 10:30 AM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 388 words
Byline: owilliamsgrut@businessinsider.com,  (Oscar Williams-Grut) Oscar Williams-Grut
Body
Jul 01, 2015( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) ;<nl/> Ryanair is calling 
for a crackdown on France's air traffic controllers and it wants the public to help it out.<nl/>
 The budget Irish airline has launched an online petition[1] calling for the European Commission to crackdown on 
the number of strikes French air traffic controllers (ATCs) declare.<nl/> Since 2009, French ATC unions have 
staged 39 days of strike action, according to Ryanair, which caused "cancellations for millions of people across 
Europe."<nl/> The most recent strike on April 12 and 13 caused 3,600 flight cancellations. There are more strikes 
planned this week on Thursday, Friday, and Saturday.<nl/> Ryanair's Kenny Jacobs says in a statement[2]: "It's 
unacceptable that Europe's consumers repeatedly have their holiday and travel plans disrupted or cancelled by the 
selfish actions of ATC unions every summer, who use strikes as a first weapon rather than a last resort. <nl/> 
"French ATC unions will again stage three further days of strikes this week, which will impact hundreds of 
thousands of European consumers. It is particularly reprehensible that these strikes are taking place at the height of 
the peak summer season, deliberately targeting holiday makers and families."<nl/> Ryanair wants Europe to ban air 
traffic controllers from striking, in the same way police and military are forbidden, or to let other European air traffic 
controllers to step in and cover for the French during periods of industrial action.<nl/> Ryanair plans to deliver its 
petition, dubbed "Keep Europe's skies open," to Brussels once it hits 1 million signatures. It's not clear how many 
signatures it currently has. You can sign the petition here[3].<nl/>NOW WATCH: How to skip long lines at the 
airport — just like the 1%[4]<nl/> [ 1]: http://www.investegate.co.uk/ryanair-holdings-plc--rya-/rns/ryanair-petition-to--
keep-europe-s-skies-open-/201507010700317921R/ [ 2]:            http://www.investegate.co.uk/ryanair-holdings-plc--
rya-/rns/ryanair-petition-to--keep-europe-s-skies-open-/201507010700317921R/

Capital Control Means Greeks Can Click, Not Buy
Capital Control Means Greeks Can Click, Not Buy
Newstex Blogs
Voice of America
June 30, 2015 Tuesday 4:40 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLCAll Rights Reserved
Length: 387 words
Body
Jun 30, 2015( Voice of America: http://www.voanews.com Delivered by Newstex) ; Monday was the day the music 
died for thousands of song downloaders and music streamers in Greece.
 The imposition of capital controls on Sunday evening means Greeks are no longer able to purchase goods or 
services from many big international online suppliers including Google, Apple and Facebook. Transfers of funds out 
of Greece were banned to prevent a collapse of the banking system after Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras rejected the 
terms of a bailout offer from international lenders. The controls mean payments via debit or credit cards to accounts 
outside Greece are prohibited. This is a problem for the big online retailers, music download sellers and airlines, 
who sell to clients across Europe from centralized transacting subsidiaries, often in Luxembourg or Ireland, and 
often for tax reasons. Since Monday, many Greeks have found they can no longer make payments online to such 
companies. "I tried to pay Facebook three euros for a small advertisement but my card was rejected right away," 
said Greek e-commerce consultant Panayotis Gezerlis. He added that he had also failed to purchase music from 
Google and to make a payment from his bank card via eBay's payment unit, Paypal. Google told Greek clients in a 
Facebook posting that it was working to find a solution. Google's European customers contract with an Irish 
subsidiary when buying advertisements. The system allows the group to pay almost no tax on profits from these 
sales, but also means almost every sale is a cross-border transaction. A spokesman for the Irish airline Ryanair 
said it also was having trouble processing payments from Greek customers, and was working on a solution. Even 
the Taxi hailing service Taxibeat, which was founded in Greece but operates internationally, tweeted on Monday it 
was hoping to be able to offer a viable payment system soon. Gezerlis said while many of the products and 
services affected were not necessities, others, such as file storage and advertising, could cause problems for 
businesses unable to pay. "There are many businesses which rely on Google servers and on Dropbox to share 
files," he said. Many big online providers including Amazon, Google, Apple, Microsoft, Adobe and Expedia did not 
reply to requests for comment. 
Load-Date: June 30, 2015
End of Document
A Londoners fight for the Skies of Dublin
A Londoners fight for the Skies of Dublin
New Europe
June 25, 2015 Thursday 12:08 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 411 words
Byline: roubanis
Body
Jun 25, 2015( New Europe: http://neurope.eu Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Share on Facebook<nl/> Share on 
Twitter<nl/> Share on Google+<nl/> Share on LinkedIn<nl/><nl/><nl/> Aer Lingus is owned by the Irish government 
(25%), Etihad Airways (5%), Ryanair (30%) and other minority shareholders. The company has become the center 
of a regulatory battle for a high stakes take over. The prize is not only traffic from or to Ireland, the U.K, and beyond, 
but mainly the Dublin airport as an alternative transatlantic hub given the congestion of UK's airports, especially 
London's Heathrow.<nl/>           http://www.neurope.eu/article/a-londoners-fight-for-the-skies-of-dublin/#socialbuzz-
bottom-infinite-view-396827<nl/> On Thursday, British Airways (BA) offered concessions in an attempt to win 
EU regulatory approval for the acquisition of 25% of the Irish air carrier Aer Lingus. 
BA is based at London's Heathrow, one of the busiest and more congested airports in the world, a fact that 
significantly limits its capacity for market expansion, especially in lucrative transatlantic services. Dublin is the 
obvious solution to London's problems. The European Commission deadline for bids for the Irish carrier is now 
extended to July 15th.<nl/> Regulatory clearance typically involves unbundling connecting flights and offering 
airport slots. In this case, BA must also secure the agreement of its major rival and 30% shareholder of Aer Lingus, 
namely Ryanair. Ryanair is being forced by the UK's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) to reduce its stake 
in Aer Lingus to 5%. However, Ryanair has not disclosed whether or not it is willing to sell its share to BA. BA is 
also offering the Irish government €1.4bn for its 25% share of Aer Lingus, but the government still wants further 
assurances.<nl/> The main rival for Aer Lingus is Virgin Atlantic, but it looks like this is not a battle that will be 
fought on the basis of cash alone. Virgin Atlantic had partnered with Aer Lingus to cater to the U.K's domestic 
market and they are worried that this partnership may be undermined after the takeover. In addition, Virgin's share 
of the transatlantic market is likely to be further squeezed. Whilst Virgin does not have the cash to outbid BA, 
regulatory complaints could undermine its rival's bid, especially given the overall negative attitude of the Irish 
government.<nl/><nl/> Share on Facebook<nl/> Share on Twitter<nl/> Share on Google+<nl/> Share on 
LinkedIn<nl/> 
Load-Date: June 25, 2015
End of Document
Bloomberg: Ryanair clashes with Denmark over labour
Bloomberg: Ryanair clashes with Denmark over labour
New Europe
June 23, 2015 Tuesday 8:34 AM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 455 words
Byline: karafyllis
Body
Jun 23, 2015( New Europe: http://neurope.eu Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Share on Facebook<nl/> Share on 
Twitter<nl/> Share on Google+<nl/> Share on LinkedIn<nl/><nl/><nl/> Ryanair is accused by Danish officials of 
disrespecting the Danish labour laws as it hires Denmark-based pilots and cabin crew on Irish labour 
contracts.<nl/> Bloomberg reported today that since the entering of Ryanair in Denmark this spring, the company 
has come under nonstop attack from unions, government officials due to its controversial employment 
standards.<nl/>           http://www.neurope.eu/article/bloomberg-ryanair-clashes-with-denmark-over-
labour/#socialbuzz-bottom-infinite-view-395775<nl/> On June 15, Ryanair was summoned by a labour court in 
Copenhagen to explain why it hires Denmark-based pilots and cabin crew on Irish labor contracts. 
Ryanair claimed that the arrangement, which it uses in other countries, is legal and that its Danish employees 'enjoy 
high pay [and] job security.' Still, the critics are accusing Ryanair of using this employment policy to avoid rules on 
wages, social benefits, and worker protections required by Danish laws.<nl/> On January 2015, Thilde Waast, from 
Denmark's FPU trade union, told Denmark's Avisen newspaper about the labour conditions in Ryanair: 'Ryanair 
pilots and flight attendants are working under conditions that are unacceptable to us, so we expect to come into 
conflict with the company…We have no interest in causing trouble for Ryanair, but we have to get an agreement 
with them to work under Danish conditions.' If the labour unions win the case, Ryanair will have to to sign a Danish 
collective agreement within five days.<nl/> Danish investors have also started to withdraw their stake in Ryanair. 
PensionDanmark, a pension fund managing $26 billion of savings from members of 10 Danish labour unions, a 
year ago sold all its Ryanair shares, worth about $7.5 million. According to the Local, other pension funds including 
the country's largest investor ATP also considering selling their shares due to Ryanair's controversial labour 
practices. On May, the mayor of Copenhagen, Frank Jensen, has also banned all 45,000 city official from flying with 
Ryanair - even if it's the cheapest option.<nl/> According to Bloomberg, Ryanair complained to the European Union 
about the restrictions on Danish municipal workers claiming that 'these municipalities are breaking EU law by 
banning their staff from choosing Ryanair's lowest-fare flights.' Moreover, the company said that even if the Danish 
investors sell their shares there are many other willing investors who want to buy the shares.<nl/><nl/> Share on 
Facebook<nl/> Share on Twitter<nl/> Share on Google+<nl/> Share on LinkedIn<nl/> 
Load-Date: June 23, 2015

Lufthansa Faces June 30 Deadline to Avert Cabin Crew Strike - Analyst Blog
Lufthansa Faces June 30 Deadline to Avert Cabin Crew Strike - Analyst Blog
Zacks Investment Research
June 23, 2015 Tuesday 8:55 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 707 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
Jun 23, 2015( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Employee-related 
concerns continue to haunt Germany's Deutsche Lufthansa Aktiengesellschaft DLAKY[1]. The largest German 
carrier is now confronted with the possibility of its flight attendants going on strike, unless the company is able to 
come up with an acceptable plan by Jun 30 pertaining to the pay and retirement conditions of its cabin 
crew.<nl/>The ultimatum to the company was served by the Independent Flight Attendants Organization (UFO) 
which represents 19,000 flight attendants of the frequently strike-plagued carrier. 
We remind investors that in Jan 2015, UFO agreed with the company to seek arbitration to resolve disputes related 
to the pay and retirement benefits of the flight attendants. However, efforts by mediators to find an amicable 
solution fell apart. Subsequently, the union rejected the proposal to resume talks with the company.<nl/>UFO has 
now stated that failure on the part of the company to come up with an acceptable solution by Jun 30, 2015 would 
result in the flight attendants going on strike the following day. Moreover, it warned of further strikes that could last 
till Sep 16, thus crippling operations through the busy summer season. This would potentially rob the carrier of 
significant revenues.<nl/>We note that Lufthansa has faced a series of strikes in the recent past, over its supposed 
efforts to reduce costs in a bid to compete effectively with carriers like Ryanair Holdings RYAAY[2] and 
Emirates.<nl/>In Mar 2015, pilots of the company went on a four-day strike following the fallout of talks with 
management over early retirement benefits. Furthermore, the carrier's plan to expand low-cost offerings has also 
come under attack from the pilots. The strike was the 14th such move by the carrier's pilots since Apr 2014. 
However, pilots have as of now agreed not to go on strike further till Jul 31, 2015 as the dispute is currently in the 
hands of mediators.<nl/>The ongoing dispute with the pilots has already resulted in massive flight cancellations and 
loss of profit for the carrier. The latest row with its flight attendants represents a fresh challenge for the 
company.<nl/>Zacks Rank<nl/>Lufthansa currently carries a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy). Equally well-ranked 
stocks in the airline space include SkyWest SKYW[3] and Hawaiian Holdings HA[4].<nl/>Want the latest 
recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today, you can download 7 Best Stocks for the Next 30 Days.

The humility of Ryanair 's CEO is driving the improvement of their customer experience
The humility of Ryanair's CEO is driving the improvement of their customer 
experience
Adrian Swinscoe - RARE Business Growth Marketing
June 19, 2015 Friday 10:53 AM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 862 words
Byline: adrianswinscoe
Body
Jun 19, 2015( Adrian Swinscoe - RARE Business Growth ...rketing: http://www.adrianswinscoe.com/blog/ Delivered 
by Newstex) ;<nl/> Nunwood[1], a customer experience research and consultancy firm, recently published their 
U.S. Customer Experience Excellence Report 2015 and I was lucky enough to get the chance to talk to David 
Conway, their Chief Strategy Officer, about the report and their findings[2].<nl/> In our interview[3], he suggested 
that:<nl/>
In broad terms the U.S. is probably two to three years ahead of the U.K. in customer experience terms; and The top 
U.S. brands are about 5% ahead of their U.K. counterparts across a number of dimensions and Nunwood estimates 
that it will take U.K. brands two to three years to catch up.<nl/>One of the main reasons, he cited for this 
discrepancy is that they have found that:<nl/><nl/>'the customer experience agenda is largely driven by the CEO 
and the executive team in the U.S. and that is a key difference between the U.S. and the U.K., where the customer 
experience agenda is being driven, in large part, by the operational team.'<nl/><nl/>I would suggest that these 
differences are not limited to U.K. firms but are shared, in many respects, across European firms.<nl/> However, 
one European firm that seems to bucking that trend is Ryanair[4].<nl/> Now, I wrote a bit of a skeptical article about 
them and their CEO, Michael O'Leary, last month where I asked: Does Michael O'Leary Really Care About 
Ryanair's Customers, Or Is He Just Being Pragmatic?[5], largely because of Mr. O'Leary's historical reputation for 
saying a number of not very flattering things about customers.<nl/> On the back of that article, Mr. O'Leary sent me 
a personal letter and also agreed to be interviewed by me about Ryanair's new programme of customer service 
initiatives.<nl/> In his letter (published with permission) and to answer my question whether or not he cared about 
his customers, Mr. O'Leary wrote:<nl/><nl/>'I am the only airline Chief Executive that really cares about my 
customers which is why I have spent 28 years driving down the cost of flying in Europe[6], this year Ryanair will 
carry over 100m passengers and save those passengers more than €10n compared to the average airfares being 
charged by our competitors in Europe'.<nl/><nl/>However, it was our interview (you can read the highlights and 
listen to the full interview here[7]) that provided the most interesting insights:<nl/>Humility is the biggest lesson he 
has learned in the last 12 months, even if as he says 'It's very difficult for someone who is Irish to be humble. We 
generally believe that we walk on water'. Listening to customers has been a 'spectacularly successful learning 
experience for Ryanair over the last 12 months' and they are seeing the changes that they have implemented 
reflected in their business results too. Do as much as you can to be nice to your customers but stay true to your 
business model. Ryanair know that service and improving their customers' experience is good but only as long as it 
doesn't threaten their cost leadership position. Investing[8] in being nicer to customers should fuel and add to your 
The humility of Ryanair 's CEO is driving the improvement of their customer experience
strategy but shouldn't dominate or replace it.<nl/>What's clear is that it is Mr. O'Leary's humility and ability to admit 
that he has made mistakes that are the main driving forces behind Ryanair's customer service improvements.<nl/> 
There are lessons here for other CEOs facing similar challenges.<nl/> Like the recent report released by Heidrick 
...ruggles: The CEO Report[9] states:<nl/><nl/>'Sometimes you have to have the courage to say, 'I know this is the 
right direction,' the humility to say when you've got it wrong and deal with it, but the courage to take action when 
you believe it's the right thing to do—despite the downside potential for yourself.'<nl/><nl/><nl/> This post was 
originally published on my Forbes.com column here[10]. Photo Credit: Lex Photographic[11] via Compfight[12]

Belgium Travel and Tourism Market: New insights
Belgium Travel and Tourism Market: New insights
CompaniesandMarkets.com
June 19, 2015 Friday 2:06 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 403 words
Body
Jun 19, 2015( CompaniesandMarkets.com: http://www.companiesandmarkets.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> 
The trend for domestic tourism has been negative, consistently declining from 2009 to 2013. This has been due to 
Belgian residents following a cautious approach in terms of spending on travel as the economy has not performed 
well. 
GDP at constant prices, when measured in national currency, grew at CAGR of 1.11% from 2009 to 2014. This 
implies that Belgian residents do not have much disposable income available to them, which limits their spending 
power. However, growth of 1.7% was recorded in 2014 and domestic trips are projected to reach 2.9 million by 
2019<nl/>All categories witness a decline in 2009, with business tourism experiencing maximum decline due to the 
global recession, meaning there were far fewer inbound trips for business purposes. Countries in Western Europe, 
such as the Netherlands, France, and Germany were adversely affected by the Euro crisis, which meant there was 
almost negligible growth in inbound tourism during 2012 and 2013 as these are major source countries for tourism 
in Belgium (collectively account for about 60% of the trips. Inbound spending is likely to reach EUR14.2 billion 
(US$201.1 billion) by 2019<nl/>Travel agents play an important role when booking trips such as airline and hotel 
reservations; however, their role is gradually changing. Now, most people browse hotel and airline websites and 
book their flights, hotels, and holiday packages directly. As of January 1, 2014, travel agents no longer require a 
license, which reduces barriers to entry. <nl/>Over the forecast period (2015-2019), their role will transition from 
agents involved in the selling of holidays to consultants advising tourists about a destination<nl/>Brussels Airlines, 
the flag carrier of Belgium, has been gradually losing market share due to the entry of LCCs. Irish LCC Ryanair 
plans to increase its passengers through Belgian airports by 20% in 2015, by adding five new routes to Belgium in 
its 2015 summer timetable<nl/><nl/>For more information on the "Travel and Tourism in Belgium to 2019" market 
analysis, see the latest research: Travel and Tourism in Belgium to 2019[1]<nl/>Follow us on Twitter 
@CandMResearch<nl/> [ 1]: http://www.companiesandmarkets.com/Market/Travel/Market-Research/Travel-and-
Tourism-in-Belgium-to-2019/RPT1310031?aCode=c64cd82a-b5ae-48fb-9757-eca787e7a8bf

'I can do it!': Summit celebrates powerful women
'I can do it!': Summit celebrates powerful women
Deutsche Welle Business
June 16, 2015 Tuesday 6:31 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 839 words
Body
Jun 16, 2015( Deutsche Welle Business: http://www.dw-world.de/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> They've made it 
despite the odds. But only after years of tireless work in a male-dominated world. DW's Manuela Kasper-Claridge 
reports from the fourth "Fortune Most Powerful Women" summit in London. 
Carolyn McCall is no stranger to the spotlight, but even she looks like she can't quite believe they've all come to 
London's posh Rosewood Hotel because of her - their role model. But in the world of businesswomen, the 53-year-
old Brit is a super star - the quintessential leader.<nl/> McCall is the chief executive of Easyjet and has managed to 
do what many deemed impossible when she took the job back in 2010. Alongside Ryanair, Easyjet is now Europe's 
most successful low-cost carrier. Under McCall, the company's revenue has doubled and the airline now flies to 70 
European destinations.<nl/> Cheap and on time<nl/> So, what's behind her success?<nl/> "Low fares and good 
services go hand in hand," McCall said. But that wasn't what Easyjet was known for, when she over the reins. The 
company's reputation had hit rock bottom, and customers were running away in droves, turning instead to the 
competition. To win back customers, one of the first things she did was to make sure that all flights left and arrived 
on time.<nl/> But McCall knew this was just a drop in the bucket and that there would be even greater challenges 
ahead. Sure, she was known as a successful executive, having previously headed the Guardian Media Group, but 
she was far from an aviation expert. Meanwhile, Easyjet was racking up losses, and executives were at 
loggerheads with each other.<nl/> Still, she said, "I can do it." Five years later, the Easyjet chief is widely regarded 
as one of the UK's most successful businesswomen.<nl/> Female power<nl/> The women in the audience are 
glued to her lips. Many of them can tell similar stories of tough management decisions and the pressure exerted by 
shareholders and colleagues.<nl/> The "Most Powerful Women" conference in London brings together successful 
female executives who are invited by the US magazine "Fortune." Among them are bankers, entrepreneurs, 
lawyers and consultants, mainly from Europe, but also from the US, India, China and the Middle East. And all of 
them are surrounded by men cultivating their own male-dominated networks.<nl/> 50 billion and 9 kids<nl/> Helena 
Morrissey is a living example of female power. The slender woman is in charge of Newton Investment, a 50-billion-
pound (69-billion-euro, $78-billion) fund. She's a staunch opponent of a female quota system and has made a 
splash with her "30% Club," launched in 2010. Its goal is to increase the number of women represented on the UK's 
top 100 corporate boards to 30 percent by 2015, but through voluntary, rather than mandatory, means.<nl/> "At the 
moment we stand at 23.6% representation, this is up from 12.6 percent," Morrisey said proudly.<nl/> One of the big 
challenges is to get companies to broaden their horizon when looking for candidates to fill open board positions. 
Many simply aren't aware that for each male candidate, there's often an equally qualified female. By recommending 
suitable talent, the initiative makes sure that women increasingly pop up on directors' radars.<nl/> Today, the 30% 
Club has expanded to include branches in South Africa, the US, Ireland and Hong Kong. And it's not just women 
'I can do it!': Summit celebrates powerful women
who support the initiative. The organization also counts several male top managers among its members.<nl/> 
Emerging from her father's shadow<nl/> Ana Botin, head of Spanish banking dynasty Santander Group, is also in 
London to share her experiences. Today, the 54-year-old scion is one of the world's most powerful banking 
executives. But this wasn't always the case.<nl/> For years, she lived in the shadow of her notorious father, Emilio 
Botin. When he died in 2014, the board of directors unanimously appointed her chair of the Group. After graduating 
Harvard Business School and an eight-year stint at JP Morgen, she returned to Spain to work for Santander, 
Europe's second-biggest institution. In 2010, she took over at the helm of Santander UK.<nl/> When Botin took over 
from her father, she didn't miss a beat. She soon made headlines for her decisive leadership, replacing several key 
figures at the top and ringing in a new era for the company that left no room to rest on the company's laurels.<nl/> 
But it wasn't a tough decisions, she told the audience in London. After all, it wasn't her first time working for the 
family business.<nl/> "It's always easier to change from inside," said Botin. "The biggest challenge is to find the 
right talent."<nl/> Image is (almost) everything<nl/> One thing her father taught her early on was that being a leader 
is about more than being the best, it's also about projecting the right image.<nl/> "I just concentrated on doing the 
best I could. But I learned that wasn't enough," reflected Botin.<nl/> The women in the audience nodded their heads 
knowingly.<nl/>

inflow was seen in the iShares MSCI EAFE ETF (EFA), which added 7,200,000 units, or a 0.8% increase week over 
week. Among the largest underlying components of EFA, in morning trading today Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY) is up

Dow30 (UDOW), which added 550,000 units, for a 33.3% increase in outstanding units. Among the largest 
underlying components of UDOW, in morning trading today 3M Company (MMM) is off about 0.9%, and American 
Express Company (AXP) is lower by about 0.9%.

Wizz Air Adds Glasgow to Vilnius Route in September 2015
Wizz Air Adds Glasgow to Vilnius Route in September 2015
Pressat
June 10, 2015 Wednesday 10:42 AM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 573 words
Byline: Pressat
Body
Jun 10, 2015( Pressat: http://www.pressat.co.uk Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Wednesday 10 June, 2015<nl/> 
Accessibility to Lithuania from the UK is on the rise as Wizz Air is set to introduce a flight between Glasgow and the 
Lithuanian capital, Vilnius. 
It will be the first time Vilnius has been served as a destination from Glasgow Airport and Wizz Air will operate a 
year round, twice weekly service starting on 16 September 2015.<nl/>Wizz Air is the largest low-cost airline in 
Central and Eastern Europe and Paul White, business development manager at Glasgow Airport said "the new 
Vilnius service will no doubt prove extremely popular with both Lithuanian and Scottish passengers." Daniel de 
Carvalho, Corporate Communications Manager at Wizz Air echoed these sentiments as he announced that fares 
will be starting from only £18.49.<nl/>UK access to Lithuania is already well established with flights leaving from 
London, Edinburgh, Liverpool, Birmingham, Doncaster and Bristol. Wizzair offer flights to Vilnius while Ryan Air was 
the first carrier to set direct flights from Scotland in 2010 with a service running twice a week from Edinburgh Airport 
to Kaunas and from Liverpool and London Stansted to Vilnius. Kaunas International Airport is the second busiest 
civil airport in Lithuania after Vilnius Airport and as the second largest city in Lithuania, located just an hour's drive 
from Vilnius, less than a three hour flight to either of these cities will take visitors to a treasure trove of natural 
beauty; Vilnius' baroque old town, Ninth Fort, Trakai Castle and the Curonian Spit are just a few gems waiting to be 
discovered and part of what put Lithuania 3rd in Lonely Planet's Top Countries for 2015 and Europe's best kept 
secret.<nl/>For more information on Lithuania see www.Lithuania.travel<nl/>-ENDS- <nl/>For more information 
please contact: Lithuanian Tourism Office in the UKAlexander GrayTel: + 44 (0) 208 877 4516Email: 
lithuania@representationplus.co.uk Visit:            www.Lithuania.travel;<nl/>Like us on Facebook<nl/>Follow us on 
Twitter<nl/>Notes to Editors: Visit:            www.Lithuania.travel Ryanair (           www.ryanair.com) and Wizz Air (      
     www.wizzair.com) both fly from London Luton to Vilnius International Airport. Ryanair also fly to Vilnius from 
London Stansted. Air Baltic via Riga from Gatwick. For more information, visit            www.vilnius-airport.lt/en. Year 
round events include Mardi Gras in February, Vilnius International Film Festival in March, the International Jazz 
Festival in April, the International Contemporary Dance Festival "New Baltic Dance" and Street Music Day in May, 
the Medieval Festival in Trakai Peninsular Castle in June, the Cultural Night ‚Let it be the Night' in July and the 
Vilnius Marathon in September and the "Christopher Christmas" music concerts in December, with many other 
notable events throughout the year.Lithuania is the southernmost country of the three Baltic States and has a 90km 
coastline along the Baltic Sea. Summers are generally warm with temperatures up to 30°C. Winters are cold with 
easterly winds bringing temperatures down to as low as -12°C. Spring and autumn are mild and there is normally 
Wizz Air Adds Glasgow to Vilnius Route in September 2015
snow cover for two months of the year. <nl/> No media attached. Please contact Pressat Wire for more 
information.<nl/><nl/> Distributed by            http://www.pressat.co.uk/[1]<nl/> [ 1]:            http://www.pressat.co.uk/
