After a 6% decline in 2012 due to the bankruptcy of the national carrier Malév, transportation recovered in 2013 
showing 3% value sales growth. After bankruptcy of Malév, air transportation was characterised by share takeover 
by low cost carriers, especially Wizzair and Ryanair. In 2013, this competition along with other low cost carriers 
turned into consolidation amongst the bigger players.<nl/>Value sales of transportation in Hungary declined by 6% 
in 2012, after significant growth of 7% in 2011. The decline in value sales of transportation was prompted by a value 
decline in air and growth of 4% in other transportation in 2012. Air was seriously affected by the bankruptcy of the 
main national air carrier, Malév Hungarian Airlines Rt, in February 2012. There was a decline of 5% in the number 
of people travelling by air in 2012.<nl/>For more information on the "Transportation in Hungary" market analysis,

Student Changes His Name Because It's Cheaper Than Changing Flight Booking
Student Changes His Name Because It's Cheaper Than Changing Flight 
Booking
The Huffington Post
June 5, 2015 Friday 9:30 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 507 words
Byline: Andy Campbell
Body
Jun 05, 2015( The Huffington Post: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> We all know that 
booking a flight is a constant tactical battle with airlines[1].<nl/>But no passenger has won (or lost?)
 the booking war as heroically as 19-year-old Adam Armstrong. The student from Manchester, England, changed 
his name to Adam West because it was cheaper than changing his Ryanair flight booking[2].<nl/>The airline wanted 
to charge him $337 to change a mistake on his ticket. He told The Sun[3] that his stepfather accidentally booked 
him as "Adam West," because that's what he called himself on his Facebook page.<nl/>"Her stepdad got my name 
from Facebook but I had put it as Adam West as a joke, because he was the actor who played Batman on TV," 
West said.<nl/>Ryanair is known for its cheap flights but ample fees for any changes or services[4]. It charges $69 
to check in at the airport, for example. The airline wanted to charge West twice for his change because he and his 
girlfriend were both on the booking.<nl/>Instead of giving in, the teen went rogue. He changed his name (for free) 
and will fly to Ibiza as Adam West next week, the Daily Mail reports[5]. The Guardian reports that he did have to pay 
about $157[6] to change his passport, however.<nl/><nl/>Ryanair released a statement[7] to explain that the rule 
was in place to deter scammers:<nl/> Customers are asked to ensure that the details they enter at the time of 
booking are correct before completing their booking and we offer a 24 hour 'grace period' to correct minor booking 
errors. A name change fee is charged in order to discourage and prevent unauthorized online travel agents from 
'screenscraping' Ryanair's cheapest fares and reselling them on to unwitting consumers at hugely inflated costs.

change-adam-west-ryanair-flight_n_7522154.html<nl/> [ 1]:            http://www.huffingtonpost.com/hoppercom/5-
tips-for-finding-cheap-_b_6994158.html?ncid=txtlnkusaolp00000603

This kid legally changed his name because it was cheaper than paying a Ryanair ticketing fee
This kid legally changed his name because it was cheaper than paying a 
Ryanair ticketing fee
The Business Insider
June 5, 2015 Friday 10:50 AM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 438 words
Byline: lbrinded@businessinsider.com,  (Lianna Brinded) Lianna Brinded
Body
Jun 05, 2015( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) ;<nl/> Ryanair is a no-
frills European budget airline that charges high fees for any extras.<nl/>
 And when we mean anything extra, £15 ($23) for printing off your boarding pass if you didn't print it off at home or 
even £30 ($46) upwards for checking in a bag. <nl/> So when Adam Armstrong, 19, found out that it would cost 
£220 ($337) in "admin fees" to get his name corrected on a Ryanair ticket, he opted to change his name by deed 
poll instead because it was cheaper, as originally reported in The Sun newspaper.<nl/> Ryanair says it charges 
steep fees to correct names in order to prevent ticket reselling fraud.<nl/> Armstrong is booked to go on holiday to 
Ibiza next week with his girlfriend, India Lomas, 17. However, her father booked his ticket under the name "Adam 
West" after looking at his Facebook profile. Armstrong had used the name "Adam West" in homage to the original 
Batman actor.<nl/> However, Armstrong found out that he would be charged double the usual £110 admin fee[1] for 
changing a name on a ticket because his girlfriend was listed on the same booking, according to The Sun.<nl/> He 
changed his name for free via deed poll, then paid £103 ($158) for a new passport — less than the amount he 
would have paid if the fee had not been doubled.<nl/> On Today FM's "Anton Savage Show" this morning in 
Ireland[2], Armstrong (now West) said "yeah, I'm not giving Ryanair a penny."<nl/> Ryanair told Business Insider: 
<nl/> Customers are asked to ensure that the details they enter at the time of booking are correct before completing 
their booking and we offer a 24 hour 'grace period' to correct minor booking errors.<nl/> A name change fee is 
charged in order to discourage and prevent unauthorised online travel agents from "screenscraping" Ryanair's 
cheapest fares and reselling them on to unwitting consumers at hugely inflated costs. <nl/> Under our 'Always 
Getting Better' improvement programme, we have reduced our baggage, sports equipment, airport check-in and 
missed departure fees, as we continue to improve the Ryanair travel experience for the 100 million customers we'll 
carry this year.<nl/>NOW WATCH: A Japanese lifestyle guru explains how to organize your home once — and then 
never again[3]<nl/> [ 1]: https://www.ryanair.com/en/fees/ [ 2]:            http://www.dailyedge.ie/adam-west-ryanair-

Global Air Travel Demand Up in April, North America Sluggish - Analyst Blog
Global Air Travel Demand Up in April, North America Sluggish - Analyst Blog
Zacks Investment Research
June 5, 2015 Friday 9:45 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 1190 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
Jun 05, 2015( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> The monthly data 
released by the International Air Transport Association (IATA) revealed a 5.9% year-over-year increase in demand 
for air travel across the globe for the month of April 2015. The rise was attributable to an increase in both 
international and domestic traffic (measured in revenue passenger kilometers) in the month. The report also 
revealed a 6.1% rise in capacity (measured in available seat kilometers). The greater increase in capacity 
compared with air traffic resulted in the load factor (percentage of seats filled with passengers) declining 10 basis 
points (bps) to 79.4% in April.<nl/>International Traffic<nl/>
The 5.2% increase in International demand was driven by strong performance of carriers from the Asia-Pacific, 
Latin America and Middle East.<nl/>International traffic in the Asia-Pacific region registered a handsome 9% growth 
on a 6% rise in capacity. The greater increase in traffic compared with capacity led to a 220 bps rise in load factor 
to 78.3%. Carriers in the Middle East which include the likes of Emirates, Etihad and Qatar Airways reported an 
8.2% increase in April traffic on the strength of the economy to withstand the weak oil revenues. However, the 
greater increase in capacity (13.3%) resulted in the load factor declining 360 bps to 77.2% for carriers in the 
region.<nl/>International traffic for Latin American carriers which include the likes of GOL Linhas Aereas 
Inteligentes S.A. GOL[1] and Copa Holdings SA CPA[2] for the month was up 6.3% on a 7.3% rise in capacity. 
International April traffic for European carriers which include the likes of Ryanair Holdings RYAAY[3] climbed 3.7% 
on a 4.7% rise in capacity. Economic stimulus boosted demand for carriers in the region. African carriers 
disappointed in the month with both traffic and capacity declining due to weakness in the economy.<nl/>Strong 
Dollar Hurts North American Carriers<nl/>The IATA monthly report however did not reveal healthy traffic data for 
the carriers in North America. International traffic for carriers like United Continental Holdings Inc. UAL[4], Delta Air 
Lines DAL[5], Southwest Airlines Co. LUV[6], JetBlue Airways Corporation JBLU[7] and Alaska Air Group Inc. 
ALK[8] inched up 0.7% with the strength of the U.S. dollar hampering international leisure travel into the U.S. 
Capacity improved 4.1% and load factor fell 260 basis points to 78.1% due to greater increase in 
capacity.<nl/>Mixed Picture for Summer Travel<nl/>The IATA said that although weak fuel prices have emerged as 
a boon for aviation companies given the inverse relation between fuel costs and the value of airline stocks, the 
outlook for carriers is a mixed one as far as the impending busy summer season in the northern hemisphere is 
concerned. According to the forecast, the strength of the U.S. dollar is likely to a dampener.<nl/>India, China Boost 
Domestic Traffic<nl/>According to the report, domestic travel demand ran the show in April. Stellar domestic traffic 
growth in India (20.7%) and China (15.5%) boosted domestic passenger traffic by 7.2%. However, domestic 
demand (up only 1.7%) in Russia was weak during the month with the economy in recession. The domestic traffic 
Global Air Travel Demand Up in April, North America Sluggish - Analyst Blog
picture in the U.S. was better than the broader international space, with the metric reporting a 4.3% 
growth.<nl/>Total domestic capacity for the month climbed 6.4% and load factor climbed 60 bps to 80.8% driven by 
the greater increase in traffic. Russia revealed the greatest imbalance between traffic and capacity with the latter 
rising 13.2% and leading to empty planes.<nl/>Air Freight Demand Weak<nl/>IATA said that the 3.3% increase in 
global cargo volumes was much less than 4.3% growth witnessed in the first three months of the year. Air cargo 
volume is a key indicator of business confidence. Weak world trade growth was blamed for the weakness in 
demand growth for air freight.<nl/>Slowdown in the Asia Pacific region was the main culprit. Carriers in the Middle 
East registered a healthy 14.1% growth in air freight demand. The increase was attributable to the expansion of 
network and capacity that has encouraged air freight to go through hubs in the Middle East.<nl/>Want the latest 
recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today, you can download 7 Best Stocks for the Next 30 Days.

Aer Lingus Reports 1.5% Passenger Increase for May
Aer Lingus Reports 1.5% Passenger Increase for May
FFT.ie
June 5, 2015 Friday 4:25 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 142 words
Byline: Mark Murphy
Body
Jun 05, 2015( FFT.ie: http://www.fft.ie Delivered by Newstex) <nl/>            http://fft.ie/wp-
content/uploads/2015/06/aerlinguspassengers.jpg Significant transatlantic increase for carrier.<nl/> Passenger 
numbers at Aer Lingus rose by 1.5% in the month of May compared to the same period last year according to newly 
released statistics.<nl/> Significantly, transatlantic traffic is up by 10.9% compared, up to 143,000 from 129,000 in 
May 2013.<nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/>The company said a total passengers numbers for the month, including Aer Lingus 
Regional flights, rose 1.5% to 1,062,000, compared with 1,046,000 a year earlier.<nl/> Passenger load factor, a 
measure of how full the aircraft are, was up 1.7% to 80.4%.<nl/> The figures come after Ryanair also reported 
positive numbers, with numbers rising by 16% for May compared to a year earlier.<nl/>

The Irish Government Wisely Agrees to Let IAG Buy Aer Lingus
The Irish Government Wisely Agrees to Let IAG Buy Aer Lingus
The Cranky Flier
June 1, 2015 Monday 2:59 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 998 words
Byline: CF
Body
Jun 01, 2015( The Cranky Flier: http://www.crankyflier.com Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Ohayou gozaimasu, 
everyone! I'm back from a week in Japan and it was fantastic. Stay tuned for trip reports in business class on an 
ANA 787 and Suites class on a Singapore A380. Both were excellent, as you'd probably expect. 
But those aren't ready yet. For now, let's get back to the business of airlines.<nl/> There were a lot of things that 
caught my eye last week, but I can't write about them all. Today, I thought I'd talk about the culmination of a long 
process. IAG, parent company of British Airways, Iberia, and Vueling, has finally convinced the Irish government to 
allow it to add Aer Lingus to its trophy case[1]. The deal really is a good one for both sides.<nl/><nl/>IAG has been 
trying to purchase Aer Lingus for quite some time now, but opposition from the government (which owns a quarter 
of the airline) was holding it back. It took some guarantees to maintain the brand and service levels into the UK in 
order to get the Irish government to come around. Yes, Ryanair still owns nearly 30 percent of the airline as well, 
but it has to sell all but 5 percent of that[2] (though this is still under appeal). Regardless of what Ryanair decides to 
do[3], it likely won't kill the deal.<nl/> That doesn't mean that this is officially done though. The EU still has to sign 
off on it from an anti-trust perspective. But we're at a point now where I'd be surprised if this didn't happen. And it's 
a good thing, for the most part.<nl/> There were three big concerns that were specific to this deal that caused some 
hesitation. Some of these were really unfounded.<nl/> Losing Its Airline<nl/>One of the concerns was that Ireland 
would lose its national airline and would just become a set of routes in another airline based elsewhere. While that 
might make more sense if it were possible, that's not how IAG's model works. IAG prefers airlines to keep 
independent brands with separate management teams, as evidenced by the way it handles British Airways, Iberia, 
and Vueling.<nl/>That doesn't mean Aer Lingus will just do whatever it wants as a completely independent arm, 
however. We know that that deal is going to bring Aer Lingus into the joint venture with American over the Atlantic. 
Aer Lingus will also join oneworld and start using Avios as its frequent flier point currency. And you know there will 
be plenty of 'synergies' along the way that will be discovered.<nl/> To placate the government, IAG formally agreed 
to keep the Aer Lingus brand as an airline based in Ireland. This wasn't a stretch anyway.<nl/><nl/> Slash and 
Burn<nl/>Another concern is that Aer Lingus would see major cuts in the same way that Iberia did. But there's a big 
difference here. Under its previous regime, Christoph Mueller already did the slashing that Aer Lingus needed to 
become viable, and it has been making money. Iberia was a bloated company that was in desperate need of 
change to even have a chance of profitability when IAG showed up. Aer Lingus is fairly well-positioned, so the 
concern about slashing and burning should be minimal.<nl/><nl/>Heathrow<nl/>The last concern is probably the 
most valid. Aer Lingus holds a lot of slots at Heathrow and uses them to fly to various cities in Ireland. Some think 
IAG wants those slots for British Airways to use on other routes. That's fair, but it should also happen to some 
The Irish Government Wisely Agrees to Let IAG Buy Aer Lingus
extent. After all, if BA and Aer Lingus both fly Heathrow to Dublin, then why not fly fewer flights with bigger airplanes 
and then use the remaining slots for something else? I suppose the bigger concern from the government is that 
smaller cities will simply lose flights to Heathrow entirely. That's a very fair concern.<nl/>To compensate for that, 
IAG says it will commit to maintaining existing schedules between Heathrow and Dublin, Shannon, and Cork for 7 
years. All other Aer Lingus Heathrow slots will be used for flights to Ireland for 5 years, though it doesn't say on 
which routes. And that commitment was enough to get the Irish government to make a move.<nl/><nl/> Beyond 
that, of course, there are the usual merger concerns. Will this be good for travelers? Will it be anti-competitive? The 
EU needs to consider that now.<nl/> For passengers, there is a lot of good here. Joining the IAG empire will mean 
people in Ireland will have seamless access into a much bigger network. And the airline's re-entrance into oneworld 
(it was a member for several years) is also going bring more benefits. Plus, IAG expects to grow Dublin as a 
Transatlantic jumping-off point.<nl/> There are some areas of concern. First is Heathrow since there isn't 
competition from there to Ireland if this goes through. But Ryanair has such an enormous presence from Ireland to 
other London airports and Europe in general that this should be a fairly minor concern.<nl/> Transatlantic 
competition may be another area to think about. After all, there are very few airlines outside of the big three 
alliances that fly over the Atlantic these days. Aer Lingus has been a lower fare carrier, especially in relation to one 
way pricing. It would seem likely that this would change, but then again, maybe not. IAG may find that the Aer 
Lingus strategy is a good strategy to use for that carrier. As we saw with Vueling, IAG isn't necessarily looking to 
have a single strategy over every carrier it owns. It just wants the right strategy for that carrier.<nl/> Assuming this 
does go through, we'll find out how this plays out soon enough. But I tend to believe this is a smart move.<nl/> [ 1]: 
http://phx.corporate-ir.net/External.File?item=UGFyZW50SUQ9Mjg4NjEzfENoaWxkSUQ9LTF8VHlwZT0z... 
[ 
2]:       
     http://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/transport/11408051/Ryanair-forced-to-sell-Aer-Lingus-stake-
under-Court-of-Appeal-ruling.html [ 3]:            http://www.irishtimes.com/business/transport-and-tourism/ryanair-to-
make-own-decision-on-aer-lingus-stake-says-minister-1.2231440 
Load-Date: June 1, 2015

Advocate assisted commerce improves customer experience and drives business results - Interview with Scott 
Pulsipher of Needle
Advocate assisted commerce improves customer experience and drives 
business results - Interview with Scott Pulsipher of Needle
Adrian Swinscoe - RARE Business Growth Marketing
June 1, 2015 Monday 6:12 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 1012 words
Byline: adrianswinscoe Adrian Swinscoe
Body
Jun 01, 2015( Adrian Swinscoe - RARE Business Growth ...rketing: http://www.adrianswinscoe.com/blog/ Delivered 
by 
Newstex) 
;<nl/> 
 
 
 
 
 
 
     
http://media.blubrry.com/adrianswinscoe/p/blogpodcasts.s3.amazonaws.com/ScottPulsipherNeedle010515.mp3[1]<
nl/>Podcast: Play in new window[2] | Download[3]<nl/>
<nl/>Today's interview is with Scott Pulsipher, President ...O of Needle[4], a US software firm that is pioneering 
advocate-assisted commerce. Scott joins me today to talk about what Needle are up to, trust, customer experience 
and advocate-assisted commerce.<nl/> This interview follows on from my recent interview: A degree of humility 
always succeeds in business - Interview with Michael O'Leary of Ryanair[5] - and is number 145 in the series of 
interviews[6] with authors and business leaders that are doing great things, helping businesses innovate and 
delivering great service and experience to their customers.<nl/> Highlights of my interview with Scott:<nl/>Needle is 
pioneering advocate-assisted commerce. In online commerce we are often faced with a lack of trust and access to 
trusted advice when making purchases. What if businesses could allow their own customers and advocates to help 
new customers? Doing so would dramatically improve the customer's experience and increase the likelihood that 
customers would find and buy what they are looking for. Scott quotes some Forrester research that says that only 
20% of us trust the associates of the company that we are doing business with. Needle works with firms that are 
selling what they call 'considered purchases', where they are generally at a higher price point, often entail extensive 
usage after purchase and where there are lots of different options. Scott tells the story of Carhartt[7], who provide 
technical workwear. Needle helped them find and engage their advocates such that when a Carhartt shopper is 
displaying certain behaviours on the Carhartt site, the shopper will get an invite (pop-up) that will ask them if they 
would like to 'chat' with a Carhartt expert/customer that may be able to help them with any purchasing questions 
they have. If the customer clicks yes then this tends to lead to a dramatic increase in the customer being able to 
locate the right product, higher customer satisfaction and NPS as well as higher and more frequent purchases. This 
can lead to a 6-10 fold increase in conversion over a self-service customer and a 10-25% increase in the average 
order value. All of the advocates are clearly identified through their bio and picture as fans of the company, experts 
and purchasers of the company's products. Advocates are rewarded primarily through 3 things: products, brand 
experiences and cash. Advocates' primary motivation is that they want to help. They love to receive products and 
exclusive brand experiences but the cash element also has to be enough that they are willing to show up and do 
'work'. Advocates also receive a schedule of when they are to be 'live' and helping customers just like any other 
Advocate assisted commerce improves customer experience and drives business results - Interview with Scott 
Pulsipher of Needle
role. There are advocates for everything out there so this is not an exclusively large brand opportunity. For 
ecommerce businesses this would mean that they would need in excess of 500,000 visits per month to their site to 
ensure that the right amount of community can be developed. This could help firms scale their sales efforts and 
drive incremental revenue without increasing headcount. To identify if this could be for your firm then first identify 
the higher price point product category that has great engagement but low conversion rates and start there. The 
majority of online businesses are pre-occupied with traffic and how to increase it. However, Scott advocates that a 
$1 spent on trust, engagement and community will generate a return 10-fold higher return than a $1 spent on 
driving higher traffic. Not everyone understands advocacy and not everyone trusts what their advocates might do. 
But, when Needle works with their clients they experience big uplifts in satisfaction and NPS as well as significant 
increases in conversion, average order value, loyalty and incremental revenue.<nl/>About Scott (taken from his 
Needle bio[8])<nl/> Scott Pulsipher is the President ...O of Needle[9].<nl/> Scott was previously the general 
manager of Amazon Webstore, a division of Amazon Services, where he directed overall strategy and global go-to-
market efforts. Under his leadership, Amazon Webstore was launched in the US and Europe, and rapidly scaled to 
support the ecommerce business of tens of thousands of companies. Prior to Amazon, Scott was the senior vice 
president of Products and Marketing for Sterling Commerce, which was acquired by IBM in 2010. Scott received his 
MBA from Harvard University. When not working, Scott tries to keep up with his family of six children, while 
sneaking in the occasional round of golf or day of skiing.<nl/> You can find Scott on LinkedIn here[10] and on 
Twitter 
@scottpul[11].;<nl/>

Ryanair Holdings plc Cut to 'Neutral' at Goldman Sachs (RYAAY)
Ryanair Holdings plc Cut to 'Neutral' at Goldman Sachs (RYAAY)
The Legacy
May 30, 2015 Saturday 2:48 AM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 503 words
Byline: Taylor Nule
Body
May 30, 2015( The Legacy: http://www.localizedusa.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Ryanair Holdings plc 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY) was downgraded by analysts at Goldman Sachs from a 'buy' rating to a 'neutral' rating in a 
research report issued to clients and investors on Friday, TheFlyOnTheWall.com[1] reports.<nl/> Shares of Ryanair 
Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY[2]) traded down 2.06% on Friday, hitting $66.60. The stock had a trading volume of 
1,333,430 shares. 
Ryanair Holdings plc has a 52-week low of $49.70 and a 52-week high of $71.79. The stock has a 50-day moving 
average of $66. and a 200-day moving average of $65.. The company has a market cap of $18.45 billion and a 
price-to-earnings ratio of 18.63.<nl/> Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last posted its quarterly earnings 
results on Tuesday, May 26th. The company reported $0.06 earnings per share (EPS) for the quarter, missing the 
consensus estimate of $0.11 by $0.05. Analysts expect that Ryanair Holdings plc will post $3.80 EPS for the current 
fiscal year.<nl/> RYAAY has been the subject of a number of other recent research reports. Analysts at Beaufort 
Securities reiterated a 'buy' rating on shares of Ryanair Holdings plc in a research note on Wednesday. Analysts at 
Imperial Capital downgraded shares of Ryanair Holdings plc from an 'outperform' rating to an 'in-line' rating and 
lowered their price target for the stock from $85.00 to $70.00 in a research note on Wednesday. Analysts at Kepler 
Capital Markets upgraded shares of Ryanair Holdings plc from a 'hold' rating to a 'buy' rating in a research note on 
Tuesday. Finally, analysts at Zacks[3] upgraded shares of Ryanair Holdings plc from a 'hold' rating to a 'strong-buy' 
rating and set a $77.00 price target on the stock in a research note on Monday, May 18th. Three equities research 
analysts have rated the stock with a hold rating, six have given a buy rating and one has assigned a strong buy 
rating to the company's stock. The company currently has a consensus rating of 'Buy' and a consensus target price 
of 
$66.67.<nl/>

Holdings 
plc 
is 
an 
Ireland-based 
holding 
company 
for 
Ryanair 
Limited 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY[4]). Ryanair operates a low-cost, scheduled-passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-point 
routes 
between 
Ireland, 
the 
United 
Kingdom, 
Continental 
Europe, 
and 
Morocco.<nl/>

Apple Watch Brings Flight and Airline Apps to Your Wrist
Apple Watch Brings Flight and Airline Apps to Your Wrist
iPads Advisor
May 30, 2015 Saturday 4:02 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 1568 words
Body
May 30, 2015( iPads Advisor: http://ipadsadvisor.com Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Apple Watch will certainly make 
the flying encounter more convenient for both casual and also frequent flyers, with a variety of airlines updating their 
apps for the Apple Watch in current weeks, or announcing support coming soon, consisting of American Airlines, 
Delta, United Airlines, JetBlue, British Airways, EasyJet, Ryanair, Qantas Airways, Air Canada, WestJet, Emirates 
as well as Japan Airlines.<nl/>Notable airlines that have actually not announced or intended Apple Watch 
assistance include Southwest Airlines and Virgin Airlines in the United States, and Cologne-based Lufthansa, the 
biggest airline company in Europe. As even more airline companies begin updating their apps for the Apple Watch, 
nevertheless, it is likely that will certainly comply with in an initiative to stay up to date with their competitors around 
the world.<nl/>
 The summary here offers a more detailed check out Apple Watch apps for several airlines across the Usa, 
Canada, United Kingdom, Australia, France, Ireland, United Arab Emirates and also Japan. A handful of other 
general flight-related apps are additionally specified that provide basic air travel statuses, alerts, real-time 
separation as well as hold-up info and also more for a simpler taking a trip experience.<nl/> United 
States<nl/>American Airlines<nl/>American Airlines for Apple Watch provides comprehensive trip info on your wrist, 
including entrance modification announcements, an in-flight map with approximated traveling time continuing to be 
until arrival, and luggage case and also link information. You could likewise obtain an alert when it's time to leave 
for the flight terminal as well as sign in to your battle directly from your Apple Watch. American Airlines is free on 
the App Store. Delta Delta Air Lines will certainly additionally be joining the mix of airline company applications for 
Apple Watch in a future upgrade to its existing Fly Delta application for iPhone and iPad. Delta for Apple Watch will 
certainly supply alerts concerning trips to customers ahead of their boarding times, and also it will certainly offer 
them accessibility to the boarding pass stored on their apples iphone straight on the wrist.<nl/>Delta for Apple 
Watch will provide air travel numbers, gate numbers, trip times, and also other info. If an air travel obtains changed, 
for example, customers will certainly obtain an alert on their Apple Watch. There will certainly also be an alert when 
an air travel is approaching a location city, with details regarding luggage pick-up. Fly Delta is totally free on the App 
Store. United Airlines United Airlines has actually not released screenshots or thorough details regarding its Apple 
Watch intends, yet it has actually confirmed that assistance for the wrist-worn gadget is in the jobs. United's 
application will certainly offer at-a-glance details on upcoming trips, including entrance numbers and standing, and

May 30, 2015 Saturday 8:23 AM EST

http://www.lulegacy.com/logos/hss-hire-group-plc-logo.jpgBeaufort Securities restated their buy rating on shares of 
HSS Hire Group PLC (LON:HSS) in a report issued on Thursday.<nl/>
 Beaufort Securities has also updated their ratings on a number of other stocks in the last week. The firm reiterated 
its buy rating on shares of Ryanair Holdings plc. Also, Beaufort Securities reiterated its hold rating on shares of 
AstraZeneca plc.<nl/> HSS Hire Group PLC (LON:HSS[1]) opened at 200.00 on Thursday. HSS Hire Group PLC 
has a 1-year low of GBX 4.25 and a 1-year high of GBX 220.00. The stock has a 50-day moving average of GBX 
155. and a 200-day moving average of GBX 177.. The company's market cap is £235.58 million.<nl/> A number of 
other firms have also recently commented on HSS. Analysts at Numis Securities Ltd reiterated a buy rating and set 
a GBX 235 ($3.64) price target on shares of HSS Hire Group PLC in a research note on Wednesday. Analysts at 
JPMorgan Chase .... reiterated an overweight rating and set a GBX 260 ($4.02) price target on shares of HSS Hire 
Group PLC in a research note on Wednesday. Analysts at Canaccord Genuity initiated coverage on shares of HSS 
Hire Group PLC in a research note on Thursday, May 21st. They set a hold rating and a GBX 215 ($3.33) price 
target on the stock. Finally, analysts at Berenberg Bank raised their price target on shares of HSS Hire Group PLC 
from GBX 225 ($3.48) to GBX 235 ($3.64) and gave the company a buy rating in a research note on Tuesday, May 
12th. One equities research analyst has rated the stock with a hold rating and four have issued a buy rating to the 
company's stock. The company presently has a consensus rating of Buy and an average price target of GBX 
236.25 ($3.66).<nl/><nl/><nl/> Receive News ...tings for HSS Hire Group PLC Daily - Enter your email address

Delta Air Lines ( DAL ) Adds Five New Routes from Seattle - Analyst Blog
Delta Air Lines (DAL) Adds Five New Routes from Seattle - Analyst Blog
Zacks Investment Research
May 28, 2015 Thursday 6:05 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 620 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
May 28, 2015( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> In sync with its 
capacity expansion plans, premium U.S. carrier Delta Air Lines DAL[1] plans to initiate flights from the Seattle-
Tacoma International Airport to Boston, Orlando, Pasco, Wash and Victoria and British Columbia. Further, the 
carrier will extend its existing Bozeman, MT, service from the Seattle hub.<nl/>
Notably, Victoria will be the latest addition to Delta's network, subject to approval from the Canadian government. 
Delta will operate daily flights from Seattle to Orlando and Boston starting Dec 19, 2015 and Apr 4, 2016, 
respectively. Likewise, the company will run three daily flights from Seattle to Pasco and Victoria effective Nov 1, 
2015 and Apr 4, 2016, respectively.<nl/>Delta will be operating Boeing 737-800 and 757-200 aircraft for servicing 
Boston and Orlando clients while 65-seat CRJ-700 jets will be used for Bozeman, Pasco and Victoria.<nl/>Of late, 
the Seattle-Tacoma International Airport has been gaining significant importance for Delta's operations. The 
company has already invested $15 million to improve the facilities at the airport and plans to flag off nearly 128 
fights from there to 36 locations.<nl/>Earlier, Delta had filed for regulatory approval to connect Orlando, FL and Sao 
Paulo, Brazil. The company also intends to introduce non-stop flights on the route effective Dec 19, 2015, following 
the authorization.<nl/>We believe that network expansion will not only drive air traffic for Delta but will also help the 
carrier gain greater market traction in Seattle in comparison to Alaska Air Group, Inc. ALK[2].<nl/>Delta currently 
carries a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). Better-ranked stocks in the airline space include Ryanair Holdings plc RYAAY[3] 
and SkyWest Inc. SKYW[4]. Both these stocks sport a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy).<nl/>Want the latest 
recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today, you can download 7 Best Stocks for the Next 30 Days.

EU carriers battle Gulf airlines' expansion
EU carriers battle Gulf airlines' expansion
Deutsche Welle Business
May 28, 2015 Thursday 6:55 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 862 words
Body
May 28, 2015( Deutsche Welle Business: http://www.dw-world.de/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Gulf-based airlines 
Etihad, Qatar, and Emirates have been rapidly expanding their networks in Europe, from German feeder cities like 
Berlin and Cologne. But Europe's flag carriers and their US allies are fighting back. 
Airlines based in the United Arab Emirates and Qatar have launched a full-pronged attack on the European aviation 
market by expanding long-haul service in Germany and creating hubs in cities like Italy's business capital Milan. But 
a coalition of EU-based airlines, backed by their US airline partners, alleges the Gulf airlines are benefitting from 
government subsidies that give them an unfair advantage.<nl/> "The gulf carriers are subsidized by their national 
treasuries," said Jill Zuckman, spokesperson for Open and Fair Skies, a lobbying group backed by US and 
European airlines. "They can do whatever they want, like fly the biggest planes from small German cities, because 
they are subsidized," Zuckman added.<nl/> Tough market place<nl/> European aviation authorities, however, have 
begun to strike back. Earlier this week, Dutch authorities froze Gulf carriers' flights at existing levels to prevent them 
from increasing to twice daily flights at Amsterdam's Schiphol airport.<nl/> It's a move that Zuckman says is long 
overdue - and one she hopes the US will follow. "In the US, we are hoping to get a resolution before the country's 
aviation system is damaged in the same way the European system has been damaged."<nl/> European carriers 
like Air France-KLM and Lufthansa are increasingly finding themselves in a squeeze: while low-cost carriers like 
Ryanair and EasyJet have won over budget travellers, the Gulf carriers - with their on-board showers and private 
suites - are picking off the top-end flyers. <nl/> Combine that with numerous labor strikes and the higher cost of 
doing business in Europe, and the EU airlines find themselves in a bind.<nl/> Fifth freedom factor <nl/> EU and US 
airlines also question the Gulf airlines' use of fifth freedom rights - these rules permit airlines to fly between cities 
outside of their home countries. A Delta flight between Singapore and Tokyo or a Lufthansa flight between Kuala 
Lumpur and Bangkok would be considered an example.<nl/> The flights are supposed to feed traffic to flights that 
route back to airlines' home markets, but many airlines sell seats on these fifth freedom flights without requiring 
flyers to continue onward to the airline's home market.<nl/> Emirates' Milan to New York fifth freedom flight is seen 
as a major bone of contention. US and EU airlines say that because Emirates is state owned and subsidized, it can 
test out new routes like the Milan-JFK route with new airplanes like the Airbus A380, and sell tickets on those flights 
at below-market rates. <nl/> Emirates counters that the route - underserved after Alitalia cut service a year earlier - 
connects Italy's business hub and wealthiest region to New York, and thus makes perfect sense.<nl/> In Germany, 
Abu Dhabi-based Etihad is seen as posing a major threat to German flag carrier Lufthansa. Etihad offers direct 
flights to Abu Dhabi from Cologne, Hamburg, Dusseldorf, and Berlin. It has also made significant investments in 
European airlines like Aer Lingus, Air Serbia, airberlin, and Alitalia.<nl/> A study by Richard Klophaus of the 
Competence Center Aviation Management at Worms University of Applied Sciences Etihad's, notes that these 
EU carriers battle Gulf airlines' expansion
investments could allow Etihad to create a steady stream of European traffic that could sustain several fifth freedom 
trans-Atlantic services - further cutting into routes presently served by EU and US carriers. <nl/> However, 
Klophaus says that's unlikely to happen right now due to "regulatory constraints and commercial reasons."<nl/> 
Intense competition<nl/> The Gulf carriers have also decimated flights between India and the United States through 
Europe. In 2008, Gulf airlines accounted for 2.8 percent of booked seats from Dallas Fort Worth to Mumbai, and 
US/European airlines took 81.1 percent of booked seats.<nl/> But by 2014, that had flipped completely - with Gulf 
carriers scooping up about 69.6 percent of booking share on this route, and the share of European/US airlines 
slipping to 28.7 percent.<nl/> Experts like Zuckman say that's because the Gulf airlines are able to offer rock-
bottom prices on brand new airplanes. Her trade group says that Etihad, Emirates, and Qatar airways are 
subsidized to the tune of $42 billion through loans and free landing fees. That has meant intense competition - not 
only for US and EU airlines, but even among the Gulf airlines themselves, who are engaged in a sort of race to the 
bottom to offer the cheapest fares possible, Zuckman stresses.<nl/> It's still unclear whether the US will follow the 
Dutch in freezing the number of flights the Gulf carriers are allowed to operate from American airports. Zuckman, for 
her part, says the Gulf airlines seem to be taking the threat seriously.<nl/> "They are sort of racing around the clock 
to add new flights to the US before a freeze might be imposed," she noted.<nl/> 
Load-Date: May 28, 2015
End of Document

Wednesday.<nl/>

Holdings Plc has a 1-year low of GBX 6.44800 and a 1-year high of GBX 11.63000. The stock has a 50-day moving 
average of GBX 1108.079 and a 200-day moving average of GBX 1009.340. The company's market cap is £15.94 
billion.<nl/> Ryanair Holdings plc is an Ireland-based holding company for Ryanair Limited (LON:RYA[2]). Ryanair

Stock Futures Slightly Higher As Market Looks To Bounce
Stock Futures Slightly Higher As Market Looks To Bounce
Stock Market Today
May 27, 2015 Wednesday 7:50 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 273 words
Body
May 27, 2015( Stock Market Today: http://www.investors.com/stock-market-today/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> 
Stock futures were modestly higher in premarket trading Wednesday, looking to bounce back after a sell-off the 
prior day.<nl/>
 Futures of the Nasdaq, S...00 and Dow Jones industrial average were all up 0.2%. The major indexes slid more 
than 1% Tuesday.<nl/> Facebook (NASDAQ:FB[1]) was up 0.3% in premarket activity. The stock is trading below 
the 50-day moving average as it tries to build the right side of a base.<nl/> Ryanair Holdings (NASDAQ:RYAAY[2]) 
was 2% higher ahead of the bell. The company reported earnings Tuesday. The Ireland-based airline is a major 
shareholder of Air Lingus , whose sale to IAG SA is closer now that the Irish government agreed to sell its stake in 
Air Lingus, reports said.<nl/> Ryanair, which has not said if it will sell its shares, is forming the right side of a 
base.<nl/> In European markets, London's FTSE 100 was up 0.7%, while Germany's DAX was up 0.3%. The Euro 
Stoxx Index was up 0.5%.<nl/> In Asia, bourses were mixed. The Tokyo Nikkei 225 climbed 0.2% and the Shanghai 
composite 0.6%; the Hong Kong Hang Seng fell 0.6%.<nl/> After a heavy day of economic reports, few numbers 
are coming out Wednesday. The Mortgage Bankers' Association mortgage application index for the week of May 22 
fell 1.6%. The purchase applications index, which measures applications at mortgage lenders and is a leading 
indicator, rose 1%.<nl/> [ 1]: http://research.investors.com/quotes/nasdaq-facebook-inc-cl-a-fb.htm [ 2]:            
http://research.investors.com/quotes/nasdaq-ryanair-hldgs-plc-adr-ryaay.htm

Low cost carriers - more connections and lower prices
Low cost carriers - more connections and lower prices
Deutsche Welle Germany
May 27, 2015 Wednesday 1:48 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 370 words
Body
May 27, 2015( Deutsche Welle Germany: http://www.dw.de/top-stories/germany/s-1432 Delivered by Newstex) 
<nl/> The time for bargain hunters and frequent fliers in Germany has never been better. 
There are more cheap flight connections and offers than ever before. Early 2015 looks set to be a record year for 
cheap flights in Germany. Low cost carriers covered some 518 connections to and from Germany, which meant 
they exceeded their prior record of 507 connections, set during the winter 2011 flight schedule, according to the 
DLR German air and space travel agency's latest "Low Cost Monitor" (LCM) report. It logged 4,800 take-offs per 
week by low cost carriers in January 2015 - a new record in itself. There was also a marked increase in flight 
connections within Germany, as well as flights between Germany and Great Britain. <nl/> According to DLR 
statistics, Germanwings - with some 1,800 lift-offs per week and a market share of 38 percent - has managed to 
push ailing competitor AirBerlin off the top spot. This development also had to do with Germanwings taking over a 
lot of domestic flight connections outside of the travel hubs of Munich and Frankfurt from its parent group Lufthansa. 
AirBerlin meanwhile reduced its cheap airfare offer down to 1,700 flights a week. <nl/> Until recently there was no 
real competition in Germany among the low cost carriers - some 87 percent of connections, according to the DLR, 
are serviced only by cheap flight operators. But that is about to change, partly because major European low cost 
carrier Ryanair will be increasing competition. For years, the Irish company focused on flights to and from remote 
airports in the provinces, but now they are increasing their activity in big airport hubs like Berlin, Brussels, Cologne-
Bonn and Rome. "On those connections where there is competition, we expect the prices to continue to sink", said 
Johannes Reichmuth, Director of the Institute of Air Travel and Airport Research within the DLR. <nl/> The DLR 
findings also reveal that the seven biggest budget carriers Germanwings, AirBerlin, Ryanair, Easyjet, Wizz, flybe 
and Norwegian collectively account for 95 percent of Germany's low-cost flight market. <nl/> sc/msh (dpa)<nl/> 
Load-Date: May 27, 2015
End of Document
Low cost carriers - more connections and lower prices
Low cost carriers - more connections and lower prices
Deutsche Welle Visit Germany

May 27, 2015( Deutsche Welle Visit Germany: http://www.dw.de/top-stories/visit-germany/s-7550 Delivered by 
Newstex) <nl/> The time for bargain hunters and frequent fliers in Germany has never been better. 
There are more cheap flight connections and offers than ever before. Early 2015 looks set to be a record year for 
cheap flights in Germany. Low cost carriers covered some 518 connections to and from Germany, which meant 
they exceeded their prior record of 507 connections, set during the winter 2011 flight schedule, according to the

lot of domestic flight connections outside of the travel hubs of Munich and Frankfurt from its parent group Lufthansa.

findings also reveal that the seven biggest budget carriers Germanwings, AirBerlin, Ryanair, Easyjet, Wizz, flybe 
and Norwegian collectively account for 95 percent of Germany's low-cost flight market. <nl/> sc/msh (dpa)<nl/>

What Helped Ryanair Outperform Many European Airlines ? - Analyst Blog
What Helped Ryanair Outperform Many European Airlines? - Analyst Blog
Zacks Investment Research
May 27, 2015 Wednesday 10:10 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 772 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
May 27, 2015( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Recently, Irish low-
cost carrier Ryanair Holdings plc RYAAY[1] reported robust financial and operating numbers with net profit for the 
year ended Mar 2015 rising 66% year over year to €867 million. Moreover, load factor increased by 500 basis 
points to stand at 88% while air traffic jumped 11% to 90.6 million.<nl/>
Such a strong performance by Ryanair was mainly supported by low fuel prices, attractive fares, continuous route 
expansion, allocated seating and the introduction of an extra carry-on luggage facility. Moreover, to enhance 
passenger satisfaction, the carrier launched an AGB program addressing customer related issues, which as a result 
has seen massive customer gains.<nl/>In order to target business class passengers, Ryanair has introduced 
business-friendly ticket facilities which have further driven demand for the carrier, thereby improving profits. 
However, profits in the reported period were offset by the company's decision to enter into a long-term fuel hedge 
contract of $92 per barrel.<nl/>Robust passenger count growth coupled with a busy summer holiday season have 
encouraged the carrier to peg its fiscal 2016 profit expectations in the €940 to €970 million range. The company 
also expects more than 100 million passengers in the fiscal.<nl/>Ryanair is also eyeing the transatlantic route with 
extremely low fares for a one-way trip. If successful in implementing its plans, the company will likely pose 
significant competitive threat to U.S. low-cost carriers like Southwest Airlines Co. LUV[2] and Spirit Airlines. <nl/>To 
support such large-scale expansion, the carrier has placed orders for Boeing 737-800 and Boeing 737-Max 200 
aircraft for delivery between 2014 and 2023. The new fleet size will not only help meet escalated travel demand but 
will also boost operating margins, going forward.<nl/>On the other hand, premium European carriers like Deutsche 
Lufthansa Aktiengesellschaft DLAKY[3] and Air France-KLM SA AFLYY[4] reported 106 million and 87.4 million 
passengers, respectively, in 2014. However, both the carriers reported loss of €732 million and €185 million, 
respectively, for the same period. Sluggish economic growth coupled with continuous strikes by pilots has hurt 
profits and passenger gain for both the carriers.<nl/>Ryanair - which currently carries a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy) 
- has been maintaining its strong performance over the last 30 years, surpassing most European carriers. Hence, 
we believe that Ryanair is poised to gain significantly from higher travel demand, enhanced customer friendly 
policies, attractive fares, increasing capacity and transatlantic route addition across the U.S. and European 
region.<nl/>Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today, you can download 7 Best 
Stocks for the Next 30 Days. Click to get this free report >>[5]<nl/>Want the latest recommendations from Zacks

Ireland to sell Aer Lingus stake to IAG
Ireland to sell Aer Lingus stake to IAG
Deutsche Welle Business
May 27, 2015 Wednesday 8:14 AM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 499 words
Body
May 27, 2015( Deutsche Welle Business: http://www.dw-world.de/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> International 
Consolidated Airlines Group has cleared a major hurdle in its bid to acquire Aer Lingus after the Irish government 
agreed to sell its 25-percent stake. 
The deal now requires support from rival Ryanair. The government in Dublin has paved the way for a formal bid for 
Aer Lingus by International Consolidated Airlines Group (IAG) after agreeing to sell its 25-percent stake to the 
owner of airlines British Airways and Iberia.<nl/> After a cabinet meeting on Tuesday, transport minister Paschal 
Donohoe said "extremely important changes" in IAG's previous offer had led to the government's decision.<nl/> 
Under the deal, IAG offers Aer Lingus shareholders 2.55 euros a share - 2.50 euros plus a 0.05 euros dividend - 
valuing the airline at 1.36 billion euros ($1.7 billion).<nl/> "Acquiring Aer Lingus would add a fourth competitive, 
cost-effective airline to IAG, enabling us to develop our network using Dublin," IAG Chief Executive Willie Walsh 
said in a statement.<nl/> The sale of the government's stake now enables IAG to make a formal bid to the Aer 
Lingus' other major shareholder, low-cost carrier Ryanair, which holds a 30-percent stake. Ryanair spokesman 
Robin Kiely told the news agency AFP its board "will consider any offer on its merits, if and when an offer is 
made".<nl/> Major assurances<nl/> The sale has been a hot topic for Dublin, with severe opposition within the 
junior government coalition party, Labour, and from unions who warned about implications for jobs and aviation 
connectivity.<nl/> But late Tuesday night a group of eight Labour lawmakers, who had questioned the deal, backed 
the proposals, saying they were "satisfied" their concerns had been met.<nl/> Dublin said IAG had made 
commitments on the future of the airline, promising to maintain the brand, sustain its existing routes, create new 
jobs and ensure the airline's lucrative landing slots at London's Heathrow airport would not be sold for seven 
years.<nl/> But labor unions reiterated their fears about job losses and deteriorating working conditions after 
restructuring, saying they would oppose the sale if their concerns were not addressed.<nl/> Ireland's largest public 
sector trade union IMPACT said the takeover would be "bad for jobs, for Aer Lingus workers and for Ireland's 
connectivity and economic development".<nl/> "The interests of IAG shareholders will always trump the interests of 
the Irish economy and the Irish travelling public," the union said in a statement.<nl/> The leader of the opposition 
Sinn Fein party, Gerry Adams, said earlier on Tuesday that IAG's concessions would be "merely a stay of 
execution" on the airline's valuable Heathrow slots.<nl/> Ireland's ruling coalition will put the decision to a vote in 
parliament on Wednesday, while the European Commission will have to assess the takeover on competition 
grounds later on.<nl/> uhe/pad (Reuters, AFP, dpa)<nl/> 
Load-Date: May 27, 2015
Ireland to sell Aer Lingus stake to IAG
End of Document
Spirit Airlines (SAVE) to Connect Los Angeles Oakland - Analyst Blog
Spirit Airlines (SAVE) to Connect Los Angeles Oakland - Analyst Blog
Zacks Investment Research
May 27, 2015 Wednesday 2:40 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 676 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
May 27, 2015( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Spirit Airlines 
SAVE[1] plans to flag off non-stop flights between Los Angeles International Airport (LAX) and Oakland 
International Airport (OAK), starting Nov 12, 2015. Under this latest plan, the company will operate one morning and 
one evening non-stop flight on a daily basis.<nl/>With the launch of this service, travelers from Los Angeles will 
able to save time by skipping the four-hour road journey to San Francisco. 
Moreover, passengers will benefit from Spirit Airlines' affordable ticket rates, thereby increasing air traffic and load 
factor (percentage of seats filled with passengers) for the carrier. Furthermore, the new offering will open up more 
travel options during a busy holiday season.<nl/>Interestingly, Spirit Airlines charges 40% lower ticket rates as 
compared to other carriers. Even after considering value-added services, the ticket prices have been kept at a 
significant 35% discounted rate. This largely attracts budget-conscious passengers who can avail flight services to 
their favorite destinations at such reasonable costs.<nl/>Moreover, the company's Ultra-Low Bare Fares (TM) 
program and the Frill Control (TM) service allow passengers to pay for only those services that they require.<nl/>In 
the first quarter of 2015, Spirit Airlines came up with strong financial numbers. Operating revenues surged a 
significant 12.6% year over year while adjusted net income grew 85%. Lower fuel costs and 22.1% growth in 
Revenue Passenger Miles (RPM) or air traffic have supported the upside. The company also exited the reported 
quarter with 70 flights, up 25% year over year.<nl/>Hence, we believe that launch of such new services coupled 
with increased number of carriers under its belt will continue to drive profits for the company going 
forward.<nl/>Spirit Airlines currently carries a Zacks Rank #4 (Sell).<nl/>Stocks to Consider<nl/>Better-ranked 
stocks in the same industry include Ryanair Holdings plc RYAAY[2], SkyWest Inc. SKYW[3] and JetBlue Airways 
Corporation JBLU[4]. Both Ryanair and SkyWest sport a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy) while JetBlue carries a Zacks 
Rank #2 (Buy).<nl/>Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today, you can download

Airline Stock Roundup: Southwest Capacity Forecast Triggers Major Selloff, Ryanair Outperforms - Analyst 
Blog
Airline Stock Roundup: Southwest Capacity Forecast Triggers Major Selloff, 
Ryanair Outperforms - Analyst Blog
Zacks Investment Research
May 27, 2015 Wednesday 10:10 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 1680 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
May 27, 2015( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> There were quite a 
few updates last week from companies in the airline industry. However, all that was overshadowed by the airline 
sell-off that reflected dwindling investor confidence. The airline industry, which has had an incredibly good run over 
the past couple of years, tumbled significantly last Wednesday.<nl/>
The trigger was Southwest Airlines' LUV[1] announcement at the Wolfe research global transportation conference 
that it plans to increase its capacity in the band of 7% to 8% in 2015 as opposed to the earlier projection of a 7% 
increase.<nl/>Southwest's projection caused panic among investors who feared that the capacity expansion would 
lead to an oversupplied market even as fuel costs continue to be weak. The capacity additions could further result 
in a possible price war between legacy and low-cost airlines.<nl/>Meanwhile, American Airlines Group's AAL[2] 
CEO Doug Parker stated that the carrier intends to compete aggressively against the capacity expansion and will 
not lose customers on pricing grounds. However, some market watchers have called the selloff, which caused a 
loss of approximately $10 billion in market value last Wednesday, a mere overreaction.<nl/>Apart from this, airline 
behemoth Delta Air Lines DAL[3] was in the headlines owing to its plans for expansion in Brazil. Not falling behind, 
Southwest Airlines, in keeping with its expansion initiatives, announced a new non-stop service from the Ronald 
Reagan Washington National Airport (DCA) to Orlando, FL, effective Nov 1, 2015.<nl/>According to data released 
by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, average airfares in the U.S. for the month of April decreased 1.3% over Mar 
2015. The April figure was also down 7.5% on a year-over-year basis.<nl/>European low-cost carrier Ryanair 
Holdings plc RYAAY[4] performed very well in fiscal 2015 (ended Mar 31, 2015). The annual net profit of this 
Ireland-based budget airline jumped 66% on a year-over-over basis on the back of increased revenues and low 
costs. Moreover, the carrier, which is seeing good times thanks to its customer friendly 'Always Getting Better 
(AGB)' scheme, presented a rosy outlook for fiscal 2016. <nl/>Overall, it was a bearish week for the sector. Major 
airline stocks plummeted in the wake of the airline sell-off. The upward movement of oil prices added to the woes. 
In view of this bearish sentiment, the NYSE ARCA Airline index declined 3.4% over the past week.<nl/> (Read the 
last Airline Stock Roundup for May 20, 2015[5]) <nl/>Recap of the Past Week's Most Important Stories <nl/>1. 
Share prices of major airline stocks including Southwest Airlines, United Continental Holdings UAL[6] and American 
Airlines plummeted following the news that Southwest Airlines intends to increase its capacity in the range of 7% to 
8% in 2015 as opposed to the earlier projection of a 7% increase.<nl/>Investors were clearly concerned that airline 
capacity growth at a rate higher than the U.S. GDP would lead to an oversupplied market. With major airline stocks 
Airline Stock Roundup: Southwest Capacity Forecast Triggers Major Selloff, Ryanair Outperforms - Analyst 
Blog
plummeting, the recently launched airline ETF - U.S. Global Jets ETF - also lost value (read more: Air Stocks and 
ETF Plunge[7]).<nl/>2. Delta Air Lines, which is constantly looking to expand its operations, filed for regulatory 
approval to connect Orlando, FL and Sao Paulo, Brazil. Delta intends to introduce non-stop flights on the route 
effective Dec 19, 2015 following the approval. Delta's agreement with Brazilian carrier GOL Linhas Aereas 
Inteligentes GOL[8] should pay off well in this regard (read more: Delta to Expand in Brazilian Skies, Connect 
Orlando-Sao Paulo[9] ).<nl/>3. In a bid to expand its operations and improve customer convenience, Southwest 
Airlines announced that it intends to boost its service in Florida. In line with this objective, the carrier intends to 
introduce a non-stop flight on a daily basis on the DCA- Orlando route from Nov 2015 (read more: Southwest 
Airlines to Boost Service in Florida[10])<nl/> 4. Data released by the Bureau of Labor Statistics suggest that 
average airfares in the U.S. for Apr 2015 declined 7.5% on a year-over-year basis. Soft oil prices over the period 
and increased competition were primarily responsible for the decline. The figure was down 1.3% from Mar 2015 on 
a seasonally adjusted basis, once again reflecting the brunt of soft oil prices (read more: Airline Fares Decline in 
April, Soft Oil Prices Hold Key[11]).<nl/>5. Ryanair Holdings reported robust financial and operating numbers with 
net profit for fiscal 2015 up 66% year over year at €867 million. Moreover, load factor increased 500 basis points to 
88% while air traffic for the year jumped 11% to 90.6 million. The strong performance of Ryanair was mainly buoyed 
by lower fuel prices, attractive fares, continuous route expansion, allocated seating and extra carry-on luggage 
facilities.<nl/>Moreover, the carrier has launched the AGB program which has drawn massive number of new 
customers to Ryanair. In order to target business class passengers, Ryanair has launched business friendly air 
ticket facilities which have further driven demand for the carrier, thus ramping up profits. However, profit for the 
reported period was offset by the company's decision to enter into a long-term fuel hedge contract of $92 per 
barrel.<nl/>Robust passenger growth coupled with the onset of one of the busiest summer holiday seasons ever 
has encouraged the carrier to expect profits for fiscal 2016 in the range of €940 million to €970 million. The 
company also plans to carry more than 100 million passengers for the first time in fiscal 2016.<nl/>Performance 
<nl/>The following table shows the price movement of the major airline players over the past week and during the 
last 
6 
months. <nl/> <nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/>

>As the chart above suggests, all airline stocks traded in the red over the past week, due to the major selloff in the 
space. Shares of American Airlines Group depreciated the most, losing 15.67% over the past week. Furthermore, 
most of the stocks shed value over the last six months. JetBlue Airways JBLU[12] was a notable exception having 
gained appreciably (33.70%) over the six-month period.<nl/>What's Next in the Airline Biz?<nl/>With the recent 
airline sell-off on capacity and pricing worries deemed more of an overreaction, we expect the dust to settle soon. 
With nothing major lined up at the moment, stay tuned for usual news updates in the space. Focus, in particular, will 
remain on the price movement of airline stocks, given the volatile nature of oil prices lately.<nl/>Want the latest

EFA, ICLN: Big ETF Inflows
EFA, ICLN: Big ETF Inflows
Market News Video
May 27, 2015 Wednesday 3:47 PM EST

Body

May 27, 2015 (Market News Video:http://marketnewsvideo.com/ Delivered by Newstex)
 Comparing units outstanding versus one week ago at the coverage universe of ETFs at ETF Channel, the biggest 
inflow was seen in the iShares MSCI EAFE ETF (EFA), which added 7,800,000 units, or a 0.9% increase week over 
week. Among the largest underlying components of EFA, in morning trading today Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY) is up 
about 1.4%. 
And on a percentage change basis, the ETF with the biggest increase in inflows was the iShares Global Clean 
Energy ETF (ICLN), which added 1,600,000 units, for a 25.0% increase in outstanding units. Among the largest 
underlying components of ICLN, in morning trading today SolarCity (SCTY) is off about 0.1%, and Companhia 
Energtica de Minas Gerais (CIG) is lower by about 0.2%.

Ryanair is predicting an 'irrational' airline price war that could be great for customers
Ryanair is predicting an 'irrational' airline price war that could be great for 
customers
The Business Insider
May 26, 2015 Tuesday 8:20 AM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 683 words
Byline: owilliamsgrut@businessinsider.com,  (Oscar Williams-Grut) Oscar Williams-Grut
Body
May 26, 2015( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) ;<nl/> Budget airline 
tickets aren't exactly expensive right now thanks to low oil prices, but Ryanair thinks the cost of flying could fall even 
further.<nl/> Irish no-frills airline Ryanair reported its full-year results this morning[1], which revealed a 12% jump in 
revenue to €5.65 billion (£4 billion, $6.16 billion) and a 66% rise in profit after tax to €867 million (£613 million, $946 
million).<nl/>
 But it warned investors not to expect a similar rise next year, due to competition from rivals on ticket prices.<nl/> 
Here's Ryanair (emphasis ours): <nl/> While our traffic growth this year will be strong, (up 10%), it would be foolish 
not to expect some irrational pricing response from competitors who cannot compete with our lowest costs and 
fares. Ryanair will remain vigorously 'load factor active/price passive'. Therefore, even with the benefit of lower oil, 
aircraft and financing costs we may suffer periods of fare/yield weakness especially during the H2 winter 
season.<nl/> What that basically means is that Ryanair plans to focus on filling its planes — measured by load 
factor — to reap benefits from efficiency, rather than cutting ticket prices to attract more customers. <nl/> But if 
rivals do just that, it could hurt Ryanair's yield — a measure of revenue per customer, per mile flown — as it's 
forced to either trim prices or sees customer numbers fall. <nl/> If all this were to happen, it would be good news for 
consumers, as airlines would be offering cheaper seats in a bid to win business.<nl/> Ryanair, which celebrates its 
30th birthday in July, has itself upped competition with its main European rival, easyJet, by focusing on customer 
service, something it was once notorious for being bad at. Ryanair has made changes including allowing customers 
to select seats at check-in and take an extra piece of hand luggage on board for free.<nl/> The company praised its 
"Always Getting Better" transformation plan for helping boost customer numbers by 11% to 90.6 million in the year. 
This is what boosted revenue and profits, along with cheap oil. <nl/> A drop in oil prices cut costs by 5% last year, 
but this is a smaller benefit than at other airlines. Ryanair buys 90% of its fuel well in advance through "hedging" 
agreements to guard against a jump in price. What this means is it agrees a price to buy the fuel many months 
before the actual deal is done. This protects the company from any sharp and unexpected price jumps.<nl/> This 
practice will also pin back growth next year as oil is hedged at $92 (£59) a barrel, well above its current price of 
around $65 (£42) a barrel.<nl/>Aer Lingus battle<nl/>Ryanair also used its results to attack the UK's Competition 
and Markets Authority (CMA). The watchdog has ordered Ryanair to sell its 29.8% stake in rival Irish airline Aer 
Lingus. The CMA argues the stake is anti-competitive and also puts off potential bidders for Aer Lingus.<nl/> British 
Airways owner IAG has since been bidding for Aer Lingus[2], but an appeal by Ryanair to have its sell order revoke 
in light of the buyer interest was rejected. Ryanair said today: "We believe the CMA will be totally discredited if they 
Ryanair is predicting an 'irrational' airline price war that could be great for customers
do not reverse this manifestly erroneous ruling."<nl/> The company added: "In the meantime our approach to the 
IAG offer remains unchanged. The Board of Ryanair will consider any offer (should we receive one) from IAG on its 
merits, if or when it is received." IAG and Aer Lingus are negotiating.<nl/>NOW WATCH: Forget the Apple Watch 
— 
here's 
the 
new 
watch 
everyone 
on 
Wall 
Street 
wants[3]<nl/> 
[

http://uk.businessinsider.com/afp-aer-lingus-says-considering-improved-bid-from-iag-2015-
1?utm_source=partner..._medium=newstex..._term=original..._campaign=partner 
[ 
3]:

Ryanair reports big rise in profits
Ryanair reports big rise in profits
Business Matters
May 26, 2015 Tuesday 8:18 AM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 224 words
Byline: Business Matters
Body
May 26, 2015( Business Matters: http://www.bmmagazine.co.uk/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Net profit for the year 
to the end of March rose 66 per cent to €867m (£614m; $948m), slightly ahead of analysts' expectations, reports 
The BBC[1].<nl/>
 The airline's 'Always Getting Better' customer experience programme had attracted 'millions of new customers to 
Ryanair', chief executive Michael O'Leary said.<nl/> Falling oil prices also reduced operating costs.<nl/> 'Our AGB 
programme is transforming our customer experience, our service, and the way we listen and respond to our 
customers,' 
Mr 
O'Leary 
said.<nl/> 
'We 
have 
won 
substantial 
traffic 
and 
share 
gains 
in 
all 
markets.'<nl/><nl/>Passenger traffic was up 11 per cent to 90.6 million customers, while total revenue rose 12 per 
cent to more than €5.6bn.<nl/> To cope with rising demand, Ryanair said it had ordered 183 Boeing 737-800 planes 
for delivery from 2014-18, and 200 Boeing 737 Max 200s from 2019-2023.<nl/> The new aircraft will be cheaper to 
finance and operate, with engines 18% more efficient than their predecessors, the company said.<nl/> Much of the 
growth in passenger numbers is being driven by its new Business Plus and Family Extra services, it added.<nl/> [ 
1]: 
http://go.redirectingat.com/?id=8781X675786...1...=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.bbc.co.uk%2Fnews%2Fbusiness-
32880096...f=rss

Stocks Skid Early As Home Prices Top; Ryanair Up On Earnings Beat
Stock Market Today
May 26, 2015 Tuesday 3:49 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 265 words
Body
May 26, 2015( Stock Market Today: http://www.investors.com/stock-market-today/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> 
Stocks opened lower and worsened Tuesday morning, with the Nasdaq falling 1% and the S...00 and Dow slipping 
0.8% each.Volume was tracking higher across the board in the stock market today[1] compared with a sluggish 
pace Friday.<nl/>
 Economic reports gave investors plenty to think about after the long weekend.<nl/> Home prices rose 0.9% 
sequentially and 5% year over year in March, according to the latest S...ase-Shiller price index. Price gains came in 
slightly above consensus estimates for 0.9% sequential and 4.6% year-over-year growth. Nineteen of the 20 cities 
in the composite index reported price gains, led by a 3% rise in San Francisco.<nl/> Durable goods orders fell 0.5% 
in April, matching expectations.<nl/> Consumer confidence numbers ticked higher and narrowly topped 
expectations.<nl/> Recent new issue Party City (NYSE:PRTY[2]) climbed 0.5% early. Deutshe Bank initiated 
coverage with a buy rating and 25 price target. The stock is trading just below a 22.24 buy point in a short IPO 
pattern.<nl/> Irish budget airline Ryanair Holdings (NASDAQ:RYAAY[3]) climbed 3% after topping analyst earnings 
expectations with its fiscal Q4 results. The stock has been consolidating since January and is about 6% below its 
52-week 
high.<nl/>

Ryanair profit takes off on passenger growth
Ryanair profit takes off on passenger growth
Deutsche Welle Business
May 26, 2015 Tuesday 8:17 AM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 249 words
Body
May 26, 2015( Deutsche Welle Business: http://www.dw-world.de/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Irish no-frills carrier 
Ryanair has reported a strong increase in profit for the fiscal year to March. 
The airline said improved results were attributable to better customer service leading to higher passenger numbers. 
Ryanair reported Tuesday its profit after tax soared to 867 million euros ($948 million) in the fiscal year to March, 
marking a 66-percent increase in bottom-line earnings year on year.<nl/> Europe's largest airline by passenger 
numbers saw the volume of its clients rise by 11 percent to 90 million, hitting a much higher level than the 4 percent 
penciled in at the start of the fiscal year.<nl/> Executives said a big chunk of the full-year growth was attributable to 
its Always Getting Better program aimed at turning round Ryanair's reputation for poor customer service.<nl/> 
Tailor-made offers<nl/> "Always Getting Better is the key, it has been very well received," finance chief Neil 
Sorahan said in an interview.<nl/> The program has introduced lower fees, flexible tickets for business travelers 
and a move away from small regional airports.<nl/> The airline once again declined to provide any details on 
whether it planned to accept an offer by British Airways owner IAG for its 30-percent stake in Aer Lingus. "The 
board of Ryanair will consider any offer from IAG on its merits, if or when it is received," the company said in a 
statement.<nl/> hg/pad (dpa, Reuters)<nl/> 
Load-Date: May 26, 2015
