No sign of take off as Lufthansa pilots extend strike to three days
No sign of take off as Lufthansa pilots extend strike to three days
Deutsche Welle Germany
March 19, 2015 Thursday 2:49 AM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 269 words
Body
Mar 19, 2015( Deutsche Welle Germany: http://www.dw.de/top-stories/germany/s-1432 Delivered by Newstex) 
<nl/> Lufthansa passengers are set to face a third consecutive day of travel chaos after German pilots union 
Vereinigung Cockpit extended the ongoing strike until Friday. 
The walk-out is the thirteenth in a year. Vereinigung Cockpit called on Lufthansa pilots on Wednesday evening to 
extend the ongoing strike to Friday, with short and medium-haul flights facing disruptions.<nl/> The first day of the 
current walk out saw the cancellation of some 750 domestic flights. Around 80,000 passengers planning to travel on 
short- and medium-haul flights were affected.<nl/> The announcement came just hours before the Lufthansa pilots 
began their second day of strikes, which extended across long-haul and cargo flights.<nl/> Flights with Lufthansa's 
subsidiary carriers, Germanwings and Eurowings, remained unaffected.<nl/> Retirement dispute<nl/> The ongoing 
dispute between Germany's flagship air carrier and Cockpit lies at the heart of the airline's plans to compete with 
low-cost airlines sich as Ryanair and easyJet.<nl/> In order to cut costs and expand budget operations, Lufthansa is 
proposing to raise the age at which its pilots can take early retirement. The airline's pilots are currently currently 
able to retire at age 55 and receive up to 60 percent of their pay until the normal pension kicks in at the age of 
65.<nl/> Months of renewed strikes have followed unsuccessful negotiations, which cost Lufthansa around 232 
million euros ($245 million) last year alone.<nl/> ksb/bk (Reuters, AFP, dpa)<nl/> 
Load-Date: March 19, 2015
End of Document
Watch-list of European Islamic State sympathisers stands at 10,000 people
Watch-list of European Islamic State sympathisers stands at 10,000 people
Atlas Shrugs
March 19, 2015 Thursday 4:00 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 690 words
Byline: Pamela Geller
Body
Mar 19, 2015( Atlas Shrugs: http://pamelageller.com/# Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> How long do the media and 
cultural elites expect people to buy the 'it's just a tiny fringe' line of taqiyya?<nl/> I mean, really.<nl/>            
http://pamelageller.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Britons-travelling-to-Join-Islamic-State-in-Syria-
564225.jpg<nl/> 'Watch-list of suspected European Islamic State sympathisers stands at 10,000 people,' By Aaron 
Brown, Express.co.uk[1]<nl/>
 THE SHEER quantity of names handed over by the EU makes the task of policing the Turkish border with Syria an 
almost IMPOSSIBLE task, an expert has warned.<nl/> Jytte Klausen, who is the founder of the Western Jihadism 
Project, said the watchlist given to officials is a 'capacity busting proposition'.<nl/> 'The Turks complained that they 
can't do it, and you know what, they can't,' the Harvard and Brandeis University professor explained.<nl/> 'It's a 
capacity busting proposition, to watch out for 10,000 westerners.<nl/> 'They are not going to be able to check most 
names on that list of 10,000.<nl/> 'Only if there is a case where there is an urgent bulletin out, because it has been 
discovered that they had left - and the urgent bulletin would be on the top of the desk - that's when you can catch 
people as happened here.'<nl/> Her comments come hours after three British teenage boys were detained by 
officials in the country as they planned to travel to Syria.<nl/> The three teens were detained after British police 
were made aware on Friday two boys had gone missing and were believed to be travelling to Syria.<nl/> Inquiries 
revealed they had travelled with a third person, the 19-year-old man.<nl/> It has been reported that the trio travelled 
to Spain and then took a flight to Turkey.<nl/><nl/>PA<nl/> Left to Right: The suspected Jihadi Brides - Kadiza 
Sultana, Shamima Begum and Amira Abase <nl/> Hayat Boumedienne, the widow of one of the terrorists who 
carried out an attack in Paris in January, also touched down in Syria via Turkey and Spain.<nl/>Prof Klausen 
described the indirect routes that are increasingly taken by would-be jihadists.<nl/> Due to gaps in intelligence 
sharing, travelling through another country makes it easier to arrive undetected.<nl/> She said: 'There is not 
comprehensive data sharing among the European Union countries with respect to people who are merely 
suspected of doing something. Getting on a plane is subject to far less scrutiny than getting off a plane.<nl/> 
'Therefore you have airports like Gatwick, and other European airports, that have a lot of discount airlines flying 
out.<nl/> 'They have been put under strict orders to look out for certain risk profiles. But they look out for their own 
folk, so at Gatwick, you are not going to look for people from Spain, and vice versa.'<nl/><nl/>Booking seperate 
tickets and splitting up the journey to war torn Syria can make it more difficult for authorities to hunt down the would-
be Jihadis, she warned.<nl/>She added: 'It's become common practice to buy separate itineraries, so if you book on 
Ryanair to go to Spain, and you were booked on another itinerary to go from Spain to Istanbul, those two itineraries 
do not come up as connected travel documents when you leave Gatwick.'<nl/> She added that Turkey was not the 
Watch-list of European Islamic State sympathisers stands at 10,000 people
only route to reach Syria. 'We do know of a number of people who have not flown directly from Spain to Turkey, but 
who have taken the far more cumbersome route through north Africa.'<nl/> Once through immigration in Turkey, 'It 
really is as easy as getting on a bus', she said.<nl/> 'I think there is a lot of very innocent traffic there too (going to 
the border).<nl/> 'I have been on those buses in Turkey, everyone goes on the buses, there are a lot of tourists. 
How are you going to tell from a bunch of young girls who are tourists from people who want to go to Syria?'<nl/> 
She added: 'These days most of them dress like tourists, or if they have a beard they shave it. The girls dress like 
normal teenagers.'<nl/> [ 1]: http://www.express.co.uk/news/world/564225/ISIS-Islamic-State-European-Union-
Turkey-Immigration-Border-Syria

http://www.planebuzz.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/04/home-typewriter-copy-1.jpgYou know, one of these days 
we need to stop posting in the middle of the night. 
One of these days.<nl/> Hello earthlings! Goodness. We've had back to back issues within less than a week this 
last week due to yours truly traipsing around the countryside.<nl/> Last week I was at the ISTAT Americas 
conference in Scottsdale. Subscribers got to hear about the Bombardier/Embraer presentation that proved 
Bombardier doesn't have a clue as to how to address the perception issues of its CSeries. Then we talked a great 
deal about AVITAS SVP Adam Pilarski's update on the price of oil and why he thinks it's not going higher anytime 
soon.<nl/> For more than a few years, Adam has steadfastly said that oil was going to drop to $40 a barrel — and 
his reasons seem pretty valid today.<nl/> Then we talked about just what Air Lease Corp.'s Steve Hazy wants in 
Boeing's new airplane. Hint: Twin aisle. 200-225 seats.<nl/> But we talked about a lot more — but that was last 
week.<nl/> In this week's follow-up issue we give you our take on the Aviation Summit that was held in Washington 
on Tuesday. This year it became a place where both sides of the Open Skies fight presented their respective cases. 
Lots of noise around all of this — but all of that really means nothing. We remain convinced that the report the U.S. 
carriers has put together is more than enough for the State Department to open up consultations on the Open Skies 
agreements.<nl/> We also talk this week about American Airlines' inclusion in the S...00; Ryanair's plans to start up 
a trans-Atlantic operation; Spirit's descent into adolescent frat house humor again; Spirit's arrival in the monthly 
DOT Air Travel Consumer Report, and we also have another Cranky Analysis column by Brett Snyder. This week 
Brett, who moonlights as a contributing editor for us, looks at the Atlanta market. Have fares gone down since 
Southwest Airlines has eliminated AirTran? Not hardly.<nl/> All of this, and much, much more — in this week's 
edition of PlaneBusiness Banter. [1]<nl/> [ 1]: http://www.planebusiness.com/banter/

The Zacks Analyst Blog Highlights: American Airlines Group, Ryanair 
Holdings, JetBlue Airways, Delta Airlines and United Continental Holdings - 
Press Releases
Zacks Investment Research

Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 2202 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
Mar 19, 2015( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) ;<nl/> For Immediate 
Release<nl/> <nl/> Chicago, IL - March 19, 2015 - Zacks.com announces the list of stocks featured in the Analyst 
Blog. Every day the Zacks Equity Research analysts discuss the latest news and events impacting stocks and the 
financial markets. 
Stocks recently featured in the blog include the American Airlines Group Inc. (AAL[1]-Free Report[2]), Ryanair 
Holdings (RYAAY[3]-Free Report[4]), JetBlue Airways Corporation (JBLU[5]-Free Report[6]), Delta Airlines (DAL[7]-
Free Report[8]) and United Continental Holdings (UAL[9]-Free Report[10]).<nl/> <nl/> Today, Zacks is promoting its 
''Buy'' stock recommendations. Get #1Stock of the Day pick for free[11].<nl/> <nl/> Here are highlights from 
Wednesday's Analyst Blog:<nl/> <nl/> Airline Stock Roundup<nl/> <nl/> It was a week which saw a new member 
from the airline space making its way into the coveted S...00 index - American Airlines Group Inc. (AAL[12]-Free 
Report[13]). The carrier is set to join the much sought-after list from Mar 20 (after market close), replacing Allergan, 
which has been acquired by Actavis.<nl/> <nl/> European low-cost carrier Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY[14]-Free 
Report[15]) also grabbed headlines during the week with its board approving plans to connect destinations between 
the U.S. and Europe at amazingly low fares. However, the transatlantic service is unlikely to commence before 
another four/five years.<nl/> <nl/> Low-cost carrier JetBlue Airways Corporation (JBLU[16]-Free Report[17]) was 
also in the news for a bilateral codeshare agreement inked with privately held Silver Airways. JetBlue also 
announced healthy traffic data for the month of February. Important metrics such as revenue passenger miles 
(RPMs - a measure of air traffic), available seat miles (measure of capacity) and load factor (% of seats filled by 
passengers) grew on a year-over-year basis during the month.<nl/> <nl/> On the price front, most airline stocks 
gained over the past 5 trading days, benefiting from plummeting oil prices. As a result, the NYSE ARCA Airline 
index climbed 5% over the said period.<nl/> <nl/> (Read the last 'Airline Stock Roundup' here: Delta-Led 
Consortium Complains, Republic Airways Included in S...00[18])<nl/> <nl/> Recap of the Most Important Stories 
Over the Past Week<nl/> <nl/> 1. JetBlue Airways inked a codeshare agreement with Florida-based Silver Airways 
with the aim to improve customer convenience. The current deal extends the Dec 2013 ticketing partnership signed 
by the two companies (read more: JetBlue, Silver Airways Ink Codeshare Pact; Strengthen Ties[19]).<nl/> <nl/> 
Furthermore, JetBlue Airways' Feb 2015 air traffic was up 10% year over year to 2.9 billion. Capacity improved 
The Zacks Analyst Blog Highlights: American Airlines Group , Ryanair Holdings , JetBlue Airways , Delta 
Airlines and United Continental Holdings - Press Release....
7.4% to 3.47 billion and load factor increased to 83.5% from 81.6% in Feb 2014 (read more: JetBlue's February 
Traffic Rises on Favorable Factors[20]).<nl/> <nl/> 2. American Airlines Group, formed following the Dec 2013 
merger of AMR (American Airlines' parent group) and US Airways, is set to join the S...00 after market close on Mar 
20. The carrier has been added to the S...00 GICS 'Industrials' sector or Airlines Sub-Industry index (read more: 
American Airlines Group to Enter Coveted S...00[21]).<nl/> <nl/> 3. According to media reports, the board of 
Ryanair has approved the carrier's plans to connect destinations across the U.S. and Europe. Approval has been 
gained to operate to and from around 14 European cities and almost an equivalent number of American cities. 
Ticket prices have been kept unbelievably low with one-way tickets between US and Europe costing approximately 
$15 (promotional offer) according to a report at investors.com.<nl/> <nl/> The services, however, are not 
commencing immediately. It will take another four to five years as Ryanair needs to bolster its fleet before entering 
the lucrative transatlantic market. In the event of Ryanair entering the U.S. market, competition would intensify for 
domestic carriers that already face the threat of market share reduction from Gulf carriers.<nl/> <nl/> 4. According 
to a report appearing in the Reuters, the dispute between US carriers and their Gulf counterparts took a fresh turn 
with the U.S. government asking Delta Airlines (DAL[22]-Free Report[23]), United Continental Holdings (UAL[24]-
Free Report[25]) and American Airlines Group to furnish more information to support their claim of massive 
subsidies enjoyed by certain Gulf carriers.<nl/> <nl/> The U.S. carriers, in a complaint to the Obama administration, 
had alleged that massive government subsidies have allowed Gulf carriers like Qatar Airways, Etihad Airways and 
Emirates to expand their fleet and international operations substantially, in turn, eating into their market share. 
According to the report, the Obama administration has put forward approximately 20 questions to representatives of 
the U.S. carriers based on their allegations.<nl/> <nl/> Today, Zacks is promoting its ''Buy'' stock recommendations. 
Get #1Stock of the Day pick for free[26].<nl/> <nl/> About Zacks Equity Research<nl/> <nl/> Zacks Equity 
Research provides the best of quantitative and qualitative analysis to help investors know what stocks to buy and 
which to sell for the long-term.<nl/> <nl/> Continuous coverage is provided for a universe of 1,150 publicly traded 
stocks. Our analysts are organized by industry which gives them keen insights to developments that affect company 
profits and stock performance. Recommendations and target prices are six-month time horizons.<nl/> <nl/> Zacks 
"Profit from the Pros" e-mail newsletter provides highlights of the latest analysis from Zacks Equity Research.

EFA, EUMV: Big ETF Inflows
EFA, EUMV: Big ETF Inflows
Market News Video
March 19, 2015 Thursday 7:50 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 188 words
Body
View Video
Mar 19, 2015 (Market News Video:http://marketnewsvideo.com/ Delivered by Newstex)
 Comparing units outstanding versus one week ago at the coverage universe of ETFs at ETF Channel, the biggest 
inflow was seen in the iShares MSCI EAFE ETF (EFA), which added 9,600,000 units, or a 1.1% increase week over 
week. Among the largest underlying components of EFA, in morning trading today Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY) is up 
about 0.1%. 
And on a percentage change basis, the ETF with the biggest increase in inflows was the iShares MSCI Europe 
Minimum Volatility ETF (EUMV), which added 50,000 units, for a 25.0% increase in outstanding units. Among the 
largest underlying components of EUMV, in morning trading today Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY) is up about 0.1%.

RyanAir To Introduce $15 Transatlantic Flights - Before Taxes
RyanAir To Introduce $15 Transatlantic Flights - Before Taxes
Taxgirl.com
March 18, 2015 Wednesday 7:49 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 991 words
Byline: Kelly Phillips Erb
Body
Mar 18, 2015( Taxgirl.com: http://www.taxgirl.com Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> I'm planning a trip to Europe[1] this 
year and preparing to take the kids along. There are three of them and as they've grown too big to successfully hide 
in my luggage (even though I pack rather light), that means that I get to buy them tickets, too. They love this. 
My bank account does not.<nl/> So you can imagine that I was pretty excited to hear that Europe's biggest budget 
carrier, Ryanair, is planning to offer some seriously cheap transatlantic flights by 2020. I realize that's still five years 
away but my kiddos will still be in tow by then (frankly, I can't imagine the youngest ever letting me leave without 
him - especially when he gets wind that I'm headed near an English Premier League site).<nl/> RyanAir's plan is to 
offer flights at deeply discounted prices from Europe to the U.S. I realize that's the wrong way (since I'm on this side 
of the pond) but I'm guessing those flights will also head back the other way. I can make this work - especially since 
tickets would start at £10 ($15 US). No, that's not a typo. They really are hoping to price tickets beginning at £10 
($15 US)[2], or roughly the cost that I pay to get to and from the City of Philadelphia by train. Suburban Philadelphia 
to Philadelphia, New York to London. What's the difference? Apparently, not much. Except for the whole flying over 
the ocean part.<nl/> But before you start planning your trip to Hogwarts, there's a catch: those little 'extras' for 
which RyanAir, like other budget airlines, charges you additional. Things like baggage and seat reservations. They 
also charge for air. Really. For £50 ($73 US) per hour, you can reserve therapeutic oxygen[3].<nl/> The real 
charges, however, are taxes[4]. You'll pay an estimated $200 in taxes for that £10 ($15 US) ticket from the U.K. to 
the U.S. That works out to about 1300%. And unlike the fare, you can't use a service like Kayak to negotiate your 
tax bill down.<nl/> BARCELONA, SPAIN - FEBRUARY 10: Planes operated by Vueling and RyanAir are seen at 
Aena operated Barcelona - El Prat International Airport on February 10, 2015 in Barcelona, Spain. Shares in state-
controlled Spanish airports operator, Aena, began trading today on the Madrid stock market. The Spanish 
government will retain a 51% controlling share in the firm, as it seeks to raise 3.9 billion Euros through the sale of 
the remaining 49%. Aena operates major hubs in Barcelona and Madrid, as well as a further 15 airports in Europe 
and America, including London Luton. (Photo by David Ramos/Getty Images)<nl/> In fact, taxes and fees on travel-
related services[5] continually astonish eager travelers each year. The cost of the most basic trip can easily 
escalate quickly. In the U.S., federal taxes and fees make up more than 20% of the cost of a typical $300 ticket. 
Even worse: the cost of fees and taxes has increased each year since 1971 even though the average cost of the 
base fare has decreased (you can download a historic list of air travel-related excise taxes here[6] as a pdf).<nl/> 
Inside our own borders (plus Canada and Mexico), your ticket could include a ticket tax of 7.5%; a flat Travel[7] 
Facilities Tax of $8.70 on flight segments to or from Alaska or Hawaii; a flat U.S. Federal Segment Fee of $4.00 
within the continental United States; a Passenger Facility Charge of up to $4.50 per facility; and the September 11th 
RyanAir To Introduce $15 Transatlantic Flights - Before Taxes
Security[8] Fee of up to $5.60 one-way[9], or $11.20 roundtrip (however, there's no cap so the fee applies to each 
of multiple stops).<nl/><nl/>And if you're wondering what all of this has to do with flights leaving from outside of our 
borders, that's because U.S. taxes may apply to those, too. You can expect to pay the U.S. International[10] 
Transportation Tax of $17.50 for all flights arriving in or departing from the United States, Puerto Rico, or the U.S. 
Virgin Islands; a $5.00 U.S. Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service Fee; and a $7.00 U.S. Immigration and 
Naturalization Fee for international arrivals. Those are just U.S. based fees: that doesn't include foreign taxes and 
fees imposed by other countries.<nl/> If those fees feel a little bit higher than this same time last year, you're not 
crazy. Fees were bumped last year. Specifically, on July 21, 2014, Congress boosted the September 11th Security 
Fee from $2.50 per leg with a $5.00 cap to $5.60 per leg with no cap. Folks weren't happy about that so the law 
changed again[11] in December 2014, imposing a cap on round trip travel. And before you exhale a breath because 
those fees are keeping us safe, it's worth noting that the fee hike is not earmarked for increased security: it was part 
of a deficit reduction strategy.<nl/> Other fees and taxes may also apply to hotels, booze and food - you certainly 
won't get out of a trip abroad tax free.<nl/> But look at it this way: if you're saving a few hundred dollars on airfare, 
you'll have more money for Guinness, Quidditch sets and invisibility cloaks (my kids swear we can buy those).<nl/> 
[ 1]: http://www.forbes.com/europe-news/ [ 2]:            http://money.cnn.com/2015/03/17/news/companies/ryanair-
transatlantic-flights/index.html [ 3]:            http://www.ryanair.com/us/questions/what-is-a-ryanair-therapeutic-
oxygen-medical-clearance-form/ [ 4]:            http://www.forbes.com/taxes/ [ 5]:            
http://www.forbes.com/sites/kellyphillipserb/2014/07/07/the-real-cost-of-summer-vacation-dont-get-buried-in-taxes/ [

http://www.faa.gov/about/office_org/headquarters_offices/apl/aatf/media/14.1.17ExciseTaxStructureCalendar2014.
pdf [ 7]:            http://www.forbes.com/travel/ [ 8]:            http://www.forbes.com/security/ [ 9]:            
http://www.tsa.gov/stakeholders/september-11-security-fee-passenger-fee 
[

Ryanair Passenger Traffic Jumps by 29%, Europe EHIC Services Limited Reports
Ryanair Passenger Traffic Jumps by 29%, Europe EHIC Services Limited 
Reports
SourceWire
March 18, 2015 Wednesday 11:21 AM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 512 words
Body
Mar 18, 2015( SourceWire: http://www.sourcewire.com Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Leading providers of the EHIC, 
Europe EHIC Services Limited, has reported on Ryanair's recent investment in more Boeing planes after passenger 
traffic jumps.<nl/>
<nl/>Ryanair have recently gone shopping for more jets and have bought three Boeing 737-800 aircraft of an 
estimated worth of $280 million at list price. The Irish firm has continued to enjoy strong traffic figures, which have 
led to the recent purchases. The latest Boeings will bring the total to 183 new 737-800's in Ryanair's hangars, with 
the latest three to be delivered early next year. <nl/><nl/>Chief executive, Michael O'Leary, wants to grow annual 
passenger numbers from 90 million passengers to 160 million passengers by 2024. The entrepreneur pointed out 
that the growth would create around 10,000 new positions for pilots, cabin crew and engineers, as tourism 
throughout Europe continues to grow. New routes across the EU will create new opportunities and jobs 
internationally across a range of sectors. <nl/><nl/>Creating more winter routes, rather than reducing capacity 
during the colder months, meant Ryanair saw its traffic grow by 29% to 5.8million fliers in February. The load factor, 
which measures how many plane seats were full, increased by 11% to 89%. <nl/><nl/>The airline has now outlined 
its latest customer service improvements for the coming years. They are set to begin trimming airport check-in fees 
and missed flight charges, and make it easier to opt-out of its own-brand travel insurance.<nl/><nl/>As experts in 
European travel, Europe EHIC Services Limited takes a keen interest in relevant industry news. A spokesperson 
from the company has made the following statement. 'With more flight routes and seats available on budget airlines 
than ever before, more and more tourists will be taking trips to destinations throughout Europe. <nl/><nl/>This is a 
fantastic opportunity for countries, tourists and airlines alike. However, as passenger traffic increases it's imperative 
that tourists are travelling with correct travel insurance. <nl/><nl/>'Travelling Brits should always be carrying a valid 
and in-date European Health Insurance Card. As we travel to Europe more frequently, we will need our EHIC's 
more than ever before. <nl/><nl/>The card gives travellers access to discounted or free state healthcare in most 
European destinations. With Ryanair making it easier to opt-out of own brand travel insurance, it's imperative that 
tourists are always carrying the right kind of insurance protection with them at all times.'<nl/><nl/>Europe EHIC 
Services Limited[1] helps people travelling to Europe with attaining a European Health Insurance Card (EHIC), 
freely available from the NHS. European EHIC Services Limited assists in completing your application for an EHIC, 
ensuring that there are no errors or missing elements within the application. The card can only be used within the 
European Economic Area and Switzerland. - Buzz Carter 18-03-2015<nl/> [ 1]: http://europeanhealthcard.org.uk 
Ryanair Passenger Traffic Jumps by 29%, Europe EHIC Services Limited Reports

Ryanair Forays into New Skies, Adds Transatlantic Routes - Analyst Blog
Ryanair Forays into New Skies, Adds Transatlantic Routes - Analyst Blog
Zacks Investment Research
March 18, 2015 Wednesday 6:50 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 576 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
Mar 18, 2015( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> In line with its 
ambitious five-year expansion plans, Irish low-cost carrier Ryanair Holdings plc RYAAY[1] has decided to initiate 
transatlantic flights with fares starting at as low as £10 for a one-way trip.<nl/>Initially, Ryanair will connect around 
14 cities like London, Berlin and Dublin in Europe and a dozen locations in the U.S. including cities like New York, 
Boston and Chicago.<nl/>
To support such large-scale expansion, the carrier has decided to expand its fleet size with Boeing 787 Dreamliners 
to its existing fleet. The company has also placed an order for 183 Boeing 737 aircraft and 200 Boeing MAX 200 
planes.<nl/>This a major development for the carrier as this initiative has opened up the busiest airline market for 
the company. If successful in implementing its plans, Ryanair will likely pose significant competitive threat to U.S. 
low-cost carriers like Southwest Airlines Co. LUV[2] and Spirit Airlines SAVE[3]. Moreover, leading U.S. carriers like 
Delta Air Lines Inc. DAL[4], American Airlines and United Airlines will also face the burnt with competition 
intensifying in the transatlantic route.<nl/>In Europe, Ryanair offers flights to 170 cities, inclusive of the less popular 
ones, at extremely low fares. The company expects fiscal 2014 traffic to exceed 90 million with load factor likely to 
reach 87%. In Feb 2015, the company reported financial numbers for the third quarter of fiscal 2014 wherein 
revenues jumped 17% year over year. Moreover, the carrier witnessed 14% growth in passengers against the last-
year quarter figure.<nl/>Braving all economic odds, Ryanair continues to perform strongly for the last 30 years, 
surpassing the performance of most European carriers. Hence, we believe that Ryanair is poised to gain 
significantly with the transatlantic route addition across the U.S. and European region.<nl/>Ryanair currently carries 
a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). <nl/>Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today, you can 
download 7 Best Stocks for the Next 30 Days. Click to get this free report[5] SOUTHWEST AIR (LUV): Free Stock 
Analysis Report[6] RYANAIR HLDGS (RYAAY): Free Stock Analysis Report[7] DELTA AIR LINES (DAL): Free 
Stock Analysis Report[8] SPIRIT AIRLINES (SAVE): Free Stock Analysis Report[9] To read this article on 
Zacks.com click here.[10] Zacks Investment Research[11]<nl/> [ 1]: http://www.zacks.com/stock/quote/RYAAY [ 2]:       
     http://www.zacks.com/stock/quote/LUV [ 3]:            http://www.zacks.com/stock/quote/SAVE [ 4]:            
http://www.zacks.com/stock/quote/DAL

5]: 
 
 
 
 
 
 
     
http://www.zacks.com/registration/pfp/?ALERT=RPT_7BST_LP194...D=ZC_CONTENT_ZER_ARTCAT_ANALYST

Airline Stock Roundup: American Airlines to Join SP 500 - Analyst Blog
Airline Stock Roundup: American Airlines to Join SP 500 - Analyst Blog
Zacks Investment Research
March 18, 2015 Wednesday 6:50 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 1402 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
Mar 18, 2015( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> It was a week 
which saw a new member from the airline space making its way into the coveted S...00 index - American Airlines 
Group Inc. AAL[1]. The carrier is set to join the much sought-after list from Mar 20 (after market close), replacing 
Allergan, which has been acquired by Actavis.<nl/>European low-cost carrier Ryanair Holdings RYAAY[2] also 
grabbed headlines during the week with its board approving plans to connect destinations between the U.S. and 
Europe at amazingly low fares. 
However, the transatlantic service is unlikely to commence before another four/five years.<nl/>Low-cost carrier 
JetBlue Airways Corporation JBLU[3] was also in the news for a bilateral codeshare agreement inked with privately 
held Silver Airways. JetBlue also announced healthy traffic data for the month of February. Important metrics such 
as revenue passenger miles (RPMs - a measure of air traffic), available seat miles (measure of capacity) and load 
factor (% of seats filled by passengers) grew on a year-over-year basis during the month.<nl/>On the price front, 
most airline stocks gained over the past 5 trading days, benefiting from plummeting oil prices. As a result, the NYSE 
ARCA Airline index climbed 5% over the said period.<nl/>(Read the last 'Airline Stock Roundup' here: Delta-Led 
Consortium Complains, Republic Airways Included in S...00[4])<nl/>Recap of the Most Important Stories Over the 
Past Week<nl/>1. JetBlue Airways inked a codeshare agreement with Florida-based Silver Airways with the aim to 
improve customer convenience. The current deal extends the Dec 2013 ticketing partnership signed by the two 
companies (read more: JetBlue, Silver Airways Ink Codeshare Pact; Strengthen Ties[5]).<nl/>Furthermore, JetBlue 
Airways' Feb 2015 air traffic was up 10% year over year to 2.9 billion. Capacity improved 7.4% to 3.47 billion and 
load factor increased to 83.5% from 81.6% in Feb 2014 (read more: JetBlue's February Traffic Rises on Favorable 
Factors[6]).<nl/>2. American Airlines Group, formed following the Dec 2013 merger of AMR (American Airlines' 
parent group) and US Airways, is set to join the S...00 after market close on Mar 20. The carrier has been added to 
the S...00 GICS 'Industrials' sector or Airlines Sub-Industry index (read more: American Airlines Group to Enter 
Coveted S...00[7]).<nl/>3. According to media reports, the board of Ryanair has approved the carrier's plans to 
connect destinations across the U.S. and Europe. Approval has been gained to operate to and from around 14 
European cities and almost an equivalent number of American cities. Ticket prices have been kept unbelievably low 
with one-way tickets between US and Europe costing approximately $15 (promotional offer) according to a report at 
investors.com.<nl/>The services, however, are not commencing immediately. It will take another four to five years 
as Ryanair needs to bolster its fleet before entering the lucrative transatlantic market. In the event of Ryanair 
entering the U.S. market, competition would intensify for domestic carriers that already face the threat of market 
share reduction from Gulf carriers.<nl/>4. According to a report appearing in the Reuters, the dispute between US 
Airline Stock Roundup: American Airlines to Join SP 500 - Analyst Blog
carriers and their Gulf counterparts took a fresh turn with the U.S. government asking Delta Airlines DAL[8], United 
Continental Holdings UAL[9] and American Airlines Group to furnish more information to support their claim of 
massive subsidies enjoyed by certain Gulf carriers.<nl/>The U.S. carriers, in a complaint to the Obama 
administration, had alleged that massive government subsidies have allowed Gulf carriers like Qatar Airways, 
Etihad Airways and Emirates to expand their fleet and international operations substantially, in turn, eating into their 
market share. According to the report, the Obama administration has put forward approximately 20 questions to 
representatives of the U.S. carriers based on their allegations.<nl/>5. Troubles do not seem to end at Germany's 
Deutsche Lufthansa Aktiengesellschaft DLAKY[10] with the carrier's pilots calling yet another strike on the non-
resolution of disputes regarding early retirement benefits. Furthermore, the German carrier's plan to expand low-
cost offerings has also come under attack from the pilots. The pilots had gone on strike several times over the same 
issue in 2014, resulting in flight cancellations and loss of profit for the airline.<nl/>Performance<nl/>The following 
table shows the price movement of the major airline players over the past week and during the last 6 
months. <nl/> <nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/><nl/>
<nl/><nl/><nl/> <nl/> <nl/> <nl/> <nl/> <nl/> <nl/> <nl/> <nl/> <nl/> <nl/> <nl/> <nl/> <nl/> <nl/> <nl/> <nl/> <nl/> <nl/
>As the chart suggests, all major airline stocks traded in the green over the past week due to plummeting oil prices, 
with the exception of GOL Linhas Aereas Inteligentes GOL[11], which lost 5.86%. Additionally, most of the stocks 
have also gained over the last six months, with JetBlue witnessing the highest upside (71.07%) over the period. 
<nl/>What's Next in the Airline Biz?<nl/>With no major event lined up over the next five trading days, stay tuned for 
the usual news updates. Investors are also likely to keenly await further updates on the dispute between U.S. 
carriers and their Gulf counterparts.<nl/>Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research?

If Anyone Will Make Low Cost Transatlantic Flying Work, It's Probably Ryanair
If Anyone Will Make Low Cost Transatlantic Flying Work, It's Probably 
Ryanair
The Cranky Flier
March 17, 2015 Tuesday 11:49 AM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 1029 words
Byline: CF
Body
Mar 17, 2015( The Cranky Flier: http://www.crankyflier.com Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> I can't remember the first 
time we heard Ryanair chief Michael O'Leary talk about wanting to fly Transatlantic but it's been something he's 
talked about for years. And now, the board has officially voted to make it happen[1]… in the next 5 years. The 
Atlantic is littered with graves of failed low cost efforts, but if anyone is going to figure out how to make this work, 
Ryanair is a good candidate.<nl/>
<nl/>The problem with low-cost, long-haul flying is that the longer the flight, the fewer chances there are to cut 
costs. On longer flights, fuel eats up a greater percentage of total cost than on shorter flights. And there is no low 
cost fuel (not that you'd want to use, anyway). Sure, there are airplanes that are more fuel efficient, but the tradeoff 
is a very high capital expense to acquire those aircraft. Just ask Norwegian. It spent a bunch of money on buying 
those expensive 787s to fly to the US, and it's still trying to figure out how to make money with them.<nl/> There's 
also a problem of demand. On longer haul flights, the low fare, leisure demand is much more cyclical than on 
shorter domestic flights. With Ryanair, people in the UK think nothing of hopping off to Spain for a weekend in the 
middle of winter. But a longer trip to the US? That's usually saved for longer breaks often centered around school 
holidays. During the rest of the year, business demand is stronger but that's more often in the premium cabin, 
something that most low cost carriers don't try to tackle.<nl/> But Michael O'Leary is a smart man and he knows all 
of this to be the case. That's why he hasn't started flying Transatlantic yet. He hasn't been able to make it work on 
paper, so he has to wait for conditions to be right.<nl/> The announcement of board approval mentions that the 
airline is in talks with the aircraft manufacturers. The problem for Ryanair is finding an airplane that's fuel efficient 
enough without having to break the bank to buy the thing. That eliminates the gas-guzzling A340 on the used 
market. Ryanair is a much bigger fan of buying new and direct anyway. Could the A330neo be a good option? It 
sure could be. Or maybe the 787 or A350 is a good option. But Ryanair has to wait for demand to die down and the 
manufacturers to become hungrier. I'm sure the airline has a number in mind and it will wait until it can hit it, 
however long it may take.<nl/> The airplane you choose is one thing, but how you outfit it is equally important (if not 
more so). In the past, low cost carriers have tried to pack them in. Look at Cebu Pacific which puts 430+ seats on 
an A330. Some have tried a premium cabin but they're not very good. Norwegian has a premium economy-style 
premium cabin on its 787s[2], but that's not going to attract anyone with money to spend. It's also a small 
percentage of the airplane. That's really for the coach traveler who wants a bargain on something a bit better. It's 
still the leisure traveler that's the target market.<nl/> Air Asia X started moving in the right direction. It has angled 
flat beds on its A330s[3]. This isn't world class but with a price difference versus traditional competitors, it's worth 
If Anyone Will Make Low Cost Transatlantic Flying Work, It's Probably Ryanair
considering. But there are only 12 of these on the entire airplane. It's insignificant.<nl/> Ryanair knows there's great 
money to be made up front. Back in 2008, O'Leary gave his famous quote about the ideal premium cabin product… 
beds and blowjobs[4]. And he wants a bigger percentage of premium cabin seats on each airplane to help generate 
enough revenue, even with fares being so low compared to competitors in each cabin.<nl/> With a product like that 
at a lower price, Ryanair can attract more business travelers, which helps offset the big demand shifts. And since 
Ryanair has a huge presence in Europe with an increasingly business-oriented clientele, it can make inroads into a 
Transatlantic market better than some random upstart like La Compagnie[5].<nl/> In terms of routes, Ryanair wants 
to serve 12 to 14 cities on both sides of the Pond and then connect those dots. I would assume that the airline 
would try to leverage its existing passenger base and fly from its strong positions in Europe to larger cities in the 
US. That's been confirmed with Ryanair showing interest in places like London/Stansted and Berlin. But I've also 
seen mention of Berlin and Cologne. Those are much newer cities for the airline, but they are cities that Ryanair 
believes will provide growth within Europe. When flights start several years down the line, you can imagine these 
will be well-developed.<nl/> It will be interesting to see which cities get served in the US. Will Ryanair go toward 
bigger airports in popular places? There is a higher cost, but again, on longer flights that's a smaller percentage of 
the pie than on short haul. And people in Cologne want to go to New York, not Newburgh (or whatever airport it 
might want to consider). That doesn't mean it can't serve smaller airports, but with bigger airplanes on longer 
routes, it will need as much help as it can get to fill those seats.<nl/> Does this mean Ryanair will be successful? I 
wouldn't say that. But if anyone is going to crack this nut, there's a good chance it'll be Ryanair.<nl/> [Original 
Atlantic Ocean photo[6] via Shutterstock and Original Ryanair aircraft photo via Markus Mainka[7] / 
Shutterstock.com[8]]<nl/> [ 1]: http://www.irishtimes.com/business/transport-and-tourism/ryanair-s-board-approves-
transatlantic-flights-1.2141529 [ 2]:            http://www.norwegian.com/uk/travel-information/travel-services/premium-
cabin/ [ 3]:            http://www.airasia.com/my/en/inflight-comforts/seat-options.page?section=airasiax#flatbed [ 4]:       
  
 
 
 
http://crankyflier.com/2008/06/18/oleary-wants-to-offer-blowjobs-on-airplanes/ 
[ 
5]: 
 
 
 
 
 
 
     
https://www.lacompagnie.com/en [ 6]:            http://www.shutterstock.com/pic-66354040/stock-photo-waves-during-
a-storm-in-the-atlantic-ocean.html [ 7]:            http://www.shutterstock.com/gallery-706186p1.html?cr=00...edit-00 [ 
8]:            http://www.shutterstock.com/editorial?cr=00...edit-00 
Load-Date: March 17, 2015

Ryanair approves transatlantic flight scheme
Ryanair approves transatlantic flight scheme
Deutsche Welle Business
March 17, 2015 Tuesday 1:47 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 262 words
Body
Mar 17, 2015( Deutsche Welle Business: http://www.dw-world.de/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Ireland's Ryanair 
has confirmed its resolve to get transatlantic flights off the ground within the next five years, including from Berlin. 
But for that it'll have to expand its fleet with suitable long-haul planes. The executive board of Irish no-frills airline 
Ryanair gave the green light for plans to start operating low-cost transatlantic routes in the next five years.<nl/> 
"The Guardian" and the "Financial Times" said Tuesday the carrier was aiming to include Dublin, London, Cologne 
and Berlin as its European bases for flights across the pond to New York, Boston and Washington.<nl/> "European 
consumers want lower-cost travel to the US and the same goes for Americans coming to Europe," Ryanair CEO 
Michael O'Leary said in a statement. "We see it as a logical development in the European market."<nl/> Fleet 
reshuffle<nl/> Ryanair said proposed transatlantic fares would start from as little as 10 pounds ($14, 13.2 euros) 
one-way, with regular prices close to 100 pounds per ticket.<nl/> But the airline will first have to talk to 
manufacturers about sourcing suitable long-haul aircraft.<nl/> "It's unclear how quickly Ryanair might be able to 
hold of enough aircraft, but it's hard to see the service operating before 2019-2020," "The Irish Times" 
commented.<nl/> Ryanair is Europe's largest carrier by passenger numbers and has forecast profits between 840-
850 million euros for its current fiscal year running until the end of the month.<nl/> hg/ng (AFP, Reuters)<nl/> 
Load-Date: March 17, 2015
End of Document
Ryanair Board Approves Transatlantic Flights For As Low As $10
Ryanair Board Approves Transatlantic Flights For As Low As $10
The Huffington Post
March 17, 2015 Tuesday 3:00 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 300 words
Byline: Carly Ledbetter
Body
Mar 17, 2015( The Huffington Post: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Ryanair[1], the 
Irish airliner famous for its ridiculously cheap ticket prices[2] and lack of luggage space[3], announced Monday that 
the company's board has approved transatlantic flights. <nl/>The airline "would like to offer low cost flights between 
12-14 European cities and 12-14 US cities. The business plan is there but it's dependent on attaining viable long 
haul aircraft and we estimate that's 4 to 5 years away," a Ryanair spokesperson told HuffPost via email. Ryanair 
confirmed that the flights to and from Europe would start at $10. <nl/>Michael O'Leary[4], CEO of Ryanair, has said 
for years[5] that the airline would offer cheap transatlantic flights as soon as theyacquired long-haul aircrafts[6]. 
Ryanair confirmed via email that they are currently "talking to manufacturers" but provided no further details. 
<nl/>Once the equipment is finally in place and flights begin, customers should expect to pay all sorts of additional 
fees on their $10 ticket. As O'Leary has<nl/> [ 1]:

to stop production in a meeting the day before. <nl/> 3. A report in Brazilian magazine Veja alleges that I[4]ran

Ryanair is planning to launch Europe to America flights and they could start at just £10
Ryanair is planning to launch Europe to America flights and they could start 
at just £10
The Business Insider
March 16, 2015 Monday 4:15 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 394 words
Byline: jbarrie@businessinsider.com,  (Joshua Barrie) Joshua Barrie
Body
Mar 16, 2015( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) ;<nl/> Ireland's budget 
airline Ryanair is set to launch transatlantic flights — and they could cost as little as £10, the Guardian reports[1]. 
The company's board has approved plans to begin flights between up to 14 destinations in Europe and the US. 
It's part of a five-year strategy to continue growth.<nl/> Cities served would include New York, Boston, and Chicago 
stateside, the Guardian says, and London Stansted, Berlin, and Ryanair's native Dublin across the pond. The long 
haul addition to the company's flight offerings could come into operation in four or five years' time.<nl/> The airline 
has announced it is in talks with manufacturers over buying suitable aircraft for the venture — currently, it only 
carries out short to mid-length journeys, so would need much bigger planes to make the trip over the Atlantic. 
According the Guardian[2], Ryanair CEO Michael O'Leary has been trying to set up the service for some time. 
Indeed, the crossing is one of the more profitable routes in the world, though dominated largely by airlines such as 
British Airways and American Airlines right now.<nl/> Obviously, given the nature of Ryanair, which adds lots of 
extra costs to tickets, the £10 price tag will be much more once everything paid for. Food and drink, baggage fees, 
and other extras bump up the price. However, all things considered, The Telegraph estimates that a return fare 
would still cost just £185.20.[3] <nl/> That price is remarkably cheaper than other low-cost competitors flying over 
the Atlantic. Norwegian Air Shuttle runs flights from London Gatwick starting at about £300 — without 
baggage. <nl/>NOW WATCH: Amazing Animation Shows All Flights Over The World's Busiest Airport In 24 
Hours[4]<nl/> [ 1]: http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2015/mar/16/ryanair-plans-to-offer-flights-between-europe-
and-america [ 2]:            http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2015/mar/16/ryanair-plans-to-offer-flights-between-
europe-and-america [ 3]:            http://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/travelnews/10665050/Ryanairs-10-flights-to-the-
US-would-the-experience-be-worth-the-savings.html [ 4]:            http://www.businessinsider.com/uk-airspace-
heathrow-flights-time-lapse-2014-
12?utm_source=partner..._medium=newstex..._term=original..._campaign=partner 
Load-Date: March 16, 2015
End of Document

Germany Tourism Market: New market data analysed
Germany Tourism Market: New market data analysed
CompaniesandMarkets.com
March 14, 2015 Saturday 2:21 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 512 words
Body
Mar 14, 2015( CompaniesandMarkets.com: http://www.companiesandmarkets.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> 
Germany's tourism market is well developed and mature, but the coming years still offer sufficient opportunities to 
make it an attractive proposition to established hotel groups. 
The coming introduction of the Holiday Inn Express and Premier Inn brands to the country show the belief of major 
worldwide hotel chains in the potential of the German budget hotel market size, which we anticipate will be an area 
of growth in the coming years due to falling airline prices encouraging price sensitive travellers to Germany. Due to 
improving economic conditions of neighbouring countries, government initiatives to encourage Asian Pacific 
travellers, and decreasing airline prices, we forecast a consistent rise in both inbound and outbound tourism from 
Germany, as well as a 27% rise in tourism receipts from 2015-2018, a final figure of USD 71.06bn. Threats to the 
industry include declining consumer confidence of both domestic and international households due to a potential 
economic downturn in Europe, and a deteriorating relationship between the EU and Russia over the Ukraine crisis 
leading to a decline in trade and tourism between Germany and Russia, Germany's 10th largest source 
market.<nl/>The movement of large brands such as Holiday Inn Express and Premier Inn into the German market 
shows the potential of the moderately priced market currently. This is the area we anticipate the most growth, due 
to an increasing amount of price-sensitive tourists being able to visit Germany due to increased consumer spending 
for households in neighbouring countries (such as the UK, Netherlands and Austria), and the decreasing prices of 
budget airlines due to increased competition between the airline companies.<nl/>Expanding airports in Berlin and 
Frankfurt will increase capacity, and budget airlines such as Ryanair, Wizz Air, and Easy Jet have pushed 
established players such as Lufthansa into increasing their low budget offerings, culminating in decreasing prices 
for the consumer and an increase in tourists. As Europe is the largest source market for inbound tourism to 
Germany, the potential for an economic downturn in the coming months is also a risk for the German tourism 
industry, such is the importance of the region to total receipts. Additionally, we see hotel developments and 
openings in Frankfurt of indicative of the driving force behind Germany's recent and future growth in tourism- as the 
largest financial centre in continental Europe, the city attracts large amount of business travellers as well as cultural 
tourists, and the city is prospering thanks to Germany's recent economic performance. <nl/><nl/>For more 
information on the "Germany Tourism Report Q1 2015" market analysis, see the latest research: Germany Tourism 
Report 
Q1 
2015[1]<nl/>Follow 
us 
on 
Twitter 
@CandMResearch<nl/> 
[ 
1]: 
http://www.companiesandmarkets.com/Market/Travel/Market-Research/Germany-Tourism-Report-Q1-
2015/RPT1296803?aCode=c64cd82a-b5ae-48fb-9757-eca787e7a8bf 
Germany Tourism Market: New market data analysed

Friday fantasies
Friday fantasies
IPKat Weblog
March 13, 2015 Friday 9:54 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 1384 words
Byline: noreply@blogger.com,  (Jeremy)
Body
Mar 13, 2015( IPKat Weblog: http://ipkitten.blogspot.com Delivered by Newstex) <nl/>            
http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-wNRIVGL0d1o/VQLLS-rJFSI/AAAAAAAA4kA/Qiu1qq-eOjc/s1600/punt.jpg 
Forthcoming 
events. As usual, the IPKat urges readers to take a look at his Forthcoming Events [1]page and see if there are any 
upcoming IP events that take their fancy. Many are free or offer discounts to readers of this weblog. Among the 
events added this week are IBC's annual IT Law Summer School, which takes place in August in the agreeable 
surroundings of Downing College, Cambridge. The same company's annual IP Summer School will be held there 
too, and details will be posted as soon as they are available: this Kat will be running a coexistence agreement 
negotiation exercise at that event, which should be fun.<nl/>            http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-
WNpnmCN3Duo/VQLPVnW7OVI/AAAAAAAA4kM/uAz-kPUPSVo/s1600/ryan.jpgRyanair Chase. 
Listening to the radio yesterday, this Kat learned that there is an annual horse race, run on the third day of the 
Cheltenham Festival, which goes by the name of the Ryanair Chase[2]. Apparently there are 17 fences to be 
jumped and there is a generous prize of £200,000 [3]for the winner [though Merpel is quite puzzled as to what a 
horse might want with so large a sum of money, or indeed with any cash at all]. Having personally experienced the 
Ryanair brand at first hand, this Kat finds it difficult to whip up excitement for a race, or indeed anything else, that 
goes under that name. He has visions of air passengers being made to jump 17 fences on their way to a distant 
airline departure gate, and of jockeys being asked to pay a premium for a decent saddle. Since he has not flown 
Ryanair for a few years now, he wonders whether things have changed, and whether the brand now conjures up 
more positive images for its users than it did for him then. After all, the mere fact that Ryanair is paying out money 
rather than sucking it in can be taken as a positive sign. What do readers think?<nl/> http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-
NkVPmYqSqOs/VQKq7VJVhLI/AAAAAAAA4jE/UyUwU_hcTdU/s1600/jiplpgreen.gifLooking for a job? As the jiplp 
weblog reported earlier this week, IPKat blogmeister Jeremy, who is the founder editor of the Journal of Intellectual 
Property Law ...actice (JIPLP[4]) and has been toiling away at it since 2005, will be retiring from that role at the end 
of this year and the publisher, Oxford University Press (OUP), is already looking for someone to replace him. The 
job is a demanding one, but it's also fun: you get to correspond with leading IP personalities from around the world, 
you have a chance to read -- and edit -- loads of articles and current intelligence notes before anyone else gets to 
see them and you also have the thrill of working with OUP, one of the world's oldest brands and a stickler for quality 
control. Oh, and you also have the pleasure of working with several members of the IPKat blog squad (Eleonora, 
Darren, Birgit and Neil are all editorially involved). JIPLP comes out monthly; it is supported by a formal website, a 
weblog, a LinkedIn Discussion Group and a Twitter account. Supported by a hugely impressive editorial and 
production team, as one might expect from OUP, JIPLP comes out in print, online and in mobile-enabled format, 
Friday fantasies
and it is an increasingly influential voice in professional, commercial and academic circles. If you feel that you can 
take JIPLP to the next level and relish a truly satisfying challenge, you can get further details here[5]. But you'd 
better be quick: OUP wants to hear from you before the end of this month.<nl/>            http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-
cCexNUQEBak/VQL90Wx-6EI/AAAAAAAA4k8/wEuEIpvECik/s1600/aripi.pngAround the weblogs. The MARQUES 
Class 99 design blog reports, thanks to a guest post [6]from Evelina Marchesoni, on another Italian ruling on design 
rights in vehicle wheels, the difficult relationship between complex products and component parts and the role 
played by assessment of the aesthetic dimension of the effect of an allegedly infringing product: unlike the earlier 
Italian case involving wheel trims (Case C-500/14 Ford, here[7]), this one is not going to the Court of Justice for a 
preliminary ruling -- the court said so! Ben Challis has delivered another CopyKat copyright round-up, here[8], just 
in time for the weekend (thanks, Ben!) Meanwhile, PatLit has a short note [9]on what seems to be a bit of a non-
event: the report that summarises responses to the UK government's call for comments and consultation on what 
changes, if any, need to be made to the UK's Patents Act 1977 to make UK law compatible with the operation of 
Europe's new (but not yet operative) Unified Patent Court. Finally the patent term extension-oriented SPC Blog 
notes a ruling on Otsuka's failed attempt[10] to get a paediatric extension for aripiprazole on the ground that the 
Japanese pharma company had not met all the conditions for extension of the term before its supplementary 
protection 
certificate 
had 
already 
expired.<nl/> 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-BbQJK--
Z7pA/VQK2x1KMBiI/AAAAAAAA4jo/v3EkT1BpHKg/s1600/ipho.pngNaughty OHIM! This Kat has noticed in the past 
that, while his good friends at the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (OHIM) are getting very good at 
examining Community trade mark (CTM) applications, weeding out the not-so-registrable ones and generally 
running the CTM system smoothly, they do have their blind spots. One relates to the promotional material[11] which 
OHIM asked MARQUES out to prospective participants in its popular webinars on IP-related issues. The technical 
requirements for prospective participants are that they have "a computer or IPAD or IPHONE". This Kat is not 
impressed: does the fact that the words iPad and iPhone are in capital letters detract from the fact they are being 
used as generic terms for tablet computers and internet-enabled mobile phones respectively -- and who should 
know better than OHIM, which has granted CTMs to Apple for each of them (see eg Nos EU008817281 and 
004748133).<nl/> 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-
GqOR9e48cgw/VQLxZFilChI/AAAAAAAA4ks/k5Coy6dcpgE/s1600/IMG_2804.jpgCongratulations! This Kat enjoyed 
the hospitality of Managing Intellectual Property magazine at this week's banquet at the Intercontinental Hotel, Park 
Lane, to mark the tenth anniversary of the Managing IP Global Awards. To his delight, one of this year's two awards 
for outstanding achievement went to former Court of Justice of the European Union and Irish Supreme Court judge 
Fidelma Macken[12], with whom he used to teach law at Trinity College, Dublin back in the 1970s. To his greater 
delight, this year's award for IP in Ireland went to DFMG Solicitors, for whom Patricia McGovern[13] was there to 
collect the trophy. Both Fidelma and Jeremy lectured Patricia at Trinity and were delighted to see that one of their 
star students had done so well. Incidentally, it was a good night for Ireland all round, since the other recipient of the 
outstanding achievement award went to Simmons ...mmons' Kevin Mooney[14] (though maybe it should have gone 
to Mrs Mooney after Kevin's kind words about her).<nl/> [ 1]:            http://ipkitten.blogspot.co.uk/p/for-your-
delectation.html [ 2]:            http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ryanair_Chase [ 3]:            http://www.cheltenham-
festival.co.uk/2007-10-09/cheltenham-fetival-prize-money.php [ 4]:            http://jiplp.oxfordjournals.org/ [ 5]:            
http://jiplp.blogspot.co.uk/2015/03/jiplp-search-for-new-editor-begins.html 
[ 
6]: 
 
 
 
 
 
 
     
https://www.marques.org/Class99/default.asp?XID=BHA639 
[ 
7]: 
 
 
 
 
 
 
     
https://www.marques.org/Class99/default.asp?XID=BHA615 
[ 
8]: 
 
 
 
 
 
 
     
http://the1709blog.blogspot.co.uk/2015/03/the-copykat-fridays-feline-feast.html 
[

http://patlit.blogspot.co.uk/2015/03/report-on-possible-amendments-to-uk-law.html 
[

http://thespcblog.blogspot.co.uk/2015/03/no-paediatric-extension-when-conditions.html 
[ 
11]: 
 
 
 
 
 
 
     
https://www.marques.org/Class46/default.asp?XID=BHA4032 
[

NRK shows lottery balls-up
NRK shows lottery balls-up
The Foreigner
March 12, 2015 Thursday 11:58 AM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 5223 words
Byline: Michael Sandelson
Body
Mar 
12, 
2015( 
The 
Foreigner: 
http://theforeigner.no 
Delivered 
by 
Newstex) 
<nl/> 
 
 
 
 
 
 
     
http://www.nyinorge.no/en/<nl/>Martine's suspected murderer disregards human dignity, says father[1]<nl/>           
http://theforeigner.no/pages/news/martines-suspected-murderer-disregards-human-dignity-says-father/ Odd Petter 
Magnussen issued his statement almost seven years after his daughter's death in London.<nl/> Continue reading[2]

Norwegian pilots get Ryanair lift, discussions afoot
Norwegian pilots get Ryanair lift, discussions afoot
The Foreigner
March 5, 2015 Thursday 9:51 AM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 625 words
Byline: Michael Sandelson
Body
Mar 05, 2015( The Foreigner: http://theforeigner.no Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Published on Thursday, 5th 
March[1], 2015[2] at 09:45 under the news[3] category, by Michael Sandelson[4]            
https://plus.google.com/100411584603581443982/about . Last Updated on 5th March 2015 at 10:08.<nl/>
European cockpit colleagues cite cheapness concerns. Travel misery continues for Europe passengers amongst 
reports of possible negotiations.<nl/> There might be movement towards settling the current dispute.Sky interior, 
Norwegian plane Photo: Norwegian<nl/> 'The race to the bottom between airlines to set unsustainable terms and 
conditions should be fought at every opportunity,' the Ryanair Pilot Group (RPG) says in a statement.<nl/> 'The 
actions of NPU pilots operating for NAS to protect normal employment contracts and working conditions deserve 
the maximum support of every worker in Europe,' they add, citing a European Commission-funded report[5] into 
dumping and safety.<nl/> Norwegian Pilots Union aircrew working for Norwegian Air Shuttle through wholly-owned 
Scandinavia subsidiary Norwegian Air Norway (NAN) have been on strike since Saturday.<nl/> Wednesday saw 
industrial action widened. All domestic Norway flights were cancelled, some Sweden and Denmark domestic flights 
affected, and most inter-Scandinavian capitals flights cancelled. The strike hit some 35,000 passengers.<nl/> 'I'm 
not sure Norwegian realise what implications this [walkout] will have in the rest of the world,' Parat union leader 
Hans-Erik Skjæggerud told The Foreigner[6].<nl/> And while there has been some contact between them and 
Norwegian last night, the situation is much the same today, Thursday.<nl/> No domestic Norway routes are being 
flown, some Sweden and Denmark flights are affected, and most services between the Scandinavian capitals are 
cancelled.<nl/> Norwegian has been hiring in aircraft and pilots from other countries in efforts to provide some 
semblance of service, which unions view as strike-busting.<nl/> Talking of 'last resort industrial action', pilots at low-
cost carrier Ryanair say other airlines or NAS pilots in other countries should resist Norwegian's attempts to garner 
support to "the maximum extent legally possible".<nl/> 'The threat and risks associated with the employment 
models being adopted by NAS and other low-cost carriers are not acceptable in any modern industry, and we 
commend our colleagues in NPU for their efforts to secure normal employment contracts and working conditions,' 
they conclude.<nl/> According to NTB, Norwegian is now attempting to get the National Mediator (Riksmekleren) 
aboard for negotiations with union Parat and pilots. Both parties wish an end to the strike, reports NRK.<nl/> 
Affected passengers in Scandinavia can check the status of their flights on Norwegian's web pages[7] (in 
Norwegian).<nl/><nl/>Published on Thursday, 5th March[8], 2015[9] at 09:45 under the news[10] category, by 
Michael Sandelson[11] https://plus.google.com/100411584603581443982/about . Last updated on 5th March 2015 
at 10:08.<nl/> [ 1]:            http://theforeigner.no/pages/news/archive/2015/03/ [ 2]:            
http://theforeigner.no/pages/news/archive/2015/ [ 3]:            http://theforeigner.no/pages/news/ [ 4]:            
Norwegian pilots get Ryanair lift, discussions afoot
http://theforeigner.no/pages/contributors/michael-sandelson/

IEFA, EURL: Big ETF Inflows
IEFA, EURL: Big ETF Inflows
Market News Video
February 27, 2015 Friday 4:33 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 192 words
Body
View Video
Feb 27, 2015 (Market News Video:http://marketnewsvideo.com/ Delivered by Newstex)
 Comparing units outstanding versus one week ago at the coverage universe of ETFs at ETF Channel, the biggest 
inflow was seen in the iShares Core MSCI EAFE ETF (IEFA), which added 21,500,000 units, or a 33.1% increase 
week over week. Among the largest underlying components of IEFA, in morning trading today Ryanair Holdings 
(RYAAY) is up about 0.8%. 
And on a percentage change basis, the ETF with the biggest increase in inflows was the Daily FTSE Europe Bull 3x 
Shares (EURL), which added 250,000 units, for a 31.2% increase in outstanding units. Among the largest 
underlying components of EURL, in morning trading today Vanguard European Stock ETF (VGK) is up about 0.3%.

BREAKING NEWS: CJEU says that Member States are free to determine who must pay droit de suite royalty
BREAKING NEWS: CJEU says that Member States are free to determine who 
must pay droit de suite royalty
IPKat Weblog
February 26, 2015 Thursday 10:58 AM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 1069 words
Byline: noreply@blogger.com,  (Eleonora Rosati)
Body
Feb 26, 2015( IPKat Weblog: http://ipkitten.blogspot.com Delivered by Newstex) ;<nl/>            
http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-RGQF8XEzWGo/VO71ZykrOuI/AAAAAAAAGUo/x01RFymcFAw/s1600/CJEU-
logo2.jpgCopyright has increasingly become linked to de-materialisation of both works and their exploitation 
channels, so it is kind of re-assuring to find cases that are still about the analogue world. <nl/> This morning the 
Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) issued in fact its decision [not yet available on the Curia website] in 
Case C-41/14 Christie's France[1], a reference for a preliminary ruling from France seeking clarification as regards 
that peculiar creature of EU copyright known as artist's resale right, or droit de suite [Merpel explains that this 
phrase does not mean right to a (hotel) suite, but rather the "right to follow" the sale of one's own 
artwork] within Directive 2001/84/EC[2] (the Resale Right Directive)<nl/>
 As this very blog reported[3] a few months ago, despite its appearance as a case concerned with a specialist (and 
possibly pretty niche) area of copyright, Christie's France is yet another CJEU decision dealing with the relationship 
between IP rights and contract law [to this end readers will promptly recall the very recent judgment in Ryanair[4], 
here[5]].<nl/> Background<nl/> Article 1 of the Resale Right Directive sets an obligation for Member States to 
provide for the benefit of the author of an original work of art an inalienable, unwaivable resale right. This consists of 
the right to receive a royalty based on the sale price obtained for any resale of the work, subsequent to the first 
transfer 
of 
the 
work 
by 
the 
author. <nl/> 
http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-
rx43edmhUiQ/VO71okHUKPI/AAAAAAAAGUw/a0BijHnr7bY/s1600/paris-the-ritz-imperial-suite-marie-antoinette-
recreated-room.jpgArticle 1(4) further states that:<nl/> "The royalty shall be payable by the seller. Member States 
may provide that one of the natural or legal persons referred to in paragraph 2 [sellers, buyers or intermediaries art 
market professionals, such as salesrooms, art galleries and, in general, any dealers in works of art] other 
than [that's the important bit] the seller shall alone be liable or shall share liability with the seller for payment of the 
royalty."<nl/> Christie's France decided to change its terms and conditions so that the buyer, and not the seller, 
became liable to pay the royalty. The issue thus became: can a contract derogate from the seller's obligation to pay 
the royalty as is enshrined in the Directive? <nl/> The Syndicat National des Antiquaires (SNA) did not think so: it 
actually took the view that, in placing the onus of the resale royalty on the buyer, Christie's France's general 
conditions amounted to unfair competition. <nl/> Thus litigation ensued, and the Court of Cassation decided to stay 
the proceedings and seek guidance from the CJEU.<nl/> The following is the question that the French court 
referred to the CJEU:<nl/> "Must the rule laid down by Article 1(4) of Directive 2001/84/EC ... on the resale right for 
the benefit of the author of an original work of art, which makes the seller responsible for payment of the royalty, be 
BREAKING NEWS: CJEU says that Member States are free to determine who must pay droit de suite royalty
interpreted as meaning that the seller is required definitively to bear the cost thereof without any derogation by 
agreement's being possible?"<nl/> The CJEU decision As stated in the relevant press release[6], this morning the 
CJEU held that "[t]he cost of the royalty that has to be paid to the author on any resale of a work of art by an art 
market professional may be borne, definitively, by the seller or the buyer".<nl/>            http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-
USQK-WNOINY/VO72KsP16MI/AAAAAAAAGU4/M7vyi_o9pDo/s1600/flat%2C550x550%2C075%2Cf.jpg 
According to the Court, <nl/> "[T]he Member States alone may determine the person liable for the royalty. Although 
Directive 2001/84 provides that the person by whom the royalty is payable is, in principle, the seller, it none the less 
allows for a derogation from that rule and thus leaves the Member States at liberty to specify another person from 
among the professional persons referred to in the Directive who, alone or with the seller, will assume liability for the 
payment of the royalty. The person who has been designated in that way by national law as the person by whom 
the royalty is payable may agree with any other person, including the buyer, that that other person will definitively 
bear, in whole or in part, the cost of the royalty, provided that acontractual arrangement of that kind does not affect 
the obligations and liability which the person by whom the royalty is payable has towards the author ... [S]uch a 
derogation is in keeping with the Directive's objective of bringing to an end distortions of competition in the art 
market, since the harmonisation concerned is limited to those domestic provisions which have the most direct 
impact on the functioning of the internal market. For the purpose of achieving that objective, thus circumscribed, it is 
necessary to make provision as to the person liable for payment of the royalty and as to the rules for establishing 
the amount of the royalty. However, such provision is not necessary with regard to the question as to 
who, definitively, will bear the cost of the royalty.<nl/>The Court does not exclude the possibility that such a 
derogation may to some extent have a distorting effect on the functioning of the internal market. However, such an 
effect is only indirect since it arises as a result of contractual arrangements that are independent of the payment of 
the royalty to the author, for which the person by whom the royalty is payable remains liable."<nl/><nl/>A more 
detailed analysis will follow as soon as the judgment becomes available, so: stay tuned!<nl/> [ 1]:            
http://curia.europa.eu/juris/liste.jsf?language=en...ALL...=C-41/14 
[ 
2]: 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
http://eur-
lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:32001L0084:EN:HTML 
[ 
3]: 
 
 
 
 
 
 
     
http://ipkitten.blogspot.co.uk/2014/03/can-contracts-derogate-from-obligations.html 
[ 
4]: 
 
 
 
 
 
 
     
http://curia.europa.eu/juris/document/document.jsf?text=...id=161388...eIndex=0...lang=EN...e=req...=...=first...t=1...
=331775 [ 5]:            http://ipkitten.blogspot.co.uk/2015/01/breaking-cjeu-says-that-owner-of-online.html [ 6]:            
http://curia.europa.eu/jcms/upload/docs/application/pdf/2015-02/cp150024en.pdf 
Load-Date: February 26, 2015
End of Document
EZU, UVXY: Big ETF Inflows
EZU, UVXY: Big ETF Inflows
Market News Video
February 23, 2015 Monday 6:32 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 170 words
Body
View Video
Feb 23, 2015 (Market News Video:http://marketnewsvideo.com/ Delivered by Newstex)
 Comparing units outstanding versus one week ago at the coverage universe of ETFs at ETF Channel, the biggest 
inflow was seen in the iShares MSCI EMU ETF (EZU), which added 17,300,000 units, or a 8.3% increase week 
over week. Among the largest underlying components of EZU, in morning trading today Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY) 
is up about 1.4%. 
And on a percentage change basis, the ETF with the biggest increase in inflows was the ProShares Ultra VIX 
Short-Term Futures ETF (UVXY), which added 6,050,000 units, for a 32.3% increase in outstanding units.

New Partnership With Vodafone Ireland
New Partnership With Vodafone Ireland
Pressat
February 19, 2015 Thursday 5:48 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 412 words
Byline: Pressat
Body
Feb 19, 2015( Pressat: http://www.pressat.co.uk Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Thursday 19 February, 2015<nl/> 
Ryanair, Europe's favourite airline, today (19 Feb) launched a partnership with Vodafone Ireland under which 
Vodafone will support Ryanair's communications and IT needs across Europe, including its ticketing, check-in, 
ground crew, inflight crew and pilot systems.<nl/>
Vodafone will provide local and wide area network access, telephony, fixed line and mobile 3G and 4G functionality 
across Ryanair's 189 locations in Europe and North Africa, while the partnership will also allow the roll out of 
Electronic Flight Bags (iPads in the flight deck), creating paperless cockpits, as well as a new inflight sales system, 
as part of Ryanair's "Always Getting Better" improvement programme.<nl/>Ryanair's Chief Technology Officer, 
John Hurley said:<nl/>"Over the last 30 years, Ryanair has revolutionised and democratised air travel for European 
citizens, growing to become Europe's largest airline with the widest route network, connecting 189 destinations in 
30 countries, through more than 1,600 routes - and all on the lowest fares. As part of our "Always Getting Better" 
improvement programme, we're continuing to enhance the Ryanair experience for our 90m annual customers, and 
this partnership with Vodafone will provide us with the technical support to allow us to make these improvements 
quickly and seamlessly, including the introduction of paperless cockpits and a swifter inflight sales 
system."<nl/>Vodafone Ireland Enterprise Director, Anne Sheehan said:<nl/>"This partnership is one of the most 
significant for Vodafone in Ireland and is further evidence of our strategy of providing large enterprise with total 
communications solutions to drive productivity and efficiencies. We have embraced Ryanair's dynamic and unique 
approach by providing complete end to end technology solutions and we have tailored to Ryanair's requirements 
across 189 locations in Europe. Ryanair is a company that is driving innovative technological solutions in the airline 
industry and Vodafone is delighted to partner with them to drive this evolution."<nl/>- See more at: 
http://corporate.ryanair.com/news/news/150219-new-partnership-with-vodafone-
ireland/?market=en#sthash.cc66DT51.dpuf<nl/><nl/> No media attached. Please contact Pressat for more 
information.<nl/><nl/> Distributed by            http://www.pressat.co.uk/[1]<nl/> [ 1]:            http://www.pressat.co.uk/

Feb 19, 2015( Stock Market Today: http://www.investors.com/stock-market-today/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> 
Major averages were mostly unchanged in early afternoon trading Thursday after starting the session mixed amid 
mixed economic data.<nl/> The Nasdaq was up 0.3%, while the S...00 and Dow Jones industrial average dipped 
0.1% and 0.3%, respectively. Volume was also mixed, running higher on the NYSE but lower on the Nasdaq, in the 
stock market today[1].<nl/>
 Weekly jobless claims came in lower than expected. But the Philly Fed's business[2] outlook and the Conference 
Board's index of leading economic indicators disappointed.<nl/> Travel bookers outperformed, led by Priceline's 
(NASDAQ:PCLN[3]) 8% gap-up following Q4 results that topped forecasts. Airlines were also big movers. Delta Air 
Lines (NYSE:DAL[4]), Ryanair Holdings (NASDAQ:RYAAY[5]), Virgin America (NASDAQ:VA[6]) and Southwest 
Airlines (NYSE:LUV[7]) each rose 2% while Spirit Airlines (NASDAQ:SAVE[8]) lifted 1%.<nl/> Virgin on Wednesday 
trounced Q4 consensus estimates and announced a new http://news[9].investors.com/business/021815-739743-
virgin-america-shares-soar-fuel-costs-fall.htmflight to Austin, Texas, that challenges Dallas-based Southwest. It and 
other carriers have seen fuel costs drop amid sinking oil prices.<nl/> BJ's Restaurants (NASDAQ:BJRI[10]) gapped 
up and soared 17% to its highest level since July 2011 as it cleared a 51.40 cup-base buy point in hefty trade. The 
stock is extended 7% past the entry. The restaurant operator reported Q4 earnings late Wednesday that topped 
and revenue in line with views. Comps climbed 1.2% vs. last year's 2.7% decline.<nl/> Other restaurants rising in 
volume included Fiesta Restaurant Group (NASDAQ:FRGI[11]), up 3%, Texas Roadhouse (NASDAQ:TXRH[12]), 
also up 3%, and Jack In The Box (NASDAQ:JACK[13]), up 1%.<nl/> Follow Nancy Gondo on Twitter:
